Cons: The main reason I left was due to not receiving a promotion to become an Account Executive after hitting quota for a year consecutively and being a clear top performer. I was not a “favorite” and continuously worked tirelessly to appease the Commerical Sales Managers to earn a promotion. It is too bad to see this is still how Datadog operates - if you can’t get on a Managers good side, rumors spread about you or you don’t fit their “ideal mold” your performance meant and still appears to mean nothing.

Review Title: Do your research before starting a Commercial AE job here
Pros: - In depth training of Command of the message & MEDDICC (applicable for all future sales roles and essential to your success at Datadog) - The ability to stand behind a very strong product suite throughout sales cycles is a major plus - No layoffs due to a very smart CEO/C-Suite spending money in the right areas - Most people on the floor are great human beings
Cons: - This is the most stressful job I've ever had. Although there are a few positive aspects to mention above, these pale in comparison to the negatives. If you're considering a role at a supposedly "stable" tech company, I strongly advise you to read the negative reviews closely to understand what you're getting yourself into. During the interview process, they might claim that 30-40% of reps hit quota, but this is far from the truth. In reality, only about 5-7% (and that's being generous) of sales reps consistently hit their quotas, and many of them rely on opportunities closed in the past to achieve this. - When you're grinding from 7 am to 6 pm and hitting quota, your managers and leadership will love you. However, if you're working those same hours but falling short, you'll notice a significant change in the way you're treated from top to bottom. The VP of Sales will give locker room pump up speeches about how, “you can do big things here and make a ton of money”. While that happens for a few individuals every quarter, 97% of reps struggle day in and day out. - When sales reps regularly make jokes about suicide in the office, that usually means there's a bigger problem within the org as a whole. (Don’t try to justify this and say this happens everywhere, it really doesn’t.) - If you have a doctor's appointment or car troubles one of the three days you’re supposed to be in the office, expect to hear about it from your manager. That’s just not okay apparently. - When a high performing AE leaves the company, people talk about it for a day or so and then it’s old news. The next "hungry" sales rep steps in, eager to prove themselves until they too eventually burn out. It's an ongoing cycle that repeats itself time and time again. - Unfortunately, it's unlikely that anything will change within Datadog's commercial sales org. From a revenue perspective, it works. They are willing to sacrifice their employees mental wellbeing in order to please investors long term.

Pros: good benefits and good product to sell

Pros: - Decent pay - Decent stock - Decent tech stack - Decent coworkers
Cons: - No bonus - Poor 401k match - Unfettered and unchecked management politics - Biased promos The situation at the company has seen quite a transformation. During the post-pandemic period, a significant influx of managers, ranging from EM1 to VP levels, joined the company. It's become apparent that each of these managers is primarily driven by their career advancement ambitions. They chose to join Datadog and brought in numerous new hires, seemingly as a means to bolster their own standing within the company. Engineers, for the most part, tolerated this situation as it didn't directly impact their day-to-day work. However, with the recent decline in the market, the C-suite has started to scrutinize these empire-building endeavors, seeking concrete evidence of their achievements. Moreover, they've reduced the available headcount for these managers, which has prompted them to set unrealistic deadlines and closely scrutinize their own engineering teams. Consequently, we've witnessed a wave of engineer layoffs, and those who remain are under immense pressure to produce results, even though the managers seem uncertain about the specific goals they want to achieve. It appears that these managers are primarily concerned with protecting their own positions, even if it means sacrificing the well-being of our services, team morale, and the actual work being done. Regrettably, the atmosphere within the company, especially within the NYC office, has become quite hostile due to management's insistence on framing every engineer's existence as a zero-sum game. To pave the way for a more promising future, it's imperative that management undergoes a restructuring process that emphasizes technical expertise. We can only hope that this review reaches the ears of Datadog's HR department and is subsequently brought to the attention of Olivier and Alq, so they can take corrective action with regards to our current management team. Datadog should consider a reevaluation of its leadership, similar to the approach taken by Meta, in order to rid the company of empire builders who are now resorting to engineer layoffs.

Review Title: Great Company! Great Product! Life Changing Career!
Pros: Datadog is the premier product in the monitoring and observability space. As we are an expensive product you very rarely lose deals based on the products capabilities. The sales culture here is very lively and collaborative where it is very easy to learn from your peers who are seeing success. I came in to this role from being an SDR at another tech company and Datadog has given me the skills to really thrive in a sales career at any company. The benefits are also top notch with full health coverage and $1200 for a fitness reimbursement.
Cons: This is a full sales cycle role where you will be making a lot of cold calls and emails on a daily basis. This isn't for everyone and as they hire a lot of people from SDR type roles you can see some high turnover. If you are up for the challenge you will succeed and make a lot of money.

Unless you're closing whales (which feels more like luck of the draw and timing than a result of hard work) than the base pay is pretty weak compared to similar roles. Extremely high turnover and with minimal people hitting their number the morale can be pretty bad unless you are a top performer.

Some of this can have direct downstream impact on Sales which is very frustrating when commissions is 50% of your comp package.

Review Title: Great place to work, great place to grow your career.
Pros: Datadog's sales program teaches the skills to be successful in any new logo driven enterprise software sales motion. If you can make it here you can make it anywhere!
Cons: Can't think of any clear cons!

Pros: Great pay - it’s a tech company formed in the late aughts that blossomed right before the pandemic. Salary is great. They try VERY hard to be seen as a good company to work at.
Cons: This is just my situation. But it is a doozy. I was contacted by one of their recruiters, looking to hire for the position since the person who had that position got promoted. Interview was fine, expect for one Sr level person who the recruiter warned me was an odd person. Little did I know how odd. I got the position, and took the job. The immediate team and manager were fantastic, but there was some cult-ish and strange sense that I could not shake. Almost 2 years into the position, it became very clear just how thin skinned the Sr level manager really was. If management even gets a hint of a worker who has a mind of their own, be prepared for surveillance. I was contacted by a Sr person in the HR (people ops! Naturally!) dept telling me to take my TikTok account down because it seemed like I was speaking negatively of the company. Meanwhile, the Sr person who had just become my manager recently was actively looking at ways to get rid of me. Eventually it came to a place where there was just no way to be at the company and maintain my sanity. But it is amazing the lengths at which HR will go to bat for bad leadership and make excuses. I heard from other employees during my tenure how bad things could be, and I am sad to learn that no one exaggerated just how bad things can be. The CEO and his co founder are pretty aloof for all their talk of how much they consider themselves part of the team. Which is fine, they’re both worth multiple billions. But they’re pretense that they are just like us - that’s not an honest picture. For all their talk of being a very modern company, sadly Datadog is just as “corporate” as 100+ year companies.

Pros: If you are a budding software engineer with minimal experience in this space, you will be exposed to a lot of technologies that will help you grow and build confidence in your technical skills. If you need a push out of your comfort zone..this is a good experience. Great team mates.

Training on the product is short lived and not really monitored. Your development is dependent on your own willingness to learn the product and the many technologies it integrates with. Management is much to be desired and disorganized. The Pay is low.

Delivery Fees: For some orders, delivery fees might be high, adding to the overall cost for customers.

Wait Times: During peak hours, there can be longer wait times for food delivery.

Review Title: Decent processes, toxic or immature leaders
Pros:
I worked there for 3 years, and I must say processes are pretty well defined and established, and you can work in an organized and structured way. They keep getting better as the company scales.
Delivery Hero pays well but is not as competitive as they claim.
Cons: Politics can easily take place and stop you from being productive enough to grow and deliver the right value. Unfortunately, toxic managers stay in power and even get promoted, while they regularly get negative feedback from their team and peers in multiple cycles. Senior leadership is not close enough to monitor the manager's performance and HR partners don't take necessary actions to escalate cultural problems in a meaningful way (at least I didn't feel that it's happening). This might not be the case in all departments though, so make sure you ask the right questions during your interviews.

Review Title: Great culture and positive work vibes
Pros:
- Great culture - the Management does a great job of driving the organizational values of caring as heroes, delivering solutions, and always aiming higher.

- Cutting-edge technologies, processes and products.
- Truly multinational, greatly diverse workforce (gender, nationalities, age and work experience).
- Pay may not be so great but good and comparable to market rates.
Cons:
Currently, one layoff after the other is creating an atmosphere of uncertainties and fear over the future of the business and employees.

Also, the plunging share price in the stock market is eroding employees' total take-home package.

Review Title: A Mixed Experience of Growth and Challenges
Pros: Working at Delivery Hero offers a unique opportunity for both professional and personal development. Being part of such a large organization allows you to engage in teamwork and contribute to a product on a grand scale. This environment is incredibly conducive to honing your skills and learning how to navigate complex projects and diverse teams effectively. The experience here is invaluable, providing a solid foundation for any professional looking to grow in their career.
Cons: However, one of the significant challenges within Delivery Hero is the lack of transparency regarding company decisions and employee relations. There exists a culture of secrecy where important information is often withheld until the last moment, making it difficult for employees to feel fully informed or engaged with the company's direction. This opacity can lead to uncertainty about the company's future and undermines trust in the leadership. Clear communication and transparency are areas that need considerable improvement to foster a more inclusive and trusting company culture.

Review Title: Stay away with a 10 foot pole!!
Pros: Used to be a good place to work.
Cons:
This place used to be a commendable workplace, one I could genuinely endorse and take pride in. Regrettably, the transformation it has undergone is deeply disappointing. The toxic atmosphere that descended after a series of layoffs is palpable.

We were inundated with demands for more projects and initiatives, most of which proved utterly meaningless and were promptly forgotten once delivered. The disheartening reality is that individuals here are primarily focused on justifying their salaries and falsely claiming credit for work they didn't genuinely contribute to.

Performance evaluations underwent frequent and arbitrary changes to align with management's preferences. Promotions and raises were inexplicably granted to those who excelled at flattery rather than demonstrating competent job performance. What's even more disheartening is that bringing up concerns about underperforming colleagues with your manager proved futile, as they simply brushed it aside.

Even if you consistently met all your deliverables, a lack of visibility would swiftly result in being placed on a Performance Improvement Plan (PiP). This place has devolved into a hire-and-fire institution, where even individuals who relocated with their families found themselves out of a job within weeks.

Despite its aspirations to match the prestige of FAANG companies, the stark reality is that the compensation here doesn't even come close. They incessantly adopt detrimental practices from other companies while discarding existing, effective ones.

My advice to the management is simple: heed the voices of your employees. Until that crucial change takes place, I genuinely cannot, in good conscience, recommend Delivery Hero. I strongly advise steering clear of it.

Review Title: Bloated hierarchy and lack of clear direction
Pros: Employees from different countries and backgrounds, nice HQ location
Cons: People were laid off the week before Christmas, and some of the people who were let go were employed for only 2 or 3 months. Is management hiring people without knowing if they're going to be needed in 3 months? Seems like they don't know what they'll do next quarter, which shows poor planning skills. Plus, most of the people who were let go were ICs or low-level managers, which means that the company now has even more directors and VPs per person than before. Lots of people creating noise in meetings and not enough people to actually do the job.

Review Title: The worst company I ever worked for
Pros:
There are some great people and depending on how strong your director is to cushion and push back on some questionable decisions the people above them make, it could be a pleasant place to work. The more junior you are, the less you need to deal with the very questionable moral of our senior leadership.
Work life balance is fine, but this is due to the fact that we overhired and lately there was not that much work, after the latest layoff, things will probably change.
Cons: Multiple rounds of layoffs were executed over the past year and a lot of people were dismissed not fully legally. Employees who do not know their rights have been brainwashed to think that it is totally fine to be laid off due to poor performance (not fired the legal way but laid off). It is sad and disheartening to watch how morally degraded people are in very senior leadership positions and ruined a perfectly wonderful place to work.

Review Title: Great company to work until...they lay off :)

Pros:
* A good start for an early career
* People are great
* If you want you can do things (the problem appears when you realize that you do not have to)
* Team dependant but management is not that bad
* Some interesting benefits like the educational budget
Cons:
* They do not listen to the employees, I left the company because even being a top performer they did not care about minor requests I made.
* There is no transparency at all. We were improving in making the company profitable, but 433 employees were fired at Christmas. Furthermore, half of the company was sold in Asia and employees were notified because of a competency leak.
* Unethical strategies to keep their public image clear, i.e. change work policies such as remote working to force people to leave instead of firing them.
* Compensation should be better in Berlin, given the crazy price of the accommodation.
* Too many pointless meetings, at least in my group.

Review Title: Fantastic benefits, motivated colleagues, few bad apples
Pros:
The benefits available to people joining DH are fantastic. As follows:

Cons: It's a corporate, not a start up - you get that feeling, especially as you move up the chain.

Pros:
You will get to meet some expectational talents here(that is if there will be any left at the rate DH is heading).

Colleagues try to make the environment conducive for one another creating a really inclusive and friendly environment .

1000$ for your educational budget and other added benefits.

Salary is good
Cons:
The management doesn’t care about their employees. There has to be some sort of C-level and management changes and intervention in that company.

Performance matrix is not clear and transparent.

Mediocrity is constantly rewarded.

I had the worst manager anyone could be unfortunate to have and despite complaints from almost everyone on the team nothing was done.

You can’t plan long term here because the goal post is constantly shifting-no clear direction on where DH is headed.

No job security- the fact that you are a high performer doesn’t guarantee anything, your role can be suddenly declared redundant and you are laid off.

The work environment is now very toxic and tiring. I would advise people for their mental health to steer clear of this place, if they can.

Review Title: Great interview, great relocation, great team, poor manager
Pros:
Interview with HR was well structured. Interview with hiring manager was challenging and supportive at the same time. Interview with tech lead was challenging and supportive at the same time.
Great support with relocation for the whole family, documentation, accommodation seeking etc
Great team of true professionals
Salary is higher then average
Benefits
Office
Cons:
On the first day I found out that my hiring manager was not with DH any more and I will have a new manager. New manager was not so in tech but she assured me that her expectations from me would be the same as I discussed with hiring manager. 
During my all probation period I have receiving very positive feedbacks like “great job”, “I’m happy that you are in my team”, “perfect, perfect, perfect” etc. In addition my team performed great that was confirmed by staff manager. I had a great connection with my team, all members valued me. All seemed to be good. That’s what I thought until the last week of my probation.
On the last week of my probation my manager + 2 HRs informed me that my probation was not successful and DH will not continue working relationships with me. My manager said that I was too in tech though she expected from me more dive in business. I was shocked, my team was working on API integration solutions. How comes PM of the team to be more in business then in tech? What about our agreements? It was so inconsistent, untrustworthy and misleading. I can accept that expectations might have changed, but this ALWAYS MUST be communicated in timely manner but not on the last working day! I consider it as unfair and harmful for all parties: me, my team, DH. Absolutely wired experience. Maybe there were other reason (mass layoffs recently, so if it was costs optimisation everyone who is on probation are at highest risk), but the one that was declared seems to be a nonsense.

Pros: You have the chance to work with fairly new technology (the ones that were bought before starting saving money) - awesome flexibility in working hours - your voice on professional topics is really heard -high salaries
Cons:
They unfortunately change things one day from the other, you might wake up with an email to announce a layoff (no call to announce, no clarity about the amount of impacted people) or you might loose benefits. I was sold this company as young modern company, especially pushing over the working from abroad benefit, which has now been removed for everyone (again, by a sudden email with no real reasons). The company is also going big brother mode, by tracking that you go to the office at least twice a week by tracking badges, using cameras and accessing your messages on slack. 
With the introduction of the two days in office policy (and all the big-brothery things) it has also been forbidden to us to choose in which building/floor sitting without taking into consideration the massive difference between the three buldings (originally one was made for collaboration, meaning not a lot of desks with monitors, and the others for focus time, meaning not a lot of meeting rooms or collaboration zones). 
They refuse to listen to their employees by stating that all the companies in Berlin are making the same changes, like we did not have contacts with the rest of the industry in the city...

Pros: Fast paced, lots of traffic, challenging
Cons: No international work, top down decisions, needless diversity initiatives.

As for compensation, it's not exactly stellar. The pay is lackluster, considering the tumultuous environment and the expectation of dedication. The office dynamics are far from welcoming, with an overall vibe that lacks cohesion and friendliness among colleagues.

In short, this company's lack of consistent direction, coupled with underwhelming compensation and a disheartening office atmosphere, paints a grim picture of a workplace struggling to find its footing.

Cons: 1. **High Employee Turnover:** there is big amount of employee rotation, sense of community died 2. **Work-Life Balance in Software Engineering:** In the software engineering department, achieving a work-life balance is impossible. There is a tendency for employees to work overtime without receiving adequate compensation. 3. **Performance Pressure:** The emphasis on performance lead to a very competitive atmosphere that kills social interactions. 4. **Managerial Skills in Tech:** While the managers in the technical department are undoubtedly skilled in their field, they often don't have any people management skills. 5. **Promotion Criteria:** The promotion process seems to favor individuals who are more assertive or vocal. Colleagues who are quieter are being bullied and put in problematic situations. 6. **Bullying and Gaslighting:** There have been instances where bullying behavior was tolerated, after multiple complaints. 7. **Transparent Layoffs:** There are quiet layoffs happening, employees are released without clear communication, every month around 10-30 people getting MSAs

Review Title: A Great Company - But not in the Americas
Pros:
World leading software (although now aging) and some of the brightest people you'll ever meet. If you do well here you're good. Generally excellent benefits.
Probably the nicest group of owners you'll ever meet (in Paris).  For younger members of staff there's a lot done of social events (parties, events, breakfasts) many of which are of a high quality.
Cons: Changes in senior management have changed the culture of the New York office. There is an increased level of churn in the staff - in particular longer term employees have been moving out - as the focus has moved to a younger/offshore sourced team. High usage of offshore hiring, not to the benefit of local staff. Work hours can be brutal and while many of the line managers are excellent technologists they have little if any experience in managing people. General situation is that people arrive - are very happy in the first 2-3 years and then become restless.

Pros: Great place to start, multicultural, fruits and coffee/tea available. You get to work with tons of smart people and learn an incredible amount about industry.  Top notch health benefits package.
Cons: This is a staging job at best. Very click-ish. If you get along with the right people, you can get away with murder. Especially if you speak French. No attention to junior consultants. Salary is bad considering the work hours needed. Some incredibly arrogant, insecure and rude people in senior management.

Review Title: Good for fresh grads with no prior experience or very experienced managers
Pros:
Good entry point to finance if you're fresh out of school 
Good Travel opportunities and benefits
smart people and collegial atmosphere
Cons:
Some managers are downright arrogant, disrespectful, and unprofessional
With few exceptions, managers lack basic people and management skills
Compensation could be better and end of year bonus is arbitrary
Career development non-existent
Senior management lacks leadership to motivate and communicates poorly with the base
Long hours comparable to working at IB or HF but with less pay

Review Title: Tough as steel, unstructured and political environment - Not for the faint of heart!
Pros:
Good experience right out of school and after in financial services

Broad range of clients - can sample the full spectrum of financial services, asset managers, hedge funds, investment banks, regional banks, insurance companies - you name it

With the right team and right client(s), one can great exposure across the entire spectrum of trading business especially on the front office consulting side.

Very capable people with some that are truly extra-ordinary

Decent pay
Cons:
Very specialized software has its downside. Stay long here and you will find it hard to exit to a career in banking or hedge funds which is what most people here aspire to as a next step in their career. 

Ideal exit point, should you choose to do that, is near the 3-4 year mark. This has more to do with the recruiting in the banking/hedge fund industry that cannot benchmark a role at Murex. 

Average person at Murex is likely to have had broader exposure than an average person at a bank in a given period of time. However this is not widely recognized. People have made later exits into banking or hedge funds but not without taking a role at least initially that is lower in stature than their roles and responsibilities at Murex.

There is a risk of being pigeon-holed. Despite the fact that different people do different things at Murex, to the outside world everyone is a Murex consultant.

Very Paris-centered and especially so for top level roles. This is a big downer for talented people at satellite offices.

Have to watch your back, especially with mid level managers that are very insecure. Be prepared to be stabbed in the back without any warning!

Management at all levels needs work on the behavioral side - starting with how to treat people with respect.

Pros: In client services departments you are given a lot of exposure to diverse business contacts and cases from multiple clients projects assigned in parallel. As your are the client facing representative who also has responsibility to validate the built software functionality, there is a lot of hands on and detailed knowledge acquired while working among bright and great people.
Cons: Work done beyond the job description is discounted. Workload and over-achievement matter less to the bonus level than the project or manager you are involved with. Very poor work-life balance. Deceptive career management practice.

Pros:
1. Salary is relatively good, but the base salary is not. Only full package is attractive (with bonus, PEE, etc). This kind of money is unreliable and some of it blocked for 5 years.
2. That's it.
Cons:
1. A career path for engineers is non-existent unless you wanna go into management and even then you must work ridiculous hours and suck-up to the right people. 
2. Bonus and raises depend on EOY objectives result, but management only allows for one "exceeded" employee per team, so welcome to the hunger games if you wanna have a decent bonus at the end of the year. 
3. Murex tolerates remote work (up to 2 days per week) but does not encourage it. Management and work culture make it clear that it's not appreciated. 
4. Company culture makes you feel bad about ending your day at 6pm. People stay very late and value more staying late at the office than arriving early or finishing yout work in less time. Toxic presenteeism at its finest. 
5. DEVs do not get proper recognition. 
6. Company does absolutely nothing to promote or encourage inclusivity.

Pros: 1. Navigo transport 2. Work from home
Cons: I worked at Murex for almost 2 years, here are my true feelings: 1. The Boss: He is angry everyday, no politeness, no patience. He doesn't give you an answer but criticizes your ignorance, he doesn't believe you are working unless you come to the office. He can always find something to criticize you because he is happy about that. 2. The Management: there is no clear plan even though we have many useless planning meetings, you have no way to choose what you do and how you do it. 3. The Administrative Manager: he will only give you pressure and push you to do more and more. 4. The Project: Ten million lines of legacy code (created 10 or 15 years ago), thousands of shit tests which may take years to finish ! You have to enjoy your deadline. 5. The Task: Hundreds of fixes waiting for you every day, there is no way to create something or learn something new, your work is to fix old projects. No way ! 6. The Career Path: You can't see any career path, after several years you are still at the beginning !! 7. WLB: You told me about work and life balance ? Are you kidding me ? So what's the idea to join the D** Team ? for having fun ?

Pros: If you are looking for a company that makes you part of a family PCCW is where to go. They really take the time out to help you grow within the company. No worries thinking you don't have enough experiences. They work side by side with you to make you successful. Everyone makes mistakes but in their eyes it's just room for improvement and they make sure to guide you down the right path.  When I first started working for PCCW Teleservices, I was just trying to find a job until I finish with school. But now PCCW is my career. :)
Cons: Every company has cons but nothing to complain about.

Pros:
Flexible - if you're willing to voice your need, you can get flexibility from management
Scheduling - you may be hired into a less desirable shift but there are opportunities to move up
Time Off - although paid time off is not accrued until 6 months, you have the ability to take time off
Advancement - for entry level employees, advancement up the chain can happen if you are hardworking and knowledgeable
Cons:
Overworked - those in management positions are spread thin
Response Time - because of the limited resources getting what you need can take time
Development - you have to work hard to get any development time to move up or development for your job

Pros: Abundant chances for learning, professional development, and advancement within the organization. Flexibility to choose projects that ignite your passion, generous time-off options, and a strong commitment to maintaining a healthy work-life balance.
Cons: The cons include mandatory in-office work within the general area of main locations, tightening restrictions on PTO, variable bonus amounts dependent on company performance, and a hierarchical structure with limited influence from immediate managers on work/life requirements.

Pros: If you relish the idea of your job outcomes being directly tied to your sales prowess, then this role aligns perfectly with your preferences. Excelling in sales affords you the privilege of dictating your schedule, earning higher compensation, and enjoying exclusive perks. However, for those whose sales performance falls in the mediocre range, the absence of tangible benefits is accompanied by recurring coaching sessions aimed at improvement with a threat of being fired if you don't.
Cons: Their sole focus is on sales, neglecting the provision of exceptional technical support. The true essence of teamwork eludes them, despite their claims of fostering collaboration among teams. Instead of promoting unity, they create an environment where individuals are pitted against each other. Actions are taken not out of genuine necessity but rather to impart lessons. Moreover, a prevalent air of self-congratulation permeates the organization.

Pros: Enjoyed working with incredibly talented people across the marketing and analytics departments. Good leadership from the CMO and VP of Marketing.
Cons: Company seems to be in flux with some of the service lines other than phone insurance.

Pros: Money is good if u can hot ure metrics
Cons: I’ve seen jobs loss. I seen ppl written up. I seen the absolute no support from high up. As management not only am i taking charge of my store but also marketing.. multi billion dollar company and can’t afford to assist in anything…

Review Title: RUN AWAY!!!! Do not work here! Toxic Atmosphere!
Pros: Pay per call can be good. Until they manually reduce your metrics so you aren't paid as much. Insurance seems good for a group plan.
Cons: Asurion Middle and Upper management is absolutely clueless. They do not care anything about the customers and just want you to pitch Home Tech Protection until the customer either buys or dies. Shady sales approach. Reps continually lie just to get a sale, with no reprimand by management. Unrealistic sales goals if you have even a shred of integrity. A revolving door of reps who do not have a clue what they are doing and coaches who do not care if they mess up customer's claims as long as they sell the protection. This organization should be ashamed of themselves. What a joke. Is in no way shape or form a sales job. As sleazy as it gets! Do not do it!

Pros: Asurion is very diverse and treats their employees kindly.
Cons: I can't think of one

Pros: The pay is wonderful! You get your hourly rate plus bonus for sales and meeting metrics.
Cons: It is very hard to achieve the monthly sales goals. When people have called in repeatedly they hear our sales pitch every time. Customers say no once, twice, three times before we can stop our pitch. Our coaches listen to our calls and rate them. They pick them apart with a fine tooth comb and yes they will say great job doing this or you did that perfectly, but they will also ask why you didn't get the sale and why you didn't ask them a fourth time etc. We were basically suppose to badger the customer until they give in and say yes. We were told it was no longer a customer service position, that it was now a SALES position. If you don't make your sales goal for a month, you get a warning. The next time a written warning and then you get terminated. When I was first hired you got to pick your own schedule, right down to when your breaks were. Now you have to bid on shifts and if your sales aren't meeting goal, you won't get anything close to what you need for a schedule.

Pros: Good team support at store level
Cons:
-Awful management, always says "reach out for help if you need it!" and then either refuses to help or flat out doesn't know the answer and will not assist further. 
-Does not care at ALL for employees. Constant understaffing, cannot retain employees, raises are next to nothing, promotions often denied to women who also make less money than male coworkers
-Sketchy hiring policies. Bait and switch upon hiring, will offer you a job and then say "oh by the way we changed the role" after you already signed contracts. They also offered me a higher pay on the phone, confirmed with me on the phone, and then my offer letter had a lesser amount.
-Poor training. Expects coworkers to teach new hires.
-Sketchy firing practices. Employees who make them the most money in sales are HIGHLY prioritized and favored, even to the point of letting them get away with multiple infractions other people were fired for.
-Impossible workload. Massively stressful. Often sends employees to other stores to cover and is forced to host "repair parties" where employees work OT until midnight to get workload down.
-Management takes frequent PTO and gets flown to Florida multiple times a year to get drunk and take time off while their employees don't even get sick pay.
-People quit without even finishing training. Often.
-NO SICK PAY.

Pros: I met some good people while i was there .
Cons: Stress will be your best friend. Asurion sticks with same process and does not want to improve anything especially when it comes to agent lying to get a sale. don't blame them because company puts a pressure on them. PTO you earn it but to use it is another problem . if you are not a SALES person Asurion is not for you. You sale then you good. you don't you are going to get harassed by the coach/supervisor until you quit or get fired. you also get promised to move up but it never happens. i have met some good people who left for something better. if you care about your mental health look elsewhere.

Pros: Amazing leaders, culture of reliability and everyone are approachable
Cons: None None None None all good

Review Title: Used to be a great place to work
Pros: Good pay and decent benefits
Cons: The acceptance letter never mentioned sales. The description of the position was to drive to people’s home and provide them with a five star experience by setting up their replacement phones. Nothing about sales. Now the focus is on sales and experts are using every sales tactic bad and good to get the home protection sale. Experts are lying to get a sale. Not only that but also have to sell Verizon 5g and Fios to eligible customers plus accessories, upgrades and new lines. We only have 23 mins to spend with the customers. Routing is so bad that we can’t take our breaks properly otherwise more than one job will be late and it’s not fair to these customers. Operations need to focus on the above.

Review Title: Started out as the best job I ever had and became the worst!
Pros: Pretty place to work. Benefits start on the first day.
Cons:
I started with the company in 2004, filing claims. I moved to tech support and then escalations, where I was stuck for the next twelve years until I gave up and quit. 

The company hired a guy who turned the entire company into a metrics and stats game where everyone but management, including tech support, has to upsell various add-ons. If they don't they get fired. I saw this happen at Sprint, in 2003. It took awhile for Sprint to tank, but it did. It's going to take Asurion awhile to tank, but watch it. Let's not forget that Eddie Limpert turned Sears into a metrics and stats game, pitting all the sections of the company against each other.

Pros: If your perform well and apply feedback, you’ll improve. Local culture can be very good with engaged management.
Cons: If the feedback is vague, non existent, or lacks direction, you are still responsible for your performance. Going above and beyond in other areas are not considered and equality of performance between team types and tenure are not considered. Pay is based on region not performance. Lack of accountability amongst teams site to site. Closure of sites. Lack of growth opportunities if not in Nashville.

Review Title: Cares about its people, diverse, fast and results driven
Pros: Diversity - Asurion is easily the most diverse corporation I have been with, from race, ethnicity, age, gender and sexual orientation. The organization transparently updates all employees with progress and offers vast employee resource groups and clubs to join. This diversity brings the best ideas to the table. Results driven - Asurion values its people and the results they bring. If you treat others with respect and produce results, you will have a great career here. Fast - Asurion is a massive company with a lot of people, but it doesn't take long for great decisions to get action within your team or partner teams. Everyone is running in the same direction and accept great ideas no matter where they come from. There's even a place for ANY employee to suggest ideas and process improvements to the C suite. People - There's a theme here with people. From the interview process to the onboarding process to the continuing education inside the building - this is a company that really, really cares. People are recognized and celebrated for their successes. It helps develop a culture of the behaviors we celebrate so employees can model. Amenities - The corporate HQ is gorgeous and modern. Ergonomic, state-of-the-art gym and dining, and amazing collaboration spaces.
Cons: Not many Cons. Once you get a company that cares this much about its people, stay. You'll find a lot of people who have been here for a long time.

Pros: Fast paced, room for growth, changes in scenery, benefits include company compensated access to ubreakifix. Extremely generous mileage compensation, decent health plan.
Cons: I worked there 6 months and it went from a customer focused service to deliver and set up electronics to a sales position. The commissions are pitiful, at most $25/sale and their rules about trying to record people in their own homes make customers very uncomfortable and distrustful, and since you aren't allowed to contact customers after the deliveries you're given no opportunity to save a cancellation, but the company still counts them against you. I was #1 salesman in the region for 3 months, even met the ceo and had a photo op, but because my numbers were good they gave me more stops on my route, which I appreciated, however, since I was then seeing 2x the customers as my fellow teammates, my numbers skyrocketed despite the percentages remaining reasonable albeit ahead. I have prior sales experiences which was why I was successful to begin with. Then, witb no warning whatsoever, I was placed on unpaid administrative leave while the company investigated my sales tactics, I wasn't asked to give any statements or elaborations and after the "administrative leave" the company completely ghosted me. I never got any resolution whatsoever. This job is, in my opinion, extremely volatile and I strongly recommend against working here as you can be terminated either for not making enough sales, or apparently, making too many.

Pros: Best company I've ever had the opportunity to be a part of. As someone who was never a fan of the corporate world, I took a chance and found the one company that I believe will be my career for the rest of my employment life. I started as a part-time expert, worked my way to full-time and then made it to the coach level about 6 months ago. Plenty of opportunity if you apply the feedback you're given, show up every day and give it your all. Every person I've dealt with in the company from experts, to coaches, HR, SE, OM, Senior OM all the way up to Director have been fair, helpful and never discouraging. I would recommend this company to any and everybody who wants to make a good living at an honest company.
Cons: Literally not a single thing.

Review Title: Don’t waste your time working here
Pros: The only pro for this job is that the commission is uncapped, which helps make pay checks a little bigger
Cons: Asurion lied when onboarding you, and gives a sign on bonus to entrap yoh for a year or it has to be paid back. I joined the company to grow my technical skills in repair and was also made out ti believe that they covered/do full tuition reimbursement. While there is tuition reimbursement it is the biggest pain to even get and they only cover 2k a school year. Upper management is miserable, if you don’t get at LEAST one homeplus a day you have to have an “adapt” where they basically smack you in the wrist and say to get a sale, but yet when you ask for help to strengthen sales you get met with “well did you offer?”. Mind you, when I was being onboarded by my recruiter sales were made out to be OPTIONAL and never did she communicate that sales are the ONLY metric they care about. Just to make things better, we don’t have actual “sick time off” and in order to accrue ONE DAY of PTO you have to work 1 month straight (you earn 2 hrs of pto per pay check). Avoid working here at all costs. Intrusive company who doesn’t care about you as a person.

Pros: • You get a degree of autonomy and self-direction on the road and during service calls • Mileage reimbursement (sort-of) • Perks for good performance and/or meeting quotas
Cons: • Soooooo many middle-managers delivering conflicting info • Required use of personal vehicle • Online "trading" : 50,000 video modules that, and I'm sorry but it's true, you HAVE to skip or cheat at least a little to complete them all in the allotted time. You can't catch up by watching them outside of paid training hours, either. • The training seems to assume that you're a sociopath who has to be taught how to talk to people normally and feel emotions like empathy, interest, or compassion. • Like working for your high school yearbook committee (Ever felt motivated by that really enthusiastic and upbeat Cool Aid drinker who's doing a poor job of disguising their contempt for you by pantomiming a genial manner of discourse whilst sounding like a patronizing space-alien? Me either!)

Pros: The money was really good. 19/hr+bonuses from sales.
Cons: The company doesn’t care about you actually helping the customers, they just want you to get the sales. There’s gonna be 1-1 coaching soften and you’re never gonna talk about how to satisfy the customer or anything like that, they’re gonna show you your sales metric and carry on about ways you can get more sales when you can only convince someone only but so many times to buy a product.. I started sugarcoating the product to get more sales(was bringing in no less than 6 a day, which is beyond great) and I was congratulated yet told that I wasn’t being truthful with the customers and it could cost me. Very aggravating job. They also throw in a little future goals talk to make you feel like you can move up with the company, but you ain’t moving no where fr. At least not for another 6+ years.

Review Title: I am happy with my employment.
Pros: Great people, reasonably understanding and flexible with schedule, decent pay rate and benefits. I work 100% remotely which is my preference, my team's home base is in a different city/state than where I live. Monthly performance based bonuses. Abundant incentives and employee groups to join. I do not perform any sales in my current role.
Cons: Lack of interdepartmental communication is the biggest issue I experience affecting my ability to do my job. I wish we were able to get a cost of living pay adjustment, the company provided a market adjustment in 2020. I have previously suggested opening the opportunity to request unpaid time off. One of my greatest concerns is a lack of remote opportunities to advance my career within Asurion, also I am unable to travel with my work away from my physical home address due to the client restrictions.

Pros: DEVELOPMENT, OFF TIME DEPENDING ON LEVEL OF SENORITY!
Cons: Shifting unrealistic goals you do a good job you dont get praised for it. Upoer management is kind of like a boys club. They do throw sick partys in nashville though

Job Title: CLAIMS CUSTOMER CARE REPRESENTATIVE - Licensed Adjuster Personal Lines
Pros: Great benefits, Health care plan
Cons: It was a dream job where my ability to move up in the company and make a good wage wasn't dependent on any kind of "sales". But that quickly changed to pushing a new insurance program and if you didn't make any sales, you could expect a write up and, eventually, to lose your job. I'm happy I left when I did.

Review Title: The Slow Death of a Giant
Pros:
-The compensation when first starting is great. Possibly slightly lower pay than other companies, but great benefits.
-Great work life/home life balance depending on team.
-Incredibly smart and talented people to learn from and work with.
-Dependent on team, but many managers lead with empathy and understanding. You are treated like an adult and expected to be able to self motivate.
Cons:
-Compensation goes downhill the longer you stay.
-Making any headway on new projects is near impossible. A lot of meetings with zero progress made, and unless you're working on something flashy, you'll be given zero resources and encounter active roadblocks to progress and change.
-Lack of ownership and accountability. If internal systems exist for specific vertical information, it's outdated. More often than not, it doesn't exist.
-Appearance is more important than actual performance. Office politics are intense and it's not what you know, it's who you know.
-ELT lacks transparency and clear communication. The strategy is always working, even when it's not. 
-Regular layoffs that are not performance based. The only warning you may receive will be a company wide email at the end of business the day before anyone knows if they're impacted or not.
-The company has lost sight of what made it great.

Review Title: Excellent culture, excellent employer, but embrace frustration
Pros:
- A unique and incredibly employee-supportive culture
- Equality, inclusion and diversity are not only reasons of pride for the company, but we live them every day
- We all really work to enable everyone building your own business 
- Extremely customer centric, we listen to our customers, we know what they need (but we are not able to deliver, see Cons)
- One of the most known brands on earth, used by million people every day
- Beautiful offices around the globe
- Smart, supportive, competent and friendly colleagues
Cons:
- Slow, over-engineered, over-complex. Building a simple customer solutions takes years. 
- Decision-by-committee, rounds of 30 people to discuss features, VPs vetoing AB tests, hours and hours of meetings that bring nowhere 
- Get used to structural changes every year, I have colleagues that had ten different managers in six years
- Leadership levels seem disconnected from the reality of the delivery work. Talking about things that exist only in powerpoint decks

Review Title: Good company but needs to focus better
Pros: eBay provides a lot of intangible benefits for employees and the people who work for the company really want eBay to succeed.
Cons: eBay is too top-heavy which clogs up the decision making process. Too many leaders need to have their fingers in every pie and justify their continued role at eBay. Projects drag out as leaders go around and around on decisions that have already been made.

Review Title: What is work life balance and progression
Pros: Great Benifits, good people work here. No other pros
Cons: Work your way up to where you want to be. Every coaching session your asked to consider your progress and career and then one day your told your going back to a department in that you start day one in here on. For a company that thrives on the work life balance quote they have really fooled me. I went from core business hours to be told ill be now working shifts till 9pm and full weekends. Never felt so let down or only a number after working so hard for years. Absolutely horrendous. No communication

Pros: Nice People, flexible work schedule, willing to push out deadlines due to practical issues/considerations
Cons: On multiple projects with different responsibilities at once, and yet still unclear what needed to be done to the point I didn’t have much to do most days. Maybe different in other departments, but my section I don’t think I heard “I don’t know the answer to that” or “I’m sorry about this problem” once from anyone but me. The more specific my questions about a specification or process got, the more silence I heard. Given the recent layoff (2024) people had reason to be afraid for their jobs.

Review Title: A step in the wrong direction
Pros: Since eBay's acquisition of my employer, TCGplayer, a lot has changed, but there are still things about my job that I enjoy. I have many years of experience specializing in many different parts of the work we do, and enjoy the ability to do work I excel at, that adds a lot of value. Additionally, I have a lot of great coworkers that make the work environment fun and enjoyable to spend 40 hours a week at.
Cons: Regrettably, eBay has made a mess of their acquisition of TCGplayer in many ways. For a large company with a long history of purchasing other companies, the transition from to eBay's systems, pay structure, and benefits were very poor, despite having a dedicated transition team meant to facilitate these processes. Additionally, eBay was eager to continue TCGplayer's stance of poor cooperation with their democratically elected union, from running a highly aggressive anti-union campaign during the union election process, to delaying the bargaining processes with baseless legal appeals. Beyond this, our pay has been stagnant for the last 3 years, does not account for the cost of living or rising inflation. Additionally, we have seen a reduction in available paid time off since the eBay acquisition.

Pros: If you're a full-time employee you will definitely be able to learn a lot. Benefits are incredible.
Cons: Extremely variable experience depending on your manager. Lots of meaningless meetings. Incredibly difficult to get anything done in an appreciable window of time. Vitriolic levels of workplace toxicity, backed up by almost every amicable team member I'd worked with jumping ship in the span of a few months. Also assigned responsibilities highly disproportionate (i.e. in excess) to my actual job level / compensation. Nobody is motivated and a lot of blame-shifting all around. It is an absolutely thankless role, exacerbated by employees I knew did legitimately earnest / above-and-beyond work getting laid off regardless simply to meet upper management headcount culling. It's depressing since none of this was at all the case when I entered.

Pros: Global Impact: eBay is a globally recognized e-commerce platform, giving you the opportunity to work on projects and initiatives that can have a significant impact on a worldwide scale. Diverse Workforce: eBay often fosters a diverse and inclusive work environment, which can offer you a chance to collaborate with people from various backgrounds and cultures, enhancing your cultural competence and perspective. Career Development: The company may provide opportunities for career growth and advancement, with a range of roles and departments, allowing you to explore different aspects of the business. Innovative Culture: eBay has a history of innovation and technological advancement. Working for such a company may expose you to cutting-edge technologies and methodologies. Employee Benefits: Many employees receive competitive benefits, which may include healthcare, retirement plans, and other perks like employee discounts on eBay's marketplace.
Cons: Workload and Stress: Depending on the role and department, working at eBay can be fast-paced and demanding, potentially leading to high stress levels. Competitive Environment: Like many tech companies, competition can be intense, and you may need to continually prove your value to the organization.

Review Title: Not as human first as they claim
Pros:
Wellness weekends (shared 4 day weekends across company)
Feels like immediate team cares about you, but definitely not leadership.
As far as I'm aware recent layoffs had a nice severance (5 months). Unsure if will be that way still going forward.
Cons:
No recent salary increases. Pay is not as high as other companies. Bonus is only ever stock.
Rto mandate even though you're team is in different states and countries, so you drive in for zoom meetings. It also doesn't take into account pto or sick days, so it encourages people to come in sick. (Told you have to "plan better" if you can't make minimum...).
Half of your time will be meetings, more talking about how to do the work and not enough time to do it.
Pto amount not super generous, wellness weekends help. 
Reorgs removed required roles that business is not refilling, so more non work put on others outside of sprint commitments.

Pros: F5 used to be great, a relaxed culture where the work was the focus and management prioritized the happiness of their technical staff. The workers there are still great people, hard-working and very supportive and fun. Benefits and compensation are fair.

Lower level management have become enforcers who refuse to consider individual employee needs. We went from an "all voices are welcome" company to "shut up and comply" within 10 years.

Pros: - Love some of my coworkers and have made some lifelong friends - My direct managers have been awesome and have helped me grow - Health insurance is insanely good - While I disagree with RTO, the office is nice - Work-Life Balance is pretty solid
Cons: - IT Upper management has absolutely no idea what they are doing. The blend of incompetence and sometimes borderline hostility from management has put us in a very bad spot. The recent re-org was and continues to be the worst roll out I have experienced. From what I can see, morale is at an all time low and no one knows what to do. Any time we think we are going to get an update, meetings get cancelled. Most questions get answered with anywhere between "I don't know" and "We will have to see". Productivity seems to have been effectively shut down while management decides what to do with the re-org. - Layoffs, followed by a re-org, then followed by RTO is not the way to keep talent at F5. - Compensation is all over the place. HR will work against you when it comes to being fairly compensated.

Review Title: Great group of people but management does not lead
Pros: The people there are top notch. It is an inclusive environment, they share knowledge and help each other. Constant exposure to new ideas and technologies. Best group of people I have ever worked with.
Cons: Executive management is not leading. They are unable to articulate goals and direction of company, such as 5 year outlook, 10 year outlook, etc. New technology is up and coming they jump on it without considering what it will bring to the company other than money, so it often takes a while for them to figure out how they will incorporate it into the existing products. They give themselves bonuses and raises while the majority of the company will get promotions without pay raises. Often release security and software updates without vetting. Product versions are fragmented and span a large range making supporting various versions a nightmare.

Cons: A once great Seattle company caved to consultants to appease shareholders. Sadly, all that 'human first' rhetoric that was pushed during- and post- pandemic is a myth. Just corporate propaganda. Once the stock dropped to a temporary nadir in spring 2023, the leadership decided to pull the lever and RIF some 623 employees, the majority high performers. Yet, it doesn't seem that anyone at C-suite took responsibility, and all kept their jobs. However, they cored out the soul of F5.

Review Title: A little less dishonesty than some companies but still full of it
Pros: Good products and strategic direction
Cons: Fairly advanced capture by the Diversity and Inclusion crowd, much time-wasting. Return to Office - for a company that prides itself on being transparent and honest, whose nominal credo starts with "First and foremost, we do the right thing" they lied their ***** off about their motivations for RTO. "We, a data-driven, numbers-based company want to impose the cataclysmic costs of commuting of up to 3 hours daily on our employees with no compensation to reap all the tax benefits which the company will retain." All the costs on us, none of the benefits. So we can have more "collaboration." Like I can collaborate better in the Seattle office with colleagues in Hyderabad than I could from home. Bullpucky. No, they are getting tax breaks for occupancy and don't care how much damage they inflict to get it. The CEO can make a case. That he failed to do so tells me there is no case to make. At least, none that would be acceptable over "because I said so." The FAQ on RTO they published reads like an essay by a student who didn't read the assignment. "How about the climate impact of all those extra trips?" "We are very concerned about climate change. (EOM)" Not concerned enough to not impose all those miles of commuting on some of the most congested roads in the U.S. So anyway, I have no trust. I hate the hypocrisy of touting corporate values they ignore. "People first" - right. Look, I'd have some respect if they were honestly exploitive instead of pretending they weren't. It's like an abuser wanting to be liked.

Pros: F5 largely maintains a "human-first" approach with its employees. This humanist philosophy has been great, but it has also begun to wear off a little as leadership has instilled a more "command and control" M.O. But you can still find good home/life balance at F5.
Cons: F5 has become more "extractive" with its work force in recent years, relying less and less on the folks in the trenches for insight. If you don't mind this, great.

Pros: F5 appreciates it's employees and shows it. Always supportive and giving opportunities to advance.

Review Title: Not the company it once was
Pros: Great benefits, good corporate responsibility and donation matching, financially stable.
Cons: When I joined F5 they genuinely cared about people, doing the right thing, and supporting everyone. Now, all they care about is wringing more out from people to increase the bottom line. Deadlines are incredibly tight and have destroyed the work life balance F5 was famous for. Anyone who doesn't buy into the burnout culture they are forming is deemed expendable. Management no longer cares about employee wellness or health and their product direction is simply chasing the next release without any long term vision. Pay has been stagnant for awhile and raises are capped. Stack ranking of employees is becoming the norm where you have to mark people as low performers even if they are not. I'm not sure what happened to the company I loved, but I can no longer recommend working for them.

Review Title: F5 is a great place to work
Pros: Human first approach, career growth and mentorship.
Cons: Return to office after being remote

Pros: I almost didn't write this for fear of retaliation. The soul of the company and the pros that we had were mostly removed in the past few years. Recent pro, wellness weekends as a few extra PTO days.
Cons: Employee engagement programs were all but shut down. People who worked across departments were all let go. Internal Promotions were almost non-existent. External hiring added management at all levels who would show up, announce a major change to boost their name and then leave. Compensation did not even try to keep up with the market. 2 years with no raises due to pandemic uncertainty, followed by a "raise" and a cut in RSUs that landed in a wash despite huge cost of living increases at the same time. RTO demands while over 3/4 of employees did not see value in returning. Distributed teams not properly managed by inflexible managers. Unreasonable hours and regular weekend work because no-one felt they could actually log off for a break. I was here for over 5 years, and there was only 1 year we did not have either a major re-org or large layoffs. Layoffs often selected employees who were not redundant forcing others to pick up the slack and learn new skills rapidly. This resulted of course in spreading resources to thin, diminishing meeting SLAs on both systems, and then the employees picking up the slack being judged for not meeting what multiple people were doing before. After years of this, the weight of 5 or more resources were being carried by individual burnt out people who had no hope for improvement or any chance at success. The company has not been releasing products internally instead acquiring other companies to bolster their product lines temporarily while showing no faith in existing engineering teams. Senior leadership would not support the suggestions that were needed to resolve issues, especially with acquired companies. D&I was a meaningful program focused on policy, benefits, and was supposed to offer a path to leadership skills and promotions. Now it is just words. The real programs no longer offer hope to employees and are used for marketing to investors and colleges.

Pros:

- The job title I received was not the one I applied to. The responsibilities started similar, but it only took about 6 months for those to change to a different role than the one I was sold during interviews. 

- I'm not sure any managers who knew what there employees were doing. People seemed to either be doing almost nothing, or be overworked to meet deadlines. 

- Aforementioned deadlines seemed to be set before we even knew what product we were making. It's the definition of deadline driven development. 

- Technical leadership openly insulted developer's work, after remaining unhelpful through most of the projects. They were reported to upper management by multiple people for this. The reporters ended up leaving the company or team and the leadership remained the same. 

- Overall, perks are nice but not worth the stressful environment.

Review Title: stuck in the past in too many ways
Pros:
you may get a good manager or good teammates. 
the company does some D&I messaging.
you may get a chance to learn a lot in some roles.
Cons:
the cons grew to outweigh the pros by far. reviews on here suspiciously went up by 0.5 stars out of no where. notice all the positive reviews that have very little information in them. dont believe them.

extremely low pay across the board for most teams unless youre a manager or above.
going against the status quo is often ignored or frowned up. 
a lot of sr managers have very traditional views about how a company should be run in the bad way.
no true milestone rewards unless you work there for 10yrs which shows how little your time is valued.
many teams are under resourced which means people get burnt out quickly and then leave, creaing often a long unending cycle.
lots of outsourcing to exploit cheap labor.
didnt give raises to most ppl during the pandemic except to the top.
too much nepotism leading to too many unqualified leaders ruining departments.
tries to behave like a startup which doesnt work for a 25+yr old company with over 6000 employees. just means internal systems are messy and lots of instructions arent documented.
too many outdated systems and ways of doing things.

the list could go on. please do yourself a favor and listen to these words. unless youre getting a rare competitive offer to be a sr mgr or are escaping somewhere even worse to use this place as a stepping stone it isnt worth it.

Review Title: Ok if you don't want a pay increase or bonuses
Pros: I am onshore at a client location so I mainly only report to the management at the client. Although I still have meetings with mphasis management also and have to complete all the required training and stuff on that side also in addition to clients. I like the work. sometimes it can be alot of hours, but if you like what you do, then it doesn't matter that much.
Cons:
Been here for 2 years now, and no pay increases or quarterly bonuses like I was told about in the interview. Also, no 401K match from the company. (which I was told during the interview that they were going to be changing that soon and offering a match)
There appears to be no timelines around reviews, increases, and bonuses. There is no communication either. I was told the other day in a meeting, that it could be another 4 quarters before they look at raises again. This would be a 3 year stagnant period without a raise in the highest inflation times in several decades. I know the company is still making money, just not as much as they want to make. However 433 million USD is not loosing money. This is the first company I have ever worked for in the last 40 years that I have not been given an annual raise of at least something. Some were not good if it was a bad year, but at least it was something.

Review Title: Quality clients, nice place to work, your assignment matters the most
Pros: * Good enterprise clients who treat consultants well. * Good pay, bonus, and benefits. * Premier partnership with AWS provides early access and additional training. * Working full-time remote.
Cons: * There's nothing wrong with Mphasis that you won't find working remote at any other big consulting firm. * The projects you are assigned to matter more than working for Mphasis, and you have little control over your assignment. * I earned about 15% more with this consulting job than comparable employee offers. But had too little personal agency and too little opportunity to level up. * I was led to believe I would challenging DevOps & AWS assignments, level up, and earn more. Instead I got 1.5 years more experience doing the same thing I've done before. * I would have been better off as a Giant Co employee automating my own job and / or climbing the corporate ladder. Or being an independent consultant.

Pros: I can't find any pros for working here
Cons: I was hired as a remote employee and did not have a fully functioning computer for 20 of the 24 months I was employed. I never saw an org chart and was not told who I reported to. I set up my 401k (which has no company match) to be 50% of my gross. They never came close to withholding 50% and it was never a consistent amount. They couldn't explain to me why or how they calculated the amount that was withheld. There had not been merit increases for the 7 years before I joined. There was a merit increase announced but since I had only been employed for 11 months and 3 weeks, instead of 12 months, I was ineligible. I found out over 2 years after I quit that they never updated my employment status with the 401k administrator so I cannot do a rollover. I contacted them with no response. I followed up and was told they would submit the update - not completed after 10 days. Again, I followed up to be told the request was made with offshore. Still waiting but will likely need to resort to taking legal action. Everything is run by the offshore parent company that has no understanding of how a company is run. I cannot recommend working for this company.

Pros: This is a great company to work for. Lots of opportunities to grow and learn.
Cons: I can't think of any cons st the moment

Pros:
Note: My experience is with their U.S. operations. Mphasis has a huge presence in India, but they also do hire U.S citizens.

- They hire you and sorta modify you resume which helps you get in. It sounds immoral, but when companies reject you for "junior/entry level roles" that are barred by 5 years of experience, you gotta game the system somehow

- They'll almost always find a job. I went through a training program for their 1st job and I got paid even when on the bench. If there's an issue HR/IT support is very responsive so that's nice ( be warned, for some reason their forgot password can't recognize non- Indian numbers, which is a pain)
Cons:
There is literally 0 upward mobility. After a year of working with them and satisfactory response from the client, their total raise was capped at 5%, which doesn't even help beat inflation standards. 

In addition, they have an absurd list of monthly pop quizzes/random crap to do. And believe it or not, its not TCS levels of "Can you cosplay a human dictionary and cram all these terms" but its still a pain. I'll never understand why companies think employees have to spend literal days doing their pop quizzes on HR things

Like EVERY service based company, you'll ALWAYS make less through them than directly working with a company. And its just common sense since these companies need a way to survive

Review Title: Good resources, bad development program, low pay.

Cons: Bad development for beginners; they could place you in a mid-senior role as entry level. Low pay compared to the market. Low or no bonus pay. Low PTO days. No 401k match; not sure if this will change.

Since you don't have that experience it will be hard to fulfill your duties, but there are some cases of brilliant employees that can.

Review Title: Sinking Ship Being Plundered by Corrupt Executives
Pros:
Some of the most amazing people you'll ever work with.
Used to have a good culture but IronSource ruined that.
Cons:
Clueless and greedy executive leadership and board whose only focus is lining their own pockets and seemingly tanking what used to be a great product and company. 

No innovation - there's no product vision or direction, just meaningless buzzwords to provide the illusion of progress while the executives plunder.

Constant pivots and re-orgs. No product vision or plan = musical chairs.

HR is almost completed automated (oh the irony) so if you have a problem, good luck.

Shrinking benefits in order to pay for grotesque executive salaries.

Racist (and generally awful) behavior from IronSource towards Muslim employees that is tolerated by management.

Employees used to be able to voice their objections and opinions but that was quickly stomped.

Constantly tanking stock value: RSUs are worthless

Completely disorganized and disjointed information management; everything has to be found in one of the thousands of Slack channels.

Constantly changing tools - over 30 internal tools, most of which are in a constant state of sunset or introduction

No annual review system or way to track metrics, progress, or goals. Management doesn't set KPIs or OKRs because everyone is always being re-org'd and priorities are always shifting.

Management is too busy peacocking at conferences and on LinkedIn to actually do their jobs.

Pros: - Met very intelligent, kind, and supportive people during my time here and this is honestly the highlight of my tenure - $0 out of pay-check for medical, dental, and vision insurance in the US - Has so much potential in its product portfolio including a partnership with Apple Vision Pro - Office life is fantastic and homey with tons of events and perks, if working in-office is what you prefer
Cons: - Anyone senior director and above is completely disconnected from the rest of the employees and has no intention to bridge that gap - ironSource acquisition has completely changed the company culture in a way that undermines the voices of anyone who is not an ironSource legacy employee (i.e. Unity and Tapjoy employees) - Very little respect for C-suite and that's no one's fault but theirs. Town Halls and All-Hands meetings are a joke - Keeps advertising itself as 'competitive' in the market yet a simple LinkedIn search reinforces the conclusion that Unity is severely underpaying its employees - Marketing organization is messy and borderline toxic in some areas

Review Title: Unity Grow is not Unity.  It's Iron Source.
Pros: Benefits, free lunch daily in SF office, easy commute from BART, snacks galore. Some good colleagues but most of them left. Some fun office activities and good diversity in general.
Cons:
tl;dr--find another place to apply to. 

-Exceptionally poor management. Expect to be gaslit and ridiculed by your managers. Your voice doesn't even matter. Everything that was once Unity (grow side) is now ran by Iron Source and they have 0 empathy for employees.

-Poor culture. Just ask the employees that are still there how things were before Iron Source took over. It's night and day.

-Upper management doesn't even have a grasp on how the Unity product works and nobody is ever aligned with product functionalities and launches. Miscommunication across the board. 

-They keep trying to run Unity like Iron Source and apply strategies that make no sense.

-Management asks you to challenge them and when you do and they don't like your idea, you'll get skewered. They don't even want to bother with what you said. 

-Even though the interim CEO rescinded RTO, the management on the Grow side is forcing employees to come in 3x a week still. 

-During a meeting about culture, a manager literally said that since there have been so many layoffs, you now have space to come in and work wherever you want. 

- Clicky culture and a lot of 'yes man' mentality here. A lot of ego issues here.

-Unity has laid off over 2K+ people since 2022.

Pros: very talented and passionate coworkers
Cons: looks like there's nothing unity can do to become what it used to be

Pros: Was an amazing company to work for at the beginning of my time there several years ago, and the market is a blast to work in.
Cons: C suite could never agree on a strategy, acquired multiple companies without a clear vision, most of which were shut down within a couple of years, and now 2 years of layoffs. Add to that the way they constantly anger their core market... Someday I hope it returns to its glory days, but for now, avoid.

Pros:
Excellent employees that create an unparalleled working enviroment.
Great offices with great services.
An opportunity to work on some really fun and cool projects.
Cons: Leadership are quite directionless. All the pros of working here are somewhat overshadowed by the constant chaos of layoffs and reorgs as a result of poor investment choices and "diversification" which ultimately translates into purchasing businesses with no relation to the company.

Review Title: Talented People Aboard a Sinking Ship

Cons:
Executive management has steered this company in a terrible direction by spending a lot of money on acquisitions that they did not know how to utilize while abandoning their core business model. It's a shame so many talented developers had to suffer as a result. 

Some managers are terrible at leading, instead carrying their abusive practices from previous companies in the AAA gaming space. Aforementioned talented people have left to be where they're actually appreciated, that is if they weren't laid off. Things might improve now that a particular CEO is out of the picture

Review Title: Was good, now very very bad
Pros: The people were the only reason I stayed.
Cons:
Two words: POOR MANAGEMENT.

Unity has a habit of grossly rewarding it's upper management teams for failure all the while paying way below market for the regular employees who are the ones that work hard to make the company better.

Failed in your job, poor leader, technically inept....don't worry....here's a HUGE retention bonus (in cash and stock). You're upper management!!! We'll just layoff a couple thousand employees to make up the difference. 

What a joke this company has been for the last few years. Even the "town halls" all have scripted Q&As. The company has failed its' customers and it's employees. I would avoid.
