2. It will be better if the EP application process can be faster, so that I can join in the team earlier

Review Title: Great place to work on cutting-edge blockchain technologies
Pros:
- the opportunity to work on cutting-edge blockchain technologies (like ZKP, Layer 2, DEX, Web3 Wallet)
- very talented and skilled colleagues
- nice office in the CBD of Singapore
- above-average benefits
Cons: - for people who don't know Chinese, it may be a bit more difficult to interact with the majority of the engineering department colleagues. However, the colleagues are nice and mindful, trying to use English when needed.

Pros:
I'm in Hong Kong office, people here come from different culture backgrounds. Most of my colleagues are from China mainland and Hong Kong local. Teams here talk and corporate friendly and no unpleasant things such as "Office Politics". What's more, we several work overtime, people usually come to office at 10:00am and leave at around 19:00pm, which is WLB. We have allowance for lunch and dinner so we don't need to pay on ourselves.
I'm a software engineer here and engage in the implementation of crypto transaction system. It's a challenge job because a tiny bug may cause huge loss. I was a machine learning engineer before join OKX, so compare with my previous job, I have to be much more careful when coding.
Crypto currency and Web3 are new things, but currently hard to be accepted by the government. I don't know the potential of this new industry but the financial technology in crypto is worth learning and interesting.
The team lead and mentor I meet are really nice, they are patient and often spend time introducing me the knowledges I have to know in the team. Team members here are distributed in different locations, mainly in China mainland and Hong Kong here, so we always corporate online via the "Lark" app.
Cons: The technology infra here is not perfect and still need improvement. What's more, we have daily meeting, compare with my previous company it seems too frequent.

Pros:
1. Competitive salary, lunch and supper allowance, free drinks, snacks, fruits, and work balance are ok. 
2. The company understands the frontier of Web3, fostering an environment of innovation.
3. The company is still growing fast. and there is room for professional growth
Cons: Most of the working languages are Chinese, The Good thing is, that they are trying to use English as their first working language.

Pros:
Culture:
OKX fosters a culture that values collaboration, innovation, and inclusivity. The working environment is vibrant and supportive, encouraging open communication among colleagues. The emphasis on diversity and respect for different perspectives truly contributes to a positive and welcoming workplace.

Scope of Work as a Product Manager:
The scope of work as a Product Manager at OKX is both challenging and rewarding. I've had the opportunity to work on exciting projects that have allowed me to utilize my skills and creativity. The company provides the necessary resources and autonomy to execute ideas, making the role fulfilling and impactful.

Learning and Potential:
One of the most significant aspects of being part of OKX is the continuous learning curve it offers. The company invests in employee growth through various training programs and opportunities for skill development. As a Product Manager, I've constantly expanded my knowledge base, honed new skills, and explored different facets of the industry, which has been invaluable for my career growth.

Leadership and Working Style:
The leadership at OKX sets a remarkable example. They are approachable, supportive, and demonstrate a keen understanding of the industry. Their visionary approach and willingness to listen to ideas create an environment where every team member feels heard and valued. The working style encourages autonomy while ensuring alignment with the company's goals.
Cons: Nothing to be noted; good company

Pros: I joined OKX just a month ago, and my experience has been nothing short of fantastic. The people I've had the privilege to work with are not only great but incredibly talented in their respective roles. However, I must commend the HR department and my colleagues, who have been exceptionally helpful and supportive in helping me navigate my way through the company. Their willingness to lend a hand made my transition much smoother and more enjoyable. One aspect of OKX that stands out is the compliance department. It's an area of the company that's growing, and there's a lot to be done. What's impressive is the thoughtfulness and precision with which everyone in the department approaches their tasks and planning. It's clear that they are committed to maintaining high standards in their work. I'm looking forward to continuing my journey at OKX, and I'm excited about the opportunities and challenges that lie ahead. The company's commitment to its employees and its dedication to excellence make it a fantastic place to work.

Pros: - The compensation package offered by this company is quite attractive. - Performance bonuses can be substantial depending on your department, and it might also hinge on your relationship with your boss (hint hint) - Foodpanda package and free food seems to be crowd’s favourite. - If your goal is to earn money without much stress, this place can be a good fit. - US team boasts friendly and collaborative colleagues.
Cons: - You'll constantly live with the uncertainty of your team's accounts being randomly closed, and you'll never know who the next target of the CEO's anger will be. - The management approach here follows the usual waterfall style commonly found in Chinese companies. - While they sell an "awesome" culture to potential candidates, the actual experience can be quite shocking. - It seems like some team members receive preferential treatment, even when their 360 reviews are negative. - Be skeptical of the overwhelmingly positive reviews on Glassdoor; trust those that provide an honest, unfiltered perspective. - Gaslighting sessions appear to be a part of the typical company culture, for better or worse.

Pros: My own personal experience thus far after being a month in. 1- You walk around the office in San Jose and people will say hi and stop and introduce themselves. I love that the people here are embracing of newcomers and make you feel welcome. 2-There are a mix of hardcore Crypto adopters as well as those that are more beginner and want to learn more about the industry and maybe haven't even traded. Don't feel pressure if you're not an industry expert, as long as you have an interest and passion to learn, any level can thrive here.
Cons: With the company being at growth stages as a startup company, there are naturally a lot of navigating ambiguity. If you're the type of person that likes processes to be set in place and goals to be clearly defined with a clear path on how to perform, this may not be an environment for you. If you're a self starter who enjoys figuring out problems and a challenging environment this place will provide all of that. Also with this being a global company, there are times where you have to make adjustments for WLB.

Review Title: The most exciting place I have worked at
Pros: OKX is a company that is truly becoming a powerhouse in the crypto industry and for anyone who loves crypto and wants to see it thrive, this is the place to be. Unlike my previous jobs that were slow, mundane, and boring, working at OKX has been fast paced and full of excitement. It feels like I am working on something new almost every week and the people here are down to earth and great to work with. While this fast paced atmosphere can be demanding at times, I will say that this is also a company that notices and rewards hard working individuals. They promote hundreds of people internally every year and the opportunity for career advancement is certainly there for anyone who is willing to put in the work. The benefits for US employees are very good as well.
Cons: The compensation for P4/P5 of the US compliance team seems low compared to other competitors in the industry and traditional finance. In an industry where compliance is becoming more essential everyday, the company will need to change this if they want to recruit and retain top talent.

Pros: - Competitive package with good benefits. - The Singapore tech team is very strong. You will have a chance to work with the best engineers. - Upper managers follow the situation on the ground closely and make rational decisions. - Problems are challenging and rewarding. - Engineers control the tech and sometimes even influent the product design (the level of influence is more than other tech companies). - The team respects the office hours - Most folks left office around 6pm.
Cons: - Even at Singapore office, the default language is Chinese. You will struggle if you don't speak the language. - The tech platform and its tools are still confusing and not yet matured. You will easily get lost if you don't know what to do. After you get the hang of it however, it becomes an opportunity for you to make an impact. - Everybody is expected to perform at high level. You will get left behind if your skills are not string enough.

Pros: - Good compensation package - Great benefits - Strong and helpful mentors/senior engineers - Management checks in regularly and takes suggestions/feedback seriously
Cons: - Company is expanding quicker than processes can catch up so this can be frustrating sometimes - Some teams communicate primarily in Mandarin so miscommunication is common. While management is pushing for English to be the main language for communication, this change isn't happening quickly enough - Zero chance for a hybrid work arrangement.

Pros: Innovation and Technology, Global Exposure,Learning Opportunities, Remote Work Opportunities
Cons: there is insufficient workspace and parking for employees in office

Pros: Inclusive Opportunities: One of the standout features of working here is the equal opportunities provided regardless of your level within the company. It's refreshing to know that your contributions are valued, no matter where you are on the corporate ladder. Innovative Environment: OKX fosters an innovative environment where employees are encouraged to suggest and drive new features. This creative freedom allows us to contribute to the company's growth actively. Also founder comes from a engineering background - provides a great insight to products. Recognition from Management: I appreciate how our management team consistently acknowledges and credits employees for their hard work. It creates a motivating atmosphere where dedication is truly appreciated. Competitive Compensation: OKX offers competitive compensation packages, $20 foodpanda lunch + $25 foodpanda dinner every weekday + Monthly teambonding funds + Gym funds + Learning Funds Global Expansion and Language Support: It's exciting to see OKX expanding globally. They invest a lot in fostering a diverse and inclusive workforce, with a strong emphasis on improving English proficiency. This effort truly supports professional growth on a global scale. Also there are quite a number of opportunities to travel overseas to learn from fellow overseas colleagues.
Cons: Fast-Paced Industry: The web3 industry is known for its rapid changes, which means our directions can shift quickly. Adapting to this fast-paced environment is crucial, and newcomers should be prepared for such changes. Occasional Longer Work Hours: Some days may require you to work a bit later, especially when certain features demand extra attention. However, this is a common occurrence in the tech world. Global Collaboration: Working with global teams is rewarding, but it may sometimes necessitate adjusting your working hours to align with the schedules of colleagues in different time zones. Flexibility is key in such situations. Languages: In some teams, there might be a need to learn Chinese to facilitate effective communication. However, it's worth noting that many individuals from non-Chinese backgrounds have still been able to collaborate effectively. While language requirements can be a challenge, the company strives to create an inclusive environment where everyone can contribute, regardless of their language skills.

Pros: I have been working with OKX for more than 2 years now. So far the experience have been great. As the company embraces progressive change in terms of our product as well as our working experience. Looking back at how rigid the policies back then it lay a foundation for all of us to continuously improved and listen to feedback. One thing I appreciate about this company is the growth opportunities. They encourage and support employees in pursuing their career goals, whether that means taking on new projects, or pursuing additional education and providing us the necessary benefits. In terms of compensation and benefits, I feel that OKX is competitive and fair. The salaries are in line with other competitions. Overall would recommend OKX to anyone who is looking for a change in their career and seeking for a new challenges.
Cons: Changes on company direction is too rapid and frequent. Which may affect the morale of the employee as we do not have time to adapt accordingly. There is still a room of improvement when it comes to changes in processes and also communicating the changes. Although it can be seen that the management does listen and take note on the feedback provided.

Pros: Best job I’ve ever had
Cons: Territories can be tough for some. If you have a good territory you’re set.

Pros: Splunk has amazing benefits. The best health plans and perks I have ever encountered in my career. A handful of good eggs across several orgs make it bearable. Decent work life balance but the writing is on the wall as layoffs continue and the survivors are left having to do several jobs instead of one.
Cons:
Where do I begin? This is not a place for careee growth, it’s where you can get by and coast until retirement (the average age at this org is up there). If you are part of the inner circle, you are set for life. No amount of trying to fix the limitless red tape and poor process will get you anywhere. It is impossible to do your job with slow or broken tools. People who have never done your job are in charge of how it gets done. Why? I have spent two years here and no one can tell me how to get promoted. I have had four bosses in the same time and same BS. 

The inclusion delusion here is wild. Splunk likes to go on and on about its inclusivity yet you sit on call after call where you’re the only woman, only POC, or both. 

They cut 7% of jobs and then celebrate a “successful quarter”. 

The only way to stay sane here is to find stuff outside of work that makes the groundhog’s day of a job here worth it. For your manager it’s buying a boat or something.

Pros: Work life balance and benefits
Cons:
No career growth at all. They will promote who they want, no matter how good or bad they are at their job.

Leadership rarely knows how to run a sales cycle. They just get on a call and say give me the p.o but don’t know how to do any of the background jobs 

Everyone is leaving after this Cisco acquisition. People are going to make so much money on the stock so they are coasting.

Product is getting passed up and the company doesn’t want to admit it.

If you want to work here, make sure you’re at a majors or enterprise account or higher. Leadership started this commercial growth segment and not 1 person hit quota in America. Average quota attainment was probably around 25-30% for reps but the directors were around 60-80%. Bigger account reps dominated.

Review Title: Not the Splunk it used to be
Pros: Pay, Benefits, unlimited PTO, very nice and smart co workers
Cons: I have never seen so much great and intelligent talent to leave the company. Commercial Growth segment was a joke. No one hit the quota and they laid them all off. They also wanted RSMs to sell through partners which only complicated the process even more since not all of the partners even know what Splunk does. Competition is bitting them for sure. They are trying to sell premium product to small and medium businesses and they failed miserably. Upper leadership doesn't know what they are doing ( they don't even know how to sell the solution). Since Garry joined the company the culture is getting worse and worse.

Review Title: Much worse than a year ago and very toxic now
Pros: You can do your own thing at all times and tee up a ton of stuff.
Cons: No vision. New executive leadership is inexperienced and faking it while they destroy everything they touch. Nothing ever gets shipped and everything is now top down. If you ask clarifying questions or idea share you will be pulled aside and called insubordinate. Team meetings now consist of exec talking about how smart they are and everyone else is around just to be seen so they keep their job. Its every man for themselves now with 0 career growth opportunities. Best way to describe it is - toxic and on the verge of becoming a career killing organization.

Review Title: They treat you like you're still in college
Pros:
-Easy to meet quota when I worked there
-Collaborative environment 
-Fun culture (at times)
Cons: The dynamic is so similar to that of being in college. Leadership will require you to complete homework like assignments and congratulate those that kiss a** rather than those that consistently meet quota. Extra points if you create a slide deck on a random process that really doesn't require documentation. When you're doing well they'll "promote" you laterally with no pay increase.

Pros: great place to work for parent
Cons: not enough room for opportuniy to grow career

Review Title: Great job until you have significant personal life events or hardship
Pros:
- High degree of independence and role empowerment
- Great benefits
- Opportunity to work with brilliant people, cutting-edge technology
Cons:
- Frequent emerging product issues and incidents due to significant product and corp structure complexity/distributed responsibilities = high pressure environment
- Frequent, significant change (organizational and product direction). Managers are hit or miss and depending on your role you may be passed around to different bosses more frequently.
- Some managers are more or less understanding about work/life balance, personal life issues and significant life events. I returned from paternity leave, was assigned to a new manager (both new to me and new to his role) who was not a good match and caused me a lot of undue stress
- Big company = big layoffs

Pros: Great engineering talents, culture and fun
Cons: Talents leaving, engineering leadership and executive teamm

Review Title: Its getting a little top heavy.
Pros:
Core technology is still strong, amazing, and ready to handle more. 
Passionate, intelligent, and very approachable employees, although the ones who truly grasp the deep technology that makes Splunk work are unfortunately being replaced by the directed "just know enough" approach,
Cons:
Culture has shifted from the "Go above and beyond for Splunk" to the "Just check the boxes" approach, which stifles work enjoyment and limits innovation. 
Product direction is continuously changing and negatively impacting delivered quality and substance.

Pros: Was a great company. Technology has gotten “long in the tooth” with little to no innovation. Benefits are great. Sort of a “semi-retirement” kinda vibe.
Cons: As Cribl stated “some companies choose to innovate and others choose to litigate”. Splunk has had a steady, slow decline. Competition has blown by them. Upper management is weak, mostly due to all the talent leaving over the past 5 years so the leftovers are now at the top. Splunk is more concerned with image versus reality….sad to witness.

Pros: Good benefits and smart employees.

The number of steps to complete anything are over-processed, want to sneeze - you need 5 approvals and 10 steps to make sure you sneeze right - and as a result nothing is ever completed on time and employees don't feel trusted to do their best work because they are told constantly it isn't good enough. In all my years and companies, never seen so many smart people undervalued and a power hungry leadership who thinks they only know the answers.

Pros: Great work/life balance and good pay
Cons: Have a hard time back-filling roles

Pros: Good brand name, onboarding is great, teammates, clients are good references.
Cons:
Diversity programs are not private 
Constant turnover in sales due to lack of diversity and treatment of employees who request help from their managers and are punished and ignored for their reporting 
Not a good place for women and LinkedIn can show the lack of diversity and inclusion 

They Hire younger people and fire or layoff workers who are mostly over paid and over 50 years of age 
HR is not your friend and will hide or ignore any information that you report and their follow up will never be shared with senior management 
Management is micromanaging at very senior levels that does not allow for strategic vision from the sales reps- weekly reporting of every single task is required in slack and this is from a specific group of managers 
Limited customer support for serious needs and you are required as a sales rep to do the job of sales engineers, services and other employees jobs. It is almost impossible for a sales person to focus on strategy when there are other jobs they have to perform. 
Customers are very unhappy with so many changes and management decisions for the long term may be difficult but the lack of planning with the customers affected sales performance 
Your personal data is not protected by HR labor laws 
If you leave the company and apply at other employers the same people at the company will speak about an employee negatively and do not follow up on a single complaint. I have witnessed the derogatory comments about other employees to potential employers this should be stopped immediately as it is highly against the law. 
Layoffs and terminations focused on older women 
Sales commissions are at the discretion of HR and not labor laws 
Reporting any type of sexual misconduct is ignored by HR and they do not follow up - do not report any misconduct or you will be fired 
Several people on medical leave were fired upon return and these were mostly women 
Some of these firings took place within days of their full vesting after 4 years of hard work 
Senior management promotion of women are limited and this is a good ol boys club 
Require daily or weekly updates in slack to micromanage your team weekly work - this is a practice for a very junior team not those that have worked in their careers for many years. 
Customers are exhausted from the constant changes that don’t seem to reflect their needs first 
Requests for meetings to resolve serious disputes are ignored and blocked by HR
HR decides if you are paid on your commission and ignore the law that requires commission to be paid in full
HR uses derogatory language during layoffs and termination and violates employee confidentiality and privacy 
Stock is used as a retaliation against any employee who does not adhere to their mid level manager and threatens those who want to report harassment wjth being fired 
Managers will ask you to lie about deals and there is a problem with lack of diversity 
The discrimination is very common and this was happening for many years. 
Requests to speak to senior management is blocked or you are fired- note thst this is not widespread and only a handful of staff members are promoting this type of workplace neglect 
Stock is not worth the time because they will find any reason to lay off workers to avoid paying their options and earned salaries 
Managers are not experts or experienced managers and favors men vs women.
If you are over 40 years of age you are definitely not a good fit

Pros: Great benefits, from RSUs to ESPP to family planning, etc etc. They will reimburse up to $500 a quarter for nearly anything (I used it on vet bills.) Get a quarterly "Global Rest Day" off, and a lot of holiday time in the winter. Cons: C-level and upper management seem out of touch at times. Had several incidents, like cutting bonuses after a positive investor call, where they seemed blindsided by the blowback. Large amounts of turnover on all levels make it difficult to make connections and care about people outside my immediate team.

Review Title: If you want to enjoy being a Splunker, join a Splunk partner
Pros: Good technology and a good platform, a talented dev team. New CEO seems like his head’s in the right place.
Cons: They are actively cutting benefits like equity, bonuses, etc. to cut costs at the behest of new investors and - for the first time in 20 years - actually be a profitable business. You will have to CYA to a maniacal degree to protect yourself from your co-workers. Despite an overcompensating degree of ERGs, DEI measures, etc., it’s a toxic environment. Everyone knows the party’s over, but they’re just trying to stay in for as long as they can - and they do that by trying to throw each other under the bus. A comical overabundance of middle management, with many rookie managers who really just make everyone miserable and everything worse and more complicated. They rose into leadership to fill gaps after a large number of people left in 2020 and 2021.

Review Title: Optimistic with where Splunk is going forward
Pros: - working with talented and smart people - DEIB (diversity, equity, inclusion and belonging) program: very thoughtful and important initiative for the company; you don't see this everywhere and I genuinely appreciate how Splunk prioritizes this. - great compensation - decent work / life balance - Clear message around 3 year company strategy set by the leadership team and how that impacts the work we're doing/focusing on - it took a while but there is finally a formal goal setting/career development and planning program.
Cons: - A lot of leadership churn in the last year (expected with new CEO ) but I think this change is good and at times necessary as we're evolving as a company - When I joined last year, I was surprised with the lack of processes and tools in place, and it made our jobs a lot more difficult to get things done. The good news is that with the overwhelming feedback from across the company around tech debt and lack of operational efficiency, the leadership team took that feedback and rolled out new process and tools to address this. There's a lot of change management through this and the transition has not been easy or seamless but I'm optimistic that this will set the team up for success and scalability in the long term.

Pros:
Flexible work schedule
Growth
Learning opportunities
Independence in role
Cons:
Great company overall, few cons would be the turnover rate is high in this company. In my team alone of about 30 people, within this year,  we lost about 5+ members not to mention the turnover rate amongst senior leaders throughout the company.

Salary is decent, but they could do better with yearly raises and bonuses. They always promote how well the company is doing, but it isn’t reflected in the raises or bonuses.

Another con would be the constant changes and lack of stability that comes with it. I’ve started under TR, then it became Refinitiv and now it’s LSEG. Too many rebrands and re-orgs which is draining.

Lastly,  is a personal preference, but I don’t like how woke this company is. Very left-wing and politicized agendas are brought up often in town-halls. I don’t care about race, gender or religion constantly being pushed in the workplace. The diversity efforts is very forced and uncomfortable. All I care about if you’re a hardworking individual who is capable of doing the job. I don’t know why all the other stuff matters.

Cons: There were no process in place to help facilitate professional growth. It was an environment of friends promoting friends. There was also a huge amount of nepotism within the organization. From my perspective there was discrimination within the company. Review Title: Getting worse by the day at NAIC1
Pros: The people below leadership level are amazing.
Cons:
It's become just like any other warehouse job. Underpaid and overworked. They give you inadequate support and resources to do your job and you will have to improvise most of the time. This is highly technical work which you are expected to execute perfectly, but with little to no support. Managers will only promote their friends and family instead of people who are actually qualified. Leadership sits at their desks all day long and refuses to actually help. None of them could even help if they wanted because they all were hired from outside the company and don't know how to do anything job related. Favoritism is the foundation of leadership at NAIC1. They ship people they don't like to other buildings with at most 2 days' notice, so be prepared to adjust your childcare and educational schedule in the blink of an eye.

They police the floor and micromanage everyone out of the door. All of the tenured and talented employees have either quit or on the way out. The project manager is clueless and only comes around when it's time to complain about something. The last time I saw him, he walked around the floor upset that people weren't paying attention to him and we all got reprimanded for it.

We used to be treated like actual human beings. We are now treated like robots. Just parts of the dying machine. If you work here, just remember, you are replaceable and you mean nothing to this company.

Pros: The people at WWT all care about the company's overall success. There are some talented and intelligent technical resources, as well as competent and experienced sales teams that operate with integrity and a desire to help customers succeed. The pay is good, it is privately held so no stock awards, but they make up for it with great benefits.
Cons:
Growing rapidly with silos from that expansion. 
Heavily rely on partners to support marketing and brand awareness, and miss out on opportunities to share more publically about what all WWT does and is good at.

Pros: Healthcare, LOA and PTO benefits offered by WWT are outstanding. They are working to provide better training to new employees. They genuinely care about their employees.
Cons: The company is growing so quickly, they don't have enough processes documented. Which means for some positions, people's work shows inconsistent quality. With a lack of processes, it can be difficult for a new person to learn.

Pros:
My paycheck was always correct.
They offer adequate PTO. 
Education reimbursement.
They offer every program available for free on Udemy.
Cons: Their pay is absolutely far to low for the level of knowledge they expect you to aquire and utilize. They say that the benefits they offer make up the difference. I have looked into that statement, it really doesn't put them anywhere close to the pay every other warehouse is offering. I made less than $18/hr after 5 years of employment. They also preach about how there are possibilities everywhere for growth. Unfortunately, I've only ever seen people who were connected to individuals with pull get any job that can be considered an upgrade.

Pros: Great People to work with
Cons: Career movement, can get stuck in your silo

Review Title: Not actually a great place to work
Pros: Good Healthcare, but they'll make sure to mention that they pay a lot for it every open-enrollment
Cons:
Poor raises. 

Poor bonuses.

Silent Layoffs two years in a row.

Cult-like mentality amongst both company leaders and lower org leaders. 

They claim to be a tech company but don't have the stomach to "do whatever it takes" to succeed in being a great place to work.

More interested in penny-pinching what they pay their people (and what country they hire from) than actually winning customers on quality and innovation.

They harp on innovation but don't actually have the appetite to support innovative work within the company.

Pros: The culture at WWT cannot be beat. I would not want to work anywhere else. I love the people on our team and am given flexibility and direction.
Cons: Our team is growing and changing every day, which can lead to ambiguity in the role. There aren't many cons but I would say that it is sometimes challenging to find an answer. You have to be self-motivated and unafraid to dig to discover an answer or resolution.

Review Title: DEI and favoritism is a bad mix!
Pros: Great pay! Great benefits! Great work life balance. Opportunities to learn new technologies.
Cons: Way too much favoritism! WWT leadership talks a big game of DEI, but you're only inclusive if you are part of the upper mgmt good Ole boy system. Some get promos and notoriety while others do not. Advancement is something reserved for workers in their favor. Also discrimination runs rampant. You can be discredited and blackballed for being sick. Highly illegal!!

Pros: Exciting opportunities, great customers and innovative partner ecosystem. Exec and leadership commitment to values, culture and engagement is off the charts good.
Cons: Amazing growth creates some challenges and confusion on ownership and consistency across different teams.

Review Title: Clear direction and engagement from the top down
Pros: Pay, culture, benefits, inclusion, leadership
Cons: I can’t find a single negative to say about working at WWT

Pros: Great capabilities to offer customers. Great people throughout WWT. Great benefits Great facilities
Cons: The executive team tends to be insular and difficult to crack into for those outside of STL and the various familial/friendship ties. Titles and promotions are inconsistently applied in the organization. Too many silos internally; WWT is getting too big to let various groups do whatever they want and politics are much worse today than years ago when I joined. Pay is low relative to peers. Travel restrictions. Diversity initiatives, while well intentioned aren't working well. Too many undeserved promotions; promoting based on diverse gender/race is no better than doing the same for someone part of the majority. Promote based on performance.

Pros: good work environment with decent pay and great benefits
Cons: Culture and my building has steadily declined over the years lack of transparency from upper management.

Pros: Great culture, amazing services, customer focused
Cons: Challenging market landscape with budgets being cut and competition growing

Pros: Good work life balance. Great culture, great team
Cons: Lack of pay range transparency

Pros: Nice office space and good healthcare
Cons:
Pretty much everything else 
- pay was well below market rate. They say they benchmark against the market, but they give raises of 1-2% and when I left the company, I had been searching for a while and had gotten 5 different offers over the course of my year's job search and ALL of them were paying 25-35% higher than WWT. 
- very nepotistic, boys club mentality. High bonuses for execs of millions of dollars while refusing to give raises to the majority of employees that even keep up with the rate of inflation. 
- do not invest in resources. While I was working at WWT in the corporate Maryland heights office, the company won a large contract and didn't properly staff the warehouse to accommodate the shipments. Corporate execs then proceeded to shame the employees at the Maryland heights office to work their 8-5 desk job, then go work a shift at the warehouse in edwardsville from 6pm-11pm to pack boxes because they didn't hire enough workers. This was for no pay or benefit and they called it "volunteering" to fulfill a many-millions dollar contract that WWT was getting paid for. When people didn't sign up to "volunteer," management accused people I worked with of not being team players. 
- the company spends money on very showy events like their Global Sales Meeting, where they fly out 1500 people from various sales/sales support positions to somewhere like Vegas to stay at a hotel like the Cosmo. Employees are forced to go, but then forced to SHARE ROOMS with coworkers. I knew people that had to share a hotel room with their bosses. No option was given to not attend the conference, and if you wanted to not share a room with a coworker/boss, WWT forced you to pay for your own accommodations. Very inappropriate and weird, especially since the bathrooms at the Cosmo have windows into the hotel room, so to shower, you had to coordinate a time with your roommate so they wouldn't be in the room while you showered and still would fear that they would walk into the hotel room and see you showering. The company spends money on things that don't matter while skimping on things like basic accommodations for a mandated work trip.

overall, this company does not have its priorities in line and needs to prioritize its employees rather than ONLY profit.

Review Title: Really is a great place to work
Pros: Very positive work environment, growing company, a lot of opportunity for growth, benefits are amazing
Cons: Company is growing fast, so there are growing pains along the way.

Pros: The benefits have gone down hill every year, but they are mostly company paid, so you can't even complain. They do this on purpose. If your local to STL, you gain more benefits with this. For my position, pay was good. As a whole, the company doesn't pay well and relies on cheaper labor. Some good and friendly people at the ground floor levels. It's when you get closer to corporate that it's true colors show.
Cons: The have and the have nots. I have been to STL a few times and met many good workers in the warehouses. It's factory work for the most part, but they will be incredibly jealous of you for travel and pay after you start talking to them. It's a mixed bag. They heavily rely upon being black owned, yet in four years, I never saw the "founder" nor heard his name until BLM and Juneteenth came around. You would be surprised to know he existed at all, but they promote the heck out of it now. It doesn't really matter. WWT has a cult like following internally, until you begin to see the cracks in the foundation. Silicon Valley of STL, never quite worked out. They waste a heck of a lot of money on the if you build it motto. It's a cut throat world, and WWT will burn anyone who jumps in their way.

Review Title: Overall a great org, but pay is woefully missing from the larger conversation
Pros: WWT has some of the best people you could ask to work with. The health benefits are good, and management has embraced the workplace flexibility technology creates.
Cons: Workers are getting absolutely crushed on several economic fronts. For a company that boasts revenue in the several billions, providing salary increases that are at least 6-10% (at the very least) is not asking for much. Unfortunately, no amount of culture initiatives or “perks” can outweigh the sheer stress and uncertainty your workers experience when they are struggling to make ends meet through no fault of their own. There is more than enough money to pay your workers more, retain solid benefits and continue operating as a profitable company.

Pros: Overall the company is really good. Especially for the IT/Office side.
Cons: Supply chain is lacking alot. Supervisors get their hands tied behind their back by managers. Executive management below the Jeree level doesn't make an effort on the floor, they barely walk around and really only know the best/worst workers by name/face. They don't really communicate with the other 95% of the work force. When they do walk the floor it's almost like they're subjecting themselves to something below them. Body language speaks alot about them. Not every NAIC/Program is equal. You can have awesome leadership in one area but terrible in another. Executive team should shadow their leaders more consistently to find where the supervisors/managers are lacking. The office/IT part of the company is treated differently than supply chain. I know this from GROW and communicating with them. Their leaders issues are nowhere near the leaders issues in supply chain and they always act shocked when we discuss that.

Pros: Professional Autonomy is nice, we are not micromanaged Overall day to day operations are run well within Project Engineering
Cons: Pay range is quite low, they have reduced the pay ceiling on a number of Project Engineering jobs as well. Each position within my department had their ceiling dropped by 10-20k. Pay raises not well defined but seem to be getting better? Normally it is just a flat 3% without wiggle room regardless of performance, though this seems to be improving somewhat. Only 1 year has been performance based so far, lets hope this is a trend. There are two companies at WWT. The warehouses/lab, and then the offices. They have -vastly- different cultures, with warehouse/lab being treated only as an expense not a value driver. Lack of a professional certification program, this is in the works, but has been for over 2 years. At some point it just becomes more "wait and you'll see!"

Review Title: The Best Employer I've ever worked for..
Pros: WWT has always made its people a priority and it shows. The benefits are outstanding, management is always actively seeking out how they can be better. In my 1.5 years here so far, I have seen the company take action on so many suggestions and employee feedback. They truly listen and are doing all that they can to be a top employer.
Cons: In non sales roles it can be difficult to achieve a salary at or above market rate. If you can find a way to achieve the $$ you want through bonuses and other options, there is potentially other ways to get to where you want to be, but it can be a challenge. You should look to factor in yearly raises as well, and see that you can build to market rate and beyond within a few years. The benefits are well worth the hit to the pay, especially if you are looking to have or start a family.

Review Title: Excellent Company - Great Leadership and Great Culture
Pros: Great Culture - People First!
Cons: Nothing major to report on the cons.

Pros: Great culture is constantly reinforced and work is being done to address a remote workforce. Executive Leadership is very accessible and offers many opportunities for you to provide feedback that is thoughtfully considered. There is a focus on training for anyone who seeks out opportunities and takes advantage of them. Flexible, remote working with the opportunity to get together in person allows for collaboration while still offering the ability to work without distraction. Executive Leadership is transparent with employees on both successes and challenges and has a high level of consistency in the mission and vision. The focus on Diversity and Inclusion feels genuine and is really just an extension of an already good program. Coworkers truly make this a great place to work.
Cons: Explosive growth has created operational silos. With such a high number of remote workers, the camaraderie and culture is harder to maintain to the same levels as before. Work life balance can be a challenge depending on your role.

Pros: uhhh nothing really yea no
Cons: Working at a certain technology company was an absolute nightmare. The toxic work culture, excessive workload, poor leadership, lack of career growth opportunities, inadequate compensation and benefits, and outdated technology and infrastructure made it an unbearable place to work. The company claimed to value teamwork and collaboration, but it was all a facade as employees were pitted against each other in a cutthroat competition. The workload was overwhelming, with tight deadlines and unrealistic expectations, leading to burnout. The leadership was disconnected and ineffective, while career growth opportunities were limited. The compensation and benefits were subpar, considering the demands of the job, and the technology and infrastructure were outdated. Overall, it was a dreadful employment experience that should be avoided at all costs.

Review Title: The worse employer I have ever had the displeasure to work for!
Pros: When you don’t have to interface with management (managers, directors, VP’s, etc), great peers and colleagues.
Cons: Where do I start….I came to WWT because they had a minority owner in David Steward. I, for some reason, thought this would be a racially diverse company, from management to the engineering staff, with a plethora of opportunities to advance your career; however, I was completely wrong! There were things that were done to me over the course of 6-8 months of my tenure at WWT that were unbelievable. I was accused of aggressive behavior racially synonymous with a certain minority group. I was accused of unprofessional behavior by certain account teams and management despite their being no evidence to support these assertions. Management was unsupportive despite there being plenty of evidence to support my claims of what I was experiencing as racial microaggressions. Management loved the terms, “coach them up,” and “right seat on the bus,” which only applies to the majority. There’s so much I dealt with in my short tenure at WWT, and despite being technically “laid-off,” I declined the severance out of principle. I wanted nothing from a company that treats minorities in the way I, and others were treated. I was offered a couple options, #1 was totally disrespectful and not really an option, and #2 was resignation with severance, I chose neither. I’m extremely blessed to no longer be at WWT. The stress from this situation added 5 years to my life that I can’t get back. I’ll leave with this final note, I only experienced these issues within a certain group at WWT. I’m not sure how the rest of the company is/was, but under the conditions I described, I’m glad I didn’t stick around to find out. These are my opinions derived through my experiences with the company. The great thing is that I have all of this well documented. I started capturing it early on in the process as part of my own professional therapy session. I’m not sure what I’ll do with the information, but I will show it to my children as they need to know what to expect when they enter corporate America.

Pros: Great benefits, good culture, mostly remote.
Cons: Hard to get the pay you want.

Pros: In the short time I’ve been here there is clearly a strong team culture focused on achieving results. Unlike other tech companies, there’s a lot more understanding and patience for folks to learn from their mistakes and get support to do better. One thing that will
Cons: It’s a bit scary how much the company relies on power point and spreadsheets for a lot of internal processes. It feels a bit inefficient but building strong relationships across the firms help counteract that.

Pros: Great people Great work/life balance Fully remote Great benefits
Cons: Compensation is the only con other than that everything is great here. It truly is a great place to work

Review Title: A stepping stone but not a fantastic entry point
Pros: Good upward mobility if you can get into a technology position Decent Benefits The best managers I've ever had are in their data center department Fantastic training options Decent networking opportunities
Cons: -It's incredibly difficult to go anywhere if you start in any warehouse location -A lot of the warehouses have extremely poor management -very difficult to utilize the training opportunities at the lowest level due to being in a production role.

Review Title: Unfortunately an Old Boys Network for a majority Boack owned company
Pros: Great culture, helpful Engineers and staff. Great healthcare and training. Excellent projects and work
Cons: Majority of those in upper management are of the same type. They bring their own and promote only certain types. Moving up REGARDLESS of how great an Engineer or leader you are, is difficult. Meritocracy did not apply for some. WWT was not always like this; I was there long enough to see this ugly transformation. Sad because Jim and Dave are nice people BUT I cannot say the same for the managers. You would never know it was a majority Black owned company. Sad and discouraging. Forgot all the stuff about Great Place to Work. It is pushed for PR reasons . May be great for the Old Boys Network

Review Title: Lots of variability and customization, which is good and bad
Pros: Great leadership at VP+ levels; brilliant peers doing good work; great work life balance; good pay and PTO
Cons: Onboarding is insufficient; your learning depends on you networking; not much transferability between programs and projects because of high customization to client needs; not much documentation and formal traning

Pros: The current health insurance plan is good.
Cons: 1) Frequent layoffs. WWT is hyper-focused on their "Great places to work" status, but only current employees are surveyed. Entire teams are often laid off without warning and without their "great employer" first attempting to relocate them elsewhere in the company or with regard to existing client contracts. This leads to a culture of uncertainty & fear, where workers are told to not to worry about the other cattle being loaded into trucks. 2) Services-oriented executive leadership is perpetually floundering. They simply don't know how to sell services, but when they do land a few deals they rapidly over-hire for those skillsets to meet anticipated future demand which never materializes, leading to a yo-yo-diet workforce. This feeds into layoffs as outlined in item #1. 3) They track every hour of your day with an internal tool requiring justification for everything. Viewed by some as micro-management is actually compensation for #2. 4) WWT thinks their "values" (the PATH) are unique in the industry, when in fact most large orgs have similar corporate mantras. What's unique is how hard WWT pushes these values in a cult-like manner, preached via weekly all-hands meetings and individual discussions with management centered around them. This is in addition to the billionaire chairman's "prosperity theology" ramblings, which may not be everyone's cup of tea.

Pros: Great Company good benefits and ok work life balance
Cons: Can be very reactive and not follow processes set in place. One team from another seem to operate in their own ways that cause disfunction at times

Review Title: Best tech culture I have ever worked in

Cons: The small company feel is being replaced by big company feel. This is inevitable and I believe is being addressed.

Pros: Excellent executive leadership, good pay, good benefits, and mostly good culture.

Review Title: Siloed workaholic culture, constant change, lack of focus on execution, a risk to mental health
Pros: WWT gives the architects a lot of opportunities to get your hands involved. Lots of strategic discussions if you like that.
Cons: Too many siloes. Everyone owns "something", until they have it ripped away by some other "owner". No one actually works together. You have no power to execute change with other people who might logically work with you. Management by checklist. Quarterly partner reviews are just a dog-and-pony show - there is no effort to fix things. Partner management is all about catering to a partner, not really integrating them. It's so easy to get trapped between competing demands on your role and no one will get with you to reconcile these changes. Manager X says, "we don't do that, I'll fire you if I catch you doing that". Manager Y says, "it's your fault if this fails because you don't do that task." Managers X and Y won't ever talk to each other - you have to figure out how to tread between the two poles. As long as the partner is helping fund your compensation and the check clears, they're fine with it. No one in leadership wants to hear about problems. The approach is to "counsel" you out of believing that. There's no culture of solving a problem or changing an established practice. There are too many layers of management for such a relatively small company - I influence millions of dollars of revenue and I'm 8? levels below the CEO (and it's always churning - no one ever knows who is actually in charge). I'm working 2 full-time jobs, it feels like, with little practical support to navigate between them. I'd like to look for a different role in the company, but I'd be blocked by my current boss and the vendor management. I don't even know who I'd escalate to. There's no HR group with an open door policy. I'm too well known outside WWT that when/if I started looking around, it'd be very public. There's no "quiet" job search in my role. My mental health has severely declined in this role. I'm tired of people saying (even jokingly) that I'm going to get fired when I try to take initiative to solve things that they don't care to solve.

Pros: Great people, Work life balance, great benefits

Review Title: It really is a great place to work!
Pros: The people are amazing and the benefits are fantastic. I still love working here after 13 years.
Cons: There are definitely growing pains but we are working on it. We have grown so much through the years and the team members who were hired during COVID have not experienced the real culture. It is hard to balance all of that.

Pros:
Benefits are great
A lot of different opportunities open
Character and integrity will carry you far
Coaching up is encouraged
Cons:
Staying in the same role, no matter how great you are, will not gain you a larger raise. (A con for those who have a hard time stepping out of their comfort zones)
There are teams that have not been managed properly (mainly due to customer demands and requirements) and could use experience from other program management. Like everywhere there are the teams of yes men and minimium effort workers that seem to get promoted which brings down moral. 
This is not the case for the company as a whole, but it is where you will find majority of the problem areas. Majority of the negative reviews come from those teams' employees.

Review Title: Good Benefit, no life other than work life.
Pros: Health benefit, location, free coffee, discounted snack bar.

No personal work life balance. Not an enterprise or big tech company (run like mom and pop). No advancement in career, nor on your knowledge.
If you are starting your career, you need a big company name on your resume, it will be alright, things you learn from the company won't be useful anywhere else. If you are a seasoned engineer, stay away, unless you just want a job with decent pay and if you don't have a personal life, it might work out for you too. Good old boys' system, they have a tendency of overworking Korean speaking employees, if you are not, you will be fine, just do your job and don't speak up, you will have a job. They validate my firm belief in competency breed incompetence, and this company is prime example of it. You will end up doing someone else's job and you won't even be recognized for it.

Good Luck
