Pros: I've been working for SDS America for almost two years and this has been by far one of the most invaluable experiences for junior level individuals really looking to advance their career and gain some marketable experience. This is a global conglomerate so opportunities are definitely there whether you are in IT or Business. You have exposure to many projects and challenges and take full autonomy over those projects (read: long hours, high reward... if you're intrinsically motivated). The health benefits are great. Culture is all depending on which location you work out of. Training programs are easily accessible and widely encouraged.
Cons: This organization is not for the faint of heart. SDS is still struggling with the clash of "Samsung-style" Korean culture & American workforce culture. If you have zero empathy for other cultures and cannot adapt, you will not survive. No real emphasis on work/life balance. Don't expect to be outrageously compensated either. But like I said, the learning experience is great for those wanting to gain valuable professional experience.

Review Title: If you have any other option, don’t take this job.
Pros: Cafeteria food was cheap and good, free snack in the afternoon once a week.
Cons:
This is the worst company I have ever worked in my 12 years professional career. 
	No family-working balance.   Long hours 9-6, other companies are 9-5.  However, you can never leave at 6pm.  Your manager expects you to stay late every day.  Sometimes work till midnight, and no compensation day/hour.  
	Not flexible.  Too controlling manager style.  No chatting, no talking on the phone during office hour.   Office is so quite, you just need to work like a slave.  You cannot go lunch on your own schedule.  
	No trust between managers and employees.  My co-worker was asked to bring in a doctor’s note for one sick day.  Managers get nerves when people ask for sick days, because they don’t want people to go for interviews. 
	No chance of moving up in the corporate. Korean team drives the project; I did not get to design and contributing my ideas.   
	There are so many people quit during the time I was there.   Turn over rate is very high.

Pros: Only reason to get a job at Samsung SDS America is for their health insurance benefit.
Cons:
1. Don't be fooled by the name Samsung. This company is a subsidiary and still acts like a Start-up company.
2. If you are Asian your salary will be substantially low as opposed to white folks. If there's a government audit the company would be in big trouble.
3. Just terrible management. It's very rare to find a competent manager in the company. The majority of the managers has NO leadership quality. This is by far the biggest problem with the company. Very unfortunate.

Review Title: Glassdoor wouldn't let me give less than 1 star
Pros:
Great benefits
Worked with great people
Cons:
-Staff is very underpaid
-Seems like the company has been hanging on by a thread for years
-For an IT company all the internal systems we use are very outdated
-The Korean culture clashes with the American culture
-Meetings are almost always in Korean even if you do not speak it
-Americans feel like outcasts
-The work day ends at 6pm but if you leave at 6pm you will get dirty looks for leaving on time
-Most of management talks down to its employees and treats them like 2nd rate
-The management style is micro-management
-The company is retroactive to issues it faces instead of proactive
-There are constant rumors of sexual harassment between Korean dispatchers and staff level employees and the company doesn't seem to do anything more than slap them on the hand

Review Title: Worst Company I Have Ever Worked At
Pros: Not much other than health benefits
Cons:
After working here, then eventually experiencing what it's like to work at a good company, it's like night and day.  Every single day would feel physically sick about working here.  I would walk to the front door then imagine if that door had the word, "HELL" printed on it.  People come and go like the wind here.  A lot of the Directors are absolute control freaks who probably have not taken a leadership class in their lives.

Everything here is based on fear, not enthusiasm.  Bosses will use fear against you by only complaining/putting you down/only talking about every thing bad, without saying one good word about you.  Say something wrong during a meeting that might "embarrass" your boss, then they will make you "relive" their experience ten fold.

Pros:
Good benefits, health insurance and dental, and PTO available.
There is ample opportunity to learn, though mostly through trial by fire.
Cons: Bonus is dismal.  "Cheaping out" is a common theme.  Especially when it comes to storage for the systems that are maintained.  Projects and systems show obvious signs of minimal testing, lack of QA, and strict enforcement of tight deadlines to save money.  Resources are stretched to the extreme.

Review Title: They Abuse you and use you
Pros: Good benefits, learn a lot in one year, sr. Hr manager is wonderful and a huge help.
Cons:
Instead of asking the employee what else they would like to be involved in, they go ahead and just force them into certain roles and tasks without any conversation. 
The Korean culture does not work in America. Need to change that mentality. 
There is no team work. It is like the Americans and Koreans are fighting against one another. The Koreans don't want to hear the ideas of the Americans which makes no sense since it would help the business tremendously. 
Their systems are pointless and not helpful. Need to upgrade their outlook system so scheduling can be easier to manage. 
SDS is very outdated compared to other companies.

Review Title: Only good to have the Samsung name on the resume
Pros:
If you actually get hired,  you can say you actually worked for Samsung and everyone would be impressed.

Benefits are good, they give lunch money, and pay is just okay
Cons:
You will sell your soul for working at Samsung.  SDS is the bottom feeder of all Samsung companies.  If you're Korean and not in management, be prepared to work long hours and prepare tons of reports. 

There's too many layers of management and most are unreasonable.  Everyone will start out as a contractor and you'll be lucky if you get hired within a year.   If you want to move up in your career, be prepared to relocate and work long hours.

Not worth the time.

Pros:
In my group I get to work on very cutting edge technologies. We have some really good engineers here.
Health insurance is great, probably the best you'll find anywhere.
Diverse work areas / projects.  It's a conglomerate, so SDS has access to a range of internal and external clients.
Stable relative to startups, or financial firms.
Can get nice gadgets.
Cons:
There has been a push to be more innovative, and flexible.  Some parts of the firm will really feel like a 'big firm', but other parts will feel start-up like.  The spectrum is wide.
I think the overall experience may depend on which group you work in. e.g. traditional vs. new.
Some offices are kind of drab looking.
401k matching not great. Small percentage of the IRS max.

Review Title: Good Benefits, The Work Has Its Ups and Downs
Pros:
Good medical and 401k match
Nice coworkers(even management), subsidized cafeteria lunch, fun activities (Halloween party, ping pong & other Korean game tournaments, volunteer days)
Christmas gift ($400 Samsung gift card or choose from preselected Samsung products)
It’s a pleasure to work with the IT teams on the second floor.
Cons:
B2B projects are all very unprofitable and mostly a waste of time. They mostly resell low margin Samsung devices.
Too dependent on business from Samsung Electronics and that business continues to decline.
Management has the best intentions but is unable to build the right products with the right features the market needs.

Review Title: SDSRA - bad place for your career
Pros: High quality problems to work on (but not enough quantity). Good work/life balance and good facilities (gym, nice office, nice cafe, etc). Good place to get 2 years of experience, but terrible place to stay longer than that
Cons: Low pay - 6% bonuses and 2% raises each year regardless of how well you do. Also no stock and no promotions except for a couple people who know which butts to kiss and how to kiss them. HR is completely out of touch with reality of keeping good people around in Silicon Valley. More than half the team left in the past year and more will leave soon because getting an offer somewhere else is guarantees to be higher pay

Pros: Worked with some of the smartest and brightest people in the IT services industry.  Also a huge focus on teamwork, and a dedication by everyone to do whatever it takes to get the work done.
Cons: Senior executives really don't have a deep understanding of the specific functional areas and lack the industry knowledge to drive business.  Samsung is an organization that develops and nurtures managers that are generalists and more focused on administration and management.  In order to succeed, it needs to invest more in bringing quality talent from within specific industry sectors, especially at the higher levels of the organization.

Pros: best work environment and working condition. The building was equipped with full amenities like cafeteria, restaurant, shops, and gyms (in a separate building) and colleges were the best.
Cons: Busy times, you needed to work over night for weeks. Not very diversified in terms of employees. Uses its own word system which can by annoying sometimes.

Pros: Prestigious Name / Brand and food.
Cons: Stiff Culture | Low morale | Employee high turn over - 80-90% of the time Contractual Positions. ZERO growth. System is Old School / Primitive for being in the I.T. Industry - Ridiculous

Pros:
The physical amenities of the campus are very nice. Lovely space, good cafeteria (though trending downward), good gym, plenty of nooks to work privately. Opportunities to travel domestically and to Korea. 

Colleagues are friendly. Work-life balance (compared to the other offices in Seoul) is good, but be prepared to drop your life/cancel your vacation/work for 48 hours straight if an executive comes to town at the last minute.  

The Samsung name opens a lot of doors and looks very good on the resume.
Cons:
There are exceptionally limited opportunities to move up or succeed unless you are a native born Korea. It's unclear who has it worse, Korean Americans or non-Koreans in terms of being taken seriously, getting put on good projects, or even just your colleagues in Korea being willing to work with you.  Pay for expensive areas to live like Silicon Valley and Seattle is very low. 

Annual reorganizations completely ruin any long-term planning for team. Extreme focus on P&L can make investment efforts that will pay off in a couple years but require initial work to gain traction are killed before they are given a chance. 

HQ is very opaque and it is hard for regional offices to understand strategy and direction for the year. Additionally, the Seoul Office has the final say in absolutely everything. If a product is developed in Samsung SDS America, HQ will take over the project/source code from the regional office. This leaves the individuals in the regional offices demotivated in their work. All initiatives must have a sponsor in the Korean office as well, even if it is a regional initiative.  But if you're not from the Korean office (ie you have prior personal connections) you can't even find who is the right person to talk to about sponsoring.

Review Title: Cutting edge technology, rapidly growing team
Pros: Cutting edge technology, such as Spark distributed computing framework and Scala programming language. Co-workers are good at their fields. Potential access to interesting data.
Cons: HQ is in Korea, so you may get the occasional email with snippets in Korean that you don't understand (day-to-day work is completely in English). Like with any rapidly growing team, projects change, so you have to be flexible.

Pros: The medical and well care benefits were the most positive aspect at Sage.
Cons: I am sad to share how terrible my experience was at Sage. It was a toxic, pressure cooker with managers who were narcissistic, manipulative, and volatile. I did not want to write such a negative review but I have to in order to have others considering employment here to hopefully avoid the pain. There was so much emphasis on DEI but numerous times when there was blatant ageism. I can't emphasize it enough that you will be discriminated against if you are on the older side. Sage changed the comp plan where we could only earn commissions twice a year and had quotas that were almost impossible to attain. It's such a shame to share these details because there are some very nice people who work there. I don't miss the verbal abuse, the manipulations, unachievable goals, and unrealistic expectations. I feel sorry for those who have to still suffer there. We all deserve better. It didn't have to be so terrible with such shameful behavior at times. Sarah McCune would be so disappointed if she knew how her company is behind the curtains.

Review Title: Good Place to work but things seem questionable now
Pros:
Benefits overall are good

Interesting work for developers using latest tech

Good processes in place

A lot of developers are passionate about creating innovative solutions
Cons:
There have been a number of major missteps by senior leadership including:

Team agreements - this one is set by senior leadership and teams are told to comply not agree. So much so it's used as part of the review process (how a team agreement can determine how well someone has done is beyond me). I agree that time in the office and collaboration is a good thing, but the amount of time spent should be decided by the teams themselves not senior management who want bums on seats

"High performance culture" - this one cracks me up personally. The CEO is giving all hands meetings talking about this while there are audio and video issues in said meetings. There is also a lot of middle to higher management who seem to not be doing a lot of work and instead impose themselves on others (directors etc).

We have now been informed of potential redundancies and restructuring etc, which kind of makes the above 2 now make sense. 

I personally think redundancies are counter active to a high performance culture. If you want the products Sage create to improve and involve you have to keep your high performers and keep them happy. You seem to be doing the opposite of that at the moment

Review Title: Expect constant change and no delivery on goals
Pros: Good salary, good annual bonus, access to great benefits.
Cons:
Constantly shifting priorities, senior leadership's heads turned by shiny new toys every 6 months, causing chaos for people trying to deliver software. This isn't in relation to the changing landscape of accounting, it's just bad planning and lack of foresight.

No product leadership - Chief Product Officer appears once a year and then vanishes until the next financial year kicks off. I have no idea what his views are on anything, have no sense of his strategy for the organisation and makes no attempt to foster any sense of cohesion as a product function.

As people begin to return to the office, facilities are starting to feel the strain. Impossible to get a seat at lunch if you turn up at 12:01, I've seen people eating lunch stood with food propped on a windowsill and others eating in the "break out" call pods meant for having private Teams calls.

Many colleagues feeling the same sense of disconnection, misery and isolation. Sage is currently promoting "high performance mentality" but making no fundamental changes to the core problems that are causing low performance.

Pros: I appreciate the culture at Sage—it fosters a fantastic work/life balance, and the flexibility in schedules is a significant plus. The inclusion of community service paid time off adds an extra layer of balance, making it an overall enriching experience.
Cons: The compensation falls on the lower side of the standard pay scale for this role. Frequent budget cuts, particularly targeting the marketing budget, can impact the ability to maintain a robust pipeline. Additionally, there is a lack of well-established standard operating processes within the organization.

Pros: Some of my colleagues & health cover.
Cons: Company direction is taking a nose-dive & dragging culture to an all time low as all executives care about is profit nowadays. The good people are leaving & now the best exec we had has left the business - the last person we had to look up to. Enter mediocrity & a senior leadership team that cares nothing for the people or the culture. The HR team don’t care & help sweep reports of misconduct by SLT under the carpet & engrain the failing culture. Product don’t listen to customers or sales & they churn out features that don’t work or lacks innovation. I’ve done OK at Sage, so I hold no grudges, but know I need to leave as the company & the product are running towards a hard fail & zero faith left in current exec team to turn this around. Very disappointing.

Review Title: Short stint, not for the long term
Pros: Great culture between colleagues, lots of talented and passionate people, respectable bonus and share scheme, some good perks.
Cons:
Pay is always lacking, you will feel as if you’re always paid slightly less than the work you’re doing deserves. Be prepared for random layoffs of whole teams as leadership arbitrarily restructure every 9 months. Currently the company is massively understaffed by design, whist we are told to be ‘high performance’ aka do the work of the teams we just fired for no extra pay or title. There is a real issue within certain teams of unwillingness to help and some heads of departments are actively detrimental to the roles of people who report into them.
Best to do 1-2 years to get the experience and hop to another company.

Pros: I'm lucky to work in a really positive team, with a focus on self development and constructive criticism. Everyone is working towards the same goal and when i hear of more toxic work environments I appreciate working somewhere that understands we are human, and work is only a part of our lives, not all of it. I recently utilised the work away scheme which is a major perk for me.
Cons:
It was disheartening to see that the gender pay gap has grown in recent years in the latest report. It seems nothing is being done to rectify that. 
On a smaller note, although it is the same in most modern offices, is that they're too cold (usually designed for men who are naturally hotter) I love my office days to collaborate with the team (although love the hybrid best of both worlds setup) but sometimes I'm cold to the point of distraction.

Review Title: The work remains good, but what was a positive, people-focused culture is evapourating
Pros: My team are great! Since joining I've worked with some absolutely great people, who are properly supportive, know their stuff, always have time to jump on a call and talk over a problem. I've also been part of super exciting projects, with what feels like very new tech and solutions. I've taken up more and more responsibility and feel I've really grown a lot in my short time here so far.
Cons: The culture isn't what it used to be... I used to find communication from the higher ups regular, honest and transparent. Now it's super mirky. I feel big decisions and changes come out of nowhere. It's not a massive deal, but it's definitely changed the feel/culture. I don't think I trust the EVPs, VPs and Cs anymore. Best example of this is progression. People keep asking when the hiring freeze will be lifted, and the response is always along the lines of "there is no freeze on hiring/progression and never has been". This is the party line that people are being told to say, but the reality is that my team lead (and many others across the company) have been pushing for progressions for over a year and keep getting palmed off. So, the situation is that either the Directors, EVPs and other high ups who sit above my team lead simply don't actually have the clout to push a progression through (which would be worrying at that level), or we're just being straight up lied to.

Review Title: Exceptional Work Environment and Supportive Management at Sage!
Pros:
I am writing to express my heartfelt appreciation for the incredible work culture and management support at Sage. As a recent graduate SRE, my experience with Sage has been nothing short of remarkable, and I feel compelled to share the positive impact it has had on my professional journey.

First and foremost, Sage has introduced me to a work-life balance that I never knew was possible. The emphasis on maintaining a healthy equilibrium between work and personal life has greatly contributed to my overall well-being. This has not only enhanced my job satisfaction but has also allowed me to bring my best self to the workplace each day.

The management at Sage deserves commendation for their exceptional leadership and unwavering support. The team's commitment to fostering a collaborative and inclusive environment is truly inspiring. I have found the management to be approachable, understanding, and always ready to assist. Their proactive stance in ensuring that every team member is engaged and motivated is a testament to their dedication to employee growth and satisfaction.

One aspect that sets Sage apart is the dynamic and stimulating work environment. I appreciate how the management actively works to prevent monotony and ensures that no day is like the other. This commitment to variety and challenge has fuelled my motivation to continuously learn and grow within the company.

Moreover, the opportunities for professional development and learning are abundant at Sage. The encouragement to take on new challenges, coupled with the ample resources provided for skill enhancement, has been instrumental in my personal and career growth.

In conclusion, I am genuinely grateful to be a part of the Sage family. The positive atmosphere, the supportive management, and the focus on employee well-being have made my transition into the professional world seamless and enjoyable. I look forward to contributing my best to Sage's success while continuing to grow both personally and professionally.

Thank you for providing an exceptional workplace that fosters growth, collaboration, and well-being.
Cons: No cons, all positive, great job team!.

Review Title: Not as good as it used to be
Pros: Good benefits, decent pay, decent bonus if your face fits and your product sells. Office canteen is ok and reasonably priced.
Cons: The whims of management can be quite demotivational at times. They were fantastic over lockdown, but the mandated return to office is silly when we've recruited colleagues who live a long way from the offices and were recruited on the basis that they didn't need to go into an office. Now they're told they must, so we're losing good people. There's many teams which have only one person in a particular office and there's immense pressure for them to go into the office and sit on their own. Why? Management decisions are rarely communicated well. We get extensive communications on irrelevant matters, but don't get to hear about decisions that actually impact us until after they've been implemented. The back-filling of empty roles has both been frozen for most teams. This means that existing colleagues are having to take up the load which is causing more people to want to leave. There's also heavy restrictions on progressions which means that external companies are taking our good colleagues easily. The new head office lacks soul. North Park was much better and it's a shame we didn't upgrade it. Starbucks run the coffee shop when we used to have a small, high quality independent coffee shop in the office. Sage used to be the champion of small businesses! We used to be flexible on working compressed hours and a number of colleagues went onto this arrangement. Newer colleagues aren't being allowed to do compressed hours and this is just causing resentment.

Pros: I really had a good colleagues in the team I was in. I really enjoyed working with them and they are great people. I also enjoyed days such as Sage Foundation. Sage also has strong financial results.
Cons:
The management was not great because they cared about results and not their employees. Highly stressful role with no reward such as career progression. Particularly, crazy goals set by managers that were unattainable because I had my own work to do that I was hired for as well as goals not related to my job in order to justify my promotion. Even when these goals I believed I met after high stress, they were argued by my manager I did not meet them. I moved on from the company to be at the level I knew I was at and I've not been happier. 
I didn't enjoy working here, it was full of stress and a toxic environment by managers and higher ups. I didn't feel the company kept to their own culture and values and I felt it was more a façade. I didn't have time for training too. I heard from different teams being worried of terminations because of their skills being on the more outdated side which they used to develop their product whilst their same product was being re-made in the new tech stack with a new team instead of retraining the old team. I found management to be very backstab.

Review Title: Amazing if you're in the flagship products, lost at sea otherwise
Pros: - Excellent benefits coverage (from what I've heard, always above competitors) - Finally a clearer view of invested products and the strategy of "selling Sage" to customers for the future - Invested product areas getting significant support which is a big change from its history* - Interesting transformations into AI/ML and other technology trends
Cons: - Enforced "Return to office" agreements, that are also reviewed with your EOY performance/Objectives - *Highly dependent on product area as to business investment and support. There are 3 flagship products across Sage from my view, if you're not part of these products or integrating into these, there is little or no investment interest - Large focus on Newcastle HQ and London still, leaving other offices in dark corners (but its getting better..) - Not really sure how Sage will be the "market leader" of the technology trends but they have ambition for it - Still seeing silo'd product development of technology platforms eg. AI/ML with no Sage product buy-ins or roadmap integrations? - Management tends to keep close to reliable Sage people who fit the model and won't disrupt past a point

Pros:
Great benefits
Remote work
Most leadership means well
Cons: Typically only hire account executive from outside companies hard to switch verticals, changes take forever, comp plan is not great unless you exceed quota consistently. Not set up to meet quota without being overworked.

Pros:
I’ve loved working at Sage since I first started. I’ve felt so welcomed and supported. From the onboarding mentor ,Sarah, to my manager ,Jeff, I have felt guided and helped.  

Being from a background which did not have anything to do without accountancy,  I was scared of being thrown in the deep end within the sales roll. My assumptions were proven false with the 121 help and onboarding process provided by the company.

Due to the unwavering support I’ve become confident on all the products provided here at Sage and also gained a significant amount of knowledge on Accountancy practises. I truly feel as though my career in sales would not have been able to flourish without this wonderful opportunity. 

I’d encourage everyone to consider working at Sage. The positivity of the company and the support of everyone within it goes unmatched.
Cons: I dont have anything negative to say.

Review Title: A once-great place to work ruined by leadership and old-school thinking
Pros:
- Hybrid work (used to be more flexible with compressed hours, remote work etc but they've done a 180 on this - disappointing given so many were hired on a remote basis)
- Great colleagues
- Interesting work at times
- Commitment to volunteering/ESG nice to see
Cons:
- Expected to commute to office twice-three times a week even if it means 2+ hours commuting each way - tired of hearing about how this is in the name of 'collaboration and culture' when the office is too full to be with your own team, parking is a total nightmare when you do go in, and we all know the real reason is the lease on the buildings Sage has stubbornly committed to. Everyone collaborated just fine during lockdown and ignoring the statistics around the benefits of remote work (Steve Hare has done so multiple times) is tone-deaf and comes across as an old-school mentality digging its heels in. 
- Round after round of redundancies - how can we feel happy at work when we might be next on the chopping block? Inexplicable rounds of redundancies even when company is enjoying significant profit. Colleagues with 10 years of dedication and working out of hours kicked out without a second thought. Feels greedy.
- Losing loads of amazing talent due to various things, including: inflexibility around remote work, tone-deaf C-suite, a lack of clear vision (company seems to be trying to be everything to everyone with too many activations across too many regions and products at once).
- Lack of empathetic leadership and next to no training opportunities available to employees including new managers - Sage Learning does not cut the mustard I'm afraid.
- HR are not there to help; they're there to parrot what C-suite say/want. 
- Mental health not a priority, any pleas for support or empathy on this front go ignored or denied with a coldness that is shocking in this day and age. This goes for senior management and HR.

Pros: Some of the most talented people I've ever worked with!
Cons: The opportunities to progress and remote working policies aren't great.

Pros: Upper Management are mostly clueless and have no real direction. The rest of us just have to pick up the pieces. Colleagues are really good to work with, and the work/technology can be interesting. If you can showcase your skill then advancement can be really easy, but it all depends on the quality of your manager.
Cons: Remote work was sold to us as necessary for the business with no proper justification. We're an international company, a lot of the people we communicate with are remote as we aren't at the same office. We sit there like a call centre, headsets and webcams on, not doing any real work because of the distractions in the office. Sage don't care about the travel/childcare costs incurred to us, it's not their problem. There's only two justifications I can see for moving to hybrid work, when the directors visit the office (rarely) they like it to be full so that they can film it every so often, and that they've had pressure from the canteen to get more customers. Upper management also act like cowards, changing things like hybrid working through internal twitter-like posts, instead of discussing it with us properly. This kind of behaviour has given many workers a negative outlook of Sage. Sage don't care about you, they like to shout about being human-focused but they're really not.

Pros: It was a consistent paycheck
Cons: Management when I worked here was completely disconnected from reality

Pros: Great atmosphere. Everyone is generally very lovely, talented, and eager to help each other out.
Cons: Experience can be dependent on manager. Over dependence on at times cryptic procedure versus solving issues in a timely manner, though this is improving. The only real con is a recent slide back on flexible work policy. There has been a mandated return to the office two days a week. This makes sense for some functions, but not others. My team for example is spread across multiple continents, as are the teams we work with on a daily basis. I am commuting to the office to join the same Teams calls I did at home. The reason given was that teams that came into the office were more productive than others, citing studies conducted. No details of these studies were provided. It was also referred to as a “Team Agreement” but there was no consultation with any team I am aware of and everyone I know was surprised by this. Explanation was very patronising and no consideration given to personal circumstances. Morale amongst team mates is at an all time low and it would not surprise me if some leave in the near future specifically because of the mandated return to office. Very little in the way of facilities in the office, or events, to make up for this.

Pros: Amazing firm to work for
Cons: They go over board with caring for us

Review Title: decent but not great IT company in Silicon valley
Pros:
flexible working location
great co-workers and leaders
warm company culture
Cons:
pay is not promising
benefits are average

Pros: - Intensive days for summer (july / august) - Intensive fridays - Bonus (although it is not clear at all)
Cons: - You can't grow up in the company. No new projects or if they create new projects, old manager from other projects are move into. - You have a lot of problems to raise your salary. No opportunities and they don't promote you, although you are doing your best and improving continuosly the product. - A lot of meetings saying "nothing", elderly people saying "we are working on it!, we are following our goal". But at the end, you don't see the results in your bonus or salary - 2 days per week at the office without option to change it. They only want to see people in the office, but they don't think about your situation. - You can't decide nothing without your "manager" approval. When your manager thinks that the company is their, you have a big problem to fight for your or your team. You receive only empty words, it means, they promise you they are doing all in their hands, but it is not true. - We are working with OKR, but the objectives are not related with your work or you can't do anything to achieve it. Only you waste your time in the LEAD meetings. They are useless, they are not reflected in your salary, bonus...

Review Title: Great company, opportunity to build foundations
Pros:
•Very friendly and welcoming culture
•Aspirational desires across whole company
•Motivated and engaged individuals at every level
•Great packages compared against the market, especially in the US - everyone starts with 21 days PTO with an additional 9 days for public holidays, year on year PTO increases, a week off for volunteering, fully paid parental leave for both parents, etc
•Leaders are passionate about doing the right thing for their colleagues and their areas of business
•Have seen every issue raised to HR taken very seriously, with outcomes consistently made that align to company's values
Cons:
•Sage has little to no change management skills. Every week there is an uncommunicated change that has been rolled out by teams that rarely understand the issues, the requirements, and avoid working with stakeholders to navigate
•Divide between UK based HQ and the rest of the world is huge. Central group team seem to tell rather than communicate, they rarely seek to improve foundational issues that are simple to fix - including issues that create legal risk
•Friendly culture and leaders who are passionate about their own areas create a challenge with effective communication. Company struggles to ask for or action on feedback that isn't spun in an overly positive manner, including when leadership operates with their own intentions in mind that may conflict with Sage's values
•Many leaders lack maturity resulting in silos and micro cultures. These can include keeping undesirable behaviors hidden from HR until they become a larger issue
•Some leaders have brilliant minds but do not always display our values, the company does not invest in leadership development that tackles these issues, prefer instead to focus on high level hot topics

Pros:
Great company culture and benefits
Career Path
Company communication is transparent 
enabling managers to communicate with their direct reports 
Salary Benchmarking done right
Cons: Retrenchments are ongoing every year and creates a lot of uncertainty

Pros: Good team & lots of support
Cons: Received better salary with competitor

Review Title: Pointless going above and beyond because you won’t be recognised for it
Pros: Great benefits and bonus scheme, WHEN it’s done properly. I also enjoy the office although it can feel lonely at times when you don’t have a big team in Newcastle and people outside of your team aren’t really including you. Another pro is that the culture in terms of inclusivity is good, Sage tries to show a genuine want in terms of doing the right thing for people of any and all backgrounds which I appreciate.
Cons: No point going above and beyond when you’ll only end up with a Working Well anyway. Me and many, many others will not be trying as hard next year and will focus on our role and the core responsibilities only. Additionally and to reiterate what another reviewer said, there is also a lot of favouritism and never enough growth opportunities. It’s a hard place to get new experience that you’re actually interested in, despite promises made by managers. Unfortunately a lot of it is all talk…

Pros: Salary, bonus, free breakfast paid voluntary days
Cons: Constantly on your back to sell sell sell even though you’re employed as technical support. So many targets. Threatened with performance plans all the time. Even when you perform 10 out of 12 months if you miss 2 in a row or 2 in 3 you’re on a plan. All they care about is how many customers you get to buy SEB. Trap you with a good salary sell you a pipe dream give you a nightmare

Pros: People are kind and deadlines are not a hustle.
Cons: Pretty hard to get promoted or advance.

Pros: The pay and benefits were decent and the people were kind and helpful.
Cons: The job felt lonely and isolating to me. It was a requirement that we work in-office multiple days a week, despite 95% of my team being in other locations. But all virtual meetings for my team were completely camera-off, so I never even saw the vast majority of my teammates. I also found the new hire training to be unengaging and tedious. For 4 weeks, my training consisted entirely of watching videos for a few hours a day. Other than these videos, I had basically nothing to do. A little downtime is great, but having 20+ hours of downtime a week was boring and felt like a waste of time and money (due to the cost of commuting to the office just to watch videos)

Review Title: Always scared of being made redundant
Pros: Sage is a great place with good salary and benefits. And your coworkers are great.
Cons: You are always scared of being let go or made redundant. Sage is beating its financial goals year on year but they are constantly making employees redundant to make results look better.

Pros: People are friendly and passionate about their jobs. The "work away" scheme is fantastic (10 weeks per year). Competitive salaries. Inspiring CEO. Great ambitions to become an even better company in the future.
Cons: It feels like the experience of working at Sage can be very different from one team to the other. Some decision-making processes can be long. The rythme can be quite intense, with tight deadlines, as a consequence some colleagues struggle to prioritise learning and trying new things.

Pros: I have spent a few days past 2 years at Sage, and one of the benefits of working here is that people come first , you own the dynamic how you want to work , removing barrier to thrive and looking for training and growth opportunities, for you as a person and as an employee.
Cons: As a large company, it’s normal to get lost in the mix, so you have to sort information that you need.

Pros: Sage really is one of the best organisations to work for - great culture, spirit of collaboration and - dare I say - a place where you actually feel excited about what you're doing.
Cons: Like many businesses, change is everywhere, and Sage is no different. Be prepared to re-evaluate your role and career journey each year, because the old way of developing your career is long gone.

Review Title: Broadly positive but could do better
Pros: There is a fantastic culture at Sage, everyone makes you feel welcome and part of the ream. The people are friendly, they really care about the environment, as well as diversity and inclusion, they mean what they say, I am a member of several minority groups and I really feel like I belong.
Cons: There is a lot of communication from senior leadership, but it says nothing apart from how well we are doing, meaningful content is almost non existent. Career progression is limited and there is a top secret bonus formula that will never be met, no matter how hard everybody works and how well the company is doing.

Review Title: CEO is a solid thoughtful leader, we're strengthening the product lines
Pros: Sage has 11K+ employees globally, grew by acquisition. In the last five years we have sorted out some issues with older acquisitions, sold strong groups that didn't fit with our mission, and acquired new firms that are best of brand. Now we can focus on our small and medium sized business customers - "knocking down barriers so people can thrive." These customers are a creative resilient group, and our products handle routine tasks so they can focus on doing what they love. We have a few complex products with implementation done by special teams or partners. Our CEO Steve Hare and team have brought us down to earth while raising our goals higher. Benefits are good without being over the top, work-life balance better than average, 5 paid days/year to spend on community service. Sage often promotes from within. As we're global, we welcome multilingual applicants. Some of our public facing animations are by Magoz (magoz.com). And so on.
Cons: (1) Sage North America has "colleague support networks" for employees who are [identify as] Black, Asian, Hispanic, LGBTQIA+, "future business leaders," and more. But outside of the CSNs we need to do more than track diversity numbers. (2) Six of our products have confusingly similar names. Sage 50 Canada and Sage 50 United States. Sage 100 ERP and Sage 100 Contractor. Sage 300 ERP and Sage 300 Construction and Real Estate. We acquired these awhile back and re-branded them confusingly. The rest of the product names are fine.

Pros: Stability, Job security, Salary, Helping customers
Cons:
This company is toxic.

No direction, driving the company into the ground. 

Senior management suffer from god syndrome, they actually think they’re some kind of royalty. 

You could get rid of 75% of the staff and the company would run fine, most do absolutely nothing all day.

Pros: Office 3 days a week
Cons: Commission structure can change if your doing to well

Pros:
Work life balanace
Benefits
remote work options
Team
Cons:
Advancement opportunities within roles
must accrue PTO to use it resulting in not getting the time off when you need it.
Constant changes of process

Review Title: Review of Software engineer position at Sage
Pros: Stable work, acceptable pace of work
Cons: Low salary compared to the competition

Review Title: NOT A COMPANY TO BE TRUSTED
Pros: Not a company to be trusted. There are no pros.
Cons: A very toxic working environment. The staff turnover is extremely high. The systems and processes are very bad. The management are rude, hostile, unprofessional with no training, no ethics and no morals. They are on the wrong side of the law and HR are aware of the behaviour and encourage it. There is no emotional intelligence and there is open discrimination on a daily basis. If you want to keep your mental health, do not work here. This is an employer which will lie and do not abide by the law. They will hack your personal devices and monitor your private phone calls. They will also leak your data to other employees, they have even leaked customer's information without any remorse. Open homophobia, racism and sexism is displayed daily. There needs to be new leadership and HR brought into the organisation or I do not believe this company will stand the test of time. The continuous grievances and unethical practices will bring this company down. You are losing good talent and years of experience due to HR not doing their roles properly and covering up illegal and unethical behaviour. NOT A NICE PLACE TO WORK. DO NOT APPLY HERE! The worst company to work for and they will leave you scarred for life. Be less worried about share prices and more worried about treating your staff right and being better human beings. STOP forcing your staff to write fake positive reviews to make yourself look better. Change your behaviour and DO THE RIGHT THING.

Pros: OK company, Not great. Not bad.
Cons: Company average. Good and bad.

Pros: Did have a long period of being a great company to work at - lots of opportunities to connect as colleagues, supportive of work-life balance, introduced work abroad schemes and flexible working allowing employees to request a wide range of working patterns to meet individual needs, very supportive during the pandemic.
Cons: The last year has felt very different. Flexible working requests have been cancelled, so now it's unfair with some colleagues on compressed/part-time hours to suit their home life, and others being rejected compressed hours with less consideration of individual needs. Hybrid working has meant colleagues are mandated to come into the office on a set day/s each week, again with no consideration of how individuals and teams were working pre-pandemic and impact that travel has on home life, costs and environment. Sage are very proud of their environmental impact, but don't factor in all the emissions they are producing by forcing colleagues to come in as they don't count these as company emissions. Been very tight on spend for over a year now, meaning we don't have budget for in person kick offs/ team building events, has a knock on impact on morale. New leadership in this department specifically has brought a very different vibe that seems much less people focused.

Pros:
Compensation and benefits are at par, if not better than the market
A competitive environment that brings out the best in one
Top-of-the-line products and services in the HRMS segment
A good place for fresh graduates
Cons: Rapid professional vertical growth is restricted since Sage follows a leaner approach

Pros: Ok salsary. Bit not Greta ahd to Get more monte when y9ou ned it
Cons: Bad leadership.  Not Greta for develomlnet

Review Title: A good company to work for if you have no ambition in sales!
Pros:
- You will have a good work/life balance and will not be required to work overtime. The environment is 'okay' and is not extremely stressful and high pressure like how some sales roles are.
- Most people within the company are friendly and are easy to talk to and work with.
- Sage are a well recognised company.
Cons:
- Both the base salary and the commission is well below industry average. You will earn at least 20-25% working a similar role at a competitor of Sage.
- Career progression and promotions are non existent. The only promotion that is possible as an SDR is to become an Account Executive however the chance of this happening is next to none! When there is a vacancy as an Account Executive they do not even make the SDR's aware and the job is posted online and they will look to hire externally.
- Some of the senior managers at Sage Intacct are extremely rude. The Head of Sales / Account Executive Manager for Sage Intacct does not know any names of any SDR's across the business and will actively try and avoid us around the office. There has been times where he has ignored a 'good morning' and has actively avoided any form of interaction. This is extremely demotivating when this is the person we all try to impress and build a relationship with.
- The SDR's are treated as the bottom of the barrel within the business and are not cared about.
- The company culture and morale of the team had drastically decreased over the years. 
- There is never any events or any form of team building activities.
- Targets and KPI's constantly increase and become less attainable. It feels the senior management do not want us to earn commission.
- I could not fault my direct line manager at Sage as they always had a good relationship with the team and were willing to listen to our concerns. However, I feel that they do not have any power or any influence in the senior leadership teams decisions. 
- The staff turnover in the business is appalling. Very few SDR's would stay at the business for over 18 months and this doesn't seem to be any concern for the Senior Managers.

Pros:
Culture
Growth
career
Training 
Support
Cons:
Salary
WFO 
Environment
upkeep
Speed

Review Title: Trying to be too much to too many
Pros: Great co-workers and a positive happy vibe from others. Salespeople are hardworking and dedicated and go the extra mile for customers.
Cons: Life work balance is not great with major demands on your time and little recognition for your work. Executive leadership has good morals but line managers can be bad and don't reflect the human aspect that the company touts. Poor review process and hard to get ahead.

Pros: Sage is a big company, roughly 12K employees, but they make you feel like you are a part of a family. There are many ways to accelerate at Sage as it is not a stagnant company - it's always moving and thinking ahead.
Cons: They have don't have as many office locations for the size of the company, only regional office hubs. Some may not think that's a con as that allows for many to be remote workers.

Review Title: Loving Sage but its not for everyone
Pros: Fast paced successful business environment which is exciting and hones adaptability, negotiation and influencing skills. Opportunities and support for personal growth and development Great benefits and commitment to the community and a chance to be a shareholder in Sage through Save and Share schemes Really friendly colleagues and cooperative co-workers Enough flexibility to manage work life balance with hybrid working in place Good value statements and measurement against these
Cons: Frenetic in nature and change is constant. Senior management doesn't help with prioritisation and focus - there is a constant drive for more and faster and the bonus scheme underpins the drive for the delivery of everything now. High level strategy clear, annual OKRSs clear but lacking the detail and communication of the in between goals - hence the constant change

Review Title: Little to no career growth opportunities.
Pros: Great people to work with, helpful, supporting, fun.
Cons:
No career progression framework in place.

Pros: Sage gave be some amazing opportunities. I was remote, I was an employee of a company they acquired. They treated me very well, promoted me and paid me well. The benefits were excellent. And they do listen when you have concerns.
Cons: Transparency was sometimes lacking. Also, I was brought on to design a new Customer Success journey and they liked my ideas. But, getting them from the drawing board to actual fruition was a slow and tedious business. When I was promoted to a Manager, there was no training at all and I didn't know the systems. My fellow Managers were wonderfully helpful, but it still would have been great to have some sort of training. Also, they acquired my company and we pretty much sat for a year collecting paychecks and doing nothing. Then, when they did get involved, the company wasn't really given a budget or a goal. It was frustrating as I had poured a lot of myself into that company.

Review Title: Couldn't recommend Sage enough as a workplace
Pros: -Lack of Hierarchy (managers always willing to provide support and assistance) -Great office with great facilities -Real competitive pay -Bonus scheme -Professional but also friendly atmosphere -Shares scheme -Sage foundation -Employee Care -Magic moments -Volunteering opportunities -Flexible working hours

Pros:
- Collaboration among colleagues 
- Intensive summer schedule 
- Free access to the LinkedIn Learning platform 
- Days of volunteering
Cons:
- there is no professional career model; therefore, promotions are non-existent 
- salaries are practically frozen 
- there isn't always a good rapport among colleagues on the same project but from different teams or countries 
- most managers hold their positions based on the number of years they've been with the company rather than being trained or qualified for the role 
- there are no budgets for training or any kind of development. 
- overtime is not common, but even if you work extra hours, it's not possible to record them because we are forced to report them the same way 
- after years of remote work, we are required to return to the office two days a week to encourage face-to-face interactions. However, there hasn't been a single face-to-face meeting since we returned, not even the annual evaluation 
- most of the OKRs (Objectives and Key Results) and personal goals are related to non-personal matters, and the outcomes often do not depend on you, sometimes even related to projects you are not a part of.

Review Title: 11 year old start up under extreme pressure to become profitable
Pros:
Hybrid work setup
Management considers the feedback from employees
People are generally nice and friendly
Cons:
Unrealistic targets are cascaded top down with limited resources like headcount, product support, and budget which sets up the entire organization for failure. 

Senior leadership has lost the confidence of the employees with yearly company targets being missed. 

Middle management and their teams are under extreme pressure and held responsible for unrealistic targets. While Senior leadership lacks accountability.
 
Monthly town halls are plagued with Q&A's about possible layoffs, company outlook, and slow product innovation.

Internal employee engagement survey concerns revolve around growth opportunities, senior management credibility, slow product improvements, salary, and compensation competitiveness.

Can observe a change in culture with the pressure to become profitable. It's becoming less people-oriented compared to when it started. Glassdoor reviews were previously 90% plus.

Review Title: Low confidence, high turn over, overworked, poor compensation
Pros:
- Hybrid working model but tightening on work from office 
- Friendly and helpful colleagues 
- No dress code
Cons:
The company's initial emphasis on a people-first culture and a strong mission orientation underwent a significant shift due to the intense pressure to achieve profitability, resulting in employees feeling reduced to mere numbers. The layoffs in 2022 left existing staff burdened with increased responsibilities, particularly impacting those tirelessly working on the ground, while management remained seemingly unaffected.

A lack of cohesion among numerous managers has led to inconsistent strategies and a palpable absence of clear direction. Frequent restructuring and a tendency to change strategies without warning create an environment where execution becomes challenging. Townhall meetings have become dominated by concerns about potential layoffs and inadequate compensations, but management became annoyed and chose to discontinue addressing these questions, further eroding employee confidence.

The organization faces a continuous exodus of talent, with monthly resignations reflecting an inability to competitively retain skilled professionals. There's a significant disconnect between management and ground-level operations, they are not even aware of our KPIs. Middle management contributes to a toxic work environment by fostering office drama, often rewarding those adept at playing internal politics rather than delivering value-added work to drive profitability goals.

Product innovation is painfully slow, and user-oriented teams, like the seller experience team, lack effective communication with platform sellers. The recent launch of integrated delivery is celebrated as groundbreaking, yet it raises concerns about the company's ability to catch up with competitors after 12 years in the industry. Recent product launches were clearly designed to squeeze their sellers dry to forcefully drive up revenue. 

Overall, there is an extreme lack of confidence in the company's ability to achieve profitability. While a focused, action-oriented approach may improve the situation, ongoing brain drain is further diminishing the chances of success. Good luck achieving profitability and cashing out.

Pros: Flexible working hours and work from home culture

Review Title: Wonderful people but poor directional guidelines and developmental mentoring
Pros:
I love how the senior management is as transparent as they can be about the Company's status and performance. 
People are very welcoming, and the management team are very approachable regardless of a person's job level.

Nice flexible benefits as well as yearly reimbursable wellness allowance for both full-time and agency employees. It's the employee's choice on whether they will use this allowance for their work from home setup or gym or other hobbies.
Cons:
The high level direction is clear, however the lower level strategies on how to get there is like looking at muddy water. You could be focusing on a certain KPI for half the year only to be informed that there will be changes and you need to work on something else, which is understandable. however, it would be good to at least get ground level opinion as well on how feasible a certain idea is.

Unclear professional growth/development plans, your effort may be less due to a well planned task list or your personal efficiency but you won't be as noticeable as personnel working overtime, which slowly transitions Carousell into a more traditional type of corporation contrary to their revolutionized google-style beginning.
Without a clear career path, people tend to look elsewhere for growth.

Slow tech development/improvement. Sales and marketing related app/tech drive will have less impact if customers can't have their basic needs such as a decent search function or fraud prevention features or even a more precise filter functionality.

This is just a personal opinion, but Carousell needs more visibility in Markets it caters to and craft appropriate marketing strategies that is actually applicable to the market. The marketing team, at least in the Philippines, tends to go towards a more upscale approach in terms of endorsers, but the second hand market isn't predominantly made of people who can buy things that are brand new.

Review Title: An almost incredible experience and dream job
Pros: To clarify first, yes I was affected by the layoff, and I should had probably given my feedback whilst in the company but this is for jobseekers. Competitive payout for sales and they do constant review on this which is fantastic. Flexible dress code, Flexible hours( of course with you meeting KPI), Good benefits (AL, food voucher & transport allowance) and i truly believe the Founders are nice, trusting(maybe too much) and sincere even though I see some negative reviews on them here. Truthfully, the company was INCREDIBLE for any hungry sales associate when I first joined, they allowed us to acquire merchants from broad categories while recognising renewal sales from merchants we close, everyday I was excited to wake up looking forward to work ( how many can really say that in their job) to build carousell whilst helping merchants build their business growth with carousell and of course growing my paycheque! It was a dream job! With this system it was almost like i was running my own business and i look forward to close new merchants and renewing them showing them growth on their business. I wanted to stay here till retirement.
Cons: Just too much went wrong so instead of typing them all out, i advise job seekers must be Extremely adaptable and okay with unfair KPI distribution and non thoroughly thought out major implementations… otherwise take a chance and cross your fingers for the higher end treatment due to negligence in target allocation and expectation. Still a 4 star cause i know founders are trying their best, just unfortunate they hired the wrong management. I truly feel sad.

Review Title: Really great company to work for
Pros:
This is the best company I have ever worked for. I joined the company around 2.5 year ago. 
I have a really great work-life balance while working here. I got married after a few months joining Carousell and I got a baby girl about a year ago. I was able to spent a lot of time with my family and my working hours has been very flexible. I would say I spent quite a lot of time during the day taking care and playing with my daughter and I work mostly when she is sleeping.
Really good managers. I think I was quite lucky to have a chance to work with very good managers. They gave me advices and opportunities to advance within the company. We have 1 on 1 regularly and generally we discuss about what I want to archive in my career and how to get there.
Excellent team and really smart people. Most people that I worked with at Carousell are very humble and open-mined, making it very easy for the team to discuss conflicting ideas and come up with good solutions.
The Carousell business is doing very well as well.
Cons:
- No dental benefit
- The interviewing process can be quite long

Pros:
Colleagues are generally nice 
Better WLB than shopee and grab
Cons:
Not really a con but here there’s no AWS or PB so how serious people take performance appraisals is sorely based on how much they still care to improve. 
Tech wise, they use GCP instead of AWS (like i said there’s no AWS :p) so it might take sometime to get used to for the folks in the AWS camp. 

There’s a lot of deprecated and poorly documented/hard to understand code because there’s no hard requirements on code standards. It makes people whom these code are handed over to miserable because they’re afraid to break things if they refactor. In general, very little best practices can been seen here, eg people commit large PRs expecting colleagues to review instead of doing a stacked PR, no formatting checks in auto test etc. It’s hard to push for a change in tech culture because the seniors are resistant. Then again, I guess all these are understandable because it’s not a tech company.

Review Title: Please consider these points before joining
Pros:
1. Most of the employees here came from worse working environments e.g. Media agencies, toxic local SMEs, Honestbee and hence believe that this grass is a lot greener. If you’ve been through terrible work environments, yes carousell will be (slightly) better. Is it the best place to work in Singapore? Definitely not. 

2. There is autonomy to make decisions that have immediate outcomes and visibility, and on some occasions the founders will be verbally grateful to you for them.

3. Most people on the ground here are really trying their best to do what they love and work hard. And yes, if you are looking to join the marketplace experience team, or the tech team - you are most likely to enjoy your experience there. Carousell understands that tech is competitive and will do their best to treat tech hires right, not so much for the other departments. 

4. In some departments, there’s a good culture of fun and team bonding. Carousell is intentional about spending time together and bonding, and there will be budget for this too.
Cons:
1. The Carousell group acquired 4 companies over the years - OLX (Philippines), Mudah (Malaysia), Chotot (Vietnam) and OneKyat (Myanmar). There is a lot of mess and neglect in this process and the founders are struggling to understand how to manage them, most people here complain of being overworked, underpaid and under-supported way more than their Carousell counterparts.

2. Management - the Glassdoor reviews that you read here are true. Even though most of management came from affluent and long standing histories of experience, most of them just want to oppress their reports. They know nothing and want to be treated like royalty - you will be asked to book meeting rooms for them, teach them how to record on zoom/order food on foodpanda, buy things for them and much more. (To be fair, most of the things experienced are in the People team - high turnover rate a clue?) You will be shocked at how they can say words with no accountability and tact, despite their “experience”. The founders are much younger than most and clearly struggle to manage them - all these incidents mentioned were bought up to the founders and no action taken, resulting in employees resigning because they gave up hope. 

3. As much as they seem to look corporate and SME-like, most people here will admit that it’s still very much like a start up. Little to no processes, constant change in systems and poor communication downstream. 

4. There is a deep systemic resentment towards salary. The context is as a startup, most employees who have been there for years received start up pay. Only up till a year ago, the management decided to pay competitively to new hires and that’s when the bitterness and comparison arose. Imagine only getting half or less of the salary of your counterpart and doing the exact same work - as much as this is common, Carousell is not an MNC and it doesn’t come with any MNC benefits. 

5. Burnout culture: is real here. As much as the people experience team tries to sell “work life balance” and “Wellness Wednesdays”, they don’t actually live it out themselves. You will see the team reply to slack or send emails at 12am-1am, people are angry and uncooperative and being told they lack resilience when they are being pushed to breaking point at work. There is deep mistrust for managers as most of them are deemed inexperienced or incompetent. The people team try to mitigate but everyone can tell that they are struggling with their own manager, too. When asked, most of them are on the lookout for better opportunities and said that they will leave in a heartbeat if the opportunity presents itself.

Pros: Friendly people and nice onboarding package
Cons: Nothing, really just joined so have no idea what gonna happens next

Review Title: Manager have no clue on how to run a company.

Since management are bunch or uncle and aunty, their idea of making money is to increase price of their subscription and ads for those verticals that are doing well.

Toxic Culture
- lots of politics in the company always regarding who the management likes and dislikes. For a company that is not profitable to have too many managers within a department. A lot of the associates they hire are ex-colleagues of the manages, and managers will prioritise these colleagues in terms of job assignment and promotion. 

Incompetent staff
- a lot of their managers are too incompetent. Asked their project manager a question and took him 2 weeks to answer me. He will organise a Q&A session with us, but its all questions since he cant answer us and can only note down those questions we asked and nvr answer us.

Review Title: Not a great place to work
Pros: They have flexible hours to work and inter-team mobility is available after a while. Talented teammates.
Cons:
- Culture: They talk pretty highly of their core values, but once it trickles down to following them, it's no where close. 

- Management: What they say is always right and they favor their own references and ex-colleagues when it comes down "trust". Personally, they don't treat HR folks as a business too so, HR opinion is the last opinion or better still "no opinion required" category. Highly bureaucratic/ political and very traditional in their approach and highly judgemental as leaders. 

- Attrition: a pretty high double figure attrition and a lot of people have left in HR /Tech/ product teams, clearly because they felt less heard or the leaders didn't work too hard to retain talent. Try avoiding 

- Interview process: is long, very long, very very long. They want to compete with FAANG company process but pay you peanuts in salary. They are always depending over budgets.

People team and TA team have maximum attrition this year, they say "i hear you" and ask you to move on. very insensitive even though they pretend to sound concerned and neglect you after sharing concerns.

Overall as an organisation, the co-founders pop up during townhalls to talk about company performance but very less invested in people and they go quiet on decisions for people. They may hear you out but they don't care to action out probably max assign your managers to deal with your issues. In that matter, none of the management really cares to hear about your concerns, it's too fake to be honest. So unless, you are a reference or you know some leaders well - you are bound to grow slowly in this space, highly biased in decisions and very likely to hear you out but not provide any solution or leave it to the managers to take biased decisions.

P.s. Carousell is more responsive on glassdoor than actually solving problems internally.

Review Title: Not For Everyone (But Excellent For Some)
Pros: - Lots of learning and growth. Plenty of opportunities if you seize them (and earn people's trust along the way) - Fast paced and dynamic culture. Pivot quickly, and implement new things at lightning speed. - Teams of highly talented people. People are highly intelligent and are comfortable with complexity. - Great leadership (esp CEO)
Cons: - Some tumult in business outlook, esp with BNPL closure of one market and multiple (and quickly successive) departures of key figures in that business - Lack of work-life balance. Tight deadlines, quick turnarounds, and intense stress to excel. Might not be for everyone's personality and/or current phase of life right now - Lack of diversity in strengths, personalities, and backgrounds. Results in certain traits being self-selecting over time, which can breed very rigid (possibly elitist) thinking over time. - Almost no formal DEI initiatives, and what is being done is mostly for B2C marketing campaigns (e.g. international women's day). Expect very little support as it's not seen as a company priority at all (literally the last thing on the list) - Some toxic personalities in middle management

Review Title: Think Twice: A Cautionary Review for Prospective Employees
Pros: Hybrid working arrangement is the only one I can think of.
Cons:
Working at ShopBack is challenging, and unfortunately not in the positive sense. The company suffers from a significant lack of planning, often setting arbitrary deadlines that seem disconnected from project realities. This approach breeds a chaotic work environment where overtime is not just common but explicitly encouraged. The expectation to work nights, weekends, and even holidays is glorified, with the CTO publicly praising such unsustainable practices.

While compensation is average, the expectation to deliver high-quality work under these conditions is unreasonable. Work-life balance is virtually non-existent, as personal time is frequently encroached upon by work demands.

There's a discernible culture that values compliance over competence, where 'yes men' are favored over those who genuinely contribute through hard work. This environment is compounded by a management style that fails to advocate for team members, often leaving them feeling unsupported and undervalued.

Pros: Depending on your role within the company, you can achieve a a happy medium in terms of work-life balance. Nonetheless, the salary offered is decent. Theres a good company culture going on at ShopBack with continuous development opportunities to grow your skills.
Cons: * While the company offers AL, Sick Leave, and company stocks to vest - the downside to some of the benefits include no company provided insurance plans. Furthermore, if you travel for your role or have to purchase misc. adhoc items, you have to front the cost upfront and wait to expense the items to be reimbursed.

Pros: Good learning environment and room for error given
Cons: Not much as an intern, just a good place to learn

Review Title: ShopBack is one of the best companies Ive worked with
Pros: 1. management shares their visions and progress towards common goals monthly via townhall, with great details, very candid. this helps everyone in the company (now we have 1000+ employees) to know and ask questions via slido 2. Bosses give a lot of freedom to employees to decide what they wanna do. it doesn't stop there, bosses are supportive in terms of giving guidance and will fight for the resources you need (of course you need to prove what you do is impactful) 3. Most people in the companies are quite willing to help each other. No question is dumb, and normally we can ask the same question again and again until we fully understand 4. People here work hard, peer pressure is healthy for most to constantly upskill themselves. a bit stressed short term, but fruitful long term 5. We also play hard. You heard of whole company annual retreat on a Yacht? or flying to Phuket, or have a whole Club (the ones with drinks and music)? ya thats ShopBack
Cons: 1. processes are still quite manual. means sometimes we need to OT to get things done, while in other more mature companies, it could have been automated 2.should have been more proactive in engaging employees what skills they wanna develop and provide trainings. currently we do have IDP, but many people dont use it

No micromanaging (at least within my team), and the bosses trusts in the team to get the work done.
Cons: Everything about the work in ShopBack is time-sensitive, so this means that work-life balance may be tough during peak periods. Culture is definitely getting more "corporate" as the company grows and there are more middle managers, which may or may not be a good thing as this means that there's more "layers" to go through to get things moving.

Pros: Get to work from home for most days.
Cons: The level of support provided to employees by management was lacking, with insufficient efforts made to nurture their growth and development. Commission structures were poorly planned, resulting in frequent changes that often had negative impacts on earnings. The management was known for engaging in gossip, creating an environment of mistrust and backstabbing among employees. Despite claiming to understand the challenges faced by employees in dealing with client objections, management failed to provide effective solutions. Employees were expected to maintain a high standard of work and often had to perform tasks outside of their designated roles, without any corresponding increase in salary. Standard Operating Procedures were constantly changing, resulting in frequent adjustments to administrative duties. Management seemed to believe that employees should be grateful for the opportunity to work at Shopback, a company they considered prestigious, and viewed departures as ingratitude on the part of employees who chose to leave.

Review Title: Not for everyone. If you are a foreigner, don't get lured to the compensation and simple / easy interviews.
Pros: * Fast paced work on latest technology. * Genuinely friendly and helpful co-workers (with few exceptions). * Flat hierarchy. * Opportunity / exposure to modern development and deployment practices and on the job training for relevant technologies. * Tech talks, quarterly engineering improvement sprints where everyone can contribute to an idea not directly related to business. * Diversity is great.
Cons: * Frequent change of direction from PM. * Churn in development due to new / ad-hoc requests vs priority bug fixes. * Some teams have very little process around testing and deployment, it's no wonder there will be patch fixes in Production * Lot of responsibility on team leads for stability of application. So, expect tough consequences when things fail. * Inclusion is sometimes missing and may have to struggle to fit in.

Furthermore, there isn't a proper progression structure for entry level BDs and management will dangle the carrot in front you to spur you to work towards a possibility of some kind of promotion and advancement which will never happen. Basically, you are just being utilized to bring in the numbers and will get disposed if you voice out any form of dissatisfaction or such. They will deem you as an employee who doesn't align with the company values and will lowkey manage you out for another replacement. Little to no employee welfare.

Review Title: Great place to learn and accelerate your career
Pros:
-Great culture, politicking is almost non-existent, people are genuinely friendly and care for your well-being

-1 year at ShopBack gives you 3 years worth of learning and experience at other companies; you will find that you've grown a lot and are ready to take on tougher challenges at a pace you didn't think likely before

-Career progression here is non-linear; if you do well enough, regardless of your age or years of experience, you will find yourself being promoted very quickly

-Retention rate is much higher compared to other tech companies, other than the new joiners, most of the people here have been around for 4-5 years (the company is only 7 years old)

-High-caliber colleagues; this is of course dependent on the team itself but most people I've interacted with are pretty smart. Says a lot about the company that for the good performers who do end up leaving, most of them end up in global tech giants like FAANG for example

-Stock value has multiplied several times in the past few years, which also explains the high retention rate and spurs people to work harder
Cons:
-Not for everyone because of how fast-paced the company is, everyone is expected to carry their own weight and then some, definitely not someplace you can chill and still expect to be an average performer

-Benefits are not great, insurance and allowances while decent are still below that of other comparable tech companies

I literally overheard the manager tell her family friend to bring their laptop over their house so they can train them and show them the ropes during the weekend. But for other team members when they ask the manager for help she gets frustrated or tells us she only has time to work on a certain client. Seems like management positions are given to people who are clearly not skilled enough mentally to be a leader. Negative work place environment. Contestant temper tantrums from management. Coworkers crowdsurfing your computer as they walk by your desk. Oh and during my first week working there the manager made a wild assumption that I was living paycheck to paycheck. Last VP was a racist and you could tell she could care less about the employees but more about the money being brought in. Which rightfully so but she did not have a poker face at all. Needless to say the only time you would truly enjoy working here is if nepotism favors you. I would not suggest someone who loves their life to work here as this place can make someone miserable.
