Cons: The pay is not competitive. The health insurance is very expensive. The "cost of living" raises are laughable considering inflation. Asking management for tools and resources is useless, and for a tech company the technology available for day-to-day operations is seriously lacking. HR's hiring process is a nightmare and hasn't improved the entire time I've worked at the company. The top execs are constantly getting catered lunches, which is pretty discouraging considering I can't afford to buy lunch every day on my salary. After COVID, some managers allowed their teams to work from home permanently, but other boomer managers insist we come to the office multiple days a week even though we work better from home.

Review Title: Laughable but too Stupid to Laugh
Pros: They see eye to eye with the Fuhrer on the final solution, for all of us. Swedes – And Californians too!
Cons: This company represents itself as a tech company in the background check industry. It really does the archaic paper finger printing done in the prison system, which is the sewer of a prison system. And this crowd is prisoner hungry. International prison system. God, what kind of sicko would do this kind of work. Swedes, Californians, and anybody who thinks prison camp work is a needed service and excellent way to benefit your customers. AKA No one matters but me people. Now that the pleasantries are over, let’s get down to the software business. There isn’t any. This is software customization of Java 1.0 maybe 2.0 I don’t know, and 95% of the code you cant get to and debugging is 10 times harder than normal because you can’t get to the code. And it’s almost all config files. Config file after config file after config file. And then the shmuck who “leads” the team doesn’t lead but he would pull me in to train new team mates on material I had not been told to take. Disorganized, archaic, 80’s scanners (literally), and a whole bunch of people who are fine with imprisoning people throughout the world as long as they get the money. Hitlers faithful.

Pros: Some very excellent co-workers. The product line helps catch the bad guys. I think the pay is fair.
Cons: In 25 years or service we have been sold many times. About to get sold again. Not insider info just google Advent International sell IDEMIA. Each sale the company degrades for employees. Benefits fall, pay increases get smaller, on average 1% every few years. The company just announced we will no longer earn PTO time. It is a "Unlimited PTO" that they tried to sugar coat it but any moron with a brain can see it is only being done to get PTO balances to zero by the end of the year for the sale as all that time on the books is a negative for the company. Advent is a company like Richard Gere's Pretty Woman movie depicted. Buy companies, pick them apart and sell them to make the most money. Advent does not give a damn about our products or the people. Take away EARNED vacation which is money in the bank, and substitute a program where managers can more easily disapprove time off requests. I am waiting to see when the company that is next in line buys us and stops unlimited time off and goes back to a earned vacation program. That way all exempt employees are at ZERO in the bank.

Review Title: IDEMIA is a great place to flourish
Pros:
Very collaborative company culture, set by CEO Pierre Barrial and the Group EVPs who lead each business unit. Clear focus on growth and transition to digital markets; at the same time understanding that we are playing a long game so you don't live or die by the monthly result or quarterly result. 

The team in Paris HQ is extremely supportive of the regional teams, and in fact work long hours supporting customer calls early in the morning and late in the evening in Europe, to accommodate global time zones.

Depending on one's role, there can be a lot of autonomy in how to get the results needed in personal job performance. People who performer are encouraged to flourish and grow.
Cons: The shared services (IT, Finance, HR, Legal) are staffed very lean. Most people in these functions are very willing to help, however, they are also very overloaded and often not enough bandwidth to respond timely. Things that could be done in a day or two often take a week or two.

Pros:
Coworkers are friendly. 
401k matches
PTO increases
Cons: What prompted me to write this review was a recent review by a VP that stated that working at Idemia is fantastic. This shows me the vast disconnection between the top and the bottom. Everyone on my team and MANY engineers that I speak to are always mentioning how overworked they are. Our CEO recently stated in a town hall that we are eagerly trying to fill open positions. However, the head of engineering recently told his department that all openings will be closed. In addition, my team was told this week that the open position on our team that we desperately need filled will be closed. So why is the CEO telling us something completely different ? Upper management is trying to cut costs all around so we are more attractive as a company but it’s at the cost of the lower level employees. Lower level employees, especially hourly employees, are underpaid. NO competitive salary whatsoever and we aren’t even eligible for company performance bonuses anymore. We work just as hard as anyone else! We are also encouraged to use all of our PTO by the end of the year but there is so much work to be done that taking a vacation seems impossible. Things need to change or the company will lose valuable employees.

Review Title: Worst place for software engineers to work in Nashville
Pros: Kind hardworking dedicated, yet misguided staff
Cons:
Started here as a developer in the Franklin office and quickly noticed a lack of leadership and hostility among teams. If you want a glacier placed job coding in a swath of tech debt, this may be the place for you. Take a look at the uenroll site, it hasn’t change in years. It was supposedly an overhaul from their previous dumpster fire site but looks like history has repeated itself. They had a whole team of “production ops” dedicated to keep the pile of junk running because the former engineering team failed to utilize best practices. A great place for yes-men to thrive; but challenge status quo and get a slack on the wrist.


 Management only cares about themselves and is not in alignment with with engineering, as evidenced by the high turnover. Teams act like independent islands not working in concert with each other.

Maybe they’ve update a few processes and got own board with a modern cloud provider but progress has been painstakingly slow

Review Title: Went from average to way below average
Pros: Good co-workers, some interesting projects, good work life balance. Many projects are just maintenance now so the work day can be very laid back. Some teams can be good if it's seen as critical. Non-US employees seem to be happier.
Cons: The middle managers are not very technical making it frustrating getting things done. The idea seems to be to keep the status quo going. Lots of cutbacks which everyone feels in their wallet. Many people have left with no replacements in sight. Changes are coming and it probably won't be good for the average employee.

Pros: Pay Duties Workers Environment Benefits
Cons: Management Timesheets Coworkers Communication Open Door Policy

Pros: Amazing products and technology that are changing the lives of all daily. Great engineering team, from the top down. It is obvious that the CTO is constantly working to make things better and communicate to his org. PTO accrual is good, but only when you have managed to stay on 2+ years. Great HQ location in Reston Town Center and you get perks at retailers/restaurants and free parking in garage. Company is trying to promote diversity and inclusion, while changing culture and instilling values with new CEO.
Cons: Poor leadership that is really cut-throat. Poor culture. Constantly walking on egg-shells. Poor paternity/paternity leave. Lack of vision and connectedness due to the many leadership changes and re-orgs. The company cannot keep good talent. Promotions are few and far between. Not very competitive when it comes to pay, unless you are a sr. manager or above. HR and Finance departments are a disaster, so onboarding and task items are always a challenge. Internal processes are awful, requiring lots of hand holding and constant checking in to see if things have progressed. Environment is very clique-y. Company culture is almost non-existent, they definitely do not live up to their values. Most the work force is male and white.

Review Title: Greatest Job I have ever had!
Pros: Strong support, caring management, great opportunity to help others and to keep our world safe. Lots of work, equal opportunity to grow.
Cons: Can’t think of a single thing to complain about. All my needs are met each and every week by all departments.

Pros: I enjoy the benefits. I also enjoy gaining knowledge and experience.
Cons: So far, there is no real disadvantage:)

Pros: Some of the people who worked there were wonderful.
Cons:
I worked as an auditor on the night shift, which means I counted over 20 boxes of 500 credit cards at a time using terrible counting machines that were extremely out of date. The warehouse is the most disorganized thing I've ever seen. They give you a number and you have to search through a huge room to find a big heavy pallet that sometimes falls apart when you push it, making sheets of cards fall on you. No one was able to help me because there is absolutely no system to keep track of locations. In addition, I encountered people on the night shift staff that were blatantly homophobic, transphobic, and racist, as well as one guy that I'm pretty sure was abusing his girlfriend that also worked on the night shift. Don't get me wrong, some of the people who worked there were really great people, but management does not care at all about helping with issues. I actually remember hearing that security called some black workers into the office because they thought they saw them making "gang signs" over the camera. Absolutely insane. I'm not black but just hearing about the things which they go through there made me sick. Also the pay isn't worth it.

It was also important to keep track of an audit sheet that listed where every card was at every time. But nobody filled it in correctly because it was poorly laid out and we weren't allowed to edit it. We did though. Everybody did. Because otherwise we'd have to search everywhere to find the person who messed up the sheet and often they weren't even on our shift! 

When there's nothing to do you have to go through the cards and pick out rejects only for the quality control head to put them right back in because the company does not care about the product they put out.

Also I've heard that this place used to be better until they got bought out by a French company and the entire thing went downhill immediately.

Review Title: Good place to be an intern
Pros: Good place to be an intern
Cons: Not much age and other diversity

Pros: Flexible time / Works with future technologies.
Cons: Salary below the market and does not have a career plan.

Pros:
Good benefits. Decent pay. Middle Management. Some talented people. 

Cylance AI/ML is a solid technology - but needs to be updated.

New CEO, John G, is a positive as John Chen did nothing to drive growth.

BB QNX technology for the auto industry is solid.
Cons:
BB has destroyed both the Cylance brand recognition and product innovation. After I came aboard I lost 50% of my clients as they wouldn't renew - they went to S1 or CrowdStrike. I was told that MGT would revive the Cylance brand and aggressively market our cybersecurity solutions - neither of these things happened. 

Channel partners have abandoned Cylance. The big resellers/partners consider Cylance a non-factor and they are not even part of the discussion. Senior Leadership has done nothing to address this. 

Employee morale is incredibly low. 

Senior Management was horrific under John Chen (old CEO). John still believed that the Blackberry brand is strong in the world - it may be in Canada but not elsewhere. When I asked random people they said either "I though BB was out of business" or "..you guys make cell phones...I really liked mine...." JC knows little to nothing about cybersecurity and constantly waffled in his decisions - he should have retired after saving the company from bankruptcy.

Review Title: A Sinking Ship In Desperation Mode
Pros: Some amazing coworkers that worked hard and wanted to succeed in spite of the continuous obstacles presented. Innovative and unique technology that was unfortunately squandered by poor leadership decisions.
Cons:
Branding and market awareness are terrible to non-existent. Marketing dollars spent are a fraction of the competition and Blackberry is still basically known as "the phone company".

Delusional and inept senior leadership has created the worst sales culture I've ever encountered. Completely disconnected from the realities/difficulties on the ground and stuck in a 1990's-early 2000's mindset. New logos are all but non-existent here, and existing customers are and have been leaving in droves since Blackberry acquired Cylance in 2019. If you do not have a decent existing account base (and most territories at this point don't), your chances of being successful are slim to none. None of this, however, stops senior leadership from unrealistic expectations with ludicrous timelines.

Channel relationships have been long-abandoned and discarded. The big players have long ago abandoned Cylance (Blackberry) to where the company is a non-factor and not even part of the discussion. Leadership has done nothing to address this, and in fact, has worsened the problem by burning bridges of what remained in desperation for short-term wins that resulted in permanently fractured partnerships.

Review Title: Not a horrible workplace but inability to deliver with toxic leadership enabled by HR
Pros: Great colleagues, benefits not bad. Working for Blackberry can be a good thing or a bad thing, depending on where you are in your career. Good if you have less experience. It's a software company with security in its name.
Cons: Blackberry is behind the curve in terms of technology and culture. When you're ready to move on, recruiters may raise doubts about your career choice of working for BlackBerry. Low pay, the executive leadership is a mess. Not able to deliver new software. High turnover of COOs in recent years. Executive leadership culture is the worst I have ever experienced. I witnessed one executive bashed another executive of minority background using inappropriate remark, and in other occasions there were remarks not respectful to women. In my own experience, HR sided with poor leadership in a way that to this day it's hard to comprehend. There was teachable moment that HR could have turned into rather than showing strong hands unnecessarily. The industry is moving towards a more humane culture. Their HR should catch up.

Pros: Nice office and good snacks
Cons: Boring and not a lot of growth

Pros: You get health insurance and they had a snack room that was sometimes stocked with food for employees
Cons: The environment is very toxic, a lot of lies in the sales department, you are given unrealistic expectations, and the executive leadership is reaping millions of dollars while the sales team is struggling and they are facing cost cuts quarter after quarter. The weight of the sales team is carried by the renewals team because they struggle to sell to net new. By milking the renewals team as the cash cow they become very troublesome to their existing customer base.. The current sales leadership has a hard time using basic tools like Salesforce. You will get yelled at, you will be accused of insubordination if you wish to work from home, and no one has your back. It's the most toxic job I've ever held and hard to trust anyone in leadership positions. There was no opportunity for career advancement, I was stuck in the same position for over five years. Never once promoted. All I can say is that it is very chaotic, and you should stay away from this company if you value your mental health.

Pros: If you like working in India, sure, great company. All the jobs moved there.
Cons: They canceled 401K matching for years, canceled bonuses, called everyone to return to the office, and promptly fired them. Endless toilet flush of Marketing executives each promising to sell and one even going as far as to say "This product isn't great - but we can still sell it" - great confidence booster. This company is smoke and mirrors - great website, great marketing, but clinging to an old brand and trying to flip a bad product onto its customers.

Review Title: Dullest place I ever worked at.
Pros: One business unit (Internet Of Things) is doing well - mainly in automotive software, beard on the QNX brand. Salary is median level. Benefits are standard.
Cons: Other business unit (cybersecurity) is making large losses. The Company has publicly announced measures that could meant it splitting up or being acquired. A company struggling to ditch an image synonymous with failure and complacency in its former smartphone business. Very disjointed product portfolios - between its QNX branded products and its BlackBerry branded products. Websites are testimony to this. Very ‘engineering led’ with strong egos amongst its product and engineering leaders; marketing despite having the budgets, struggles to impose leadership and get recognized, despite lip service and some attempts to the contrary. CEO townhall meetings are excruciatingly depressing, with the cyber business being public ally lambasted in front of everyone. It’s clear sone of the old QNX stalwarts resented becoming part of BkackBerry. Lots of people with a Director title who are not really directors. Directors report to directors… Ottawa building is a hangar-like, soulless place, with grey high cubicles, lacking energy or creativity. Staffed by very in-the-weeds computer science/engineering types who develop real time operating systems and related software that lives deep in the heart of embedded systems computers. Apparently high calorie snacks and sparse fresh fruit makes it a good place… Cafeteria mediocre. No Friday celebrations; alcohol strictly forbidden anyways. Too much process where it’s outdated and not needed; not enough where there should be.

Review Title: They're making it hard to stick around
Pros: Canadian leadership care about employees. Amount of work is manageable. There are some great people I enjoy working with and who are keen to learn and grow.
Cons: Senior US based leadership doesn't care about employees as people. Recent business decisions are damaging morale and making salary and benefits even less competitive than ever. The CEO exudes negativity. He threatens and blames individual employees and teams for anything bad. Full time work from office and weak COVID policies are the last straw for many great former employees. Others are looking for better employers.

Pros: Relatively easy job technically, some good team mates.
Cons: The frequent reorgs within the company have created an atmosphere of chaos and uncertainty. Paired with a lack of effective project management and clear direction, the environment has hindered productivity and made it difficult to focus on delivering quality work. Additionally, I have found that the company's support for individual employees' needs has been extremely lacking, which has affected morale and motivation, and led to many people quitting. Now is my time to do the same. The forcing of a return to the office has been a significant source of tension for me for a while now. When I joined Blackberry, it was explicitly under the understanding that remote work would be accommodated, which was a critical factor in my decision to join. The lack of consideration for this need and the insistence on returning to the office despite my concerns have been deeply disappointing and ultimately the primary reason for my resignation. Furthermore, I must express my dissatisfaction with the HR and Benefits teams at Blackberry. Over the years, I have encountered numerous issues with their level of support and professionalism. One particularly frustrating incident was when I discovered that the Kaiser insurance option, which I was promised and specifically sought out when I joined, was not initially available to me. It took months of fighting and advocating for my rights to finally secure the insurance option I was offered in my employment contract. This was ridiculous. This experience, along with many others over the years, has left me feeling unsupported and very frustrated with the lack of transparency and accountability within the company's HR and benefits departments. Throughout my time at Blackberry, I have often felt like nothing more than a number to the corporate executives. The anxiety and stress I have endured due to their inability to effectively run the company have been overwhelming. It has become increasingly evident that the organization is facing significant struggles and is on the verge of decline. Unfortunately, the corporate culture and leadership have failed to address these challenges adequately, resulting in a toxic work environment that undermines the potential for success. I can only hope that people can leave on their own terms before the company forces them to. As a disabled queer, trans non-binary, and autistic person, I expected the bare minimum from Blackberry in terms of inclusivity and provide a supportive environment in all aspects of my employment. Even that was too much of an ask, as the company has fallen short in nearly every aspect. There is a significant lack of understanding, support, and inclusivity for individuals like myself, as well as more broadly. Blackberry has the potential to do so much better, but it appears unwilling to make the necessary changes.

Pros: Working with cutting-edge technology: BlackBerry is known for its expertise in mobile technology, including RF hardware. Engineers working at BlackBerry have the opportunity to work on the latest and most advanced RF hardware technologies. Strong brand reputation: BlackBerry is a well-established and reputable company, known for its innovation and quality products. Engineers working at BlackBerry can be proud to be part of a company with a strong brand and reputation. Professional development opportunities: Engineers working at BlackBerry have the opportunity to work on challenging projects and to develop their skills and expertise in RF hardware engineering.
Cons: Limited career advancement opportunities: BlackBerry has struggled in recent years, and as a result, the company has reduced its workforce, which may limit the opportunities for career advancement for engineers working there. Limited product diversity: BlackBerry's focus is primarily on mobile technology, which may limit the diversity of products and projects that engineers can work on. Reduced financial stability: BlackBerry has struggled financially in recent years, and this may impact the company's ability to invest in new products and technologies, which may limit the opportunities for engineers to work on new and exciting projects.

Review Title: Great Products - Great People - that no one has heard of ...
Pros: BlackBerry has some great people and great technology. Benefits are adequate to good. Product portfolio is good. Minimal travel. 401K Match. Good Work life balance.
Cons: BlackBerry has an market awareness problem. The legacy name is a hindrance in moving forward. Everyone has heard of the company for the wrong reasons. Corporate and public awareness is very weak. BlackBerry will always be known as the CELL-PHONE Company whose best days have gone bye. The purchase of Good Technology and Cylance saved the company. However, managerial decisions to kill off these brand names hurt the former brands. BlackBerry still owns products that should have been sold off or EOL'ed. Sales commissions are mostly unachievable. In general, there is no incentive to keep current accounts - as there is typically no Sales Commission on keeping an account (Renewals). High turn over. Company has no interest in maintaining employees. Stock Options to employees are extremely rare. Company has been on a "no-spend" budget for years. Company looks for every reason not to pay out commissions. Company doesn't know how or have the ability or willingness to market itself. Company does not believe in Sales Incentives - (Club) Most Regional & National Sales meetings are via zoom - This is a company that still has the mindset that they are the BB of old. Some one forgot to tell them that they are no longer on top of the food chain or relevant.

Pros: Benefits are good in general compared to similar companies. Pay is 'ok'.

Review Title: Enjoyed the job and responsibilities as it was never boring and each day presented new challenges.
Pros: Company paid Benefits are excellent  (company paid cars for sales & management, as well as healthcare foryou and your family) and Time off is generous. Smart, knowledgeable engineers that you can learn a lot from and are very personable and supportive. Challenging daily but every employee can see their own personal value within the organization. The company promotes a healthy lifestyle and encourages social events outside the office as building relationships are essential
Cons: Lack of communication & support within all levels of management. Work-Life Balance was nonexistent and results in burn out of good employees. Career advancement & recognition based more on your likability by upper management vs job performance or merit. Lack of training and support internally is counter productive and frustrating.  Gossip & Negative personal opinions (aka perceptions/assumptions, even without merit) outweighs job performance. People need to remember that they are expected to act professional and negative opinions based on assumptions impact livelihoods, respect each other.  Not all are held to the same accountability and need additional training in retaliation/bullying in the workplace.

Review Title: Wonderful company, making great strides here in the US
Pros: R&S cares about its employees and it is reflected in the cut backs from a couple of years ago where they cut everyone (and I mean everyone) pay by 10%. Not only were we able to get our 10% back, but we got our bonuses too. During that entire time, when other companies were trying to save money by cutting benefits, R&S elected to keep the benefits and 401K contributions the same. They were able to keep a strong and talented workforce.
Cons: Working for a German owned company half a world away is always a problem. Not only does the language prevent strong communication, but culture does too. For a company that has been around for more than 80 years you would think they would have worked out the communication issues. When departments won't talk, many efforts are duplicated. Many people have been making great strides in resolving this with new software tools, but people need to use the tools and that is where the problem lies. It's not that the "company' won't communicate with its employees, its the employees that can't seem to make the effort to communicate.

Pros: Nice environment north of Burbank, CA.
Cons: No leadership and training to get you up to speed to learn the systems, completely out of touch with clients because for some reasons these clients are always wrong.  Meeting with customers and understand their need is in no way part of the job, support is done only via the web and visits is not supported by management. Upper management is only worried about the 9 to 5 position the rest is up to sale to develop their business. Nothing is worse than an office that is completely empty and each employee fight and curse in each other desks, at 5 PM nobody can be found, the employees escape the building without saying anything. This is the worst environment to work in, more than once I had to go outside to speak to a customer because the cursing was out of control. The boss doesn't manage this type of situations and doesn't care what so ever about relationships and how to promote the brand to new customers. The support calls are in no way professional, there is a lot of we love you, once they hang up then it is nothing but the F.. Word. Sales are hated and pushed outside the office with hatred remarks.

Review Title: On a scale of 1 to 10 I'd give it a 6.
Pros: Decent pay and benefits. Interesting products.  90% of the employees are friendly people who work hard.  Secure facility. Convenient area to commute to.
Cons: Lack of communication between departments.  Lack of clear marketing goals that incorporate flexibility. There's a need to branch out for new avenues such as social media.  There's also a need for a revamped HR department.

Review Title: If the boss doesn't like your nose, you have already lost.
Pros: A company with many products and a versatile marked. A nice team which you can trust and rely on. Workhours are normal and the company provides good benefits.
Cons: The boss either likes you or doesn't and that is decided in the first 30 minutes. He didn't like me which made build up some tension. I couldn't work for I was paid for and I got tasks assigned which should be done by youngsters. Boss was very smart to avoid anything in a written form which could provide some proof. A handful of coworkers resigned at the same time because they couldn't bear it anymore.

Pros: Good benefits.  Access to leading edge technologies.  State of the art test equipment design meticulously for ultra low noise high end performance.
Cons: Many mid level managers are more focused on maintaining and growing their personal power than advancing technology.  Nepotism is rampant.  I regularly saw good designs killed in favor of poorer designs done by the managers friends.  Mid level managers just cover up designs that fail or blame their political enemies. The isolation between Beaverton and Munich allows mid level managers god-like power.

Review Title: Great people, great benefits, so-so work life
Pros: Great products, great facilities, great benefits, and just about everyone you work around is talented. Every day presents a new technical challenge, and if you like to travel, you can do plenty of that as well.
Cons: Hiring/firing process is highly questionable, work-life balance is not a priority, and there's no way to "move up" in this company (only horizontal moves). This company used to have a small company culture to it, but that's long gone these days.

Review Title: You get the good, but have to put up with the BAD
Pros: The benefits package is very good.  Medical, dental, vision, Rx, life insurance all 100% pd for by the company.  And the coverages on all of the insurances is very good as well.
Cons: Inconsistency between managers, People that are not managers like to act like they are and treat people like they are their boss when they really are NOT.  One person will tell you one way to do something and the next will tell you a different way, and there is NO communication between them therefore causing annimosity amongst the staff

Pros:
- Excellent upper management

- Growing

- Generally good people working in Columbia, MD

- Facility is very nice

- Culture is great - I address the CEO by his first name and he addresses me likewise

- Benefits are unbelievably good...no, fantastically great!

I have never worked for a Company like Rohde & Schwarz before. They seem to care about the workers and the families of their workers. They are imperfect for sure (read my Cons below) but one could do a whole lot worse than Rohde & Schwarz. I would love to give this review a 5 star, but because of the significant frustrations listed below, I can give only a 3 star.
Cons:
I enjoy working here for the above reasons. But, as with any organization, there is room for improvement. The Cons listed here are from one person's point-of-view. I work in a support role (read non-sales, non-service technician role) and am frequently overlooked. I'm pretty burned out and am staying here simply because there isn't anywhere to go (yet). I still do my job with dedication and passion (that is how I have always tried t work) but because of the Cons lited below, I am entertaining offers to leave Rohde & Schwarz. So, in no particular order, the Cons as I see it at Rohde & Schwarz at Corporate HQ (I will update this review if things significantly change before I leave the company).

- Advancement is slow to non-existent

- Some managers "protect" certain employees

-Staffing in support functions is inadequate (non-sales related)

- Burn-out becoming more common - good employees looking elsewhere to further career since the promotion come only to a select few 

- Recognition doesn't follow achievement - it follows self-promotion

- If you area conscientious, hard-working employee, you will be exploited. You will have more work than you ever imagined piled on you. 

- Work-life balance very difficult to impossible to maintain

Review Title: Strong focus on employees, great autonomy.  Experienced and fair management
Pros: At this company, you really get to pursue what you are good at.  Ideas and suggestions from employees are really heard, The management team is open to new ideas, and we are growing fast and have done really well over the past few years.  This allows them to invest in growth areas, products, etc.  My colleagues are really fun and everyone seems happy to work here.  Awesome benefits.
Cons: They company is light on processes and policies.  This can be a good thing, but they could improve in that area.

Review Title: I have been here for 11 yrs, and most of it has been ok.
Pros: Working here is ok. People are friendly enough. Benefits are  good. Company gives out bonuses if certain financial goals are met.
Cons: Managment is not that great. They tend to look out for certain people they like, sort of a 'good ole boy' thing. Hard work never gets noticed. Promotions are very hard to get. Pay raises are low, except for managment, who get rich off the backs of the workers.

Pros: Get to learn a lot, nice atmosphere with other employees. It was a great job as your first job out of college.

Review Title: It’s a job, no more free time
Pros: Coworkers are genuinely great people, the only reason I stuck around as long as I did. 3-weeks standard vacation.
Cons: No work-life balance. Be ready to be on calls at 6AM and 9PM on the same day 3-4 times a week and get paid below the market. You WILL be judged for not being available 24/7. Compensation and promotions are a 'buddy system' and double standards are ubiquitous with the management “clique”. Bait and switch in terms of responsibility when accepting roles, you will manage double what is originally mentioned. When numbers dip ever so slightly, downsizing happens FAST. You have no decision rights on your products, upper managment will make decisions for you then look to you for answers when things go south. YEARS of exceeding expectations on my yearly reviews with not one bonus, you have to go to war for raises.

Review Title: Not a good company for Autosar Developer

Now German colleague told that if they are not able to increase head count in Bangalore they will close the Development team here. Due to this company is offering unrealistic offer to candidate who are looking for Job but still no one is joining. So you can think of the condition. 7.No Proper HR Policy. At last i would say it is not a Automotive company so not good for Autosar developer & embedded developer

Pros: Decent benefits. Free lunches. Friendly coworkers.
Cons: Management was abusive to employees. I had coworkers crying after their one-on-ones. Management retaliated against employees by firing them when they spoke up about issues. Management ignored technical issues and placed blame on employees. So, bottlenecks created by our hardware limitations were never resolved. Management cut off our line of contact with the client, severely limiting our ability to communicate with them and get feedback. This caused morale to plummet, especially when Management began telling us we weren't sufficient despite the client's previous approval and positive feedback. Management had poor communication skills, and got mad at employees when their inability to communicate effectively led to misunderstandings with employees. Management looked outside the team when they needed to fill leadership positions, rather than promoting from within the team. Our leadership turnover rate was abysmal due to low morale.

Review Title: A place where video game & cinema artists meets !
Pros: The video game industry is sure a fun one, but working alongside a team of creative people, makes it worth the long run. People there wants to help you to learn even more about your craft and even on some days you can work very hard, it's always rewarded with fun times spent with the team inside or outside work!
Cons: As every company in the video game industry - the overtime hours. It's actually not that bad at Keywords, just depending on the project.

Pros: This company did the hiring/hr management for a major video game company, and the video game company made it feel like you were really part of their culture, which was often great. The people who worked there were usually awesome.
Cons:
They were constantly firing / laying-off workers. Many of us were consistently afraid we could lose our jobs at any moment. One day I came in and almost half the employees in our department/area had been laid-off. They also had a bunch of snacks and free food cards we could use, but ended up cutting those off after a couple months. 

They also said they worked 4/10hr shifts, which was great because I had a long commute, and the three days off made up for it. Only a month or so after joining, they sent out a survey asking workers if they wanted to keep that schedule or switch back to 5/8hr shifts. The employees overwhelming voted to keep 4/10s but management switched back anyway. Employees constantly were reporting to management about the problems going on, but nothing ever changed. I ended up leaving after about 6 months.

Pros: if you are fresh or just started your profissional carrier, it is good to start with
Cons: wage per hour and not full time

Review Title: Fun work environment, constant change in projects
Pros: Keywords consist of a great group of diverse people from all over the world for the language testing roles, and this makes for a fun and up-beat work environment. We get to work on great Xbox games, and the pace and mood on each project is always different. We get paid vacation, and sick days.
Cons: Everyone is on a contract, which means some instability in terms of what the future holds. For some people this isn't a viable option in terms of a steady income for paying the bills, and providing for their families. There are few FT jobs, but some people seem to be moving up the ranks - so some good with the instability!

Pros:
Great system for marking testers' individual growth with a clear pathway to leadership positions

Project leads treated everyone fairly from what I saw, made themselves available to talk to, and occasionally took the time to make team members feel noticed and appreciated

I thought the company's handling of COVID was acceptable. Working from home options were given where applicable, and furloughed employees were given the option to join other teams when positions opened. The in-studio safety measures felt adequate as well.
Cons: There is a bit of a clique culture among the testers on a longstanding team, so it is easy for new team members to feel alone. This has even lead to bullying through social exclusion on rare occasions. I suppose it is somewhat unavoidable to form these environments with low-wage, low average EQ employees, and with silent bullying being hard to detect and plausibly deniable.

Pros: Flexible, Family-oriented, Supportive, Great colleagues!
Cons: None that I can think of at this time!

Pros: Free soda and coffee. Great group of diverse people that work here. Good work environment. Plenty of overtime available during the busy season.
Cons: When I began working here I was told I was a "full-time" employee but that term is used lightly and really doesn't mean anything. Even as a "full-time" employee you're still able to get laid off because of lack of work and with no prior notice. The "leads" seem to be immune to this for whatever reason. I was promised healthcare benefits when I got hired but that seems to be a ploy they use to get you to agree to their low pay. There will be no healthcare benefits so don't agree to work here based on that. They do give you Sick Days but you have to prove you were sick by providing a doctors note which makes little sense since they don't provide any healthcare benefits (who sees a doctor for a cold or flu?). Most people that work here are new to the country so they agree to the work and the low pay. Not a bad job if you're a stay at home mom or starting your career.

Review Title: NO job security, LACK of professional growth, DISHONEST management
Pros: You get some experience in the gaming industry and a Microsoft v-. Also,  fellow colleagues are really nice and the environment is multicultural.
Cons:
NO job security whatsoever. Management is constantly dishonest and very unorganized. They lie to you saying that you will have a job for 3 months, you make plans, and then they keep you for one month and after that you stay one month home. Very stressful environment as you do not know what will happen from one day to the next. 
Management plays favorites, keeping some people although they have nothing to do, promoting some people although they lack the skills. They keep promising and lying while nothing materializes. Lack of diversity in higher management, only one woman test lead.
Might be a good job for someone with no work experience, but as a career or a personal investment not worth it at all.

Pros:

Let's be honest. The pay is really decent for what you have to do. I don't see why so may people here are complaining. This is not rocket science. All you have to do is being precise and pay attention to mistakes and errors. The work hours are normal and they even "force' you to take a break every two hours.
Plus the diversity of the people working in this place is amazing.
Cons:
- High [sometimes annoying] security standards. 
- No flexible work hours [would be nice to avoid the traffic]

Cons: Did not like the workspace

Review Title: It's all about the great people!
Pros:
Keywords is very customer focused with out of the box thinking to delight their partners.  They also have a very talented production team you can always count on.  Company is also known for its fast growing, aggressive approach in acquisition on the production end. 

I genuinely respect their CEO Andrew Day as a leader, I believe in his direction and vision for the company.  I have come to know this very talented group of people for many years, their dedication in what they do inspires me and their passion can be very contiguous :) Thank you all and we will meet again soon!
Cons: While just as any other high growth business, they too face their own challenges, but I felt like I had a strong supportive team to work with.

Review Title: Interesting and Never Boring!  Lots of Growth Here!
Pros: With the vast reach of Keywords across the globe, there is so much to learn and so many connections to make.  My role is never slow, never boring.  While the company runs lean and everyone has a great deal of work, it's challenging and fun.  The teams are all so great to work with, professional and easy going.    Keywords is growing at such a high rate of speed, even if you are in the same role for awhile, it's continually changing and growing.  The opportunity to work with such a diverse workforce is wonderful.
Cons: No major cons.

Pros:
- Can work at home without distractions of coworkers/people.
- I appreciate the recognition of my hard efforts, when it is given.
- Raises are significant, when they come.
- Good Work/Life balance in terms of scheduling.
Cons:
- The gross level of micromanaging is horrific.  Sheets to record what you are doing, every time you do it.  Write an email?  Document it.  Go to the bathroom?  Document it.  They must know what you are doing every minute of every day and will check it three times over.  You need to seriously cool it with this savage, controlling behavior.  Not only is it insulting and distrustful, it it makes all of our jobs more difficult.  We would be 3x more efficient if you didn't have your hand around our throats.

- They like 'busy work' and will have no problem in trying to stretch their agents as thinly as possible for highest possible profit.  If they can convince one agent to work for 3 clients via pressure, they'll pay one person instead of hire three.  And not tell the clients that their agents are also working for other people.  In fact, I was told directly not to tell clients this information and keep it under the blanket.  As clients may not pay KWS as much if they know that the agent's attention is split.

- 'Team Leads' often fumble into their position of management with little to no training or previous management experience.  I've seen them yell, throw fits, and come down on entire teams of agents, demanding they work harder or faster with no compensation.  This in turn drops the quality of an entire team of people and the client's perception of us.  I've even had to correct timesheets that were overlooked by TLs on negligence, costing an agent nearly $400 in monthly pay. 

- Upper management handles feedback poorly and some may even resent you for coming forward with truths - because the truth can sometimes be damaging.  You have to be very careful who you trust and who you talk to if you want to keep your position or work your way up.  It's a social minefield.

- Disorganized management causes the agents to suffer.  Who talked to who about what?  Someone sent an email, but I didn't get it?  One TL was told something that the other TL wasn't and now the agents made a mistake and the client is upset?  Forgetting when people work or pinging agents at 4:00am off shift?  This is common.  This happens near daily.  It's communicative chaos.

I had a TL not even show up on training day because they 'forgot'.  Oh well.

Pros: Work with excellent people for excellent clients on excellent products, competitive pay and benefits, family friendly, work-life balance conscientious, industry pros
Cons: not sure there's a solid path for career advancement at my level, but my manager is working on it.

Review Title: A good transitional job to get to where you really want to be.
Pros:
Last week of the year PTO.
Morale events.
Cons: Limited opportunity in the positions available.

Pros:
Meeting nice people from all over the world, and learning about their cultures and lives can be a lot of fun. Great coworkers with varied backgrounds and across all ages.

If you are interested in games, you will get to see/try new titles before the public.
Cons:
The work at Keywords is project based, meaning they will call you in to work X number of days or weeks. In between projects, you will be at home without compensation. When interviewing, they may tell you to expect 2-4 weeks of downtime per year, but this is very far from the truth. There is NO guarantee that you will have work, and when they do call you in, projects tend to shift and change with no warning. This means that you might show up to work, expecting a few weeks of income, only to be told that the project has been delayed. As projects get close to deadline, aforementioned poor planning manifests itself as last minute overtime requests, often on weekends.

Management is the main problem at Keywords. The top manager has often stated to me and others that his philosophy is: "I don't care if people hate me, because no one is irreplaceable."

This "Leadership Style" lays the foundation for how employees are treated, creating an often toxic atmosphere of intimidation and fear. The rest of the management team is typically overwhelmed and therefore mostly disinterested in the well-being of testers (to them, the priority is making Keywords look good to the client, not the employees). Don't expect anyone from management to be on top of communication, and don't expect to be thanked for your work.

Compensation is low for the work and what management expects from you in terms of availability and "loyalty". They pay people based on a combination of how rare the languages are, and how desperate they are for filling that seat. If your language is common (such as Spanish), you will be making an hourly rate in the teens. If your language is harder to find, you can squeeze them for much more. If you do apply to work there, it's important that you know your value and ask for a matching hourly rate - because you are not likely to get a raise after you start.

While I was there, there were several examples of people who asked for a raise and were made to wait months for an answer (I waited 5 months). If you do get a raise, you risk being moved to the bottom of the list - meaning if there is another tester covering the same language for less, they will call them in before you when there is work to do. Not surprisingly, this sometimes creates jealousy and mistrust between testers.

Outside of the pre-scheduled breaks, you are expected to quietly sit and work even if there is nothing to do. This happens regularly due to poor planning, but you are still supposed to give the appearance of working on something. Again, this is so it looks good to the client. There will be days, where all you do is sit and look at a spreadsheet and wait for an email to tick in.

There is a high turnover of people, as many leave as soon as they find something elsewhere. While there, I offered numerous suggestions for how this could be improved, but was eventually told that it was not a priority, just the nature of the business.

If you are looking for a career path, you can try to work your way from tester to test lead. That's as far as it goes, though. Be prepared to go above and beyond to make yourself stick out from the others who are trying to do the same thing. I did exactly that, taking initiatives and developing tools and processes for the benefit of everyone, on my own accord, some of which ended up becoming department standards. This sort of thing is expected from those who seek advancement. However, even if you do succeed in getting a promotion, know that a lead position comes with a ton more responsibility and expectation, but your compensation will stay pretty much the same as when you were testing.

There is no HR available, should you have a need for that.

Pros: fun and easy work with an insider look into the world of gaming
Cons: not enough work projects to keep up with bills

Pros: Employees from many cultures and countries.
Cons: Short project and not much work to do

Pros:
- Reasonable option for inexperienced professionals getting started in the industry
- Some interesting people to work with
Cons:
Those who hold a university degree and/or have at least 2 years of relevant work experience should only consider this company in dire circumstances (beware that this company is capable of making those even WORSE). 

In anything but the most unfavorable of job markets, you could definitely find something that pays more and afford more job security and growth should you stay in the job market. Anyone who isn't a bilingual 18-24 year old with zero experience should absolutely AVOID working here unless you're interested in derailing any career momentum you may have and stress over your own personal finances.

 If you DO happen to fit the demographic mentioned above than I would recommend working very diligently during the SUMMER months between E3 and holiday release time (after that there are hardly any projects/work so you'll be laid off) to build your resume and network a bit. If you're not going back to school or have something better lined up by October, you're going to get screwed - so plan ahead and don't be victimized by this company's deceitful practices like so many others who have already commented here have been in the past. 

Their testing processes are rather lax, allowing for too many errors to end up in released products and not creating an environment for individuals to develop into the best testers they could be. This company has also had at least one issue with unreleased content being LEAKED while being contracted for a well known company - maybe that's why they LOST that contract?? 

Work here at your own risk....and SHORT-TERM ONLY. Have an exit strategy mapped out on your very first day or you will definitely lose out and end up on unemployment waiting for the phone to ring.

Pros:
-Good/Fun Summers job for students
-Job on the side  for adults leaving still with parents or for a house wife
-First time experience in Microsoft
-Sometimes cool games to test
-Meet other foreigners from lots of diferent places
Cons:
-Management is incompetent & they lie to you at interview about the type of job it is. This is not a year round job. You will be home MONTHS (not days and weeks like they say) before they call you back in, if they even call. They will not fire you because you could sue them, so they just keep lying and says that they will tell you if something comes  when there's no accountability and you're home without pay. 

-Dead end job. Sometime they say to be politically correct that the loyal, hardworking people will get hired fulltime or promoted. This rarely happened in the long time I was there (not even had ONE work review) and most of the smart, experienced people get jobs on better Microsoft teams or they go to Amazon (pays way more). Then you lose all of the best comrades.

-Testers are paid by language and not skill/experience. If you speak a more rare language, like Dutch or from Norway, you can ask for $20+ an hour but then they will just cut you after the project's over because they don't want to keep you around for that much. Spanish will pay a lot less but you do the same amount of work or more.

-People who pay there own rent can't afford to stay at this company. You will soon be forced to the streets looking for another job if you start here anyway. Why bother?? Just find a better job (and the main manager will tell this direct to you if you make a complain...he is a jerk who does not like the responsibility being the boss He secretly wants a demotion cuz' the company is quite bad) 

-Worst Boss of your career life ever guaranteed. Unprofessional, tries to do cover up, seams cool sometime, but he generally just hates every person, major stress issues. No honest work evaluation given, only criticism of his staff behind closed doors. Donald Trump would be better!!

Review Title: Great company, great pay, solid customer base, ample sales opportunities
Pros: Lots of great supportive people who are more customer focused than other tech giants I have worked for. The offer I accepted was higher than I had expected for my experience level (Around $100k base / $100k comm for Enterprise AE role with 10 yrs B2B exp.). Lots of selling tools, a dedicated CSM (vital to your success), a shared SDR, and a shared SME for each major product category. Customers generally like us, are easy to engage with and accept meeting requests. Competitive offerings with lots to upsell within accounts across other departments and LOBs.. The products are competitive and sufficiently suited for customers' needs,
Cons: It can be easy to get stuck in discussions about legacy paper-based services that customers know Iron Mountain for (offsite records storage and doc shredding are their bread and butter). While there is a big opportunity for converting these legacy customers to digital services, Iron Mountain has most room to grow in it's cloud, digitization, and digital storage businesses. Nearly all sales are generated within existing customers who have large offsite storage accounts already, by forming relationships with the right people to find new projects, expansions, and renewal upsells. Frequent account team changes and annual rep reassignments seem to have the most damaging impact to these relationships. Rarely are deals won from a position of clear product superiority or lowest price, but rather from trusted relationships with the customer's AE and account team.

Review Title: The people here are really good, the process is not
Pros: The people on the team are all very good at what they do. They work really well with each other and with outsiders. I could easily ask anyone for help and I can easily give anyone constructive criticism.
Cons: The technology department rules the roost, upper management loves to talk about design first, but they will not back it. Dev will take over and make poor decisions to hit deadlines instead of making a good experience for the users. This has been happening over multiple years and we lose potential clients because of it. We also desperately need a business analysts that can create requirements.

Review Title: Awesome place to learn and grow
Pros: I was recruited to join Iron Mountain a year ago. When first contacted I thought, "the shredding company?" which is a common misperception. Iron Mountain is so much more. Our Matterhorn growth and transformation story is awe-inspiring and to be able to be even one sentence of one page of one chapter of that growth story makes me feel like I'm having an immense impact. Not to mention the Head of Executive Search and the Head of Talent Acquisition are 2 of the best bosses I've had in my 20+ year career. They really know the industry and the talent function, and have the patience to impart what they know in a meaningful and resonant way. I am beyond blessed to have joined such a great team and am delighted to be able to help recruit some of the best and brightest executives to join our climb.
Cons: The organization is growing and changing so rapidly that (1) sometimes it is hard to keep up with what each of the business units are doing which can be challenging when trying to tell the full IRM story and (2) there are internal transitions that are part of the growing pains of an organization undergoing this much transformation.

Review Title: Great place to work and grow
Pros: Absolutely love the team and the people and culture at Iron Mountain. If you are looking for a great place to work, when people respect each other, they value their team members and appreciate talent. This is the place for you. The senior mgmt clearly communicates throughout the organization, there is a sense of camaraderie and belonging for all employees. It has a diverse group of people from around the world and everyone's opinions matter at Iron Mountain. I feel like you can get heard and everyone is fighting to win customers - working towards presenting our best foot forward. Customer comes first and I love that everyone's always working to make this a better place to work.
Cons: Like all companies there are always things that can be a hinderance in your work like the company is too big and sometimes takes long to get things approved or done, sometimes there are too many people involved or you don't know whom to go to for a resolution in IT. But that comes with any big organization. I also think budgets get shifted, but that is also normal elsewhere. I think working with awesome people overrides all these issues that probably exist in every company. I'd pick great culture over these cons.

Executives consistently mispresent the truth and hide critical information from employees. In an organizational meeting, one of the executives accidentally said "When are we telling them we are moving" (or along those lines) which prompted a lot of backpedaling and lies until they came clean that they were planning a major move across state and hiding that information until the last minute to prevent workers the ability to look for new jobs. 
Constant layoffs negatively affect the operational efficiency. Employees are consistently overworked and reprimanded. 
The organization ties bonuses to revenue/profit but which is a negative since they will claim a year was not profitable even though they spent 975 million acquiring a company then another 250 million acquiring a second. How is an organization that is spending nearly 1.25 billion acquiring their competition unprofitable and why are bonuses affected by that?

Review Title: American Company with full of Indians
Pros:
$80 commuter credit per month
OK pay package
Cons:
I recently had the experience of working for a company based in Boston, MA, with the Engineering team located in Tampa, FL, and another significant presence in India, encompassing various levels from management to Engineering leads.

During my tenure, I observed some challenges in the organizational culture and communication, which I believe could be improved. Notably, I found the decision-making process regarding layoffs to be unclear. Despite receiving a high performance review (4.0 out of 4.0), I was unexpectedly laid off. This coincided with the company hiring new team members, which raised some questions for me about the criteria used for these decisions.

For those considering employment with this company, I would advise paying close attention to the company culture and communication practices during the interview process. It's crucial to ensure that the environment aligns with your professional values and expectations for a supportive and transparent workplace.

Review Title: Great place to build a career!
Pros: The size and scope of Iron Mountain enables an ambitious employee to advance and pursue new opportunities in various areas. I have been here more than 20 years and had positions in Operations, Account Management, Territory Sales, Digital Solutions and Enterprise Sales. It has been a great career! I can honestly say that any time there have been gray areas, the company made a decision that was fair to me. I appreciate the fact that Iron Mountain did not rest on its reputation as the leader in records management. Instead, leadership recognized that we are an "information" management company. They have developed a wide range of new services and products to keep us relevant as the way information is handled and used changes. The future is bright. I have recommended Iron Mountain to friends and family members and some of them are ow my colleagues here.
Cons: The bureaucracy at Iron Mountain can be frustrating at times. It takes a while to learn how to get things done.

Pros: *Company reputation: we service 95% of Fortune 500 companies. *Flexible work environment: many remote jobs; culture respects family time *Growth mindset: company is constantly working acquisitions and promotes idea generation across all job roles
Cons: *Pay increases and bonuses can be very political/less performance-based: I've encountered 10+ individuals from 3 different divisions offer this or similar unsolicited comment to me, personally, and have countless others say this is the case generally. There is a lot of chatter around annual awards time...frequently encounter these discussions on a yearly basis.

Review Title: Lacked Leadership Diversity. Leadership lacked professional integrity and maturity.
Pros: During interview process, seemed very open to embracing new leader with new perspective, previous experience, expertise and success. There were some senior leaders who respected expertise and welcomed ideas, perspectives and effective leadership skills. Compensation at upper levels is reasonably competitive. Opportunity for cross-functional collaboration if you get "connected" with the right people.
Cons: Certain leaders have privileged attitude and attempt to bully new hires. Lack of professional integrity and maturity among leaders was appalling. Allowing certain leader to go unchecked for their unethical behavior resulted in a very toxic, hostile environment. Taking credit for other's ideas and presenting as their own, sabotaging initiatives, false accusations, inappropriate accusations, falsifications of performance metrics were a constant with certain leaders but not addressed, empowering continued unethical behavior and actions.

From the great benefits for Healthcare, vision, dental to all the wonderful opportunities for saving on College for my kids, 401K for my future, and many perks to save on auto/home insurance and many, many others.
Cons: The only con that I have to offer is that many positions with the new landscape are now work remotely, and the challenge to that is you are never off or away from your computer/work. Process improvements are underway but I anticipate it will be 2-3 years before this is better for the overall organization.

You will be competing against your own machines at a cheaper price by 3rd party re-sellers. High stress times = crazy amounts of micro management. No room for career growth. Service sucks too.

I got overpaid commission and didn't realize it since they were doing advances on commission since delivery time was 6-9 months. They withheld my commission 4 months later with 0 notice. I had to door dash every day after work to make up for it and started losing my hair from stress. Asked for a raise and no one cared!

Review Title: Good entry level job, but not a career.
Pros:
There are many entry-level positions at Konica Minolta and the company is willing to take a chance on individuals who lack experience. The training was decent and managers are fine with letting you learn at your own pace. Coworkers are more than willing to lend a helping hand and help fellow staff members get up to speed.

The work environment is generally comfortable and there is a cafeteria on site. The company also hosts lots of events and activities for staff, especially during the holidays.

Their corporate roles are good for entry-level folks looking to gain some exposure to, and experience in the corporate world.
Cons:
The biggest con at this company is lack of flexibility and WFH options. During the pandemic everyone worked from home. Then they implemented a hybrid policy that allowed for 2 days WFH. Then they only allowed one day a week as WFH. The 2 days WFH seemed reasonable, and lowering WFH to one day a week seemed unwarranted. They implemented some new stuff to make up for it, but what is the point? Why not just let us WFH at least 2 days a week? Most of the jobs at Ramsey HQ can be done completely remotely to begin with. Seems completely unnecessary. From what I understand, folks in upper management are allowed to work completely remotely. Rules for thee, but not for me. 

In addition, there is a high degree of micromanaging here. Seems that most managers do not care about quality of work. The only thing that managers seem to care about is if you are sitting at your desk like a good worker bee. Don't be away from your desk too often or 5 minutes late because someone will tattle on you. Also, don't ask for too many days off or your manager might get annoyed. A lot of long-time employees will be rude, disrespectful, and bossy. Some of the disrespect you can experience is truly shocking. But it seems like people just put up with it because KM is the only place they have ever known and they are afraid to leave.

Pros: Great ongoing training, flexibility, Great leadership
Cons: Competitive Industry that at times feels commoditized, when competing against KM dealers in the same market

Pros: I have enjoyed a career with Konica Minolta by working hard and being rewarded for it. The company has done a great job to provide incentives to learn, opportunities to take on new projects and business plans. My immediate manager has provided great support and guidance to help me advance my career. The products we support, the everyday people I interact with are great to work with. In my role, I interact with a large cross section of the company from sales, service, administration, logistics, finance, warehouse teams and everyone is generally friendly and easy to work with.
Cons: Providing a more clear growth path to help advance in position, while recognizing the challenges we face by being more lean in headcount. Sometimes it takes time to get the right IT tools in place to support what we do, but no company is perfect and the continuous effort to make things better is noticed.

Review Title: Dying Industry with Old School Thinking
Pros: Decent base, autonomy for some, uncapped commissions if you get lucky.
Cons: Ridiculous quotas. A rep in NYC has the same quota as a rep in Orlando, FL. Territories are completely disjointed, starting, yours will likely get you 25% of your quota (they'll promise 70%) if you are lucky. Angry customers, difficult administration and logistics, lots of busy work in CRM and micro-management under some managers. Print is a dying industry, and this company is trying to pivot to software and solutions, perhaps too late. They use third parties for a lot of their solutions and are usually more expensive than competitors on top of being viewed as a legacy copier company.

Cons: - US managers can be old school/cliquey

In the midst of transforming the business from a Multi-Function Printer product company to a digital solutions provider that expands printing capabilities to encompass intelligent information management, managed print production, IT services, cybersecurity, and more. You need to be comfortable with and energized by change. Friendly, dedicated employees that have the best interests of the business at heart.
Cons: Progress is never a straight, smooth road. There are unexpected challenges or obstacles to progress, because when you are a company of 150 years, there are always legacy systems and processes. The company and employees are interested in addressing these areas. If you are willing to take ownership and drive change, you can have a great impact.

Pros: Most colleagues are pleasant. That's it, really.
Cons:
No promotional potential. Definition of a dead-end job. Awful compensation. An employee actually warned me during my first week to "make sure they pay me." In 3 years, I've only received a single 1% raise, and the same for my coworker. No cost-of-living increases; in doing the math on the US Fed BLS. website, I've lost over $7k since starting here due to inflation alone. I was even rated as "exceeding expectations" one year and still received nothing. Company constantly tries to find ways to cut costs while charging customers more, but never passes any of the increased profits down the line. Old fashioned "on-site" culture.

Dying industry--printing. Good luck 10 years from now. Contracts lost frequently due to most companies going 100% remote.

Come here only if you have a plan to leave and need a stopping point, and definitely don't come if you'd be working in the "lower ranks" such as warehouse, etc. They barely recognize you're human and will treat you as if you're a general laborer for the rest of the company and assign you tasks unrelated to your actual job.

Pros: Decent Salary good people, high pressure
Cons: No career advancement , high pressure

Review Title: Transforming into a new image is never easy....but it is rewarding to see progress
Pros:
Exciting time in the company and industry as Konica Minolta drives digital transformation internally and for customers. 
If you like to build new capabilities, spearhead new initiatives, and be challenged to learn new skills every day, then this is a great time to be part of Konica Minolta.
The company culture is broadening and there is a large focus on inclusion globally. 
Truly care about people and are evolving to be more responsive to employees' career development needs and goals.
Cons:
Change is hard....it means getting out of your comfort zone. It means there are people who are unhappy, stressed, and not bought-in. However, the executive leadership has been as transparent as possible about the direction the company is going. Regular town halls by the CEO and executive leadership team has been outlining the strategies for employees.
Nothing is perfect and there are lots of employee initiatives that are in the works, but not yet delivered. The future is bright, but navigating.

Review Title: Requiring Delivery Drivers to become install technicians was not smart
Pros: Nothing! Everything was absolutely horrible working at that job.
Cons: Nothing. Money is extremely low. Especially for delivery drivers. If you look at the total scenario of the job as a delivery driver you will be doing working for Konica Minolta. If you strictly want to do delivery, do not sign up for this job as a delivery driver for Konica Minolta.

Pros: Working from home. Big knowledge base.
Cons: Grueling process to be even considered for a promotion

Review Title: A Candid Look at Tata Consultancy Services for Business Analysts
Pros:
Professional Development Opportunities: TCS offers various training programs and resources for skill enhancement, providing avenues for professional growth and development for business analysts.

Diverse Project Exposure: Business analysts at TCS have the opportunity to work on a variety of projects spanning different industries and domains, allowing for a broadening of skills and knowledge.

Emphasis on Work-Life Balance: TCS promotes work-life balance through flexible work arrangements and wellness initiatives, demonstrating a commitment to supporting employees' overall well-being.
Cons:
Communication Challenges: There are instances where communication breakdowns have led to misunderstandings and delays in project timelines, highlighting the need for clearer communication channels within the organization.

Complexity of Projects: Some projects at TCS have been overly complex, requiring extensive problem-solving skills from business analysts. While this offers learning opportunities, it can also be overwhelming at times.

Workload Management: Despite efforts to promote work-life balance, there are occasions when project demands encroach upon this balance, necessitating careful time management and boundary-setting by employees.

Pros: There are a lot of learning platforms, but I bet you won't get time to use them. TCS, you shattered me into pieces. It took time, but I've gathered myself, and I'm in the process of repairing the damage you caused.
Cons:
A freshman who is hired in the US basically never gets any mentorships.
Most managers are busy with their tasks, and they have prejudice and jealousy toward freshmen who are immigrant Indians who are in permanent residence in the US. It might be because they had a hard way to get to the USA and still struggling because of visa issues.

Pros: Okay company, as long as you're not on the bench.
Cons:
Urgent Update: TCS is currently undergoing significant restructuring, which unfortunately includes massive layoffs in 2024. This is a stark reminder of the volatile nature of the IT industry and the unpredictable challenges we all face. It's my duty to share this news with the TCS community, not only to keep you informed but also to shed light on the harsh realities many are facing in today's economic climate. To those directly affected, I extend my deepest sympathies and support. I was laid off this week, without notice. 

Plan now for your next job... especially if you're on the bench and have been on the bench for longer than 2 weeks. Everyone on the bench is at risk!

Pros: They do take care of their employees in their own way. During COVID they were very understanding about it and didn't even make you use sick time or PTO. They gave me a severance package I didn't know I would get and had me "on the bench" for two months WITH PAY before letting me go.
Cons:
Management is all or nearly all Indian, and you don't get opportunities to move up very far if you're not.
They made us all take a class on how to deal with the Indian culture when we started. I'm sorry, but you are coming to America to do business, you should be working within OUR culture. I'm not going to go to India and demand American rights.
I noticed that the treated women and LGBTQ folks less seriously, either not promoting when they should, or outright firing for no reason.
The management are "yes men" to their clients, regardless as to whether the ask is in the scope of the contract or even achievable.
The amount of pointless corporate training is laughable, and some of it isn't even relevant to US personnel. Also, sometimes random classes are suddenly "mandatory" because some upper management has a goal to increase the group's training level. Pointless.

Review Title: Difficult Culture Shock with foreign business mentality. They don't work like other companies.
Pros:
Getting past the language/communication barriers, they are a great supportive group to engage with. They have great resources within to get anything done for a project. You will notice a network of employees to help and get solutions.
IF you do not act like a pompous/arrogant American and actually try to befriend your new Eastern co-workers, You can really have a team to support you to navigate both companies.
Cons:
You will be an outcast when you realize how differently they do business. They are not aggressive with the client and if the client perceives that, the client ends up steering the project. You will have two employers; the client and TCS. You will have cultural engagement put upon you and it will be distracting from your immediate duties. If a choice between you or the client, they will go with keeping you quiet and acting like nothing is wrong with management. You are expendable.
Any processes complete, require a screenshot to prove it.

Pros:
Many projects
Good work life balance
Cons:
No innovation
Less pay
Good for freshers only

If you miss a day to log in your hours then it will automatically add your vacation leave, you have to manually go and decline it. I have lost many vacation days like this. 
Performance band is a joke! Favoritism is what gets you noticed and a good band at the end of the year. If you do your work you will get a C band, the ones who are favored and who barely do any work get a better performance band.
