Review Title: Avoid this place if you want respect and dignity
Pros: being employed and receiving a pay check. The best part about this job is the fact that you are assigned to a client and work with them on a daily basis, so you don't have to deal with internal TCS as much.
Cons: Where to begin? as an American I am shocked at how the Indian work culture is; basically there's no respect, you are just a number. - HR doesn't help at all.. in fact they act against you - The internal system used by all employees is a massive joke (ultimatix) and everytime I open it I feel my blood pressure rise due to how badly designed it is. - There's no communication, other than the tons of daily spam you receive which makes things even more confusing. - If you are released from a project, don't expect any help in replacing you.. you have to actively look and beg other projects to take you (what is the job of a director here I wonder?) - they are focusing too much on this whole "diversity" trend which, frankly, does nothing.. it's simply a trend to look cool. - one of the worst on-boarding processes of any company I've seen in my life. There's much more, but you get the picture. My mind is boggled at how this company is still in business (at least here in the USA).

Pros:
Initial learning program that provided some training in full stack development, will sometimes provide training before a project. Some projects allow you to work remotely.

Pay and benefits were ok, but not great, for a fresher
Cons: When you're on the bench, you can be fired at any time without warning, so there isn't really any job security. If you have to relocate for a project, they provide no assistance save for covering a few days in a hotel, and give you very little notice on when you need to move (I had 2 weeks notice) and communicate very poorly on important details like how long you are going to be there. Pretty much no opportunity for upward mobility because nobody at TCS really cares to know who you are and you hardly interact with them. I wouldn't stay here long.

Review Title: Operates like a firm from the 1990s
Pros:
Wide variety of clients and projects - if you are allowed to switch.
Lots of computer-based training available.
Hires MBAs from the lesser-known schools.
Cons:
A very "old school" company that suffers from endemic (unconscious?) biases throughout. Hard to navigate the company, build your own brand, find projects, find credentials, etc. Easy to replicate previous work without knowing it, no central knowledge repository, clunky internal systems.
Heavily biased towards Indian nationals on work visas - local hires seen as 2nd class employees and overlooked in favor of visa-carrying employees to keep them in country. As with all the Indian tech firms, "creative" use of the visa system (in any country) to their advantage to help price out local competition.
All senior leaders are Indian nationals, so career progression limited.
D&I really poor.
Benefits not very attractive and well behind the market leaders.

Pros: Work from home, nice coworkers (for the most part)
Cons: Slow growth track, underfunded projects with inadequate team skillset, long hours

Review Title: An Okay Employer, A Bit of a Mess
Pros: Great smart people; good ethical company; diversity of work and a very broad client base.
Cons: I was employed at TCS for 2.5 years as part of the CXT practice which was suddenly dissolved, its team members scattered to the wind. Being allocated to a project, I happened to survive, Before that, a large round of layoffs took out a good chunk of unallocated people from the rolls. The whole thing was handled quite sloppily, the communication from Corporate was terrible. The HR support in this company is practically non-existent. Lines of reporting are fuzzy. Professional development opportunities and career trajectory pathing opps are a joke. You are only valuable pretty much as a warm body allocated to a project and making the company money, otherwise you are vulnerable to the axe. If you are looking for a good place to work that invests in its employees, I might look elsewhere.

Review Title: Could have been worse, but could have been much better
Pros: Paid fairly well, and hired me right out of school with no experience. Position was fully remote.
Cons: Very disorganized. I was hired in a group of 250+ and we were all onboarded in a single video call. Afterwards, I believe I was misplaced after getting allocated to a project for around 2 months, as I received no communication from anyone for that period. Once I was actually on the project the training was basically nonexistant. The person before me more or less neglected to train me, then left after a month. After that I was stuck as the only onshore person supporting an application with an offshore team who effectively refused to teach me anything. After a year and a half of this, I was cut from the team to offshore more work, and after a month of being unallocated I was abruptly let go.

Pros: Not that I can think of
Cons: Super bad management. No growth. Doesn't respect employees thought

Pros: Lots of incentive opportunities and access to continuous learning platforms to further your craft. As long as your performance review is good, you're guaranteed some sort of bonus - at least at entry level.
Cons:
Management can make things both very unpleasant and very confusing. There are a ton of profile and systems you have to do upkeep on that as a new employee I didn't know about until I was in trouble for not doing them. After initial training which is more of a "how to code." tutorial then training on the company, what you know is completely up to the first manager.

Also, how much you are involved with and enjoy your job is really dependent on the project. My first project I was treated like a temp worker and not even allowed to touch the code. I was strictly supposed to review logs and figure out where the problem was (not even solve it! Pass it on to someone else after that). There was quite little for me to do day-to-day and I became very discouraged. I would also be berated for not doing things that I was never told to do or HOW to do, to the point where another co-worker had to act as a buffer between me and management there.

My next assignment was much better in the beginning! I was treated like an employee who knew what they were doing and was given time to learn the code base and then was immediately expected to contribute. I loved that! Things started to go south later on because we started getting new team members and I was expected to do my job and also manage their jobs, even though I was just another developer. It was to the point I was working late because 80% of my day had been taken up with making sure they got their parts done as I was asked by my team lead.

In addition to that, this job has no employee protections against overtime or limits on working hours or days. If the client/project needs you after your 8 - 4 shift to come in 9pm to 12am you just HAVE to and no, you will not be paid for those hours. There was one point they wanted me to work 14 days straight, overtime on some of those days, with no breaks and no additional pay incentive. Yikes.

Pros: I have just started in TCS. It was a good experience with my green card process.
Cons: Looks like less increment year over year.

Review Title: Striving for Diversity, Equity and Inclusion!!
Pros:
I've had the privilege of being a part of DocuSign for over 4 years, and I can confidently say that it's an outstanding workplace that truly stands out in the corporate world. DocuSign's commitment to fostering a phenomenal company culture is evident in every aspect of its operations.

The company emphasizes openness and transparency at every level, creating an environment where employees feel valued and empowered. From top leadership down to individual teams, there's an evident dedication to listening, understanding, and incorporating diverse perspectives. This open communication culture encourages collaboration and innovation, fostering an atmosphere where everyone's ideas are heard and respected.

What sets DocuSign apart is its unwavering drive for success. The company not only sets ambitious goals but also provides the necessary support and resources for employees to achieve them. There's a palpable sense of motivation and enthusiasm that permeates throughout the organization. This drive is contagious and inspires employees to push boundaries, take initiative, and strive for excellence in their work.

Moreover, the leadership at DocuSign is commendable. They lead by example, embodying the company's values and vision. Their commitment to transparency and accessibility further amplifies the culture of openness within the organization. They encourage feedback, embrace change, and actively support the professional growth and development of their employees.

In addition to the fantastic culture, DocuSign's dedication to diversity, equity, and inclusion deserves applause. The company's initiatives to create a more diverse workforce and an inclusive environment are evident and appreciated.

Overall, DocuSign is not just a workplace; it's a community that thrives on collaboration, openness, and the pursuit of success. Working here has been an enriching experience, and I'm continually impressed by the company's commitment to its employees and its values.
Cons:
DocuSign undoubtedly stands out as a leading company in the industry, known for its innovative solutions and exceptional culture. However, as with any rapidly growing organization, there are certain aspects related to company growth that merit consideration.
One area where DocuSign's rapid growth can sometimes present challenges is in maintaining seamless internal communication and coordination. As the company expands and diversifies its offerings, there may be instances where different departments or teams face difficulties in aligning their goals and strategies. This rapid scaling can sometimes lead to complexities in interdepartmental communication, potentially impacting the overall efficiency and cohesion within the organization.

Additionally, while growth is a sign of success, it can occasionally create a sense of unpredictability or instability among employees. The swift expansion and evolving strategies might lead to changes in roles, structures, or processes that could affect employee morale or job stability, particularly if these changes are not communicated effectively or if there's a lack of clarity regarding the company's long-term vision.
It's important to note that while these challenges exist, DocuSign's leadership and management teams are proactive in addressing these concerns. They acknowledge the hurdles associated with rapid growth and are consistently working towards enhancing internal processes, fostering better communication channels, and ensuring that employees are equipped to adapt to changes effectively.

Review Title: Faulty Processes and Steals Commission from Employees
Pros:
Great product to sell
Ok on compensation (not good not great)
Flexible working
Cons: Somehow DocuSign still has not figured out how to collect the money it is owed from its customers. It allows for customers to access the platform without ever having paid for their plan. Then when they don't pay, they will be sent to collections after a year. Oh yeah! Then when they go to collections, that money that DocuSign is missing from the customer, they will come back to the account executive who originally sold the deal, and take it from their compensation on future deals.

Pros: Had some of the best people, moments, memories, and work of my life. Used to be literally the best place to work and ranked 5th in the world. Helped propel my career and thought I was going to be a DocuSign lifer.
Cons:
Turnover is crazy. Culture has changed. All budgets are cut. No stipends anymore. No holiday parties. 2 days required in office. New manager is insanely arrogant and micromanages. 

Manager tanked a large deal and client said he was horrible to work with and when I tired to save the deal they said they were 100% sure they were going with Docusign but the manager made it sound like they were the bad guy because they looked at other competition as their decision making process. They followed up a response to me that with they wished they worked with me in the whole process, but again, my manager went over my head and took over the deal and tanked it. I was #2 on my team and was put on a PIP that was cut short because it was his word vs mine, and ultimately cut. In the same timeframe 5 other colleagues in my org who have been there for years jumped ship. News to broke out a week later that a private equity firm is about to buy out Docusign. 

This is a sinking ship. What used to be. They’ve lost all their personality and everything that made them special. People don’t come first anymore.

Review Title: Pay no attention to that man behind the curtain!
Pros: Compensation is decent. We used to have some of the best coworkers in tech so some of us were able to really experience creative minds and be a part of some really cool products before our company was taken over
Cons: Leadership is run by boomer board members that actually used a bible verse in an all hands meeting a few years go. People that had been here over a decade were laid off while on paternity leave. About 3 or 4 years ago, we started seeing knowledgeable people get let go to be replaced by offshore or friends of leadership that will never disagree or insist on doing the right thing. Highly concerning judgment in respects to honesty all around.

Pros: DocuSign is a great company. They treat their employees well, offer great benefits, stock options, mental health days, and are undoubtably the best product in the market.
Cons:
Now is not the time to work in sales. Quotas are rising, territories are getting split in two year, seemingly year over year, and attainment is at an all-time low. DocuSign performed extremely well in the pandemic. However, continuing that growth at that rate was not realistic. Stock options are worth 40% of what they were due to management's inability to forecast our numbers.

The commercial org is really strugglingly across the board. OTEs are already incredibly low for market standards - and no one is hitting quota. 1/26 reps in the commercial FinServ org hit quota in Q4 (across all segments). People are unhappy and are really starting to look elsewhere. I worked at DocuSign for two years. Year one, virtually no turnover. In the past 6 months, there has been a ton (and many more are on the way out.)

There is no training program for sales. If this is your first sales job, it's sink or swim.

Our CEO told the company all-hands everyone would be getting raises. In the next call, our CRO specified - "everyone but sales". This really set the sales team off. The MDRS got raises, but the AEs and sales managers did not.

A relatively high performing MDR is out earning a commerical AE. Because of this, many MDRs don't even want to get promoted to AE - it's virtually a pay-cut if you're not an allstar AE.

Pros:
Benefits
Helpful enviornment
Innovation
Decent compensation
Cons:
Communication is poor
Inexperienced managers running teams
Product is behind as other competitors are stepping their game up in providing a better UI, AI and other automative tools
Lacking documentation for real use case scenarios

Review Title: Great Place to work....for a few months
Pros: Honestly, the culture in the sales org is incredible. Loved working with all my coworkers. Your coworkers and manager make you want to work harder. It's such a fun place to be at.
Cons:
"...it's such a fun place to be at." for a few months. The turnover rate is ridiculous and disheartening to know that hard work doesn't mean you get to keep your job. Even when you are hitting your numbers, meeting quota, and showing up every day; in the end that won't matter at all. I bust my BUTT every day and it just does not matter to anyone outside of my internal team. I hate this.

So my question is...what does it take to stay at a company if meeting/exceeding the requirements doesn't secure your position? We hire one new leader and she destroys a department. This is a business so I get it but when are leaders going to start taking accountability for loss?

Review Title: From Innovation to Desperation: The Decline of a Once Beloved Company...
Pros: This was once a place where creativity and dedication were nurtured, where employees felt valued and part of something greater than themselves.
Cons:
The appointment of a rookie CEO marked the beginning of a tumultuous era, characterized by a series of misguided decisions that seemed more akin to a high-stakes gamble than strategic leadership. Within the span of 18 months, the company has had three layoffs, each a direct consequence of ill-conceived strategies that failed to address the core issues at hand. The promise of a leaner, more agile organization has instead left DocuSign threadbare and struggling to maintain the quality and innovation that once defined it.

Equally disheartening is the role of its Board of Directors, whose detachment from the company's operations and culture is palpable. Their decisions, often made in the echo chamber of the boardroom, reflect a startling lack of understanding of our industry and the people who dedicate their lives to it. Their actions, or at times inaction, have not only jeopardized DocuSign’s financial stability but have also eroded the trust and morale of those who remain.

The current senior leadership seems hellbent on undermining the very foundation of the company's image and goodwill. The external narrative being crafted is one of success and forward momentum, a stark contrast to the internal reality of uncertainty and discontent. The disconnect between the public facade and the private turmoil has only served to alienate long-standing partners and customers, who once relied on DocuSign’s integrity and transparency.

The executive decisions of late, rather than being uplifting and uniting, have only served to further demoralize an already beleaguered workforce. Initiatives that once would have sparked innovation and collaboration now fall flat, as the overarching sentiment is one of survival rather than growth. The relentless drive for cost-cutting and efficiency, while necessary in moderation, has been pursued with a zeal that disregards the human element essential to DocuSign’s success.

Pros: if you hit your goals then your in great shape
Cons: if you are struggling, then you will not see any benefits of the pay

Pros:
- Outstanding compensation plan. Best commission plan I have seen in the industry. I have reps making well above their OTE.
- Great product that sells itself. People love eSignature and they want DocuSign. We are better than our competitors and customers are coming back.
- Easy product to sell that a new AE can be trained on in less than a week.
- Great teammates. My direct reports (Enterprise AEs), peers and direct manager are truly great people. I enjoy working with them.
- Fun ERG groups. There's always something fun going on.
- Great benefits (vacation, health insurance, ESPP, benevity, etc...)
- Work life balance is the best I have ever had. I feel in control of my job and my life.
- Support teams are great people (RMs, CSMs, SC's, MDRs). I do feel that they aren't reaching their potential though because of lack of direction from top executives. Frontline and Second Line Managers are great.
Cons:
- This could be the best company in the world to work for but unfortunately there is just so much drama at an executive level that creates distractions. Almost the entire C-Suite has changed in the past 2-years. Every new executive comes in thinking they can do it better but they end up making it worse and falling back on how things were before.
- Executives have a weird level of involvement. It's all or nothing. Too much or too little. It can feel like they either don't exist or they pop up out of no where with a fire drill. 
- The product roadmap has been rebranded with the same content every single year for the past 5 years. There are rumors of a big new product and feature set but I will believe it when I see it.
- There's a lot of female and minority leaders that have left the company. When I started, leadership was incredibly diverse and it slowly went back to the good ole boys club from yester-year. The first club was like a frat house and I guess it now feels like a country club? Either way, it's sad to see so few women or diversity in leadership. This has got to change.
- Layoffs are beginning to feel like the new normal. In 2 years we have had 3 layoffs. Managers have zero insight into this or input into who leaves so it's a shock to all. 
- Executives seem to care more about international expansion than they do about improving the North American growth.

Review Title: Not what it used to be
Pros:
- Some of the best employee benefits you'll find
- Ability to progress in your career if you know how to work it
- Great work / life balance
Cons:
- Unattainable quotas
- Culture isn't what it used to be. There's a lack of team events and bonding.
- High turnover and layoffs lead to extremely low morale
- Unhappy customers and lack of customer care from leadership
- C-Suite and Sr. Management is tone deaf to what's actually happening in sales
- Layoffs impacted several talented, well tenured, quota hitting AEs... is anyone safe?
- First large, in person sales training was held on Yom Kippur (shows lack of commitment to DEI)
- Disconnect on when it's important to be in person. GKO is still virtual but they want you to come into the office for free cupcakes and champagne,,,,

Review Title: Ship is sinking but its not too late
Pros: There are some great people still the company who really care about its success.
Cons: The engineering leadership has made some bad decisions but worse is there unwillingness to admit this and rectify to problems. Second the company has shown over and over that they are no longer an employee first company and that along with poor engineering leadership has led to extremely low morale.

Pros: The pay is competitive at the senior level, coupled with RSUs and potential bonuses.
Cons: The executive team is very disconnected with the pulse and morale of the employees.

Review Title: Need to Kick Out Some New Leaders
Pros: - My immediate teammates are all smart people who get along with each other. - Alot of talented people (although many have left).
Cons: - New leadership team seems to be brining in their friends who come in trying to change things without any understanding of what is actually going on at the working level. There is an attitude of arrogance that is thick. - Completely useless mandatory exercises that are repetitive and never looked at again after the initial effort. These exercises probably costed alot of money to come up with but add no value. - Nearly impossible to make quota. Even if you manage to sell something, there are countless ways they will deny your commission. - Lack of product roadmap. - Removal of NINE paid holidays and the CEO says to "get over it" while laughing in an all hands meeting. - Executive team is making a complete killing in compensation and still selling shares as quickly as they can. This does not send a good message to the working stiffs. - Return to office policy. Why is this necessary? This is not what the core problem is. - The culture that DocuSign was known for is vanishing before our eyes.

Money is the bottom line no matter what.

Review Title: Really love working here - great work/life balance
Pros:
I've absolutely loved working at DocuSign. It's the best place I've ever worked, especially since I'm at the point in my career where I value work/life balance, while also making a meaningful, visible impact. 
The main pros for me -
Empowered to make decisions about the area I own
Expectation and encouragement to innovate
Work life balance - no expectation to work late or on the weekends. It still happens sometimes, but its certainly not worn like a badge of honor like it is at many companies
Great company culture and expectation for everyone to be helpful, responsive, and kind
Cons:
Despite these cons below, I think we're turning the corner and things will be improving
Cons for me -
Stock not performing great currently
Working on coming out with new products and integration of products, but will take time
A lot of new execs and may have more changes coming down the line
Good comp but lower than some tech companies. To me, the work/life balance is well worth the lower tech comp that is still higher than other industries

Review Title: Great Place to Work and Grow
Pros: The people and the ability to make an impact
Cons: There can be lots of people trying to achieve the same goals but not working together as a united front

Pros: Supportive team, interesting projects, good WLB
Cons: More transparency from leadership would be helpful

Pros:
Collaboration between Product/Engineering and Support has been improving.

Opportunities to grow exist, but are hard to find. It really depends on your team and I've been lucky in this regard.
Cons: The company culture has changed over the years. When our current executive staff took over, they mentioned they loved the company culture and that's why they joined. They then proceeded to completely change the culture, employee first mindset, and started changing our benefits at our detriment.

Review Title: Look elsewhere for a sales role
Pros:
-The managers I've worked directly for (RVP, AVP, VP) have all been amazing human beings and I've made strong relationships with my peers who are also great people

-There is potential to set us apart from our growing list of competitors which would alleviate a lot of pain as a seller

-Pay is decent
Cons:
-Quotas are completely unattainable; about 10% of the reps in my direct organization will hit quota. It's mainly because they have bigger/better accounts within industries that have a higher propensity to buy than the other 90% of the reps and/or they were lucky enough to get territory overcarve from people who left. Just about every one of the bigger deals sold in the org this year have been right place right time situations and have been eSignature centric vs strategic deals/CLM deals

-Zero advancement opportunities. On top of the fact that quotas are nearly impossible to hit, there are virtually no advancement opportunities when you get to the Majors level or above. DocuSign was known for advancement opportunities for so long, but now there's no light at the end of the tunnel outside of just being able to keep your job. 

-Justifying the cost of our eSignature platform is becoming increasingly harder, especially to organizations that don't have very complex use cases. eSignature is becoming commoditized but leadership still thinks we should be able to charge outrageous prices just based off our name

-Sister teams like the renewal management team are not on the same page with AEs because they are compensated differently. RMs are compensated to mitigate churn while AEs are compensated on growth. This causes many scenarios where a RM will do anything to get a flat renewal which often takes any upsell off the table for AEs

-Morale is completely in the toilet. I am working twice as hard this year for half of what I made last year and I know that most of my peers are in the same situation. Everyone is in constant fear of losing their job which makes selling harder than it already is

-Executive leadership isn't doing much to turn things around. It's becoming more clear that the CEO and President of worldwide Field Ops came for a quick and easy pay day instead of truly trying to right the ship and their arrogance is palpable. The CEO laughs at questions during town hall meetings while the president of field ops is traveling to a different country every other week to do whatever he does. They say they're committed to the cause, then sell millions worth of stock the second they get the chance

Pros: Product is moderately easy to sell
Cons: Layoffs every 6 months or so

Review Title: Like any company, good and bad
Pros: decently competative pay in comparison to similar companies. The people that work there are great for the most part.
Cons: the change management strategy and comms strategy is AWFUL! Allan is trying to turn it around for morale sake, but with Jennifer as CHRO that's difficult. If he is smart he would get a more people centric/focused CHRO, she is the core of the morale and engagement issues there.

Pros: The best job I ever had, the best team ever, great colleagues, fabulous and transparent leadership, vision - not a cool kids clique. All before maggie and the board decided to take over and promote themselves.
Cons: Narcissistic leadership in product, terrible HR "leadership", runs like the hunger games meets your worst high school drama. Fake DEI with tons of events with nowhere to go, no roles (resume building?). It is the best tool around and current leadership cannot row in the right direction as they are way too busy giving one another more money and grandstanding while adding to the carbon footprint by flying everywhere on a "look at me" whim.

Pros:
- New CEO seems to have a good handle on future vision and how to get there 
- revamping a lot of internal processes and products to move toward future goals
Cons:
- 1-2 AEs per team are hitting quota and the rest are struggling. Middle management won’t admit it’s because they’ve over-hired and there’s issues with product fit (most vendors offer eSig for free). 
- If you’re looking to join sales, hope you like gambling. For every single lay-off round, they’ve back-filled the same positions. This time, instead of layoffs, the rumor is they’re just firing to cut numbers and not pay severance.

Pros: All the things I used to love about this company are no more. I used to love the culture (truly, it was top notch), leadership, vision and collaboration. But, all of that has changed and it is no longer the company it used to be.
Cons: Used to be the best company in terms of culture, leadership, vision and collaboration. Our customers used to love us. Fast forward to today, customers are frustrated and don't see the value they once did. The cost of our solution doesn't help, we're the most expensive eSignature provider out there. And while we could justify it several years ago, we can't anymore. As if that weren't frustrating enough, we're now tasked with more busy work than anybody knows what to do with. It's literally taking away our ability to engage with customers and shouldn't that be the main focus right now? Morale is at an all-time low and nothing works as it should which means that completing the simplest tasks is nearly impossible without jumping through 10 different hoops - and no, I'm not kidding or exaggerating. If you're considering a job here, spare yourself and look elsewhere.

Now, DocuSign is a place where what gets rewarded is finding people to blame, where management wants above all else to dictate to employees rather than convince employees that their plan is correct -- they want servants, not employees

Review Title: I think it used to be great, but I’d stay away now
Pros: Comp was decent. Strong products and name recognition. A lot of good coworkers and some good people in the various support teams.
Cons: I was heavily recruited by DocuSign and sold a vision of massive growth and CLM being the future of the company etc only to be laid off 6 months later. I then saw multiple Account Executive roles posted within a month of being laid off and was never given a chance to apply for another role. The entire time I was there I felt like I was standing in ruins of a once great civilization. Constant shuffling of teams and structure . My territory wasn’t clearly defined until I was 4 months on the job. The prime and co-prime AE structure for speciality solutions was really unclear. DocuSign’s implementation was way too expensive leading to a heavy reliance on SI’s, but engagement was clumsy and difficult leading to drawn out process for customers that really slowed down the sales cycle.

Review Title: The best company I've ever worked for
Pros: Innovative Technology DocuSign is a leading company in the electronic signature and digital transaction management space. As a Solution Engineer, you'll have the opportunity to work with cutting-edge technology and contribute to the development of innovative solutions. Professional Growth Working at DocuSign can provide excellent opportunities for professional growth and skill development. You'll gain experience in sales engineering, customer engagement, and solution design, which can enhance your career prospects. Impactful Work DocuSign's solutions streamline and digitize business processes, making them more efficient and environmentally friendly. As a Solution Engineer, you'll play a crucial role in helping customers implement and optimize these solutions, contributing to their success and driving positive change. Collaboration and Teamwork DocuSign fosters a collaborative work environment where teamwork is highly valued. You'll have the opportunity to work with cross-functional teams, including sales, product, and customer success, allowing you to learn from diverse perspectives and build strong professional relationships. Competitive Compensation DocuSign typically offers competitive compensation packages, including salary, bonuses, and benefits, which can be an attractive aspect of working at the company.
Cons: The tech industry as a whole has experienced periodic waves of layoffs in recent years, and this can be a potential downside to consider. While DocuSign's performance may vary, it's worth noting that unexpected economic or market shifts could impact job security within the company or the industry as a whole.

Pros: This review is tough to write. If you asked me over 2 years ago I would have written a 5 star review. Majority of people that work at Qualtrics are incredible. I met some of the greatest people at my time at Qualtrics. I also had a fantastic experience with my managers, incredibly supportive and overall I loved the work that I was doing. The money was also good if you work hard and hit your numbers.
Cons: It is funny because Qualtrics is an experience management company and claims to be so transparent, however they DO NOT practice what they preach. The C-Suite and upper management does not care about the people that work under them. As long as they are putting more money in their pockets they do not care that they are eliminating hundreds of jobs. 2 huge layoffs in one year with more to come. Zig reads off a script to tell hundreds of people that they don't have a job anymore. They do not listen to their employees. You can be a top performer and still not have job security. If you have an LDS manager and you are not LDS, your LDS teammates will get favored (this happens frequently). Being acquired by PE only benefitted upper management and everyone knows it. Don't work here if you value job security.

Review Title: High caliber ‘24 company with bottlenecking ‘04 processes
Pros:
TLDR: unique perks ideal for dog owners and families, good logo for a resume, caring middle management, willing to change. 

Experience bonus, dog friendly, top-tier subsidized onsite daycare ages 3 mos to <5 years, locations all over, catered lunch everyday, gorgeous office spaces, above average work life and supporting families, willing to pivot to stay growing, competitive pay, quality mid-level managers, and unique programs for higher achievers
Cons:
TLDR: Sr leaders deflect instead of owning blame and doing something about it. Employee development and customer experience are neglected/not prioritized. Laggers in most internal categories. Poster-child for talking instead of doing

Sr. Management frequently blames macroeconomic/extenuating circumstances for poor performance, lack of support for employees-middle mgmt, and ever-harshening/moving metrics and targets. All of which result in rapid burnout, directionless trajectories for careers and department, and the programs to enable personal & professional advancement are mediocre and not prioritized. 

Benefits are top notch but fall behind in the enterprise space and even other local tech companies.

OKRs are might help startups, but they more often then not create bottlenecks from incomplete programs and ideas, unnecessary additional layers that don’t communicate well, or even admin rights to dif systems that leave when people leave the company. 

Promotions/raises are unreasonably unattainable

Review Title: As wallets tighten, experience management has fallen by the wayside
Pros: Competitive starting salary. Some teams have strong work/life boundaries. Utah employees have access to a myriad of additional benefits through Qualtrics' partnerships with local companies.
Cons: Employee experience management is all but non-existent internally at Qualtrics. Originating from the C-Suite, the company has developed a culture of hypocrisy that pretends to be a culture of empathy. In addition, Qualtrics has unfortunately followed the rest of the tech industry in mandating RTO, reducing fringe benefits, halting the internal promotion process, and conducting periodic mass layoffs to give boosts to EOQ metrics.

Pros:
Great benefits
Good culture about reimbursements and time off
Good people
Good upward and lateral mobility
Good management (for the most part)
Great food/catering for lunch
A lot of office and other perks
Different groups to get involved with and events held by the company
Cons:
Recent changes to the company (being bought by SAP, going public, being bought by SilverLake, going private) have led to layoffs and restructuring. They're focusing more on offices outside of the US, in particular the Mexico City office in order to get cheaper labor.
If you're in the Provo office, there won't be much diversity.

Pros: Large company with some mature systems. Work life balance has been good; rarely work 40 hours a week. Low stress on-call. RTO currently unenforced. Engineering pay pegged at ~85th percentile by location. Good teammates and managers. Good diversity relative to similar companies.
Cons: Qualtrics has been circling the drain for a while now. Private equity bought the company out this past summer and has been slowly gutting it. Big layoffs recently, many jobs moved to lower cost locations and other countries, no leadership accountability whatsoever. Total chaos followed. RTO enforcement coming. Pay cuts (or absence of refreshers) likely coming. Everyone good is looking to leave soon. Product is also incredibly boring to work on although I don't personally mind as long as working hours stay low. Not a single person in the C-suite deserves to be there. They are driving the company away from being a survey platform (which we excel at) to being a management suggestion tool (which we're bad at and customers don't need). They set on this path when the economy was good, and many customers were shelling out for a luxury product and making decisions based on employee and customer feedback. But now that the tech economy is bad, decision making is driven only by profit, making Qualtrics' experience management insights irrelevant. For example, Qualtrics can tell Delta that customers want extra leg room on flights. But Delta doesn't care, they need the money from those 3 extra rows. It is a rare case when Qualtrics can provide an insight that 1.) is novel and 2.) is actionable in a profitable way.

Review Title: Qualtrics USED to be a dream place to work
Pros: - The best thing about Qualtrics is and always will be the people - Great perks and office space - There used to be incredible room for upward mobility and growth - If I was writing this review 4 years ago it would be very different. Pre-acquisition Qualtrics was a very supportive and great place to work generally
Cons: - Leadership is totally out of touch and doesn't give a crap about lower level employees. - Instead of cutting the CEO's disgustingly high salary, they laid off 15% of the workforce with an additional 10% to come. - They preach diversity but couldn't care less. They cut their entire DEI team and the high level people at the company are primarily all white mormon men. Women and BIPOC people are grossly underrepresented. - They will not consider hiring people who do not have a 4-year college degree which is a really outdated and classist practice. - The general vibe especially in the Utah office is cult-like and oozes toxic bro culture. - Mormon culture seeps into company culture and is uncomfortable for non-LDS - The general strategy for where the product is going is a total mess and real innovation is extremely hard. It's more arguments than productivity. - Because of terrible leadership moral is at an all time low - Back in the day, I would've recommended working at Qualtrics to anyone. But as it is today, stay away.

Cons: Nothing, it is a really cool company

Pros:
Terrific benefits like an experience bonus for $1,800/year USD, a wellness bonus for $1,200/year USD, inexpensive health/dental/eye care, contributions (matched or unmatched) to an HSA with a high-deductible healthcare plan, free snacks and food options (e.g., fully-staffed cafe, drawers and refrigerators full of snacks, both healthy and unhealthy, in the Provo office).
Excellent high-pay, stock shares (although Qualtrics is no longer publicly traded), and merit-based bonuses.
Cool culture with artistic and beautiful decoration and building design, casual attire, hybrid work model with 3-days in office (Mon & Thur, and one additional weekday determined by your department head), A younger & energetic workforce at mid-to-lower level positions.
Cons: The company is in a seemingly constant stream of changes.

Pros:

Cons:

Pros:

Cons:
-Too many empty promises ex: not doing promotions, cutting bonuses due to not rating us one quarter, inconsistent on "how" to get promoted and the process is pretty inefficient.
-"Hybrid" = come into the office 4 days a week which is tough because when many of us started, it was suggested to come in 2 days a week.
-Layoffs will happen (the layoff process was also highly unprofessional and chaotic. There is no "right" way to do layoffs, but there certainly is a wrong way.)
-Upper management was disorganized and never felt trustworthy

Pros: Love the people. Some of the sharpest, kindest employees out there. On the ground, it's a great place to work if your manager is solid. Great perks and very flexible. Work/life balance is unbeatable.
Cons: Lots of high level change. Higher managers seem to evade accountability. Some recent organizational changes with internal hiring/promotions that still isn't quite fleshed out. Interested to see career progression path.

Review Title: Sweat shop ran by the unaccountable
Pros:
Daily meals and well stocked pantry 
Smart colleagues 
Great external branding (scammed me too)
Cons:
Extremely poor onboarding, severely lacking internal alignment between leaders, functions and geography's, Spent more time on broken processes and seeking help from support teams than actually selling.

Every internal team only focuses on maximising and over charging customers instead of actually doing what’s right.

 Deal sizes/closures are little to none with average sale rep achieving between 20-25% by end of FY

Local leadership are cut throat and cunning. Huddling together to scheme and protect each others.

Beginning to suspect that churn in sales staff isn’t as organic as reported

Review Title: Come back in a few years
Pros: Good Pay, Benefits, Co-Workers, Offices, Free Lunches
Cons: Qualtrics was a good company to work for but now its just a puppet company to a private equity firm. Ever since we got acquired by an private equity firm decisions have all been about money and leadership are just copying other companies playbooks in order to reach our goals rather than taking the risks and losing face or making improvements. Everyone looks at spreadsheets rather than people. Our goal is to go public but that usually means that it is all about looking good according to the numbers. This means that a lot of the good things about working here were cut since they didn't really cut our pay. High performing workers (layoffs, and silent resignations), promos(once a year and very few slots), and outsourcing (just for cheap labor and more money) just to name a few. If you are a bright eyed worker wanting to work for a company to do good in the world and work at a purposeful company I would stay away until we go public again. If you are a 9-5 guy just doing enough to get by but don't really care about the company vision by all means come join the fun.

Pros:
- Company had somewhat of a growth phase
- "Swaggy" vibes
- Some people were great to work with
Cons:
- Company thought it was the best company out there, and made people eat it until they'd believe it. In all reality, the people thought that they had just been there so long that they either had to believe it or they were simply in luxurious positions due to the length of their employment. That makes for an interesting experience when you've seen better workplaces.
- Sales, sales, sales. There was no real solutioning for prospects, and parts of the product that no enterprise would want to use because they have their own analytics and dashboards already were forced down people their throats because that is where the money is when you're just sending survey links
- Office attendance enforcement was stupid, even pre-covid let alone post-covid
- If you don't work out of one of the two (at the time) major office hubs you will truly see how stupid all the enforced branding and hype is
- Seen leadership make some really ridiculous comments in company-wide meetings
- Once everything connected and I was doing over 100% of my target (in a supportive role) not even half way into the fiscal year, people started being nice, but at that point I was fed up with the company, because it's all glimmer and smoke
- Everything was about the stock price. Nobody ever envisioned how the customers would really experience value, and with that how that would lead to growth and higher company valuation
- I then saw people get laid off, and I knew that was coming way before it happened, because one has to be blind not to see it coming

Pros: Fun offices, free food, cool coworkers
Cons: Despite all of the big bets about increasing gender equity, etc., Qualtrics is the most sexist company I ever worked for. Just some examples: 1. Look at the senior leadership team. Most of the time, very little representation of women at the highest levels, and when there is, it’s usually in people ops or training/enablement. 2. I know for a fact that at least one male coworker who had less experience than I did started at the same time at a notably higher salary than me or my other female counterparts. 3. At one point, I learned that no woman on my team had ever gone on maternity leave and been allowed to come back to her same book of business, and only one had even been enabled to come back to her same role. Nobody ever thought to create a coverage plan policy to help avoid this. 4. Managers actively discourage men from taking their fully allotted paid parental leave. 5. The ratings system and policies mean that women who go on maternity leave are set back as much as a year when it comes to promotion opportunities, even though they are often only gone for 12 weeks. Any equity in representation seems to devolve to tokenism and making numbers look good. I am sure that much of this inequity comes down to unconscious bias stemming from the LDS roots.

Pros: The compensation is pretty good if close deals.
Cons: It is nearly impossible to get paperwork. Internal processes are a mess and constantly changing.

Review Title: If you want your function to be valued, do NOT work at Qualtrics
Pros: Until they were bought by a private equity company in the summer and recently laid off 15% of the workforce and told another 10% that they would be replaced by low cost workers in Mexico City in March, I can say without a doubt that Qualtrics was a company with incredibly talented, kind, and amazing people. I met and worked with some of the most wonderful people at Qualtrics.
Cons: Leadership: Where to start. First, the leadership is an absolute abomination. Other than a couple with Microsoft experience, the rest are inexperienced outside of Qualtrics. They do NOT value diverse perspectives, and if you push back you are silenced. Diversity: All of the President level and all of their direct reports are men. The majority are white, Mormon men. Women have no seat at any table. And it's worse for people of color. Valuing the function of PMM: From the top leader on down, there is no understanding or value of the function of PMM. They think PMM makes slides and have reorged in a way that anybody with a heartbeat is put into PMM. Some of the people are brilliant in their own area whether that's Solution Strategy or Industry, but simply assigning someone "you're now a PMM" when they have no certifications from Pragmatic Marketing and no experience truly doing inbound and outbound PMM is just absurdity. It's truly heart-broken to see the trajectory this company has made. The laid off people are the lucky ones.

Pros: Great training for anyone starting sales
Cons: Slow progression and can wait 3 years to be an AE in some cases

Pros: Very little positives these days. A few good people left, but the whole office is looking for a new job.
Cons: Probably the worst company in Dublin to work for right now. Senior executives treat staff extremely poorly. The Dublin office has lost it's lead and has suffered from heavy job cuts. Private Equity are focusing on lower cost locations for short term gain. So sad to see this once great company come crashing down. The founders should be ashamed of themselves.

Pros:
Teammates - my peers have been intelligent, driven, and helpful. I have developed personal connections that will impact my long-term career.

Industry - customer experience and employee experience are fundamentally positive concepts. You can feel good about the work you do because the ultimate goal is to make companies treat customers and employees better.
Cons:
There have been an abnormally large number of negatives working for Qualtrics.

Toxic Positivity - a large majority of the company would prefer you act positive and enthusiastic all the time, even if there are problems to be solved. Bringing up problems gets you labeled as difficult to work with and can negatively impact your career progression. You also wind up getting ignored a lot.

Product Roadmap - the leadership and strategy for the product is severely lacking. For a technology company, it’s a bad sign when there isn’t a clear strategy and path forward. ChatGPT and other LLM-technologies also represent an existential threat that leadership doesn’t seem to acknowledge.

Arrogance - most middle management or senior level employees believe they are such experts in experience management that they often talk down to customers and coworkers. Even if you join from a competitor, they will make sure you understand that they are the experts and your previous experience does not count. This was not specific to one team; it is a characteristic broadly across most customer-facing roles. Customers often get frustrated by this arrogance because experience management theory doesn’t always align to the practical implementation that customers are experiencing.

Pay - excluding engineering and excluding Utah-based employees, the pay is average. Various benefits, including health benefits, are quantified and accounted for when talking about compensation, even if other companies only use your base salary and bonus by comparison. It is a disingenuous way to artificially inflate your compensation.

Resistant to Change - the company is constantly talking about the past. The hyper growth era for the company is over but most tenured employees refuse to adjust their mindset to the current state of the company. Tenured people get promoted into roles because they might be able to guide the company back to where it was 5+ years ago, when the reality is that new voices and skillsets are desperately needed. There are also a lot of people (~30%+) that have never worked for another company in their career.

Pros: Coworkers are kind and friendly and typically don't hesitate to help others. The common employees are the best part of this company.

Top level leadership is incompetent, greedy, and hypocritical. Employee experience is the last thing on their minds, and it has continued to plummet with the recent acquisition by private equity, SilverLake.

Review Title: People are great, leadership is untrustworthy and incompetent
Pros: Coworkers have your back, middle management is great. Depending on the client, you find rewarding work for yourself.
Cons: Leadership is way too in your business. Announcing big changes every month it seems. Can’t trust them. Layoffs each year since I started. People are unsure of the long term success of the company.

Pros: -Amazing teams and co-workers -Great Pay -Sometimes you can see the impact products are having on customers and it definitely gives you a feels-good moment. -Work life balance used to be good before the current economy. -There's a lot of products that have a clear success path for the company.
Cons: -Low PTO -Leadership has no idea what they are doing, and the company is being run to the ground. They mandated return to office and gave most remote employees an ultimatum to relocate or get laid off on top of the most recent layoffs and other employees simply got told they would be let go in March next year. The relocation letters had no compensations other than being told you'd be reimbursed (no details on dollar amount). They did another round of layoffs even after we did one at the start of the year and they told everyone there wasn't going to be another one this year. There's no transparency and instead of even offering pay cuts or doing pay cuts across the board (including the CEO) they would rather just bleed valuable talent from every single team in the company. Most people I talked to don't see themselves sticking around long term (me included). Maybe if things get better.

Pros: I enjoyed my time here

Review Title: Good place to work before silver lake acquisition
Pros: Good Pay, good work life balance

Review Title: Good Intentions, Leadership Lacks Direction and Follow Through
Pros: Qualtrics hires really smart, charismatic people that I generally loved working with - I made some close friendships I'll maintain for years to come. Benefits like the experience bonus and wellness reimbursement were great. For the most part, the work-life balance was manageable, as long as I wasn't working on X4 (Qualtrics' biggest event of the year).
Cons: Most of my cons come down to the quality of senior management. There was a lack of empowerment, trust and respect - despite hiring highly experienced people. People are asked to work on projects that were completely shut down or reprioritized once senior leaders got involved - including in efforts that leaders didn't need to be involved in. Lack of transparency, which led to a rampant, toxic rumor mill. Very office-centric culture; Qualtrics asks their employees to work from an office at least four days a week, and recently either let go of remote workers hired during the pandemic or is forcing people to move closer to an office.

Cons: Qualtrics C suite is out to lunch. Qualtrics SDR leadership has decided not to promote anyone to AE like was promised and guarantied, making this entire job pointless. You will be promised to be paid corrctly, and they will lie. Quota will go up and up, and your managers will micromanage you to death. You only matter as a moneymaker for your SDR manager. They will refuse to promote you cause it stops the gravy train for managers. The last time they increased salary for SDRs was 2019, inflation is more than 25% since then. Whatever you do don't work at this company.

Pros: Surrounded by great, motivated, educated, innovative, people

Review Title: It’s gone downhill and it will be a long time before it’s good again.
Pros: The team I work with directly has generally always been supportive and great. It troubles me, because when I started working at Qualtrics, it was truly an exciting and fun time, and all of the friendships and trust we built is shattered.
Cons: - Qualtrics said our pay would be adjusted for COL in Jan 2023, and instead they laid people off. I know some people from my level making 12k less than me for the same job function. - They took away one of two promotions cycles that happen each year, so now people have to wait a LOT longer to get promoted, if they even do. The process is long and painful as it is. - Most people who work at Q will tell you they have change fatigue - SLT has no clear path or direction, so they just make changes frequently (weekly at this point) to see what works and what doesn’t work. A week without some sort of change is all I ask for. - Processes make no sense and often result in angry customers because issues take so long to address - The platform breaks with one wrong move. - No career path for my team once you become L5, L6, etc. - Laid off most of the DEI team - how is this not important to this company?

Pros: Great people and decent perks.
