I absolutely delivered, got top ratings in my performance reviews, and believe I was well liked by my peers; but I never did get the promotion I was after, and eventually I allowed myself to be hired away.

Pros: Pay is competitive including RSU and bonus. Work is challenging and there is plenty of opportunity for career growth.
Cons: "Ohana" is just propaganda. The don't value their employees any more than any other large tech company. Don't drink the kool-aid.

Pros: Tableau Swag and network opportunities
Cons: Little guidance to conduct workshops

Pros: Great benefits, nice offices, and somewhat competitive pay.
Cons: Leadership disorganized and making half baked decisions. Unnecessary layoffs and no direction. TAMs, get ready to take on more responsibilities outside of your role and pay grade.

Pros: Excellent teamwork very collaborative and supportive
Cons: Can be complex integration for larger organizations

Review Title: Salesforce is killing us quarter by quarter
Pros: - Benefits are nice - They pay me some money
Cons: - They are making our metric unattainable - they are pushing out employees - they are ruining Tableau - They are forcing us to go back to the office - They don't understand Tableau at all

Pros: Good work life balance Exciting Work
Cons: Pay could be a bit better

Review Title: Decline of a great company under Salesforce
Pros: Great product Smart and skilled coworkers
Cons: Distinctive product culture is waning since Salesforce started micromanaging Revolving door of executives in charge Values are given lip service

Pros: Amazing place to work. Great work-life balance and you have the ability to advance your career and learn a lot!
Cons: Not many cons to work here.

Review Title: Salesforce changed a once great culture
Pros: Great people, still mostly work form home
Cons: Inconsistent promotions cycle, odd product direction

Pros: Great Culture, Great Product, Great Customers
Cons: Tableau is no longer a stand alone company. It is now part of the Big Tech world. Great news is it is owned and operated by Salesforce which is one of the Best Big Tech Companies to work for…

Pros: Amazing colleagues to work with
Cons: Layoffs earlier in the year affected some folks morale.

Pros: Brand recognition keeps your pipeline full, and inbounds are extremely common. This is where the pros stop for me Amazing parental support (parental leave, fertility support, out of state abortion assistance)
Cons: This job was an amazing opportunity however the amount of responsibility you have versus the time you have to get things done is ridiculous. The processes here are not fully defined and are extremely time consuming and long (especially on the tableau side). To get a quote out it takes two approvals with no discounting and extra approvals if discounting is needed. Approvals can take days and you will constantly be submitting SOP requests. The work life balance is not there at all, and the remote workforce is a detriment when it comes to onboarding, training, promoting a culture, team cohesion etc. The differences between the way Tableau reps are supported vs Salesforce reps is astonishing and creates division in many cases. My biggest complaint is purely just that the entire company feels like everyone is purely a number.

Pros: * Great product * Good brand recognition * Good benefits
Cons: * Lots of red tape * Not the best for upward mobility

Pros: The people are genuine, hard working, and care about each other. The benefits package is fantastic with 401k match, exceptional healthcare insurance, wellness reimbursement, etc. The pay is in-line with other tech companies.
Cons: Culture took a hit with the Salesforce integration - i.e., Salesforce employees come first.

Pros: There was a core of great, intelligent, driven people at Tableau that made it a total unicorn. The provider was best of breed and the sales org was driven to succeed.
Cons: Once Salesforce purchased the company, the Tableau culture disappeared. As did all the previous leadership.

Review Title: Good company with lots of challenges ahead
Pros: - Great base salary at the principal engineer level - Many different internal opportunities
Cons: - Adapt to market changes too slow

Pros: Tableau is an amazing product with radical fan base
Cons: Salesforce killed the momentum, the culture and now Tableau is simply lost. It was amazing while it lasted.

Pros: Compensation is good, people are smart, work is interesting.
Cons: Layoffs are a morale killer.

Pros: Managers are great, no micromanaging, sales process is easier based on segment and sales cycle. Product can sell itself most of the time.
Cons: Pay is below average. Since migrating completely into Salesforce, Tableau reps merged under Salesforce reps which caused major disparity in patch/territory size for all afterwards = less pay overall in commissions. Optimistic it changes with major changes to new fiscal year though.

Pros: Great office, fun company culture
Cons: Not diverse, culturally or racially. Poor management from Salesforce acquisition onward

Pros: good people and everyone supporting your growth
Cons: lot's of turnover with leadership

Pros: work-life balance very good, people are nice to work with
Cons: n/a, everything is good, pretty chill to work there

Pros: Passionate about the product. Love the people I worked with
Cons: Salesforce couldn’t track sales and we’re messing up commissions. People started leaving in droves. So I bailed

Pros: Good company and good software
Cons: It was better before Salesforce acquistion

Review Title: A shadow of its former self
Pros: If you are looking for a slow and steady corprorate job - Salesforce/Tableau might be good for you.
Cons: People say that the company has been on a steady downhill trajectory since the Salesforce acquisition, but the reality is that the decline has started long before that. In the early days (late 00's and early 10's) the company had a truly innovative product and an amazing team that revolutionized the BI market. Now it just follows the rest of the industry, building features that on paper address the latest Gartner's hype cycle but in reality dont do anything for customers. (other BI vendors are guilty of that too). After the acquisition many teams have been absorbed into the Salesforce mothership; there is basically no more Tableau.

Review Title: Used to be awesome. Destroyed by Salesforce
Pros: This was probably the best place I've worked for a while.
Cons: And then Salesforce took over and is destroying everything that was good about Tableau. All the Tableau leaders who were well respected are now gone as are many of the strong individuals. Hard to imagine more of a culture clash between the great collaborative culture that Tableau had and the cultish culture of Salesforce.

Pros: Great Environment. Loved my co-workers.
Cons: When massive lay offs started, there was an abysmal aura in the work place.

Pros: The product is awesome. It's easy to sell a genuinely awesome product you know can help people. The product is an industry leader and SF is even bigger so the names alone help the sale.
Cons:
SF killed the company I loved. Tableau wasn't perfect but it was pretty amazing all things considered. Big enough company to carry a global name, yet there was a lot of room for creative freedom regarding how you owned and operated your business and your time. 

SF completely murdered all sense of individuality and creativity. It's extremely corporate now. Red tape everywhere. Everything has a process... almost all preposterously long and convoluted. More mandatory trainings than I've ever seen... I have nothing against training if they are actually going to bring value. But they roll out mandatory trainings just to tick boxes. 

TOTAL LACK OF DIVERSITY. OMG, can we have more white men in leadership roles? Nope. Just an endless sea of mediocre white men who only want to lead for the titles with their bros.

Pros: Great company culture, 401k plan, ESPP, good WLB
Cons: The future of Tableau in Salesforce's roadmap is vogue. Many people got laid off in the early January which indicated the unpredictable org change and individual career challenge as an employee.

Review Title: WAS the best company I ever worked
Pros: Tableau was truly a special place. Wonderful people on a mission to help people see and understand data. It felt like everyone was trying to move in the same direction to achieve a common goal. I really enjoyed coming in to work and my teammates.
Cons: The Salesforce acquisition led to a gradual decline. While at first we were hopeful that there was an opportunity to both learn from SF and have SF learn from Tableau, it became very clear that SF leadership had limited desire to incorporate strengths from Tableau. At the same time, the ability to make decisions and / or make any progress gradually disappeared. As a result, many of Tableau best employees left.

Pros: top name company - great mentors to learn from
Cons: Culture has changed drastically since becoming a Salesforce Co - upper management seems tone def to the state of the company's impact on its workers.

Pros: Great Culture and Benefits Package
Cons: Sometimes need to work longer hours

Pros: Good product, culture and team
Cons: Internal processes and integration issues

Review Title: The glory days are in the past.
Pros: Great people. Great product. Good benefits.
Cons: Post Salesforce acquisition there have been a lot of changes, re-orgs, and revisions of strategy. Resources are very tight with the hiring freeze that has been in place for some time, and now we've lost ~10% of our workforce. The latter has caused low morale and overwhelming work on those who survived.

Review Title: A planet being torn apart by its new star.
Pros: Tableau has wonderful people who've built some really amazing products, and a very creative and caring fan base. There are some very interesting challenges at this time to work on as well. They pay decently well, and have good but not great benefits (i.e., Salesforce vs say Google, Facebook or Microsoft).
Cons: The Salesforce acquisition. SF is not creative and an online only business, Tableau is a desktop and server business with online extensions existing in a creative space. SF doesn't understand either context and will destructively copy Tableau into whatever it thinks Tableau should be. Until Salesforce finishes this process there will be a huge amount of chaos,  ambiguity, and churn. People will leave at a high rate, context will drain and you'll have something completely new once complete. Luckily they've put into place a hiring freeze to spare new folks this experience.

Pros: Benefits, perks, potential of the salesforce ecosystem
Cons: No plan for my position, never really felt a part of the company (either Tableau or Salesforce. Left just before layoffs started as I knew this wasn’t where I needed to be nor would it get better.

Pros: Great product, nice people, decent pay
Cons: Salesforce's processes are becoming too much

Pros: The product! First and foremost, getting to learn how to use the product and the ability to get certified for free in Tableau is an amazing opportunity. If you are lucky to have a good manager, Tableau is a great place to work. It has great benefits, great people, and a great foundation to build your career on. You have the opportunity to travel. You have access to a data structure that will teach you how good analytics software should work. They have a lot of programs for the employee benefit: Lyra Health, a hotline for minority employees to get help (not very helpful), employee groups…but they still struggle with DEI. But they are at least aware of what needs to happen and make an effort to be considerate/inclusive. Decent annual/quarterly planning.
Cons: I got stuck under two terrible managers back-to-back. One manager I reported to HR. I know of three other women that reported him to HR and they still protected him and gaslit us all individually. Although I was told I was exceeding expectations during performance reviews, I never received a raise or promotion. My career growth was stagnant here and I saw no way up rather than getting out, in which I was able to start at a new company making $30,000 more. Tableau was acquired by Salesforce, which is also still making it difficult to be at Tableau right now. Salesforce has a bit of a cringey culture that can be toxically positive. There are also obvious pay gaps between employees doing the same level of work but they’re able to make it acceptable by keeping underrepresented groups at lower levels. Some incompetent mid-level managers who are good at puffing their chests and using buzzwords.

Pros: Great Culture for a big company
Cons: Roadmap changes frequently so you have to adapt

Pros: Fair Pay PTO whenever Wellness
Cons: Mired by Salesforce processes Lack of innovation in BI space

Review Title: It was a great introduction into the software world.
Pros: I loved all the opportunities to grow and learn ( World-class training, coaching, mentorship etc... ) We also had a two-week boot camp that helped us get familiar with the product and refine our selling style.
Cons: At times it felt like a boys club, especially in leadership. The woman leaders we did have were very in their masculine and unrelatable. We grew very quickly and it felt very clunky. Communication was siloed within the orgs. and often times was conflicting ( For example we had a foosball table in the kitchen but told not to use it.... I didn't care about Foosball, but to me it seemed like the company wanted to seem "cool" for the outside, but that was not the reality we where living..) The atmosphere felt very negtive the last couple years I was there and I did not feel supported.

Pros: We have some of the best leadership, mostly those coming from Tableau (not Salesforce...sorry SF). The leadership of Tableau is the BEST and I have had a lot of managers in my life. The SF acquisition is still shaking out, and their values and how they treat employees is not the same as the amazing Tableau leadership. I am m not saying everyone is perfect by no means, there are some Tableau SE Managers that I wonder how they got there....but the majority are AMAZING. I love this company
Cons: They are losing a lot of people because of PAY. Pay your people more and they wont leave. We do the work, we give results, and we should be paid. You will pay more in training, attrition, paying out benefits than just paying people what they deserve

Pros: Smart coworkers, laid back culture, excited customer base, good pay and benefits
Cons: Constant reorganizations (mostly due to Salesforce acquisition), development is very slow now so bugs don't get fixed

Pros: Great product, great culture, great people
Cons: Since Salesforce acquisition, the things that were special about Tableau have been systematically dismantled leaving an atmosphere of distrust and resignation (literally and figuratively).

Review Title: Nice people, not best coding practices
Pros: Good WLB!! People were very nice. :) Manager helped me be more confident in my coding abilities.
Cons: not best coding practices... I wish there was better documentation so that I could use less handholding for my project.

Pros:
* Truly excellent product to be proud of working on
* Super smart and kind folks to learn from
* Solid benefits, including paid volunteer time off
* SF actually does throw its weight around on social & environmental issues in a way that makes you feel good
Cons:
* Salesforce made a GREAT sales pitch about the acquisition, but that good sales pitch isn't reality
* Senior and tenured employees are leaving in droves — far more than a typical M&A — due to changes in how work gets done, talked about, and prioritized in the new Salesforce world
* Most employees do NOT use the product anymore and have no incentive to do so — and no repercussions for straight-up refusing to learn (a thing that is becoming common)
* It has become harder to operate in ambiguity and harder to operate in general with all the extra SF training, enablement, weekly All Hands, VPN-switching, clunky security (sometimes 2FA more like 4 or 8FA), and admin overhead
* Fewer opportunities for internal mobility and compensation growth
* A lot more "just outsource that new headcount to India" behavior
* The stock cliff has gotten far worse after the acquisition for lower-level employees — higher level ICs and managers are looked after marginally better

Pros: Tableau used to offer excellent Support until the SF takeover. Training was excellent and knowledge resources were abundant. Great eclectic team to work with of the smartest people.
Cons: Since the SF takeover support engineers have been asked to do more and more with less and less. Nobody can keep up with increased expectations, and pay has stagnated. Experienced techs are leaving and not being replaced, or being replaced in Hyderabad. Former paths for advancement seem to have been cut off.

Pros:
Management is concerned about their team and the well-being of the individuals.
Easy to use PTO without feeling like you are a burden on other team members
Colleagues are ready to help you with cases or take them over when you are out.
When there are issues upper management really does try to fix them.
The majority of the customer is awesome.
Interdepartmental communication is good and account reps are very helpful.
Direct report managers are the best.
Cons:
Feels like there is a disconnect from ground level to upper management on some topics.
Moving up is sometimes ambiguous (depends on where you want to go)

Pros: You get paid and you get some sort of corporate experience.
Cons: If you’re into being micromanaged, undermined, and treated like a kindergartener, this is the job for you. When you can and can’t take your PTO is extremely controlled (i.e. three black out days at the end of each month and eight and the end of each quarter), sales will walk all over you and management will do nothing about it. Over half of Deal Desk’s work was transferred to OM without any adequate compensation or tangible training. This team is continuously treated as entry level when this is clearly not the case - it was three years ago but once DD decided to hand over the majority of their work, this team requires some form of experience in the workforce and for some reason managers continue to hire people with no form of knowledge. Tableau is notorious for underpaying their employees - making less than $60k in tech while living in the city of Seattle is just unacceptable. There is no encouragement for career growth. Since COVID hit, management has had no regard for personal time and increased the work load while barely addressing a worldwide pandemic. Management has failed time and time again to have any sort of communication skills with their team. Seattle is full of startups - apply to literally any of those before Tableau.

Pros: very interesting using the software to analyze media trends
Cons: no cons very good working environment

Review Title: Drowning in technical debt and building more
Pros: Flexible work schedule with work from home
Cons:
Management doesn't prioritize the long term solutions and so everything is done as quickly as possible:

1. Building code takes a very long time.
2. Wiki docs are all out of date.
3. The code is very complicated and doesn't seem to be getting better.
4. We use deprecated technologies like Saltarelle that barely limp along.

Pros: Lots of opportunity to learn and grow, great product that lots of customers like, friendly environment
Cons: Starting to feel more corporate after acquisition (pro and con)

Pros: Product is amazing & helped define a new category for visual analytics
Cons: Acquisition was a drawn out process & integration was slow

Pros: PTO, medical benefits, Annual reviews
Cons: Have their favorite people for promotions Raise is way low than expected

Pros: Great culture and great energy very smart people
Cons: some ways of selling are old school

Review Title: Great Company Going Through Growing Pains
Pros: We have amazing benefits, culture, and product. It is an amazing place to work
Cons: Currently experiencing high attrition and growing pains due to the integration of the Salesforce acquisition.

Pros: Great people to solve problems with. The opportunity for the business, customers, and employees now that we are part of Salesforce
Cons: The company really struggles with implementing change, and we are going through a lot of it right now. I have lost track of how many re-orgs we've had this year

Pros: Great leadership with a clear vision for the future
Cons: Tough to navigate internal Salesforce at times

Pros:
Easy atmosphere to work in

Since acquisition, senior management usually doesn't last longer than a year so if you aren't happy you can wait it out
Cons:
Tech stack is ancient and they are still trying to manuever it to the cloud properly while bleeding employees

A lot of long tenured staff is leaving as the cliff hit and Salesforce no longer reups stock.

For a product designed for the cloud, it's about 3-5 years behind on conventional things like build tooling and systems.

Pros: Great Culture, Camaraderie, and Teamwork
Cons: Not too many Cons that I can consider

Pros: Love it! Great culture and product
Cons: No complaints. It was it’s downs but overall great company

Pros: Good company to work during the pandemi.
Cons: -Culture is not as good as it used to be. - Product has become a commodity.

Pros: Good benefits, good work life balance
Cons: Not much career growth, not much vision

Review Title: Good People, finding its way in the Salesforce ecosystem
Pros:
- Passionate people
- Focused on customer success and learning new ways to bring value
- Generally care about the employees
- Lots of decent benefits that came from the Salesforce acquisition
Cons:
- Lots of people churn at the moment from the great resignation
- Role/org churn as the integration with Salesforce and business alignment matures. It is expected, but change is not "just" change for many.

Pros: technology and health care benefits
Cons: Over worked and under paid. Once you get in you will not be able to get pay increase easy if at all.

Pros: The job is very great
Cons: Not much is wrong with it

Review Title: Great Company, great culture, too much middle management
Pros: This is an incredible company to work for. One of the best work environments you could ask for.
Cons: Company has too many middle managers who seem to get in the way of sales teams.

Pros: The leaders, the colleagues, the products, the benefits, the job security.
Cons: Working through the challenges that resulted from the Salesforce integration.

Pros: Tableau is a great place to work - kind peers, great benefits, a strong culture of rewarding success and supporting through growth
Cons: As Tableau became a Salesforce company it transitioned from a scrappy startup culture to a massive tech company in HR leveling. Once it was easy to move to different teams and try new things- now it is "you are lucky to be in the position you have today- so what makes you qualified to move?"

Review Title: You will feel more like a number than an employee.
Pros: Friendly and helpful coworkers. Coworkers are the main driving point for this company and those you work closely with are more than willing to help you succeed.
Cons: Transparency from management and upwards. There are never clear information in regards to the direction of Tech support and any response from management and upwards is usually evasive followed up with them justifying their decision rather than showing a clear understanding of employee concerns.

Review Title: loved working for tableau, sad when things changed after acquisition
Pros: tableau had an amazing culture. I had never experienced a workplace like it. management & even upper management was great, very down to earth and truly wanted to see you succeed. i'm very grateful to have had that experience.
Cons: things changed to be very corporate-y after tableau was acquired, which was expected but still a bummer

Pros: Work life balance, autonomy, and great pay
Cons: There’s nothing so far I don’t like

Pros: Great Culture, Customer love, some of the best people you will ever work with
Cons: None, other than growing into a large company poses typical challenges.

Review Title: Hyper growth mode - lots of opportunity and lots to do
Pros:
Hyper growth with aggressive goals - budget being invested in Recruiting resources
Great growth opportunities, no matter where you want your career to go 
People first approach driven from CEO level all the way down
Company wide efforts to build inclusive, success from anywhere environment for remote employees 
Inclusive interviewing and DEI efforts are top of mind across the org which drives change
Strong benefits and focus on work life balance (wellness days, etc)
Giving back is part of the company culture (Volunteering Time Off, etc)
Cons:
Internal communication and resources are at times overwhelming
There is opportunity to take more advantage of our own products/customize them better for use in recruiting

Review Title: Great People, High Demand of Work
Pros: Down to earth and humble people
Cons: You will wear many hats and navigate a lot of ambiguity with the migration to Salesforce processes.

Pros: Friendly supervisors. Good company culture
Cons: Felt difficult to progress into higher level roles since hard work wasn’t rewarded. Promotions to higher paying roles were only due to time at the company.

Pros:
Great benefits
Tableau the product is great and easy to sell 
The people are awesome
Cons: Culture has crumbled in a remote world and with the Salesforce takeover. Feels like management is doing the bare minimum at all times for their team and only focused on improving their own career paths. No communication from leadership on the path to a promotion and lots of new rules because of Salesforce. Yet be prepared at the end of each year to be bounced to a new team or territory with zero say and then told you have to stay there for a minimum of 6 months. Sales enablement is a joke. Management spends zero time mentoring, training or even reviewing deals with their team. Pay is way below market. Nearly everyone is unhappy and looking to leave this sinking ship. Working with Salesforce Core AEs is a nightmare. Most are rude and condescending and actually are pushing Tableau OUT of deals but management is scared of SF leadership and so don't say anything.

Review Title: If you want to be paid what you're worth, move on
Pros: Benefits are fantastic, reimbursement programs are expansive
Cons: If you're a BIPOC, person with disabilities or a woman, you won't be treated fairly or equitably. You'll be expected to do far more above your job description and pay grade to even be recognized among your peers and if you want to have a work-life balance and separation you will be punished for it. Pay is not competitive for the market at all unless you're a new hire, once you're hired though you cannot make any sort of career advance internally.

Pros: Culture culture culture. And Mission.
Cons: Having left around the time of the merger, it's hard to say what it's like working for Tableau remotely as it has become Salesforce. Some of my friends have stayed and are less happy but still like it, and many others have moved on.

Pros:
Good Culture
Coworkers who actually care about the business and you
Great product
Cons: Management (directors and above) in solution engineering essentially let the organization turn due to lack of career growth and not listening to the team.

Pros: Remote, hybrid work environment. Salesforce is very considerate of individual people's tolerance for risk during the pandemic and prioritizes our health and comfort levels.
Cons:
Cannot overstate how underpaid and overworked existing employees are. Without RSUs anymore (removed during the Salesforce acquisition) many talented individuals have left for other opportunities and salary offers of 50%+ more (no exaggeration).

This has left existing Renewal Managers to "pick up the slack" often double, triple coveraging. Double coveraging has become the norm and status quo. This has lead to a general burnout and low morale. 

Migration to Salesforce system was horrendous. Completely under prepared (~2 hours of live training, several ineffective e-learning modules, hard to track documentation). Countless sleepless night and breakdowns for many Renewal Managers as Customers yelled at us for losing access to Tableau due to our inability to quote and renew on time. 

Leadership's toxic positivity. If you don't "drink the Koolaid" you're viewed as a negative Nancy, ignored and passed for promotions. The leadership team full of young, white fat boys with fragile egos can't take an ounce of constructive feedback. They will never own up to issues laid out by the team leaving persistent issues unresolved. The denial is deep. No wonder why everyone is leaving.

Tableau is gone and Salesforce has swept in to "scale" the business. Another fancy tech buzzword for automating our jobs away. "Scaling" is actively being accomplished with a multi pronged approach:

- replacing back fills with cheaper, contractors from the Philippines 
- tying our compensation to multi-year contracts
- defaulting renewals to automatically renew
- chatting with "bots" to get our job done. can't even chat internally with a real human being for help

Concerned about the job security of this role.

Pros: Inclusive company culture that values its people and empowers them to make a difference. Strong sense that everyone is rowing together in the same direction to serve customers and to delivery high value and results. Strong delivery discipline toward delighting customers and ensuring customer experience is very high.
Cons: There are a few growing pains as the Salesforce companies are integrated.

Review Title: Good benefits and they don't work you to death
Pros: Mental wellness days ( free vacation day for everyone) once a month. Unlimited time off in US. There is a bit more diversity then other tech companies. RCAs that blame failure of process/ system rather than blaming individuals. Managers that actually care about you.
Cons: Not transparent about raises. The support for the quarterly release across the company is dreadful.

Pros: Tableau has a culture that is unmatched
Cons: Since Salesforce acquisition, processes are dragged out and have taken away from the Tableau family charm. Before the acquisition, I loved working for Tableau because they were all about their people, but now that Salesforce took over, you are nothing but a number

Pros: Good management and intern managers care about the intern a lot
Cons: No downsides, glassdoor is awful though

Pros: the pay structure is a 90/10 split although this is changing soon to a 70/30.
Cons: not a lot of room for growth

Review Title: It's okay for me but things aren't the best for everyone
Pros:
- Reliable job
- Decent benefits
- Remote work
- Good team culture
- Semi work life balance
- Opportunities to grow
Cons:
- Salesforce is bring lots of changes that negatively effect us
- Senior management won't hire more people even though we need it
- Pay is kinda low compared to industry standard
- Not enough PTO

Pros:
Some of the smartest, most dedicated and humble people I've worked with
Great product and market driver
Customers LOVE the product
Compensation is generally good
Cons:
RSU and refresh philosophy now that we are part of Salesforce
Some attrition with old guard

Pros: people, leadership, teamwork, product, and vision.
Cons: There are always challenges when companies grow

Pros: The product is great and helps a lot of people. As a Salesforce company, receive great benefits. The office is nice and has free snacks
Cons: Instead of hiring more people, they load more work onto the employees. Little hope of change since upper management doe not listen to employee concerns and suggestions. Get stuck in a role waiting years for positions to open up to grow up within the company

Pros: The culture is absolutely fantastic, the leadership is great, and the product truly is a world-changing, industry leading platform that I sincerely believed every one of my customers should be using.
Cons: The acquisition by Salesforce significantly changed things, and in particular the role I was working which led me to leave.

Pros: For a big company, Tableau does better than most
Cons: Tragically, Salesforce has stripped Tableau of all the magic it once possessed

Pros: I love Tableau/Salesforce due to the flexibility, work life balance, successful management and great pay and benefits.
Cons: Still working through some growing pains with the transition of systems from Tableau to Salesforce.

Pros: Nice perks.  So so pay, profit-sharing made up for it.
Cons: Lots of good folks, but many inexperienced folks given senior positions, creating an immature atmosphere.

Pros: Amazing leadership, top notch talent, and great people to work with.
Cons: None at this time - great place to work.

Pros: I've been working for Civica (US) remotely for a little over a year, and I'm beyond satisfied with everything they have provided me. My personal life has been complicated enough, and my manager has been happy to accommodate me every time I've asked him for something. The willingness of my manager to listen to my situation and accommodate my needs has been a refreshing experience compared to my past work experience. We get a monthly, sometimes weekly video update from Lee Perkins, the CEO, who updates us on the stuff going on around Civica, and it makes me feel connected with the Civica workforce even though I live far away from everyone at the company.
Cons: I guess the job is a bit underpaid compared to similar jobs at my experience level, but personally due to their willingness to let me work remotely, and their flexibility when I need to take a few hours off for things like doctor visits and family errands makes me more than happy even with the monetary loss. Vacation time is also slightly lower than bigger companies, but you won't have to take vacation time for a 2 hour doctor visit, so it evens out.

Review Title: Run as fast as your leg can carry you, Useless management.
Pros: Nothing is good about them
Cons: Acquire a company but lacks direction, bad management who is clueless but only care about how to generate revenue .Worst place to work.

Review Title: Non Profit, Generic Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Company
Pros: Brand New Fill and Finish manufacturing facility with start of the art equipment. Building the company from the ground up; facility, processes, organization.
Cons: There are no cons to speak of.

Review Title: Too many talking heads, not enough accountability
Pros: I honestly can't think of anything that isn't above the bare minimum.
Cons: Management doesn't understand the private sector. There's too much oversight for common place things like paying vendors: It shouldn't take four to five months to pay less than $200. Or six months after the project for contractors to get paid. No one takes responsibility, a lot of internal finger pointing to other teams - probably the reason it takes so long to get anything done.

Pros: Overall positive culture and attitude.
Cons: Glass ceiling a kilometer thick. If you aren't part of the main branch you're stuck.

Review Title: US Side of the Company is a Dumpster Fire
Pros: They HAD some decent, dedicated people working there. Most of them either quit or were "let go."
Cons: Zero communication between teams. Company is in reactive mode, not proactive. DIrectionless. Panders to "lifers" and sets up new employees to fail. Relying more on overseas engineers and developers.

Pros: Amazing place to be at
Cons: Nothing I can complain about

Review Title: The company itself is wonderful, with many opportunities for development and learning.
Pros:
Great employee assistance.
Compensation that exceeds expectations.
Cons: For me there are no "cons" in working in a company as it is!

Pros: The employees at Civica CMI treat each other as a family. They celebrate with you when you're happy and offer great support in times of strife. The 401K matching is very generous. Civica has an agile environment; if appropriate for your position and duties, you may opt to work from home with approval from your manager. The CEO is enacting forward-thinking changes to the structure, organization and processes to position the company as an industry leader in municipal software. The office atmosphere is fairly laid back, and the workforce in general has a good sense of humor. Persons who hire in at entry-level positions have many opportunities to move into higher positions (and many  have done so within a year or two of being hired). The CEO is very tolerant of dogs and will, on occasion, allow someone to bring a pet in for a short time. This company is extremely patriotic, and greatly supports and appreciates military service. Many staff members are veterans and their service is celebrated. Certain positions within the company are compensated very well and above industry standards.  This company values diversity. They value college degrees, but also recognize industry experience can sometimes be as valuable as a post-secondary education. The company invests in workforce development by providing corporate training seminars. As a part of a global corporation, employees have opportunities to not only learn about, but potentially visit or be transferred to new countries.
Cons: The medical benefits are pricey compared to other similarly-sized companies. There is a lack of autonomy for anyone who is not in senior management or a sales rep. Processing time for normal tasks is slow (i.e., the company is run very democratically in that all senior managers must approve ideas, procedures or projects and it complicates and sometimes halts progress). When being hired, you are sold on a vision of what the company can be. The reality is that the company does not yet reflect what their vision is, although they are taking dramatic steps to make their vision a reality. As a result of this, newly hired employees sometimes feel as though they've been promised things that rarely (if ever) pan out. Many employees work many more than 40 hours per week due to the company having previously been run as "reactive" versus "proactive". While the company is no longer run this way, current employees are still feeling the effects and paying the price for leadership decisions that were made a over a decade ago.  A small portion of the employee base earns salaries that are 10-25% below industry averages.

Review Title: They at least make an effort.
Pros: They seem to make an effort, there's a lot of corporate BS and time wasting tasks that you have to do, but generally speaking if you've been acquired they leave you alone.
Cons: There can be a lot of bureaucracy which can get annoying.

Pros: I enjoyed working here. HR was fun to visit and managers are not afraid to dive into the code.
Cons: inter-personal relationships with among certain employees were strained due to differences in perspective.

Pros: Line managers have all been excellent, upper management seems to at least care about the employees. Good benefits and fair employer
Cons: It's a large company, so there is the general bureaucracy that comes with it.

Pros: Great people. They are warm and friendly with no major hang ups about me wearing my sandals to work.
Cons: No pot luck Tuesdays. Come on get with the times.

Pros: Love the people I worked with
Cons: No room for advancement...politics.  if you were a cop you get whatever you want.

Pros: Friendly team, great location, good company values and culture.
Cons: Senior Management is out of touch.  Hiring process is over labored with little to no communication or follow up.

Pros: Induction was good introduction to company.
Cons: Company feels highly fragmented at division level.

Pros: Great coworkers, good 401K match, older legacy software is still viable.

Development group completely unable to produce quality product and blames support and implementation groups for their own failures. Overseas owners have no interesting is fixing structural problems created by management. The company invested heavily in a series of failed products and have never recovered. I do not recommended working here.

Pros: family business, friendly co-workers, donuts on friday, fast pace, no cold calling

Pros: Its a job. Lower management is very nice.

Pros: Flexible, Process oriented, laid back culture
Cons: Not many career advancement opportunities

Pros: None that I can currently identify
Cons:
Well here we go on the redundancy merry go round again. For the 3rd time in under 12 months our team are facing another brutal round of redundancies from a leadership team I’m still not sure actually know what our products do or what our colleagues deliver for this company every single day.

We continue to make money for the company and deliver for our customers but that doesn’t seem to be enough. So we continue to outsource key business functions to India and fire good quality/loyal staff in pursuit of an extra sliver of profit.

It’s honestly hard to turn up for work day in and day out when you know your efforts aren’t valued or recognised, and that your years of hard work to build the business can be minimised in a heartbeat by leadership who have been here for barely two minutes.

Pros:
Work-Life Balance: The company prioritizes work-life balance, ensuring its team enjoys a fulfilling personal life alongside professional growth.
Global Exposure: Employees have the opportunity to work on diverse projects, gaining exposure to different cultures and markets.
Career Development: The company invests in employee development, offering training and growth opportunities that drive career advancement.
Innovation Focus: The company's culture encourages innovation, empowering employees to explore new ideas and drive impactful change.
Cons: Depending on a project nothing as of now.

Review Title: A Pinnacle of Professional Fulfillment at CIVICA
Pros: Working at CIVICA has been an enriching journey, where every day feels like a step toward personal and professional excellence. The vibrant and inclusive culture cultivated by the company fosters collaboration, innovation, and continuous growth. From visionary leadership that empowers and guides, to a commitment to employee development manifesting in tailored training programs and clear career paths, CIVICA has created an environment that goes beyond work; it's a community where each member is valued and supported. With a focus on both individual achievement and collective success, I find myself not just part of a company but part of a shared vision for a brighter future. CIVICA truly exemplifies what it means to love where you work. Collaboration is not just encouraged at CIVICA, but it's ingrained in the company's DNA. The synergy among team members is palpable, leading to the seamless execution of projects and a sense of accomplishment that comes from working together towards a common goal. It's not just about the work you do; it's about recognizing and celebrating achievements. CIVICA has a robust recognition system that appreciates and rewards hard work, fostering a sense of pride and motivation among employees. Innovation is not just encouraged; it's celebrated at CIVICA. The company's commitment to staying at the forefront of [Technology Industry/Software development, cybersecurity solutions, cloud computing services.] is evident in the innovative projects and the freedom given to employees to explore creative solutions. CIVICA understands that a happy employee is a productive one. The comprehensive benefits package, including [Doc Online,Medical Insurance and many], demonstrates a commitment to employee well-being and satisfaction.
Cons: I do not see one.

Review Title: Staff have fallen way down the priority list
Pros: Full of great people and interesting projects
Cons: For many years Civica valued staff massively, and this felt real and genuine. However after various restructures and new leadership this has disappeared. Now just feel like people are juggled to preserve the "unbroken growth". Talk of strategy hasn't filtered down to the levels of coal face workers.

Pros: Working from home…. Initially only changed due to covid. Management tried to get employees back into the office but failed.
Cons: Where do I start. I’ve never had a pay rise over inflation, normally below inflation. We had a ‘record breaking’ year apparently with a big well done off the CEO .. then a below inflation pay rise across the board. In the last 18 months there’s been 2 rounds of redundancies, a management restructure and a sell off. Nobody feels safe anymore in the uk, work is being hived off to India. Many capable experienced staff have left. Morale is zero, nobody wants to work for Civica , there is no goodwill left. The CEO may be a plant by our competitors. From an employee point of view in the uk he couldn’t have made us feel any worse. The day he announced ‘great news’ for Civica being bought out, about 40 staff were having their redundancy confirmed. Avoid Avoid Avoid.

Pros:
Good social events 
learning opportunities
Cons:
Changing priorities 
Sometimes unrealistic expectations
timesheet system that requires each minute to be accounted for

Pros: Good work life balance, WFM, great recognition and good hike.
Cons: No transparent career progression programs.

Pros: Work life balance, great people and some fantastic products that make a meaningful difference to our clients....................
Cons:
The change and new structure has opened a worm hole, lack of strategy and direction, hugely under resourced and we've lost GOOD people who held the knowledge and true understanding of the market, its products.... 

We need to advance our portfolio and listen to what our clients are saying. THIS could be a wonderful place and we need to put the time, resource and strategy in place.

Pros: The company values its employees and offers them a supportive and collaborative work environment. Provides the opportunity to learn new things and keep up with the latest technologies.
Cons: Nothing so far, everything is good.

Review Title: Nice office space and seating arrengment
Pros: Working stations are excellent and supportive team members.
Cons: Graduity would deducted from employee CTC. which would not clear either it get post 5 year or before that employee can leave the organization.

Review Title: Not the company it used to be
Pros: The people are fantastic , the one constant that make Civica a great place to work .
Cons:
Poor sales governance allows for incorrect sale of products and services . In turn this puts pressure on projects to deliver under tighter conditions ultimately ending with overly stressed staff. Sales people still receive their bonus despite poor sales . 

Staff are under paid yet expected to over perform . You can earn more with less responsibility at other organisations which in turn provides a healthy work life balance . 

Inconsistent working hours across multiple BUs.

Moving a lot of support of systems over to India , noticeable less quality of support at a cheaper price but customers still pay that premium .

Pros: Flexible work locations, great people, standard benefits.
Cons: Despite announcing record profits, pay rises were below inflation yet again. Another restructure has just been announced meaning a lot of very experienced people are facing the second round of redundancies in nine months. Morale has been terrible all year, suffered even more when pay rises were announced and hit rock bottom when the redundancies were announced a few days ago. Civica make a how of saying it’s the people that make he company what it is but it’s obvious that employees are just a number now. No-one feels like they have any job security now and we’re constantly expecting more cuts. Any jobs that can be moved to India are being, presumably because it’s cheaper. It’s great being able to work from home but local offices around the country have been closed over the last couple of years meaning that unless you live close to one of the hubs you feel very isolated. I haven’t seen any of my team in person in over a year. Civica used to be a very social company but there are no social events now. It’s a pretty miserable place to be at the moment.

Pros: Super nice , friendly and inclusive company culture.
Cons: The software can seem plain weird but it's because the government bodies buying it don't usually install or configure it properly.

Pros:
Work from home 
Pay on time
Cons:
Internal Promotion process
Not offering a competitive salary

Pros: Great people who really want to be put to use. Flexible working. I believe new c suite have good intentions but comms from them seems to miss and deflect from the cons - addressing how we are going to change for the better.
Cons: Morale has gone down the drain. We say our culture is what sets us apart when there is no culture anymore - most people work from home. Staff with the experience and knowledge don’t want to engage with new starters/early careers because of this. That’s why everyone’s leaving. There are webinars and affinity groups but no one wants to spend most of their working day on calls with customers to then join another call to ‘socialise’ with team or get involved in wider initiatives. Working relationships are very superficial because of this. And managers don’t care. Those that do work from home are treated inferior to those able to go into offices in terms of access to opportunities and promotion. Talking about pay is effectively red taped and people (managers) don’t like it.

Pros: Remote working and the remaining colleagues
Cons: Civica used to be a great place to work at, but things took a nosedive late last year during the restructure mess. Morale is rock bottom and the remaining team have either lost interest, jumping ship or planning to if things don’t improve. There is a recruitment freeze which means positions for people leaving won’t be backfilled and their replacements up to speed until long after they’re actually required. The managers have been pushed into their new roles with a load more responsibilities and are about as clueless as the rest of us. I’ve even seen some line managers holding back tears over this so please, no generic responses – we need some real help here.

Pros: Good community, positive collaboration and good benefits
Cons: Salary isn't as high as alternative competitors

Pros: Civica staff and our Customers

Expenses are covered by the company though. It's all dependant on where they can get the work, so an aspect of the business model to consider before joining this sort of company.

Pros: excellent & supportive team in the case management function
Cons: I know of nothing that I would consider as a Con

Pros: As many people are saying, this doesn't seem to apply to our current working environment.
Cons:
I'm unsure what we're trying to achieve. Why am I expected to know or be able to explain to product owners what I am doing. 

Keep hoping someone is going to explain the bigger picture. My boss is focused on miniscule priorities, rather than what we need - which is a minimal viable product ready for consumption.

Pros: I don't feel like I'm alone, noone knows what they're doing.
Cons:
Working 50+ weeks, nothing is ever good enough, data is a mess and somehow this is my fault. 

Generally no guidance or knowledge is forthcoming from the people I need it from. Railroaded on calls into approving what cannot be explained. Even when you manage to do what is expected, more work is thrown at you, you cannot win.

Pros: Remote working, half decent benefits.
Cons:
Was always a decent company to work for, but not anymore. New CEO has come in, and the old exec have all left taking decades of experience and knowledge with them. No idea what the new CEO brings to the table, other than liking the sound of his own voice. 

Company now in the process of being sold (again) and with that comes a large number of job losses (again), and as per the exec, years of knowledge and experience all walking out the door. 

Everything now going to India where possible, UK based staff are almost an ‘afterthought’ these days as company only interested in getting as many jobs offshore as possible so they can pay the staff peanuts. 

Software gets ridiculed by end users but management only worried about adding more features that don’t work, rather than trying to fix what is already there. 

Pay rises have been pretty much non existent the last few years, and any that have been received are below inflation, despite all the ‘corporate waffle’ from the CEO about the ‘best year ever’.

Pros: Great company to work for, plenty of opportunities if you want to pursue them, lots of perks and benefits are available as well as regular pay reviews. Communication from all areas of the business worldwide is sent out and everyone feels included, regular updates from the CEO give a friendly feel to all business areas. A very supportive company to work for.
Cons: Lots of departments are still homeworking rather than office based which has its downside, but lots of support given.

Pros: no leadership, no direction, high volume of work and expectation, rude incompetent managers who are appointed and are incompetent. high staff turnover as the environment is toxic and there is racism, favouritism and hiding the information.
Cons: The management is chosen from old staff who have no people and technical skills and are betting on outsourcing to India to push the development. The team is very disoriented and political, and management is praising each other.

Review Title: Asset stripping ongoing at what is simply the worst place I have ever worked
Pros: The only pros have been the people, but those with decades of experience are being made redundant and replaced with graduates, or doing what is best for them, and jumping from a sinking ship.
Cons:
I have worked for seven years for Civica. I perform a specialised job, and have a first class degree from a top university, and working for Civica has ruined my confidence in my aptitude. I have received seven years of outstanding appraisals, which have not been rewarded in any tangible way. In the seven years I have worked here, my salary has increased by less than £5,000. The upper management of the company waxes lyrical about the consistent topping of the last year's profits, but this isn't seen by those of us overworked on the ground. 

I, and some of my senior colleagues have petitioned to management for my promotion, but because I have been willing to speak out on the iniquities we face, I have been persona non grata with senior management for a while now. Colleagues who joined at a junior level to me in other departments regularly have starting salaries of £7,000 more than I am currently on - and that is after me giving seven years to the company. With the recent cost-of-living crisis, I had to apply for Universal Credit because my salary is so abysmal - in a specialised job, this, to me, is absolutely unforgivable. When I spoke to one of the senior management team about this, I received the following rebuttal: "well, not all of us have noticed the cost-of-living crisis, especially as I haven't got a mortgage anymore". For me for a couple of months last year, it was choosing between paying my rent and eating, and those higher up the chain haven't even noticed the difficulty the rest of us we have been having. My rent went up by 20%, but I have received a real-terms pay cut for the past three years.

If you are considering working for Civica, I would actively discourage you.

Pros: Good Policy. Management is quite helpful.
Cons: Hike is not as per the market standards.

Pros:
Very welcoming to new employees and staff at all levels are extremely friendly and supportive. 
Company is proactively inclusive and everyone is valued and treated with respect.
I have been pleasantly surprised by the flexibility managers have demonstrated, regarding working patterns and supporting staff with caring responsibilities. 
My experience is that the company cares about its workforce and managers are very approachable.
There also seems to be good opportunities for career development.
Cons: As a home worker it would be good to attend occasional meetings in the office, as I miss the social contact with colleagues.

Review Title: No job security, becoming a mess
Pros: Flexible working is widely embraced making it easier to achieve a good work/life balance.
Cons: Yet again the business announced record profits whilst providing below inflation pay rises. Yet again we are going through another round of restructuring with associated redundancies (5th in 8 years I think). Each time we're assured this is it, this will set us up for the future, no more of your colleagues will be lost... then 12-18 months later it starts all over again. The business cannot function if it keeps losing its most experienced and talented employees. Our customers are losing patience. It's gotten to a point where it's clear the business just wants to reduce costs so it can pay higher dividends to its shareholders; it does not care that those who are left are having to work harder under more challenging conditions to try to prop the business up. It appears the business's main desire is to slash UK staff to a bare minimum in favour of cheaper staff costs in India... just be honest about it.

Pros: Highly professional and friendly team.
Cons: There is no negative I can think of.

Pros: The people - most working so hard to try and keep it all going.
Cons: Saddened at all the comments on here. The only positive ones are from colleagues in India. Really upsets me to see how bad it’s become when it used to be so great. And in such a short space of time. People are treated badly. Blame culture so people afraid to speak up. CEO and new exec totally destroying what was built up in the 17 years prior. Such a sad thing to see.

Pros:
Writing software to help people in various government departments.
Home working is acceptable and not penalised.
Cons: We've lost over half of our team in 'restructuring' exercises, but the work has remained the same. Knowledge is allowed to walk out the door, moral is at an all time low with everyone but the staff in India. Any new dev is moving to India, staff in the uk are ignored, passed over and left to maintain creaking software or given stuff from people who've gone and expected to simply know it all immediately. Foxpro? Jeeze. Who knows Foxpro any more. Our entire HR team was removed, probs because they'd try to fight our corner. Any values and ethics they had have gone in the past two years, now its all about the cash. The official christmas do this year is an extra hour at lunch time. Even the pension contribution hasnt kept pace with industry standard. its at 5% if your interested.

Pros:
Competitive salary
Generous holidays with ability to buy extra
Caring and understanding company, make you feel no problem is too small
Enjoyable work that makes you feel you are helping people
If you are not happy in the role you are doing, will listen and try and help to the extent of changing your role
Robust ways of working
No pressure applied, even when under pressure
Appreciation and praise freely and often given
Cons: No ‘local office ‘ in South Wales

Pros: Some good colleagues but now they are looking to leave
Cons:
Civica keep deleting or asking negative reviews to be deleted. 

The company isn’t a good place to work at the moment. The software is dated expensive and half developed. 

I wouldn’t recommend working at Civica at all. I am using my time to find a new job

Pros: Flexible working hours and ability to work from home
Cons: nothing to report on this subject

Pros:
Colleagues (what's left of them)
Flexible working
Home working
Cons:
Sweeping redundancies based on job title and nothing more.
Aloof senior management, together with HR (sorry "People Team") have handled recent redundancies terribly.

Lee Perkins (CEO) has never even acknowledged any of these redundancies when he sends us a "special" video of his latest dog-walk (I mean, really?!?!) You're not in the real world mate and the more you're in denial the more people see through your smiley videos!

All work is going to Vadodara in India.

Salary increases (if not frozen) were 3% for our team, not great when inflation has been closer to 10% - and this when the company boasts about record profits. 

Cue HR's standard response " I would encourage you to talk to your line manager or a member of our People team so we can understand how to best support you in your specific situation" I mean as if... I'd be out the door in a flash..

Review Title: Here lies the skeleton of a fantastic culture
Pros: The flexibility of remote working
Cons: The culture of Civica used to be fantastic and something to be proud of being part of ! People felt valued, engaged and rewarded but this is sadly, no longer the case. More recent times have brought a general feeling of being overworked, undervalued, overlooked and under appreciated.

Pros: New leadership team, increased learning opportunities for skilled/experienced individuals, complex challenges to solve and most importantly/excitingly - maturing practises and using cool tools.
Cons: Nothing comes to mind right now.

Pros: Opportunities to progress and diversify skills if you put in the effort. Very clear and transparent communications from management. Great salaries for entry level jobs (above market averages). Gaining employment is based on your abilities and potential making it a great place for people to enter the corporate/IT/government contract world. A very diverse and open work place for people of all backgrounds and lifestyles.
Cons: Performance reviews have been rebranded to focus on "personal growth and development" rather than rewarding staff financially with bonuses or salary increases for exceptional performance. Middle management/team leader salaries are on the lower end and a lack of progression opportunities after that level.

Pros: Remote working and free fruit when you go into the office.
Cons:
We've lost so many people recently, I am struggling to understand the thought process around those that have been kept.

I've spoken to my new manager twice. They were not receptive to discussing what was required from my team the first time we spoke.

The second time we spoke I was advised in no uncertain terms that I was not doing what is needed

Review Title: I wouldn't if I were you
Pros: I have a second interview next week, at a different company.
Cons:
My job (apparently), is to serve citizens, by ensuring they get the best possible outcome from our products. 

Unfortunately, I no longer have the tools to do this job. I have a new manager who not only looks like they are at breaking point, they don't understand my product. Coupled with the fact we have no visibility. of our pipeline (new system) or tangible targets and objectives is making my job untenable. 

I appreciate change was needed, however change needs to be delivered with an understanding of how targets and business objectives can be met.

Everything is currently a mess.

Pros: The people are great to work with
Cons: Not very good at what they do

Pros:
Progression only if your face fits,
Employee assistance and good benefits.
Cons: Investment in people only when it suits them, senior management not interested in individuals just profit, low pay for work expected.

Pros: Fantastic group culture in the team. I've come across one of the best in the Marketing Field, with open and talented individuals.
Cons: Big company problems. Can be challenging to work within the limitations of the company guidelines to create impactful campaigns. This, I believe, has been ironed out since my leave.

Pros: People are great, the team spirit as you watch the ship go down is great.
Cons:
A good company being driven into the ground by distant clueless management who just trot out banal buzzword statements while having no clue what anyone does nor how to grow the business.

Poor pay, lots of gimmicks. Training is available untill you ask for it and then you have to do it on your own time.

Every corner that can be cut will be cut with no thought to the consequences.

A HR department that just puts cut and paste statements about "talking to your line manager" in response to everything.

Pros: Good work, good culture, good policies
Cons: Sometimes work-life balance needs to be maintained

Pros: People, social side, meeting new contacts
Cons: Restructure has mixed up teams - Management really have no clue how what we wanted. Left to our own devices.

Pros: Civica gives bonuses every 6 months
Cons: Below average salaries. Poor promotion prospects. 5 days of 1/2 day training which is not enough. School librarians were from factories or were retrenched, many could not use PCs, expected to do everything from cataloguing books, take care of loans, help teachers to supervise students outside of the libraries, follow the orders of school managers and teachers, without respect or dignity, at salaries of $1,300-$1,500 a month while Civica charged MOE $400 a day for a school librarian, i.e., $10,000 for 25 days.

Pros: I wish it wasn't mandatory to put five words here, as it suggests there is actually a pro.
Cons: Everything - every morning I feel more anxious then I did yesterday. I'm constantly firefighting and what ever I do isn't good enough to satisfy my new boss.

Pros: Good commission structure and excellent incentive/perks
Cons: This role was completely remote

Pros: I'm not able to honestly give information in relation to this
