Cons: Little to no pay raises, bonus is small, rarely have opportunities for advancement

Pros: Hired me with no IT workplace experience WFH Call volume not too high Mostly nice co-workers - loved my Team Great first IT job to have, then move on to something better.
Cons: Very low pay The three weeks of training was mostly sitting around, or shadowing co-workers taking calls for companies you weren't training on. While most calls are easy, you will get screamed at every now and then. Some of the more experienced people would belittle people who came to them for help. Some co-workers really get away with slacking off, hardly troubleshooting, and relying on others on their Team to do basic things Supervisor was nice, but didn't really do anything but sit in meetings all day, wasn't very knowledgeable about our clients

Pros: It's a job that can be worked remotely.
Cons: No advancement opportunity, no development, no positive change after years of feedback. They will fire employees to give their jobs to more "connected" individuals. They do not interview or post openings to management, they appointment people to them.

Pros: Flexible ish scheduling Vision plan is cheap It’s like impossible to get fired
Cons: Everything Low wages Horrible management Even some of my coworkers were not great people Hiring nosedived

Pros: benefits were good for family or individual
Cons: high volume and pressure on employee on the helpdesk teams

Pros: The ability to work remotely
Cons: No annual pay increase and no growth within the company

Pros: Logicalis is a 24/7 365 MSP. They are pretty flexible regarding your schedule. I was able to create a custom part-time schedule that fits around my other job and class schedule.
Cons: As with all jobs communication could be better at times

Review Title: Highly overrated and over ranked not a fortune 500 stay away
Pros: Logicalis has great teamwork and highly skilled employees. The base pay was excellent, and there is an opportunity for certifications and training. Unlimited PTO is only great during your employment, not when you leave or when you get laid off
Cons:
This company has a great reputation for stability and no turnover rate but not anymore. It has been ranked as a great place to work and on the fortune 500, similar to other top decent organisations, but unfortunately, all those rankings are bogus and don't reflect that at all. A decent organisation that lay off its employees should be a great place to work, and fortune 500 of how they treat people when they let go. I have worked for similar organisations before and was laid off previously by other organisations. They have paid vacation pay, generous severance pay, and cash pay for cobra, and if you get a bonus, they will give you a suitable amount to reimburse for the bonus.
At Logicalis, I haven't got any of that, and the severance pay they offered was rubbish and stingy. Termination of unemployment is never a favourable decision to any employee, but decent organisations would not leave employees suffering. I have reached out to Management to revise severance but they don't care and they just replied with a standard rubbish email. The summary here is if you stay at Logicalis because they are stable, then that's not the case anymore, and if you are offered employment at Logicalis vs other organisation, then you better choose others. Also, If you have left Cisco/IBM because of their high turnover rate, then maybe go to them and leave Logicalis as they will take care of you when they terminate your employment

Review Title: Good foot in the door to IT
Pros: Lots of hands on experience to diverse support environments
Cons: Subject to additional account responsibilities with short notice

Review Title: Nice people, constant change, little to no progress on goals.
Pros: The people around you are pretty good people. Middle management, pretty good people. Work-life balance for the grunts in the trenches tends to be pretty fair. The DTO/unlimited PTO in most groups actually is quite nice, and you don't get any grief for actually taking it when you want it - this actually became my standard for my future job search.
Cons: Getting into the Director and above realm, you need to have a meeting to discuss the meeting that precedes the meeting to accomplish absolutely nothing. I feel bad for the people managers because the amount of red tape and ego management required to get any changes made to simple internal processes is near insurmountable. Company is solely sales dirven. If you aren't sales or sales aligned, dont expect much $$ past your initial offer in raises.

Pros:
(+) Little to no skill required
(+) Work from home
Cons:
(-) Management is not your ally.
(-) Extremely low paw
(-) No formal structure to grow

Pros: It is a good place to work for students because they have flexible schedules and will work around your school schedule
Cons: They do not pay well They make broad scope changes that for the bottom line profits Because of the broad scope changes it drops the moral of the employees

Pros: They give you a lot of autonomy, and trust you to do your work on your own time.
Cons: They are going woke and it’s becoming frustrating every so often. They put too much emphasis on things that have nothing to do with work

Pros: Enjoyed working with most of the folks there.
Cons: The company is pushing “digital transformation” and a VAR trying to turn MSSP. They are missing the mark in a big way. If you’re in sales I would STAY AWAY.

Pros: You can work from home
Cons: You work for Logicalis, which isn't a plus

Pros: Benefits are reasonably good and PTO policy is generous.
Cons: Executive team is disconnected from many, and continue to focus on the next thing.

Pros:
Management good
Training good
Fellow coworkers great
Cons: Promotion difficult to obtain. Hiring from outside preferred.

Pros:
Flexible work hours,
They pay for certs,
They can move you to diffrent desks to improve your skills
Cons:
Low pay,
Mangers are super busy

Pros: Great learning experience when you have to jump right in.
Cons: Not enough training to prepare you for your role.

Pros: Great leadership, clear communication, and honesty.
Cons: Semi-Frequent Restructuring/Reallocation to accommodate for new business landscape.

Pros:
So much room for growth
Great management
Great benefits
Cons: Needs longer time for training it’s only two weeks

Pros:
Pay is great
Coworkers are helpful
Supervisors are always looking out for you
Benefits are fantastic
They like to promote from within
Cons: none, this is a great place all around

Pros: Management has been great. Colleagues are very helpful. The experience so far has been educational. Great place to get your foot wet in IT.
Cons: Onboarding was a bit confusing; however, it worked in the end.

Pros: - Logicalis is a good stepping stone for people with no experience and looking to get their foot in the door.
Cons: - Once you have the experience, do yourself a favor and look for a company that will value your time

Pros: Great culture, good pay and benefits
Cons: Growth potential, salary increases communication

Review Title: Good company to start tech career with
Pros: Laid back place to work
Cons: Training could be better and more frequent

Pros: The people are great! It was a pleasure to work there. It was one of the best places I have ever worked at.
Cons: For me it was a long commute.

Pros: Great exposure to many facets of the IT Industry and Environment
Cons:
Poor Collaboration with teams, Little to no bonuses or recognition. 
No involvement in community. Long hours and shifts, then log-off with no interaction.

Pros: Flexible decent company with typical average treatment of people.
Cons: Unfortunately only cisco offerings and not very much options.

Pros:
Plenty OT available
Benefits where ok- high premiums though
Cons:
Very low pay for area
Low opportunity for advancements

Pros: Flexible and Friendly with an emerging tech culture and opportunities to grow.
Cons: I don’t have much on cons they do their best to grow the talent that’s there.

Pros: Good Benefits and pay with flexible schedule available
Cons: The management could be better

Pros: It's not stressful. You have opportunities to learn and grow, and there is good management.
Cons: Sometimes it feels like you're being micromanaged and you would get a call asking why you logged on 2 minutes late and it's like woah, calm down.

Review Title: Great team, Management leaves something to be desired
Pros: Great coworkers, lots of hands on learning opportunities if you are seeking out the right people. You get touch everything from vMware to Linux
Cons: Slow wage increases, Poor management and leadership that is slowly changing for the better but still has a long way to go. No shift preference and lower than average pay.

Pros: Great place to work and remote friendly
Cons: Vision or direction isn't always clear

Pros: Great management team and supportive environment. Lots of room for growth.
Cons: No issues thus far to report.

Pros: Nice management,Good benefits and Good PTO
Cons: Career progression and salary rises

Pros: Good entry level company for people new to over-the-phone technical support.
Cons: Some difficult calls may occur.

Pros: I enjoy working at Logicalis
Cons: Initial pay is low but after 3 to 6 months employees get a raise

Review Title: Overall a meh place with some perks
Pros: Great family oriented environment, Great pay and benefits
Cons: Sales only go for the quick sale, leaving you without work to do.

Pros: Good co-workers, good benefit grogram, good work/life balance
Cons: Recently laid off 10% of the workforce because of 1 bad month of profits.  Left a bad taste in the mouth of most remaining workers who are now overworked, under valued and just waiting to be next on the chopping block.  This company completely kisses the butt of any high performing sales person but does nothing for non-profit driven employees who are the bread and butter of the company.  They love to give away extravagant prizes as part of sales contests, like sports cars and vacations, and then rub it in the faces of the rest of the workforce.  The put on these extravagant sales meetings and the annual Presidents Club trip, but can't even afford to provide a decent Christmas party or company picnic.  If it's not a sales function, it will be put on as cheaply as possible.  So unless you are a highly skilled technical person or in IT sales, I wouldn't bother here.

Pros: Used to be a good place to work with good people
Cons: Bad management came in and ran the good help away and made it a toxic environment

Pros: Nothing to complain. Everyone is nice and friendly. Work life balance is awesome.
Cons: Nothing to complain. Keep up with the good work. People need to work harder.

Pros: Great place to work... I would recommend to everyone
Cons: 10 years but no complaints

Pros: Good Company, fair pay, good mgmt.
Cons: long hours, no coverage to take time off

Pros:
good environment
good co workes
fast computers
Cons: bad pay, bad compensation, nothing else bad about this company

Pros: Great people and talent, New CEO is outstanding along with management
Cons: Need to hire more people due to growth

Review Title: Tremendous place to grow and develop
Pros:
I am very confused by some of the previous reviews as my experience and those I talk with has been markedly different.  There are a lot of opportunities to develop yourself professionally, as long as you are willing to work for it which is the way it should be.  There are ample opportunities for career development and training which had been missing in the past.

The work life balance is tremendous with the ability to work remotely for some positions when needed.  Benefits are also very competitive.    

The technical resources from both a support and pre/post sales perspective are some of the best I have ever seen.

The new leadership in place is just that, leadership, which may have been missing in some key areas in the past.

Overall it is a company with an incredible amount of hardworking and dedicated people who want to do their best to move the company forward.  They listen to their employees and make realistic changes when needed.
Cons: The business is incredibly spread out geographically, especially from a leadership perspective which can make collaboration difficult at times.  Internal tools are not the best.

Pros: I currently work at the Service Desk and am extremely happy with my job.  The work is challenging, but I'm learning more and more each day, which ultimately is going to help me with my career.  The Service Desk management team is great.  They are friendly and don't micro-manage.  I did see a previous review mention that communication was lacking and promotions were hard to come by.  I'm not sure where that came from because the Service Desk currently has monthly 1on1 sessions, an agent led performance improvement team and monthly team lunches with agents and management.  There has also been over 15 people that have been promoted from the Service Desk to our Managed Services division in just the past year or so.  I'm happy with the opportunities and management team and work hard each day so I can earn my opportunities.  Overall, the company is a great place to work and see myself being here for a long time.
Cons: None that I can think of...the phones ring alot, but that's my job :)

Review Title: Great potential for growth and success
Pros:
I was surprised to see some of the negative reviews here.  They are not representative of the experiences I have had and I wanted to share a different point of view from some of the other reviews here.
The company is dispersed across the US and the world making for opportunities to move and grow.  There are amazing and incredibly smart people at Logicalis that I feel very lucky to work with.  We have customers that have been with us for many years and we are growing.  The company looks to the future and has an exciting vision for the future.
Cons: The distributed nature of the company does make a consistent culture a challenge, but I know it is a priority for the company.  I also know I can reach out to anyone and get the help I need when I need it.

Pros: New leadership, team building, new opportunity, new training potential, teamwork is improving, morale is improving!  Getting positive about the improvements.  New management open door policy!
Cons: Workload is heavy sometimes, could use more people on staff in some areas of our business, specifically in the customer facing support areas.

Pros: Nice people.  Benefits. Nice people.
Cons: Expecting well paid, seasoned reps to help change the company by selling new solutions, when they do just fine with the old ones.  The same approach year after year and get 10% involvement by Sales at best. Trying to hype and 'spin' the company to success, while continually taking the same approach.   Become disenchanted with the ranks who don't own the customer relationships, while the number of VPs increase with no real business impact.

Pros: Logicalis is a reseller.  Simple as that.  Your success is based solely on the accounts you bring to Logicalis.  You need to validate these customers will follow you in your career change.  Assume 50% won't follow you.  Opening new accounts under Logicalis will be very difficult if you do not have a strong customer relationship.
Cons: They'll hire you for $30K only to get your current customers.  Cheap investment for Logicalis.  Not much creative pricing strategy, they want their 35 points on Services and a minimum of 6 points on Cisco.  Cisco talent leaving Logicalis, they burnt them out.  Vendor relationship is based on location, HP & IBM.  Leadership very weak, non-strategic, almost humorous.  Keep in mind, a salary of $30K sets the bar for the next job, not a good message.  Again, Logicalis is fishing using your reputation.

Pros: You are allowed some flexibility in your work arrangement, depending on your role.
Cons: Not the best place to work, unless you are just looking for a short term "stepping stone".  Although the company is trying to implement a career development strategy for its employees, I've seen all talk and very little action.  There is very little chance of advancement here, so you're best to move on after a few years.  Your personal career development is only as effective as the manager you work for.  If you work for someone who resists change, doesn't like to be challenged, and is a fan of doing things "the way it's always been done" (which is the current mindset of most mid-level managers here), then you are doomed to fail.  Recognition and promotion is primarily based on who is best at kissing the boss's back side, rather than competence.

Pros: Once in a while you get to eat the scraps leftover from sales meetings.
Cons: This company is big on buzz words like "development" "culture" "values" and "integrity".  They talk a good game but It's all just smoke and mirrors.  Another review made a joke about cannibalism, but it's actually pretty sad to see how they devour people here.  I would bet that all of the positive reviews have been written by the HR staff.  They are overstaffed in that department and have plenty of time on their hands, let's face it.  My best advice is to run far away from this nightmare, if you have any self respect or pride.  I stuck it out for a very long time hoping that things would change for the better but they did not.  The executive team will back their management staff to the bitter end.  Bullying and harassment are common and also tolerated.  If you dare to make a mistake, however large/small or correctable, you will be raked over the coals for it but your manager will take zero accountability, they will even throw their own employees under the bus.  So much for a culture of teamwork, it does not exist.

Pros: This company has a history to be proud of and overall it's a good place to work.  The company has great benefits and competitive salaries.  Great employees with awesome technical ability.
Cons: It's too focused on selling anything that a customer will pay for instead of focusing on what we do really well.  We are always chasing the next shiny object without performing any analysis as to whether there is any real money to be made.  Frequently the company expects a well thought out product without giving the resources to do the thinking.  Most people have multiple jobs/hats.

Review Title: Company has come a long way
Pros:
The company switched from a strict form of vacation to an open vacation policy. So no more being burned out throughout the year just to save 2 weeks around the holidays. 

The new management is constantly working to improve performance, quality of life and overall focus.
Cons: People above local management still do not understand what it takes to really make the business successful and make technical decisions based on their perception and not the technical viewpoint. They would rather suffer and buy something small than get the right device for the job.

Review Title: Good company to work for. Good benefits. Remote opportunities and many offices allow you to stay with them.
Pros:
I have enjoyed working at Logicalis since day one. Everyone is always willing to help you learn something new, or get something done on a project - even those outside of your team/region. I feel comfortable going up to anyone in the company with a question or comment - this goes all the way up to the CEO.

Logicalis helps their employees progress by offering new training/learning opportunities, and they even help employees transition into new careers, whether it be a lateral or vertical move.

Great benefits and colleagues.
Cons:
There are times where the processes are too slow. This is the case at most corporations, or big companies, so it is not a big deal, but it can be a pain when trying to wrap up a project.

Account executives & sales teams have the most say. A lot of other employees in the company have to cater to them.

Pros:
Half of the managers/leads are very solid.
They are smart hard working and receptive, the other half........

One manager in particular would "go to bat for you" 
Could come across hard, but in reality actually cared about his team

Very nice office, co workers were great very few bad apples
Cons:
positions just didn't seem to open up, good for those people, not good for people like me wanting a new challenge after a year.
people largely stayed where they were, even more lateral moves like changing accounts wasn't  common

monthly reviews, they are short, have little information that helps you, and the one complaint that was leveled at me I couldn't get any information about. 

not in regards to which user complained, but even exact nature of the complaint.
so that clearly helped no one. How can you fix an issue you have are not aware of???

Pros:
- Career Path program
- Great medical benefits packages
- Salaries based on current market trends for IT support and management 
- Discretionary vacation time - no need to worry about "banked PTO"

Logicalis values their employees as much as they value their customer base. Management constantly requests feedback from employees on improvement ideas and sees them through to fruition! Communication is solid between managers and employees and the open door policy is prevalent across the board in all departments.
Cons: A company that is growing at the pace that Logicalis is will always experience growing pains in regards to acquisition adjustments and personnel changes. While this occurs, the outcomes are no different than what you would experience at any other company that is growing. Change is inevitable and you simply have to move with it or get out of the way.

Review Title: Just another cog in the wheel
Pros:
Limited travel for engineers
Sales people are treated like royalty
Great lower-level management - the only reason I stayed as long
Cons:
The culture of just five years ago is dead and gone
Salary/bonus not on par with industry for engineers
Sr management is out of touch
Unless you are directly involved in the sales process, you do not matter.
Little to no upward mobility
Not recommended for office staff, network engineers or project managers - none of these positions matter to the upper management.

Pros: Decent pay, friendly and knowledgeable coworkers and good people to work with.  Continuous education is definitely encouraged and paid for by the organization and there are good vendor relationships in place with major vendors, which allows employees in technical roles to learn a lot and put knowledge under their belts.
Cons: The culture is terrible and management always finds someone to blame when something goes wrong.  Middle management and upper management in the Managed Services division are mostly clueless and they maintain a culture of fear and intimidation among employees.  When something goes wrong, the question asked is not "how do we fix it" but rather "who's fault is it?"  Processes are very immature, and the entire organization is driven by quarterly sales numbers rather than real concern for customers and employees.

Pros: Great technical minds for those in the trenches, some of the sharpest folks I have ever worked with, decent benefits (prior to currently offered).
Cons: No tangible recognition for those doing the work.  Recognition came to those who won the business, rarely to those that supported it.  New senior leadership's vision is based on a continually moving target.  New seniors came in and used the "Bulldozer" tactic, as they do, to fill roles with "club members" further expanding the gap between the management team and the folks working for them.  Complete disconnect between Senior Leaders and the folks manning the guns.

Review Title: Ok place if your just starting out in IT
Pros: Hires entry level personnel, can work around school sometimes and co-workers are friendly. Holiday and other office events are fun. The experience is great if you are lucky to work a more technical account.
Cons: Very poor management: too many bosses, too much micromanagement, no incentive to do more than just enough to not get fired (think Office Space). There is very little room for professional growth, non-competitive wages, management cares more about the clients than their employees, and it shows. The way everything is run has a pungent corporate drone atmosphere.

Review Title: Could be a great place to work
Pros: People there are great to work with and are generally very supportive and willing to help out.   Staff is very focused on delivering quality to their customer  and do a very good job despite the lack of any leadership.
Cons: Management in the Tempe office think they are a cross between Steve Jobs, Ray Kurzweil and Tony Robbins and aren’t really any of them except in their minds.  There is a complete lack of leadership in the Tempe office it’s all about  being self-directed and self-motivated which is management talk for leave me alone I’m busy thinking of the great next disruptive technology never-mind there’s a business to run.  But keep thinking those positive thoughts because your awesome.

Pros: I had to write five words here to submit the review.
Cons: Time tracking nightmare. Almost non-existent raises, seemingly not performance based. Senior management is primarily focused on sales instead of services. Zero career path in managed services. New job recs are filled with outside talent rather than training current staff.

Review Title: Logicalis used to care about its employees, but has gotten too "corporate"
Pros: Salaries are slightly higher than the industry average, however pay raises are small and infrequent.
Cons:
Too much in-fighting between departments
General mistrust of management
Poor communication from the top down
Zero career path
Policies are unclear and arbitrarily enforced
HR is not there for the employee and the worker bees have no voice or rights

Review Title: NO leadership at the Senior VP Level
Pros: Great people, highly technical, great support methodologies, potential to become great if they course correct soon
Cons: Sales Leadership produces poorly and is not held to account. Operations leadership has nothing but their own career and best interest in mind and will lie to progress. These leaders say and do what the can to survive while providing poor leadership and communication to the employees of Logicalis.

Pros: You have an opportunity based on your own determination to learn a lot in the IT field. Hours can be flexible and the colleagues are fantastic.
Cons: management. You have got to do a better job at being a leader. Communication is lacking, rules and procedures are constantly changing based on the situation (big business no-no) and seemingly they will only change if you are about to be proven wrong. NO opportunity for advancement. If you do well, you will be stuck forever.

Pros: Logicalis is a global company with a wide variety of solutions to offer to all companies.  There is concise direction and leadership in place to achieve strategic direction.  The company is full of great people who have a passion to assist customers and employees successful.
Cons: As with any organization and certainly within this industry, there are challenges.  It has been my experience that Logicalis works to address these challenges in a way that benefits the customer, the employees, then the organization.  This is a formula that i believe will continue to lead to success.

Review Title: Working hard is the name of the game here.
Pros: Hands on technical gear, Partnerships with vendors including HP/IBM/ Cisco. Hardworking sales force; hardworking suport staff. Company appears to be growing in a slow economy. Business models seem sound. Service offering is extensive. For the most part you have the tools needed to do your job. Training is valued.
Cons: Can get overworked if you allow it. More work than people. . Growth can be painful; the "bottom line" rules as is the case most everywhere. Culture is too separated in silos. Cross team / intra team communication, effort and work all need increases.

Pros: This is a very good place to start if you do not have any experience. If you have or are planing on getting your A+ certification, this is a really good place to get your experience because you will be handling issues that will allow you to use your A+  and grow your tech skills. That is not the case everywhere. The pay starts at $15 an hour. It's better than most helpdesk positions where the pay begins at $13.00 an hour. You do have to pay for your benefits. The health Insurance is pretty good. If you are looking to move up in the tech world, there is a Network Operating Center with Network Administrators, System Administrators and Server Administrators. The company likes to have a monthly birthday celebration where the provide cake and ice cream. There is also a sales meeting every three months where they give you free pizza. They really like to feed you here. There is also a free pop machine. They give put out free fruit every Tuesday. They also give away free Tiger tickets once a year even though the seats (and the team) aren't very good. The people are pretty friendly. If you are a tech, anime, video-game, PC nerd then you will fit in here. I'm not trying to be condescending when I type that. The Helpdesk Operations Manager is fair but he does hold everyone to a high standard. If you do your job and keep good attendance, you won't have to much to worry about.  This place is growing as well. They continue to get contracts and the team leaders will stand up for you if a customer gets rude. I've also seen quite a few people get promoted to technical and managerial roles. They have a award here call "Rock Of The Service Desk". If you win, you get to have dinner with the CEO, the buy you a prize and you get promoted. They monthly drawings for perfect attendance. If you win, you get an hour of free PTO or a parking pass to the underground garage. Its's not glamorous but it is there way of showing you they do notice you.
Cons:
There are too many manager. There are about eight of them here. Luckily each manager has their projects that they look out for. However, I really think it could be more efficient if they had team leaders for each contract. 

The dental benefits are trash. They are cheap but not very good. You get one free cleaning per six months and the co-pays are expensive once the work gets gone. I got a root canal in March and that sucked up my entire insurance for the year. I did not know that dental insurance had a cap before I started here. 

They promote form within but once you get chosen it can take over a month to get to your position. I guess that there is this policy that promotions can only be done on the 1st of every month which causes the NOC to hire from the outside. It's just a faster process. 

The raises are not very good. I think it is something along the line of 38 cents after the first year. 

you get a lot of vacation time but you have to complete with everybody on the desk instead of just the people you work with on whatever contract you are on. Good luck with trying to get a day off on a Friday. 

You don't get holiday pay for all federal holidays.

No tuition reimbursement. 

The temperature control in this building is bad. Its always too hot or too cold. 

People have had their lunch stolen. Seriously

The managers don't do any evaluations so it is hard to get feedback on your performance. 

If you can, get a nightshift because there are no mangers around to hawk you. They sometimes like to micro-manage.

Review Title: The past was ok, the current is better, the future is brighter.
Pros: Last five years of turnover in executive management has been a big improvement. I've been acquainted with many parts of the organization which has grown a lot over the years through some great acquisitions. Each of these has brought some great skills and culture to Logicalis. The trajectory of the organization is on target with the direction of the market and the talent in most areas is first rate.
Cons: Positive changes in culture take some time to reach all nooks and crannies of the organization.

Review Title: Nice place to start for beginners
Pros: Extremely helpful staffs and well-maintained knowledge bases to help you out with. Pay is good but could be better. The break room is super cool and has everything that you need like utensils, napkins, coffee, vending machines with free pops etc. Work environment is very relaxed. It can get super busy and very quiet depending on the time of the year.
Cons: Management can be a little better. Sometimes, they demand too much of you without communicating about that to you. Sometimes, there is way too much politics that you don’t understand if you are being treated unfairly or not.

Review Title: Worst company I have ever worked for
Pros: The co workers are friendly and helpful
Cons: I was told a lot before starting and even had the emails from the HR department to back with what I was promised, but once I got in nothing I had been told was what was going to go on.  The training is done by people who have been on the account for sometime and know it, but what they call training is merely reading through the tech docs.  Always under staffed so you can forget a good work to life balance.  They will deny days off without a problem.

Pros: Pay, co-workers. Your co-workers are great, which makes it hard to leave the job, but outside of that and pay, the job is miserable and you dread having to go in every morning.
Cons: Management picking there favorites and micro-managing things such as ones PTO. Not the job that was described in the interview or in your job description. Expect you to honor what you signed in your offer letter, but they do not honor it. Manipulate employees who are not one of their favorites. No room for growth, since they hire outside the company when positions open up. Treated like you mean nothing to them. Don't appreciate their employees. Training consists of sitting next to someone and monitoring them for a week or so.

Pros: The only reason to work here is because you have to collect some form of a paycheck so you can pay your bills.
Cons: The benefits have gone completely down hill. Bonus payouts have been taken away. Management treates employees like they mean nothing. Then management has the nerve to act shocked and offended when people leave.  HR pretends like everything is fine and dandy. Everyone is so fake.

Review Title: Expectations and job function changed drastically
Pros: Some of the co-workers were decent to be around
Cons:
When I started working for Logicalis, I was explicitly told that we would be supporting one company and fully integrate with their systems. However, within a few months, they added 2 more companies to support fully (this means learning new protocols and proprietary software for each company). By the end of my employment with them, they were about to add a 4th company to the roster

The worst, however, was management's obsession with the appearance of working. I was fairly consistently in the top 5 reps (out of about 30 people) at the time, yet I could barely turn to talk to a coworker without management asking what I was up to. The last straw for me was when they required phones to be put away during your shift and started SCHEDULING bathroom breaks. That is simply disrespectful, especially for those who are doing a good job.

Being Bilingual made my (and my bilingual coworkers') life more difficult as well. I had an extra call queue to handle as well as taking any spanish ticket that came in.

Also, because they hired many unqualified (and frankly immature) reps, that meant that callouts were literally a DAILY issue. I got the "..can you come in to cover for *** who called in sick?" call at least twice a week. 

Tickets are not dispatched, but rather everyone is expected to grab tickets AND calls as they come in. This makes it to where a few top dogs end up carrying the load of picking up tickets to avoid the whole team getting yelled at. 
Management is the typical stick-up-the-ass type repeating corporate policies as if biblical truths. There are no real incentives to be a good employee here other than personal ethics.

All in all the micromanagement, co-workers not pulling their weight, and being treated like a prisoner who can't get up to pee made this job too much for me. The job itself was really not that bad.

Review Title: Poor handling of talented staff- do your homework before you work there
Pros: The people that work there are talented and driven. Pay is commensurate of skills and well applied. Services and product are valuable. Very good marketing department.
Cons: The company manament fails to display nusiness maturity. There is no consistency in product to market management. The intellectual property lives in the head of management. The suite of products could be better and better documented. Follow-through from management is not there. There is no vision just a focus on revenue and margin. As a result a lot of talented people have been laid off so that the business financial outlook be saved in the view of the parent company. They also make promises to prospective talent that they fail to keep. The top three people in the company are setting the culture and it is not developing to be a good one, which is a shame because the people under it have what it takes to make Logicalis one of the best emerging leaders in their market by the fact that they bring amazing credibility to the company.

Pros: You get a laptop and good vacation time.
Cons: Managers here are mostly a joke. Not all, but mine was a micro manager. Told me I need to start emailing her when I use the restroom? wtf. That was the last straw for me. Why is this stuff allowed by HR. That's another thing, HR is not there to regulate anything like this. Manager's can come up with whatever stupid rule they want for the department, even if unethical and it's all just ok. They play games. Manager's do not treat a top perfomer as a benefit to the department or company, I'm sure they're feeling regret about that right now! HR needs to step up and make rules and regulations company-wide. And train Manager's to know how to be a Manager so I don't have to do it. Here, if your manager thinks it's a good idea, then that's law and your manager can make up stupid rules and you basically have to follow them and like it or get lost. Go to a real company. Does Datatech even knew what goes on here? Things such as internal controls? Hello! Public Company! Where are they? So much passive agressive bs going on here all the time. The controller is educated and smart, but at the same time very dense. Get it together. Then they promote and make people manager that have ZERO people skills. Or you request pto time and get in trouble for it... or get told not to take any pto time for a while. Um, you can't give people pto days and then get mad when they use them and start a problem when there isn't one. There was this one manager that never even talked to her employee.... wow great idea. The Leadership here disgusts me.

Pros:
Flexible work locations
Strong focus on the sales organization
Cons:
Little/No career progression
Focus on organizations other than sales is mediocre 
Internal incentive programs are demotivating
Recognition, outside the sales arena, is poor
Training opportunities are lackluster; internal training portal is so confusing that navigating it should count as college credit
Leadership in silos; focuses on tactical or personal agendas instead of strategic development 
Middle/Lower management lacks focus in aligning strategy to tactics, spends more time in reactive mode instead of proactive mode
Lack of management cohesiveness across the layers makes it as if you are working for multiple companies
Communication is not utilized effectively
Delivery teams highly overworked
Resource limitations abound
Teamwork is nonexistent 
Visibility and understanding of organizational matrix is poor leading to duplication of effort and inefficiency
Work/Life balance is poor
Back office processes are confusing, inconsistent, and difficult to utilize
High turnover makes customer interactions more stressful
Corporate culture does not create a positive atmosphere, focuses on placing blame first and de-emphasizes root cause analysis
Organizational maturity is low

Policies and procedures are inconsistent, utilized arbitrarily and when questioned become supplemented with additional process.  The sheer pain from knowing that your attempt to improve things will end up with additional procedural overhead prevents all by the most sadistic from striving for improvement.  Will a system designed by sadists will promote corporate excellence?

Current toolsets are out-of-date, out-of-touch, and instead of doing at least one thing well, does many things poorly.   Great emphasis is directed at presentations, demonstrations, etc.  But, zero thought is given to the tools, infrastructure, and delivery.   Would you buy your technology solution from a company when the sales rep is doing a BYOD demo on a Hello Kitty phone? 

Organizational methodology is weakly coupled and when combined with the communications issues, silos, and general culture creates an atmosphere where accomplishing anything easy is difficult and anything difficult impossible.  This is unfortunate because I remember a time when our delivery teams did the impossible with a panache that defined the brand.

Pros: It was generally easy to take PTO when needed. When you work in the call center, there are a bunch of different clients, so the opportunity to learn a lot of different technologies exists.
Cons: For the call center, I would say pay was below average, especially since raises were a very rare thing. Overtime and weekends are often mandatory, and a holiday or two is usually thrown in as well (the call center operates 24x7x365). Not a lot of chances to move beyond the call center, if that is where you are starting. Benefits were also above the industry standard and coverage wasn't great.

Review Title: Great people, those great people also leaving
Pros: I have met the best people working at Logicalis. Honest, smart, dedicated and a true teammates in every sense of the word. 30 days PTO, great benefits, flexible depending on what position you have.
Cons:
The culture of Logicalis has changed in my tenure here. Upper management is so desperate to make numbers, the amount of micromanagement and pressure that comes down from the top is unbelievable. The new president is a tyrant in every sense of the word. This company lacks direction. Every year we have a new charge to follow, a new strategy to adhere to. They change their minds so much, we don’t know our heads from our rear ends. Upper management has grand ideas and strategies for the future, however changes are made before the resources are in place to implement those changes. Very little thought to how these grand ideas affect the employees, the business and the customers.
The ground level is left to clean up the mess.  The pay stinks and they will “promote” you with extra work and title, but not compensate you.  When a manager tells
you to to change companies to make more money, that is telling. Oh, and the real great people in the company...they tend to fire and replace with inferior management. I once was happy but now struggle to find my peace among the chaos. Good people are dropping like flies and that is really telling. There are much better places to land.

Pros: Good team and tech stack
Cons: Everything is good in this company

Pros: HERE has the most helpful and collaborative employees I have ever experienced at any previous company. They truly have a team culture that strives to win together.
Cons: Ramp time for new employees can be significant without a GIS or Location Services background.

respectfull work environment

Pros:
During my tenure at HERE I've found the culture to be exactly what I was looking for and couldn't be happier. With open communication and a collaborative environment, leadership provides strong direction, while getting to know you as an individual. They help foster your development goals while ensuring you exceed your objectives. Team members are supportive and understanding as you get up-to-speed learning the organization and the industry. Tons of flexibility too, while they encourage work/life balance. 

Additional benefits:
- Department Executives want to hear from team members as recurring skip-level conversations take place throughout the year.
- Summer Hours - Work some extra time Mon - Thurs and get Friday afternoons off!
- Opportunity to work anywhere in the world on a temporary basis, I believe the time limit is 30 days.
- Sabbatical opportunity after a certain duration with the company.
Cons: The organization has gone through many changes so you have to be flexible and adaptable as all of the processes may not be well defined. You also need to be prepared that there are personal changes due to the "great resignation", as well as reorganizations. If you aren't open to taking early morning or late night calls, this global environment may not be for you. I've found that the team really works together to understand and address these challenges head-on and what's needed to accomplish the objectives.

Cons: The company has been trying to reinvent itself every couple years, and I don't think the C-suite and the rest of the leadership team really knows what they want to be or how to get there.  Plenty of projects we worked on were deprioritized, paused, and in so many other ways kept from finding their way to production.

Pros:
Unlimited PTOs, there are people even take 1 month's PTO without any issue.
Besides some senior managers, most people are friendly and easy to work with.
Cons:
1. The managers I have worked with during the 4 year are all micro-management. 
2. Very unfriendly to foreign employees. 
H1b: lawyer response email WITHOUT any time manner, and immigration HR never response my direct message or email, which result in a lot of REF H1b cases.
GreenCard: When join the company, both HR and manager said after 6 month we can start the GC process, but then they start to find different kinds of excuses to delay the case. Then 4 years later, that's when my H1b has less than 2 years left, they said they can start my process, but I need to sign an agreement saying: if during the whole process, if I left Here, I need to pay all expense for my case.
3. Bad benefits, beside base salary and basic insurance, no other benefits at all. There is even a cut of 5% of your salary since pandemic happen and they are laying off 5% of people now.
4. Not very much tech skill you will learn here, most are business logic.

All foreigners be careful of this company, if you need working visa or green card sponsorship, this company will give you a lot of hard time. And put you in a very bad situation.

Makes claims of positive culture, but doesn't live it.

Company is doing "fine" as is, but has a hard time actually leveling up its technology and reach.

Cons: - Recent layoffs were a bad sign. Full disclosure: I was one of those laid off, but it was the employees who were being kept that seemed almost more upset, as they had a significant amount of work to make up for, and there was little direction around that transition.

Review Title: Awesome Office in Chicago, Flexible working culture, Employee Friendly
Pros:
- Senior Leadership is focused on making the company be a world-class leader in locations and maps data
- As a new joiner, competitive salary and benefits compared to most of the companies
- Quarterly reviews
- Technology-driven

The company has a lot of potential. A lot of Underground work is going on. Should be in a great position in the next 2 years.
Cons: - People leaving because of many reasons (re-org and salary match being the top most reason).

Pros:
Very nice, qualified people to work with
Interesting technology
Interesting job assignments
My line manager is the best
Cons:
Poor benefits; premiums for medical go way up every year, dental is subpar, DTO vacation plan is a disaster (previously Paid Time Off-PTO was better). Some managers don't want to let you go on vacation, Bonuses are nearly nonexistent, raises are a joke-get the highest review possible and you may get a 2% increase if you are lucky, no career path, poor internal training-you are on your own, Europe and India have better benefits than Chicago and don't get laid off at the rate Chicago employees do, as layoffs always start in the USA.

Quarterly layoffs and reorganizations indicate that the Leadership Team (LT) keeps trying things that don't work. Somehow, people manage to get their jobs done in spite of this.

The LT conducted a focus team for the survey with the intent to get more good survey responses. The focus team was told at the outset not to bother evaluating any questions that were LT related, just make suggestions for what people at our level could do to help. Management also had a shadow team who the original focus team was unaware of, that filtered the suggestions made so not to offend the LT. 

Upper level executives keep disappearing from the company, but the ones who need to go are still there at the highest levels. 

The car consortium who owns the company had promised not to interfere in our daily operations when they bought the company, but they are always interferring. I have heard in meetings many times that we have to stop what we are doing and work on something for one of the owners.

 Getting promoted from within is nearly impossible. Make sure if you accept a job here, you get the salary you want and you are hired in at the level you want to be at 5 years from now. Then at the end of 5 years, you may be ok.

Also some decline in the Automotive business due to Google / Apple and the company has pivoted to focus on other industries but is a ways off for meaningfully breaking into those industries.

The work is interesting and fast paced - which I like. Cool technology and opportunity to work with some of the top automotive and technology companies around the world.

At times, you may need to join meetings pretty early (6am) or in the evenings, depending on the location of teammates and customers you are working with.

Review Title: Very stable workforce; that's not always good
Pros: There are many employees with 10 (or even 20) or more years; they are very stable and have a solid foundation.
Cons: Because most of my peers have a couple of decades' experience, change is very difficult; there isn't a good culture of change, even if there is a need. "The way we do things" is the order of the day; it can be tough to join as a seasoned professional.

Pros:
I learned some life lessons. I learned some computer programs and time management. Keep your guard up and not be too nice to people. They see that as weakness.

I love their company lunch gathering and fun holiday decorating.
Cons:
While I enjoy organizing paperwork and having a private space, it really bothers me that many of the conversations I hear almost everyday is each clique is bad mouthing about someone and not shy about it either. It's really toxic. 

One day I was accused of not getting my work done and complained about my task, which is not true. Not only did I get things done ahead of time with enthusiasm, I even asked others if they need any help. 

I don't know what I have ever said or done to deserve such accusations. I kept to myself most of the time. I hope things have improved since I left.

Pros: Nice coworkers but that is it.
Cons:
My mental health went down the drain working for this position because you are working 2 positions at the same time. Management had the bright idea of combining support I and support II positions into one single position. This means you take the interactions, document the cases, and close every single case. Cases that should go to more experienced team members are now your responsibility. You WILL have to be in contact with analysts and customers until the issue is resolved. Most managers have NO IDEA how to help you because they were hired from lateral positions in different companies, they just hold the title and go to meetings all day. This means, you WILL be trapped under a pile of unresolved cases because you are expected to close 15+ cases per day but an interaction can range from 5 minutes to 1+ hour. It’s like management wants you to fail. On top of this, during “tax season” you will have MANDATORY overtime. Your kids, spouse, family emergency… will have to wait because there is MANDATORY overtime. Your manager will have a word with you if you fail to comply to their terms. They 100% expect you to keep taking calls no matter what. They will lie and say they don’t micromanage and only “keep track to make sure you are getting the right help” but here is a list of the things they will track and record: Your calls, your chats, your status, your computer screen, your keyboard, your mouse clicks, your open cases, your closed cases, amount of time spent talking to customers, amount of time spent not talking to customers, amount time going to a personal break, and amount of time working on open cases. No micromanaging here though according to management.

You will be working over 40 hours nearly every week (including weekends). Every 2 weeks you will meet with your manager who will break down every thing and point out your deficiencies. 

Please do not work here and take care of your mental health. This job will squeeze the joy out of your life. Waking up to talk to rude customers is not a way to live.

Forget moving up here too. It will take years and if you’re not brown nosing, you have no chance.

Review Title: Easy Life, but Sense of Stagnation-- Even Despair
Pros: people don't work too hard, so there isn't much pressure on you to work hard, either. good pay, good benefits. people were nice
Cons: "go along to get along" culture means that new ideas/perspectives are tolerated, at best. everybody is just keeping their head down to get a paycheck. you aren't really growing or being challenged. they will heap praise on you for doing the bare minimum. your colleagues, though nice, will hold you back if you ever try to actually accomplish anything. if you take another job for five years, then come back, it will be the exact same conversation-- like, nothing happened.

Review Title: I either want to say a lot more or a lot less than one sentence.
Pros: Coworkers are good people. Product leads the market. Pay is competitive.
Cons: You'll hear upper management say "If you see something that can be improved, bring the idea to your manager." Most of my great ideas took an investment now to boost profit and lower costs in the future - and the quarterly profits approach squashed idea after idea. This is not unusual for the corporate world, so it's not like the same con isn't part of the game in a lot of companies, so take the observation with that grain of salt.

Review Title: The worst job I have ever had
Pros: None that I can think of.
Cons: I went into this job with a positive attitude but now I am desperately seeking other employment. No training, no database. NO DATABASE! what multinational publishing company doesn't have a proprietary databse/production system? Everything is done on excell spreadsheets. My "superior" spends all of her time in meetings and combing through spreadsheets line by line looking for mistakes or omittances so that she can write you up. I have been gaslit, lied to, and blamed for things that occurred before I even started working there. I was promised a remote position only to find out that I would be required to come into the office 2 days a week. I have been recorded without persmission, and spoken to like a child. ANd the worst part is that I have just as much experience in publishing as my "Superior" and significantly more experience in computers. The pay is sub-par and after the interview when I was offered the job I tried to negotiate a higher salary but was shut down immediately. The culture is very "Lord of the flies" in the respect thatthe only way to survive is to throw someone else under the bus. I chose not to do that to my co-workers and my boss was not happy. I have never received any kind of compliment from my boss. Not so much as a "good job." Just going into the office causes me to feel sick. If you like toxic work places then this is the job for you.

Pros: Used to have tons of pros. Now not much. Still good work-life balance. Decent benefits. Good health insurance though prohibitively expensive for a family.
Cons: The newest leader is awful and unhinged. Yelling at employees for stupid things. Half the company is considering quitting. Still, we are throwing things at a wall hoping they will stick. Punishing people for company failures and focusing on single employees rather than the bigger problems. No plan to move forward or organize things, just threats of further punishment if we don't "fix things". All of it is just making people fearful and angry. It is a small company that is about to be smaller if they do not do something to make people less upset. You cannot take away freedoms and expect employees to work harder for you. You cannot yell at them like they are children and embarrass them in front of clients and expect them to be loyal and motivated. I haven't had a decent raise in years, yet the cost of living keeps going up. I am supposed to be happy with my 2% a year. But they up my insurance premiums each year and expect me to work harder.

Review Title: Be Leary of being a sales rep in the Tax division
Pros: You can make good money in some areas, the benefits are good.
Cons: The accounting department for the Tax division is so horrendous, that if you are in sales, you will have many many problems arise, that no one will take care of because the billing/accounting division consist of just a few people who take care of the entire North America. They do not answer emails nor do they answer phone calls. Any billing issues will become your problem, and in my experience could take up to a year to resolve or even if it is the companies error. this takes so much time away from sales and is a constant stressor. Also, your quotas will change after the month has ended most of the time to your detriment, and you’ll never get an actual accounting of why. At all costs, avoid selling tax programs that they have no interest in improving.

Cons:
Depressing, fatalistic atmosphere.

Shuffled leadership and created many "task forces" and "growth offices" with redundant responsibilities.
Oodles of consultants that have yet to add value.
Added some new faces but they seem to be drug down by legacy players.
Continues to hemorrhage A-team talent primarily due to compensation - no material bonus payouts in years and next to no increases, stock has only declined precipitously
No plans to address attrition - attitude seams to be that if people leave on their own a RIF will not be needed.
Leadership seems to be either "out of their league" or so mired in legacy HPE thinking that no one has good ideas on how to realistically grow or stop the bleeding.
I hate writing this. I really enjoyed working there for a long time.

Review Title: Know what you’re getting into and have a strategy.
Pros:
The people I worked beside and my employees were always willing to fight together in the trenches. Our team has a strong culture. 

Benefits were pretty good.
Cons:
It was difficult to understand how our business was connected to other parts of the business. Everyone seemed siloed. 

Some leadership have been there forever and are self preservationists. When things go right, they take the credit from others. When things go wrong they throw others under the bus. 

No accountability for bad leadership. (No internal NPS). 

Lack of SMART goals from our specific leader. At the end of the year you could have hit all of your goals and still be told that you are terrible at your job.

Review Title: Used to be a great place to work, not anymore
Pros: Truly smart and amazing coworkers. Work life balance and pay is decent
Cons:
What a shame used to be amazing place to work 4 years ago when I started with a great almost cultish culture! All that is gone and current leadership is complete disaster. It feels like a high school clique, lead by the bully mean girl who’s not open to feedback. So many shenanigans, nobody believes in Twilio magic anymore. No enablement for SEs, we find about new features from clients. 3 layoffs and same mistakes with all, layoff AEs and leaving customers to hang without a new point of contact. We lost so many opportunities again due to layoffs and reorgs as customers had no new reps for 2+ months. Customers are frustrated and some opportunities were lost because “we’re on our 4th AE this year!”
Just came back from SKO and our newest coolest product is something you would see 5 years ago. No long term vision. Lost so many smart people and unfortunately I think many more are leaving.

Pros: Benefits are amazing, best insurance possible.
Cons: Structure could be improved in a better way. Initial training can improve as well (onboarding process)

Pros:
Thoughtful, transparent leadership 
Market leading product 
Many products in the bag to sell, and you can sell with confidence because the products are good 
Good management at every level. Collaborative deal execution. 
Very receptive leadership at every level to ideas. Leadership fully implemented feedback from even interns in order to improve things 
LOADS of resources to get deals done. 
Lots of learning opportunities. Lots of recognition for achievements.
Focus on D&I led to an incredibly diverse team and brilliant ideas. 26+ countries represented with massive growth outside of the US.
All this lent to an exceptional culture, there was no other company like this ever before. A lot of this magic is gone now.
Cons:
Several layoffs due to over-hiring and over spending.
Unclear long term vision and execution behind that long term vision. 
Lack of long term thinking or learning from past issues in some ways
Far too many changes, pivots and reorgs. 1st line manager changes several times in a year.
New CEO, LOADS of C-suite changes over the years. 
Too frequent territory remapping. Losing accounts in September for example when you just start to get traction breaking into an account. 
Customers are jarred from switching account reps many, many times. 
Cumbersome internal processes, very hard to navigate how to close deals or get approvals. Twilio gets more in the way of deals closing than any competition. 
Total miss with 2nd and subsequent covid waves. Massive opportunity for revenue lost. 
Too much focus on lengthy product training vs sales execution 
Highly complex comp plan and thus there are many conflicts over comp payouts and timing
Very competitive and commoditized market. Twilio does well at differentiation and shipping new features for the roadmap, but just know that there will be loads of completion in every deal. 
Knowledge loss at every level as most tenured employees have left.

Pros: The people here really care about each other and the work they do. Managers here I've interacted with are also always trying to improve the workplace and empower others.

Pros: During the pandemic years, I had the opportunity to partner with some of the brightest and most collaborative marketers. Creative problem-solving was encouraged, and there was plenty of budget to think outside the box with targeted marketing campaigns. There was a clear vision provided from marketing leadership and we consistently charted our progress against key KPIs. I learned a lot from both peers and leaders at a pivotal juncture in my career. I was enamored by Twilio's commitment to being an anti-racist company, the Twilio magic principles, and of working in an environment of positivity. I left the company in early 2022 for an opportunity that I just couldn't decline (more responsibility, solving interesting problems, better benefits and compensation). I feel lucky to have left the company when I did, as I missed the mass layoffs and culture decline.
Cons: To put it bluntly, leadership has issues. This is true in marketing and org-wide. Since the hire of the new CMO, VP leadership in marketing have departed the company one by one—a telltale sign of a lack of faith of leadership's competence and the in the direction Twilio is headed in. The CEO Jeff has systematically mismanaged the company, yet refuses to step down. He refused to relinquish a misplaced faith to Twilio Flex, despite its low performance and lack of interest from customers. And now I fear Twilio Segment may be headed in the same direction,

Review Title: Changed Perspectives: Twilio's Evolving Leadership and Unmet Potential
Pros: Market-Aligned Compensation: Due to changing market dynamics, Twilio's salary offerings have naturally aligned with the median. While not a direct result of internal salary adjustments, this shift reflects the current competitive landscape in the tech industry, positioning Twilio's compensation packages within the average range.
Cons:
Executive compensation appears misaligned with the company's financial performance. For example, the CEO's salary is notably higher than that of the CEO of Disney, a significantly more valuable and profitable company, raising questions about the appropriateness of such compensation amidst the company's financial challenges.

There has been a noticeable turnover in staff quality and efficiency. High-performing individuals ('A players') have largely departed, and the current team composition poses challenges to rapid and effective cross-functional collaboration.

The company culture has shifted towards a more political environment, particularly at the Director level and above. This shift often results in decisions that prioritize short-term gains or personal agendas over long-term company benefits, such as the underutilization of costly tools despite expert recommendations.

There's a tendency to view team underperformance as an issue with individual contributors rather than a reflection of leadership effectiveness. This perspective is contributing to a culture where systemic issues are not adequately addressed.

Management style has increasingly favored political maneuvering over strategic competence. A notable number of managers lack a deep understanding of the strategies and tactics pertinent to their functions, which, coupled with poor decision-making, has had a significant cost impact on the business.

Pros: There is a good work life balance
Cons: Uncertainty in the business and long term strategy

Cons: Leadership is not aligned on company direction; culture has diminished tremendously; very clickish environment; a lack of accountability at the VP level

Basically everything else.

There is no rhyme or reason to who is laid off, it doesn't matter how long they have been with the company, if they are a top performer or not, they are just released.

Cons: Lack of manager training and accountability and shortage of HRBP availability makes for very uneven quality of middle management. There is no professional development stipend and very little funding or support to attend industry events/conferences. Several rounds of layoffs and slashed experience/culture/travel budgets majorly impacted company culture and morale, as could be expected. I hope it can be built back up.

Review Title: The good days of Twilio are behind it
Pros: Twilio is (was?) full of talented employees, who were creative thinkers, builders, and teammates. Unfortunately, the enthusiasm of many of these employees drained over the last year in light of faltering leadership (see cons). Work/life balance was fantastic, with remote work opportunities and unlimited PTO.
Cons: Management at all levels is a disaster. The leadership changes direction so regularly that it is difficult for teams to achieve their goals. Not only is this frustrating, but over time the cumulative impact of projects repeatedly being discarded is a huge hit to morale. Team and departmental management lacked the skills needed to motivate and grow their employees; in my 2 years at Twilio I was rarely provided with any practical leadership or professional development opportunities despite asking for them. Despite their stated commitment to diversity and inclusion, my experience was that men were regularly favored over women in terms of promotions, leadership opportunities, stretch assignments, and access to their skip-level managers. The majority of their stated anti-racist layoffs, at least on my team, consisted of women, people of color, and people with disabilities. It is my opinion that the DEI team that was established is just for optics; my team regularly interacted with them and they had a reputation for using intimidation and bullying tactics to achieve their goals - completely counteractive to how a DEI team should behave.

Review Title: Was good while I was there, but change abounds
Pros: Loved my team and my managers, appreciated that the focus wasn't just on the hamster wheel of work work work, but bigger picture of how to improve our processes and do bigger, more impactful projects. Even as a remote employee, I was able to meet my team several times over the course of a year in-person and the environment was fun, inclusive, and felt meaningful. Compensation, salary increases, benefits, and perks were great. The CEO was very vocal about DEI topics and made an effort to be anti-racist.
Cons: I was laid off and now entire teams have been eliminated. Leadership has a lack of understanding of processes or why they exist, and employees have been treated as liabilities instead of talented assets. Many benefits have been stripped as the company tries to contract and earn a profit.

Review Title: I wouldn't feel very confident for Twilio's future
Pros: Benefits were really great, they started to dwindle them at the start of Q1 in 2023, like taking away our phone stipend and this is for people who are using our phones to do our job. My boss at the time before they left was awesome, really great to work with and supportive. Work life balance is pretty good given they have an open vacation policy.
Cons: Company did two rounds of layoffs in under four months? Nobody saw it coming but rumors were flying left and right and nobody in leadership was addressing them. I worked in TA and my candidates had to go through 3-4 rounds of interviews which felt insane even for my green entry level roles. We undoubtedly missed out on really strong talent because of this process. hiring managers want everything in a candidate but then are baffled when we lose out on them because we took too long in the process. Partnership between a Talent Researcher and Talent Partner is just strange, too many cooks in the kitchen and you're doubling the work. You just need one recruiter per position, quit dividing the hirng.

Review Title: Great company and market leader if you can handle the drama
Pros: Benefits, pay, technology, products, tons of talent
Cons: stressful, prior layoffs, voices of IC not heard, leadership unwilling to listen or change.

Pros: I've been working as a recruiter at Twilio for over two years, and I can confidently say that it's one of the best companies I've had the pleasure of working for. Team collaboration, transparent communication, cutting-edge technology, professional development opportunities and a focus on employee well being are just some of the pros to call out from a company standpoint. Twilio believes in giving recruiters the autonomy to make important decisions. Our strong employer brand, competitive compensation and benefits are very well received in the market.
Cons: You need to be comfortable working remote as our real estate footprint has shrank.

Review Title: Essential product in the tech stack
Pros: Competitive salary, 401k match, RSUs, remote work with option to go into the office. Many smart and kind ICs. Catered lunches at the offices. Sells a product that is essential to almost any business that wants to have a smart/modern customer engagement strategy. Seen as the leader in the CPaaS space. I always felt that my work was valued at Twilio. APIs are excellent.
Cons: Layoffs were obviously a huge hit. The company is looking to be profitable and is making business decisions to get there. This is completely understandable. For go to market teams, the reality is there were too many cooks in the kitchen. One person can, and should do the job of three. Company is going through growing pains and is trying to iron out business goals and objectives to get to the next level. The company isn't in a bad place, it's just going through reorganization/"how to get to the next level" progressions. You could argue over-hiring has played a major role in that.

Pros: Good pay, some great people and an interesting problem set. There is much that needs to be done to modernize the tech stack and many interesting challenges to work on, if you happen to get a leader that is able to see this and empower you to take them on.
Cons: Leadership is a real mess at Twilio. Constantly shifting priorities, infighting, politics, lack of vision, low levels of technical understanding, all blanketed with a lack of awareness of these weaknesses. The company was oriented around growth and when that suddenly stopped being the focus, ended up destroying its culture to try to adapt to the changing market. Silos that were marginally annoying in 2021 turned into WWI style entrenchments in 2023 where directorial fiefdoms prevent any sense of community or ability to collaborate outside the scrum team.

Review Title: Great company but pain with change
Pros: Twilio is a great company that really cares for its employees. It is struggling managing change after their 2nd round of layoffs but all in all they care.
Cons: Struggle dealing with change and addressing changes with employees.

Pros: Work from home and flexibility

Review Title: A place to grow slowly but consistently

Cons: - Pay is low compared to similar companies in bay area, partially due to the falling stock price. The losses due to the stock is not covered in terms of cash(base-pay) - Removed all employee perks in order to achieve profitability but not seeing any substantial change in last one year - Since the time I have joined, seen a lot of reorganization(May be due to market conditions)

Review Title: A decent home for a house cat designer.
Pros: Twilio is remote first, you're not required to come into an office if you live near one of their locations. The company takes personal growth and development seriously. I've never seen a company allow you to train and expand your professional skills on company dime and time. It's amazing. The compensation is on par or above what a designer at this level would make in house or at an agency. The benefits are decent, Healthcare offerings could be improved. Specifically dental, there's only one option. Unlimited PTO is great, there's a good culture on my team that encourages folks to take off. Overall this a relatively low stress environment for a designer who is okay with having a clock-in, collect, repeat mentality. You won't make the most groundbreaking work but it's a comfortable place to grow and look towards the future.
Cons: In the field of design, Twilio is a place like many others. You probably won't move up until somebody leaves. It's top heavy with several mid-senior level designers and art directors. The title structure makes growth feel like an unnecessarily long venture. Example - there are 3 steps of visual design positions before you could become a Senior designer. This trend continues up the ladder. You're designing for a pretty niche audience and the subject matter is dense. It's challenging to understand who you're designing for. Probably best suited for designers that also have an interest in programming although it's not required and you could do the job without knowing any coding languages.

Pros: Decent time off and short term leave
Cons: You don’t know if you’ll get laid off or not

Review Title: Everything BUT A Great Sales Org
Pros: Work-Life Balance, Pay (For Sales, they offered a very competitive Base Salary + OTE), Unlimited PTO, Paid for 70+% medical insurance
Cons: Not a sales org by far. Even the CEO will tell you, “We are Developer First,” meaning they still haven’t figured out to care and cultivate their sales org. There is no sense of direction especially when it comes to sales and generating revenue, even though obtaining profitability at all costs is the goal. So why lay off a ton of top performers just to appear “fair” if generating revenue is so important?! You’re not really selling here either, you’re promoting platform consumption and cheerleading to developers to use the platform. You do more account management then prospect. The comp plan is the most confusing on the market as well. It should of have been a red flag when I asked ten different people to explain the comp plan and got ten different answers. Even if you’re over performing, you are at risk of being cut if they don’t achieve their financial goals every quarter.

Pros: Great people and strong culture
Cons: Lost its luster and way

Easier said than done when there was no cohesive message from marketing and sales, quotas made no sense, and they forced SDRs to use awful pre-written templates for outbound.

Pros: Co-Workers were great people and talented sales reps
Cons:
- Culture of micromanagement. Sales management at Sprinklr has no idea how to run a proper sales organization and they try to make up for it by attempting to control every aspect of the sales cycle. This in turn creates a massive bottle neck where reps do not have their own autonomy and require management involvement to simply call a customer. Your manager will want to be on every call, every email, maintain access to your call notes and will want them all in the format of their choosing; which they will change on a whim.

- 95% of reps here will not make any money. The quotas are set high and the territory is thin. Most people make their base salary.

- The company grew quickly due to a low rate environment and went public. Due to this they have people who were SDRs when it was a startup, who are now attempting to manage seasoned sales reps. This leads to insecurity in management, who will tear down their reps to avoid the perception of inexperience.

- The company doesn't know what it wants to be. Although public, the company can't decide if it's a marketing tool, a customer care tool, or an advertising platform. All of Sprinklr's competitors have decided what they are and cost less. The product is not a need to have for most companies.

- Culture of playing favorites. Managers frequently pick and choose who gets which accounts based on who they like. Promotions are also decided this way.

Pros: Its great to have a founder/CEO that is engaged as he is.
Cons: Micro Management on the sales side. Need more focus on how leadership can help as opposed to interrogating the number of calls you made,
