Review Title: Has potential but a bit of a mess
Pros: Sprinklr is very inviting of all different work backgrounds and experience levels. They want you to WANT to work there and enjoy being there and they hit the nail on the head with amenities and culture for the most part.
Cons: I had have 5 years of sales experience before Sprinklr selling software, hardware, and financial services but was told I didn't have the right kind of experience and they started me out at an entry level position. They completely undersold the KPIs and the nature of the work because my background is account management but it was solely and outbound position which I told them I did not want but they assured me I would have plenty of customer facing opportunities and would be leading calls / qualifying needs which was not true. Ive kept up on LI with former colleagues and in my department roughly 50% of people have moved on sooner than a year which I think is telling. If you are willing to grind out an organization that changes every month and still has plenty of kinks to figure out, this is the place for you if you want that start up feel.

Review Title: Overall Great - Few Key Areas Need Improvement
Pros:
Base salary is very competitive in tech sales (Austin based) - variable comp is less than some of the %'s I've seen elsewhere, but higher base comp is always preferable in my opinion to account for the ups and downs of B2B sales.

Most amazing product ever - incredibly impactful on the market. The opportunity to sell to the literal biggest brands on planet Earth is very fun. This comes with a need for strategic, highly personalized outreach that is a very cool challenge to approach every day.

Lots of PG freedom, as long as your numbers are decent and you're putting in effort, the channel and method of outreach are always flexible, SDRs are mostly allowed to do what works for us. Now if you're struggling that becomes a different story, but that is the way of sales everywhere.

Very supportive community - since SDRs have their own territory and specified accounts to work on, there is a minimal amount of strategy guarding or gatekeeping. For the most part, everyone wants to help each other out, all managers are very willing to help people from other teams with whatever is needed.

Incredible office space that is under-utilized. If you get a job as an SDR here (which I recommend) use the office space! Free lunch 2 days per week, tons of snacks/drinks on site, many many desk spaces which are never full, game room, weight room / locker room, a bunch of soundproof call boxes / meeting rooms, etc. Really makes coming in to work a lot more fun in my experience.
Cons:
Quota is pretty high, most will not be able to hit it consistently without some luck going their way or being placed in one of the best geographic regions. However, management realizes this and will work with you if you are putting in the effort to improve - this isn't a "miss quota twice and you're fired" type of place, its about the value you are providing as a whole and how hard you're trying.

Benefits are very difficult to understand - when signing up, the UI is not good and afterwards its a struggle to find the exact details of different health plans / how to change them. Also "Unlimited PTO" is a nice dream but don't expect to be taking 3+ days off every month - metric requirements are definitely high and you have to work hard every week to hit them. PTO still has to be approved in advance by management, and it will be denied if you aren't getting close on activity metrics. However, managers are very flexible and will 100% work with you when things come up.

Product is extremely complex - pro and a con because having so many different features allows you to sell to 75% of titles out there which is very nice because prospecting is limitless, but completely understanding the product and how to pitch it intricately can take 6+ months. Nonetheless, its a really cool product that makes it feel like what you're selling actually matters - its becoming a staple of Enterprise tech stacks.

Company has exported a lot of jobs to India including tons of marketing roles, makes up a huge % of the company - makes things pretty siloed at times, along with time / cultural / language differences putting a strain on communications and content / campaign development. Currently there is limited marketing support for Sales. SDRs mostly just stick within their own teams, but collaborating across is difficult when necessary.

Confused transitions happening within leadership right now due to a few key leaders leaving. It's also very tough to transition between departments currently, several SDRs have been blocked from moving to solutions or customer success even after being approved initially due to a hiring freeze. Should be lifted relatively soon - prior to the freeze, moving departments was encouraged and pretty seamless.

Major tech stack changes currently being implemented (likely to cut costs) that are a big step back in my opinion, will definitely impact employee user experience and internal productivity. Not one single person in the company that I've talked to is happy about it, many are dreading it as much as I am, our tech stack was near perfect before.

Pros: Remote Exposure to a range of clients Structure (a strong foundation set in place by previous best-in-class leadership)
Cons: Toxic culture Limited paths for advancement Offering is overly complex and buggy, and sold for capabilities it can't deliver

Review Title: Overall a good organization, just some small issues that can seem big depending on your role.
Pros:
The people you work alongside at Sprinklr are amazing. I have made lifelong friends and have gained a numerous amount of mentors. The practitioners and middle-management are good people who I truly believe want whats best and will fight for you. I will also say that ELT is amazing.

Also, the product is best in business.
Cons:
With middle-management and ELT being amazing, the one con is that the SLT is not great. Sure, there are some exceptions, but I have found that they are the ones with the most stress and they pass that stress to everyone that reports to them and at times they can be way over the top. While most people at Sprinklr (including direct managers) will make an effort to befriend you or at minimum be nice, SLT does not. It seems that they have embraced the role of being the 'bad guy'. 

I will say though, for some of the SLT, this leadership style is effective and they are able to get the job done. However, a lot of newer SLT members see this and try to copy it, and then it just becomes a hostile work environment.

Review Title: Great company - still some growing pains so be ready for change
Pros: Overall great company, culture and leadership. We are growing fast so come prepared for change, and know some of the internal kinks are still being worked out. This lends itself to tremendous opportunity to close some big deals and make $$$.
Cons: Growing fast so come prepared for change, and know some of the internal kinks are still being worked out and a decent amount of turnover like most companies these days. Adaptability is key to success.

Pros:
Sprinklr is defining the category for the Unified Customer Experience. But what does that really mean? They are market leaders in their category, according to both Gartner and IDC, and can replace dozens of point-based solutions. From customer care, to Marketing & Advertising, to Research, and Engagement - Sprinklr is leading the way. This equates to massive market opportunity for the company and opportunity for personal career growth, advancement, and a chance to learn from a world-class executive team.

The culture of the company is second to none, even as a remote employee, everyone from our CEO to the lowest ranks in the organization is approachable, open, honest, caring, tenacious, and incredibly intelligent.

The benefits of a post-IPO company are great. Incredible TAM and room for growth of the company. Outstanding founder and CEO with a brilliant executive team to support and scale for future growth.
Cons: As with any high-growth SaaS organization, growing pains are a part of daily life. Processes have not been defined, constant hiring and onboarding of new hires, and regular "fire-drills" are simply a way of life. Maniacal focus on the most important objectives is the only key to success.

Review Title: Need to do a better job at DEI
Pros:
- Smart people
- Great product
- Okay Salary (Could be better)
- Good PTO policy
- Great Benefits
Cons:
Commitment to DEI needs to be readjusted and focused to help more BIPOC, especially in consultant/management roles, in this day and age it's not a good look.

The company has a simple way of seasoning consultants. They get pushed into high pressure situations, and they learn fast, and quickly start managing their own work. But they tend to be blind towards intricate details, especially in complicated IT product implementations. This has an interesting effect. If someone is able to do the hands-on work, everyone else tries to piggy-back on that person for their actual work. The hands-on guy gets overwhelmed, and others try to use him/her as a key resource.

Pros: Great Company, culture is amazing!
Cons: Don’t have anything bad to say

Pros: Managers are nice and are always on your side. The only good things here are the managers.
Cons:
I can vouch for everything another reviewer has mentioned in their "pixel pushing factory" review. Everything about this company is an absolute nightmare. After a mass exodus (which is still ongoing, by the way) on the design team, they have started ONLY hiring specifically entry level women POC. Everyone above your average product designer however, is not POC. You tell me what that means. 

Hint: Sprinklr will continue hiring junior POC talent while grossly underpaying and overworking them because more senior talent knows their worth. 

Design system? Research? Don't set the bar so high now, we don't even need to talk about that stuff when everything else is falling apart. 

Here's how it works:

Leadership will yell at you and lecture you about what they think UX is despite having absolutely no relevant experience in the field. You will do what they tell you, pixel by pixel, back and forth, constantly. I'm not even scratching the surface of what it's like...just know that it's bad.

Great experience for learning what a toxic work culture looks like. It can only go up from here I guess. Don't do it.

Pros:

Cons: -Growth has a slowed a bit since going public.

Review Title: Company with strong potential if it’s able to execute above peers. Culture needs some work.
Pros:
- People really care about their job. I was lucky to have a manager who was invested in my success and a network of very professional and friendly colleagues. 
- Company has a lot of potential with a great product that is loved by customers - it just needs to perform and execute.
Cons:
- Pay was not competitive. There’s a chance you’ll  be overworked and underpaid. They preach a “people-centric” culture but they could do more to actually invest in people.
- The “fire drill” culture is still present in the organization.

Review Title: All happy families are the same...
Pros: Fast growing company, exciting clients and mission. Mostly great colleagues and work environment albeit challenging most of the time, requires some time to get used to the pace and KPIs
Cons: Company prides itself as being a "family", which sounds good and it is fine when business is growing and everything goes well but can become an issue over time  and as, inevitably, we will go through some rough patches - also the strategy will inherently need acquisitions to grow and having such an intense focus on culture will likely creat more integration issues. I like a company to have a strong and clear culture but it is a slippery slope here and it must not be confused with indoctrination. Culture should come more from the bottom up (ie the people you hire) than the top down (ie training and policing).

Pros:
Team Culture
Coming from an Agency background into Tech, it was the first time having a team rooting for you to succeed. A part of this is understanding that it was a time of unprecedented growth and needing all help to succeed at scale. The other part was a homegrown culture of inclusiveness to foster belonging to a team. Wins and losses were recognized with transparency, then at the end of the day, we'll come together to tackle the next challenge. Honestly, it was the epitome of figuring it out as we go.

Great Technology Platform
The technology is enterprise ready. Though very complex, it is built to embed and scale within a company. Being able to reference across other technologies, I take my hat off on how impressive the technology is and what it can grow to be.
Cons:
Company Culture
While internal team culture was a breath of fresh air, outside of that, there are some toxic relationships across departments. It isn't unheard of to have tension between departments, however it's more pronounced at Sprinklr. Hopefully this will get resolved, but at its current state, it seems like the departments are less cooperative (outside of C-Level mandates) to work cohesively together.

Engineering Answers ≠ Process of Execution
While the technology is great, the complexity creates its own challenges in implementation, training, and adoption. This means the delivery of actualized value needs careful design and know how, which aren't intuitive to our clients. To stay ahead of the market, the technology has added "features" as an answer to competitiveness, while leaving the compatibility and know how at the wayside.

Total Compensation Package
In my time, as I advanced in more senior roles, the compensation packages were "okay", however they are not as competitive in the market overall. As of now, there are growing needs to reduce costs, so I don't see this as getting better. In terms of perks, they are standard, but not stellar in relation to the industry.

Diversity Challenges
As with many tech and companies in general, there isn't a large diversity within leadership positions. While I have had the privilege to work with some amazing colleagues who were female or a person of color, there were few representatives in positions of leadership. This does drive culture and it does show across the various departments.

Review Title: Exciting Company to work for. Growing so quickly that it has more than its share of growing pains.
Pros: Exciting product, CXM truly is the future of Modern engagement.
Cons: Extremely complicated product makes for a difficult time as sales rep and very rocky implementations.

Pros:
I've been with Sprinklr for more than 8 years and have had the privilege and pleasure to grow with the company itself. I have been encouraged and empowered to contribute in a variety of ways across various initiatives and audiences. 

Sprinklr's strengths are: 
- a tremendous, industry leading/creating product with a drive to continue innovation
- An ever-increasingly strong and clear direction from Executives on down
- An openness and willingness among leadership to discuss obstacles, challenges, and faults 
- Strong, defined values
- A supportive culture with a family-first tenet
- Supportive work/life balance through a work/life integration mindset
- Support during the challenges of Covid
- A wide range of available benefits including access to ongoing education and wellness resources
- An improving company-wide structure for alignment of strategic initiatives and goals
- A steady and effective structure for personal professional growth
- Lots of big opportunities for involvement in strategic projects that can change the course of a product, a company, and a career
Cons:
I do not feel that any of the cons below are unique to Sprinklr, nor do I think they amount to more than temporary discomfort (which itself is a useful strategy for personal and professional growth)

- potential for competing priorities/bandwidth on big initiatives
- periods of intense focus on production sometimes feels like multiple whirlwinds
- Constant innovation and production often make iterative approaches a requirement to project management and production

Pros:
- Leadership (from middle management to executive team, we are aligned to the same goals and supportive of individual contributors)

- Company Vision (we are creating a category: CXM)

- Benefits

- Life balance

- Coworkers (surrounded by people who genuinely care about their teammates, cross-functional colleagues, and most importantly our customers)
Cons: - Growing pains (resource constraints, blended roles/responsibilities, short-lived initiatives)

Review Title: My experience has been more hype then substance
Pros:
Company has done a nice job creating a market "leadership" role in the marketplace.  
Base salary was extremely competitive with a big potential upside with quota.  
They were very aggressive in their recruiting, and did an amazing job on selling me on the company.
Cons:
My review mostly applies to anyone looking to join in sales (especially outside of NYC).   
While the company appears to be growing quickly, they are covering up several issues.  I left a great company and job, because I thought Sprinklr was a rocket ship.  Unfortunately, that has not been my experience, and rocket ships can also crash. 
 
In six months, I haven't received any leads or assistance from marketing, existing customers aren't really happy in particularly because the product is very difficult to use even after long set up times (2-3 months to setup).  As a result, we are pushed to sell a lot of professional services to help customers succeed.  Therefore, while initially the compensation package was compelling, it will be extremely difficult to achieve under this environment since there are some smaller, newer competitors now winning business.  The recent acquisitions of agencies, shows the company is moving away from being a true product company and is an attempt to fill in the product deficiency. 

It appears the company did a good job locking a lot of customers into 2 - 3 year deals, and as those come up for renewal, I would suspect they start to see some real churn.

Review Title: VCE management has destroyed the company and its culture
Pros:
* product is best-in-class
* social media management space is trendy/popular/sexy
Cons:
* VCE management team (incl. Tim Page and his army) has severely damaged the company, its culture, and employee morale.   
* sales compensation plan is poor.  Definitely below-industry.  Top sales talent is not going to join with such a poor plan.
* Endless fire drills and last-minute requests to fill out "emergency" spreadsheets, docs, etc.   Feels like the entire business is running in panic mode 24/7.
* complete lack of marketing.   No CMO and it shows.   No simplicity in messaging/positioning, product briefs,  pricing, etc.    Field making up its own messaging and creating its own marketing materials.  
* massive hiring spree has dropped the quality of talent significantly.   Hiring managers were ordered recently to fill a very large number of positions in just weeks.   Not surprising that a focus on quantity (versus quality)  resulted in a decline in talent levels.

Pros: Group is very technical with lots of people to learn from. Medium size org allows for more time on projects and less rushing.
Cons: Very little onboarding. Access given, questions answered, not much info about overall architecture. Be ready to pick up how things are done through context.

Great people

Cons: You gotta hustle! It's sales

Pros: Positive workout place environment and good track for career development.
Cons: Nothing in my experience that’s been negative.

Pros: The design team has a lot of great people that really care and are trying to do great work.
Cons:
The design team is relegated to churning out UI tasks handed over from Product, typically with minimal to zero requirements or research to back up the requests. Everything is high priority. There is no real roadmap or vision for the product, so requests ultimately end up being asks directly from [big client] with little regard to how they fit into the overall application. Forget about any strategic product thinking or collaboration as a designer. Design is completely reactive, usually bouncing from fire to fire. Exploration, wireframing, and prototyping are looked at as a waste of time, all designs start in high fidelity drawing from an out of date design system.

Design patterns and components change weekly, if not daily. Designers are constantly running around trying to find the ‘latest’ design. Design standards and rules are not established. Be prepared to constantly redo your designs to match the ‘latest’ from another designers design file. There is no source of truth library. 

Leadership micromanages everything. Direction changes day to day, seemingly on a whim. You'll end up designing in circles as you try to address contradictory feedback or input given with no context of the actual problem. And you'll be asked why it's taking so long. Feedback is given without any reasoning as to the why. Don’t expect to learn or grow here, as designers are left to fend for themselves in their own silos dealing with subjective feedback.

Every few weeks people are shuffled around and teams are rearranged to work on the suddenly new prioritized feature or to put out the fire of the week. Churn is increasing as all the talent is fleeing and moral has been scraping rock bottom for months. Processes are completely dysfunctional, bottle-necked, and inefficient. Leadership seems to have little interest in fixing anything.

Design managers are experienced and truly care, but are stuck is a difficult position trying to support and setup designers for success with no support from leadership. Any proposals to update or change anything regarding processes are met with roadblocks or stone walls. 

Look elsewhere if you're a designer that cares about quality and design thinking or cares to continue to grow and learn professionally.

Review Title: Great work culture and great clients
Pros:

Cons:

Pros:
1) Work alongside sharp and dedicated co-workers who push you to be a problem solver
2) Flexible work from home policy
3) Generous PTO

That's it.
Cons: Sprinklr has undergone many changes, including new senior management, in the past couple of years that have negatively impacted workplace culture. Career opportunities are dismal for entry-level employees unless you are part of the inner "bro" circle. Expect to work long hours and not get compensated accordingly, even after multiple stellar performance reviews. If you want support from HR you won't find it, they care about making sure their upper management isn't affected by employee complaints or ideas.  There have been multiple instances of Sprinklr not taking diversity seriously and not caring to expand their team for qualified candidates. Undergoing financial changes, multiple layoffs have begun. This place will ruin your career and your outlook on the tech industry because they do not care about their employees, they only care about money now.

Pros: Great product, great tech team, inspiring leadership
Cons: Can be chaotic, can be political as any big company

Pros:
Work environment, culture, and values.  Not neglecting the technology/product here, it is absolutely robust, innovative, and amongst the highest rated in its class.  Having said that, people are what will elevate a company from great to elite.  The people I've collaborated with are the smartest and friendliest set of co workers I've had to date.  Everyone wants to succeed but realize you're only as strong as your weakest link.

The most exciting part is that this is a company in hyper growth, who is becoming more and more structured, yet retains the very foundations of it's start up culture (the degree can vary by office location as some offices are smaller than others).  You have the snack bars, catered lunches, equity, social outings, and beer in fridge.  Sprinklr creates for a very exciting yet professional workplace at the same time, where for the first time ever I can honestly say I enjoy going to work.

Our leaders are absolute visionaries, they've created something very special and unique.  The key is employing passionate people who share the same vision, and that's what you'll get in Sprinklr.
Cons: Again, they're trying to be more structured so only if you're not a self starter then that will be a huge con, as you will not be baby-fed anything in the beginning nor after.  401K match is also currently not on the table but that is something the company is looking into.

Pros: Everything is great! This place is good
Cons: There is no problem in this place

Pros: Super knowledgeable, engaged colleagues from around the globe. The culture is truly supportive of wellbeing, both on a personal level and at work. Leadership seems to truly, genuinely care about employees and their wellbeing. The wellbeing offerings are robust, cool, constantly evolving and never boring. Love the wellness platform and wellness speakers.
Cons: One must learn early on to manage their time and protect it by blocking time on the calendar. Given that this is a global company, people are working at all hours depending on where they are in the world. It is important to make sure not to burn out. But I think this applies to work at any global company. We all must individually learn to manage our time and protect it, while being productive.

Review Title: Amazing Company, Hyper Growth.. Exceptional People & Products
Pros:
Simply the most positive and charged atmospheres for employee's that i have ever experienced.

Leadership who cares and will jump in and provide you guidance yet leave you to do what needs to be done, making sure you know you have ample resources and never have to go without help when you need it.

Brilliant minds all around you at all level - each with an open door policy who are willing to take the time to talk with you and hear your voice.

Compensation is fair and on-par with other companies.  Benefits are strong and there are a number of perks that any in-office or remote employees can enjoy.

Work/Life balance is amazing.  The CEO himself talks about how important it is to have a solid work/life balance.  Having the ability to take care of business - Doctor's appointments, Gym, etc. isn't a problem.   Oh... and they have a dog @ work policy - love it.
Cons: Nothing... believe it or not... absolutely nothing so far.  This has been the best experience I've ever had.

Pros:
- Everyone in the office is super positive, helpful and fun to be around
- Great perks (snacks galore, flexible hours/option to work form home, happy hours, sports teams)
- Managers are accessible and have a genuine care for your success
- Lots of resources for newbies to learn the platform and set them up for success 
- Company hosts a training and brings in all new employees from across the world to NY for orientation/training (this is a recently implementation, so it's continuing to evolve and improve)
- Hiring/interview process was long, but they are excellent at keeping you up to date/following-up in a timely manner. They really want to make sure they're hiring people that are the right fit for the company and personify their values. Also, they genuinely work with you to find the right position that fits what you're interested in.
Cons:
- Personally, I don't see this as a con, but you have to be a self-starter to work here, and want to learn as much as you can (aka be proactive and responsible for your own knowledge and success). Not an atmosphere for the lazy or those that want to mentally check out once they leave the office.
- Typical growing pains of a start-up (fast-paced, constant changes, constant platform updates, etc.). Again, not a really a con in my book, but can be for those who aren't interested in that type of environment.

Review Title: Navigating Kyndryl: Benefits Shine, but Compensation and Management Vary
Pros: Kyndryl has a great vacation and sick-leave policy for full-time employees. They guarantee 7 days of sick time per year with the ability for your manager (or short-term disability) to increase this number. We are also given 4 personal choice holidays, 8 paid holidays, and 15 vacation days. Depending on your role and manager, there is flexibility in your working hours that allow for you to "flex" time when necessary.
Cons: Pay is lower than market value and employees that stay with the company are not given adequate raises to keep up with cost of living, experience, or new hires. A lot of your experience is solely determined by the manager that you have. Some managers are great and some are absolutely terrible.

Pros: Flexible, Flat, Focused, People friendly
Cons: Heavy Mainframe contracts, Negative GP contracts

Review Title: Making it up as they go along, quickly becoming the worst of IBM.
Pros: Great legacy with IBM GTS, as such they have access to a stellar account base. Some good people. They are working hard to provide more comprehensive services. Salaries can be good for some when they don't change the comp plan.
Cons: For some reason they did not protect themselves when the contracts novated over from IBM. So that when IBM raises their prices to Kyndryl, they try and pass it along to their customers even mid-contract with them. This causes a customer sat issue. Lots of sat issues. Not focusing on organic growth but only on the few profitable clients. Old time IBM management employees form a click and protect themselves at the cost of efficiency. There is a lot of people staying in roles where they should be shifted and moved around. Others are promoted prematurely based on old connections. Perhaps they will have a management RIF. Top leaders have exorbitant salaries while they rework the comp plan to focus on GP and reduce commissions to those who own the day to day relationships. ( see my comment above on why that is harsh - they artificially raise allocation on SOW's to increase cost of sales )

They make a big show at all the corporate meetings about how important their employees are but it is all lies so don't fall for it.

Review Title: Back to the 90s.. goodbye modern workplace
Pros: I have great management and the business departments are mostly going into the right directions by trying to get more involved with modern cloud technologies.
Cons: Internal processes are living hell right out of a dilbert comic. Their cybersecurity organization tries to control everything. The latest innovation: Tracking your violations against some made-up micromanagement policies like "your can only use approved websites". Each violation gets you a negative point and after a few you get an interview with HR.. I mean - don't they run these things by legal? In a multinational corporations you try to do things like this to your workforce? Regarding Azure.. To even request anything in azure you first need to build a perfect architecture and get it approved through processes that change constantly. And even if you get all the approvals you don't get a subscription (like in every other enterprise this size) but you get only the specific resource you asked for with very limited access to it - everyone who has ever touched azure will know where this goes.. stuff that took me 2 weeks at previous companies now takes 6 months and I don't even know if my resources still work tomorrow because someone decided to change the rules again.. in 8 years working with Azure I never had serious downtime issues.. here it's a weekly thing - I don't even know how you can get downtime in azure..??? Regarding Office365.. They restrict connectors in Power Automate.. so for each flow or power app you create you need to go through an approval process.. you want to use MS forms to get some answers quickly? Nope, you need to work through an 8 week approval process first, get a dedicated environment for it and then you are allowed to use it.. I wouldn't be surprised if they restrict excel formulas next.. (well they probably would if they'd know how to..) It's very sad since the company has great potential but this ancient culture of "we want to do it as we always did" and "our colleagues are our enemies" is really not fun. Especially if you are used to a modern workplace where cloud is normal it just feels like the dark ages here.. (remember 2014 when you needed to use your VPN to connect to a super slow jump host you share with 100 other people so you can get access to a server? yeah.. )

Review Title: Great Company - Off to an Excellent Start
Pros:
They are serious about reducing the "red tape". My team asked for a process improvement, one we had been denied by IBM and Kyndryl executed on it immediately, taking us from a 3 page process that took close to 30 days to execute to a 1 page process that executes is just 5 to 7 days.

The best female leadership diversity I have ever seen. Am very proud to see so many woman leaders - over and over. Our day one global launch party was led by one of our female executives and when we went live on the NYSE, the balcony was full of female faces.

Really appreciate all the time and effort that is spent on making training available for all employees.

There is an excellent system for making employee referrals. It lists all available career opportunities and offers bonus dollars for those making the referral.
Cons: Made a bad choice at the end of last year and didn't grant raises. They issued raises just a couple months later and I received the best raise I have had in years. Worked at IBM 2 years and AT&T for 20 plus years.

Review Title: Growth Plateaued in 2020 and on the decline ever since
Pros:
Great people. They had top talent for many years. It helped me grow a nice network for future opportunities.
SMB ERP space is the only growing area in 2023 - onward.
Cons:
-CEO is following orders since the Koch acquisition. Shed top talent and leaders during the 2022-2024 lay-offs. 
-No R&D and differentiation to the products.
It took 3 years to showcase RPA/ML inside their ERP strategy with their OS platform which is not utilized by the majority of customers. 
-New leadership is needed to spark any change and impact. IFS and Epicor are steadily going to surpass Infor by 2025-2026 for these reasons.
-Certain titles at Infor were a revolving chair and the re-orgs were occurring a few times a year.
-I heard from the top that we had years of declining pipeline growth. That's alarming.

Review Title: Finally, a company who took a chance on me..
Pros: From day one of connecting with my now manager via a networking site, I knew I wanted to work with her at Infor. I now realize she and her team saw more value in me than I saw in myself. Yet, I gave my all during the interviews after she shared the job post with me, and I landed the job. My past experience led me to where I am, but wasn't directly related to my role. I knew I could do the work and do it well, even if there was a learning curve, but I needed someone to take a chance on me. Infor did. Since, my remote team has been encouraging, attentive, available, and patient. I have zero complaints about the pay and benefits, as they are more than what was accessible to me before. There are many opportunities for growth and networking, as well.
Cons: Because all of my teammates work remotely, opportunities to truly get to know them are few and far between. I personally do not like this, but know it cannot be helped given the environment. I've only been at Infor for 5 months, but also worry that raises will not be as plentiful as I once thought and that opportunities for lateral growth in my current department will be difficult to come by.

Review Title: Pro - Good Environment/Cons - Lacks Job Security
Pros: There are great individuals who work at Infor and the management teams are always available to help whenever you have questions. Most teams have incentives to work towards, which you can earn bonuses. Unlimited time off and company equipment is provided.
Cons: Very weak job security. In the two years that I worked with them, I was laid off both times very abruptly. The first time was handled professionally, as I was given the opportunity to look for another role within the company. The second time, I was not given that opportunity. My meeting was scheduled at 10PM the night before and I was laid off the next day along with other team members. The other teams couldn't care less about helping you get your job done. Especially, the AEs. When it comes to trying to get information from them, plan on waiting close to a month or two for a response.

Pros: The company has good policies about time off, and career opportunities, but most if not all managers do not support this. Most pay at the start is good, however it is nearly impossible to get a raise or promotion.
Cons: This company is extremely disorganized and does not stick by the values they claim they hold. There is very little communication around change (which happens constantly), and it is very apparent the executive leadership is extremely out of touch with what is actually happening within the company. Supervisors do a terrible job of connecting with employees, helping them grow, and find what is meaningful to them. The messaging and vision of this company is inconsistent with what is observed as an employee of almost 2 years.

Review Title: Get experience here, take it elsewhere to build your career
Pros: Most positions offer WFH and unlimited paid time off. There are many excellent individuals here and opportunities to collaborate across teams, including globally, to grow your skills. The constant churn of employees is a positive in one way: once you leave, you have contacts at lots of other tech companies.
Cons: Evaluations haven't happened in several years. A much-heralded new review process has started at least twice in the last three years but then fizzled out when new leadership took over, and has yet to be completed. Raises are spotty, with no clear parameters for what they are based on, when they will be given, or how to achieve them. Pay is well below market standards. There have been 5 CMOs in 7 years, and too many re-orgs to count. Infor struggles with name recognition amongst the "big boys," yet executive leadership has swiftly lost their appetite and abandoned any marketing leader who suggested a significant investment in brand activity.

Review Title: Work environment that breeds creativity, collaboration and success!
Pros: Employee empowerment is key. Not only does Skyscanner focus on continued learning, but they encourage their associates to speak their minds and problem solve. They create a culture where its okay to try something new and not simply fit into the mold. They provide flexible work hours, regular feedback, charity days to connect to the community, an abundance of vacation, inter-office bonding events, and an amazing community of free-thinkers I am happy to be a part of.
Cons: I got an error message asking that I put cons in. I'm sure I'm not the first Skyscanner employee to attempt to skip this section and end up seeing that red box. It's for a reason.

Review Title: Fun, relaxed yet fast paced work atmosphere.
Pros: Skyscanner has a great company culture, and great people. The traditional "corporate" bureaucracy is almost non-existent. The reinforces collaboration through teamwork while acknowledging and rewarding individual accomplishments. They provide ample opportunity for career development and make on-going training a priority. Flexible working takes into consideration "real" life and doesn't keep me tied to a desk 9-5.
Cons: Sink or Swim. Skyscanner is a very fast paced work environment where collaboration and individual drive is key. With a complex product it is at times challenging to understand the ever changing technologies that the company is based on.

Pros: Skyscanner is a company with humble beginnings founded by the most humble and down to earth CEO you will ever meet. The company's transparency and trust in the hired staff is what truly makes it a special place to be in. Great benefits, fantastic people to work with and I always found room for growth. I learned a ton every day and I see a bright future ahead for the company.
Cons: There could often be too many meetings and being in the smaller offices, one could feel pressured to attend although it wasn't relevant. There could also be difficulty with communication between the different offices around the world.

Review Title: Unique Culture, great people, amazing technology and product.
Pros: This is the best company I've worked in my career, the culture is extremely good, everyone lives and breathe the values. It's the only company I know that really put the customer first at the heart of decisions, even if the decision could hurt profit, it's all about the traveler experience.  Lot of great technology and big scale systems, which is a dream for Engineers.  Genuine opportunity to make an impact in the world via changing Travel. Great offices. Fail forward culture. I keep learning like the first day and that is priceless for me, a lot of smart people to learn from. Strong people focus.
Cons: I can't see any, I guess that is very fast paced, but it is an Industry characteristic.

- Great health insurance at no cost to the employee. Family members added means you pay a little but nothing outrageous.
- Fully vested 401k the moment you start. And contributions up to 5% matched by the company.
-Brilliant people that really are a joy to work with in all of our offices.
Cons:
-Creativity has been stifled at the cost of velocity.
-Autonomy feels like an illusion in terms of creation.
-Takes a long time to get most anything agreed upon when it comes to higherups.

Pros: Skyscanner is a rare gem for it's product scale! It's a dream to be part of this team and exciting to be part of a company that seeks to transform the travel industry pioneering what's already embedded deeply in our mindset: to be sustainable and traveller first!
Cons: Managing change and growth is always a challenge, but it's the good type of problem.

Pros:
Working at Skyscanner has been an incredible experience for me. One of the most standout aspects is the amazing people I get to work with daily. The team here are not only talented and knowledgeable but also incredibly supportive and friendly, creating a vibrant and collaborative work environment.

The company culture is exceptional. It strikes the perfect balance between professionalism and a relaxed, welcoming atmosphere. This balance fosters creativity and innovation, making it a place where ideas are encouraged and valued.

Another thing that I deeply appreciate is the commitment to employee development. There are abundant opportunities for learning and career growth. 

Most importantly, Skyscanner genuinely cares about its employees. The company goes to great lengths to ensure we're not only satisfied with our work but also thriving in all aspects. From flexible working arrangements to mental health support and regular feedback sessions, it's clear that employee well-being is a top priority.
Cons: Honestly, it's hard to point out any significant downsides. Like any fast-growing company, there are occasional challenges with scaling and adapting, but these are normally met with proactive strategies and clear communication.

Review Title: A company with a good culture, but now in stagnation
Pros:
· People are nice. Colleagues are respectful, polite and genuinely nice. That and good work-life balance are the reasons why people say Skyscanner has a good culture.

· Good work-life balance. There’s a lot of respect for personal boundaries and work-life balance. If you need time off for your physical health, mental health, or family reasons, everyone understands and encourages you to prioritise yourself and your family.

· Traveller-first approach. People care about the users, and put their needs above the needs of the business. It's a rare and admirable cultural trait for a company that big. 

· Mature product development process. Roadmaps, product hypotheses, success metrics, cross-functional collaboration and stakeholder management.
Cons:
· People choose to be nice instead of being honest. That's the flip side of the company culture of niceness. People don’t give “negative” feedback and often avoid any type of confrontation. That gets in the way of getting honest work critique, improving product quality and trying to get career development feedback.

· Career progression is almost impossible. It's a bureaucratic, document-heavy, and unclear process. It takes years and almost impossible to do by the book. To get a promotion people focus not on delivering the work, but on visibility and building relationships to be in favour with the right people from the leadership.

· No vision. There is no ambition, no big bets, no ideas for what's next in travel tech. The leadership presents a few design concepts once a year, but they never get built. There are endless conversations to align on ideas and plans, and no one ever takes the responsibility for a decision.

· Hard to be proud of the product. Product across desktop website, mobile website, and mobile apps looks and works incoherently. Since the beginning of COVID many features were shut down, and never turned back on. In the last years very few new features were launched. If you compare Skyscanner's product with competitors, it's severely behind in quality and convenience.

Overall, Skyscanner is a great place to work if you value work-life balance, nice colleagues, and a good salary and benefits. However, if you are ambitious and want to do your best work, grow, and learn, it's not the best fit for you.

Pros: - Good benefits - like take 3 , take 5 as part of 3 , 5 year service - Team building activities are amazing . - Good life work balance - Great culture. You can be flexible and take time needed as long as you are sensible and cover the times/ hours back - Intelligent colleagues to work with
Cons: - Project ideas get recycled a lot - Technologies get shifted . Once you were focussed in backend now you look at front end for example. There is an increasing need for Web in Skyscanner so distributed systems problems are not many lately . - Young management means you get to work with people who have unrealistic views of timelines and this can be dangerous . - Increased mentoring means you spend quite a bit of time bridging the gap between junior and senior level engineers - This applies for many companies however after senior engineer, your options are more limited and

Pros: Organisation grounded in engineering excellence
Cons: Too much focus on executive leadership

Pros: Good work-life balance and flexibility
Cons: Very little salary gross and not competitive

Pros: nice people, culture, office environment
Cons: business does not clearly prioritise, hard to get promoted

Pros: Since day 1, Skyscanner has repeatedly shown that it lives up to the company values. It gives great flexibility for a work/life balance, challenging tasks and the benefits are great.
Cons: There isn't much to say here. I'm not living in the country where my family lives so would be nice to increase the amount of days per year where one can work from another country.

Pros: Great people, good tech and interesting work
Cons: High expectation for the level of pay

Pros: Supportive team, great benefits, excellent work life balance
Cons: More competitive pay, need a bigger office space

Review Title: A brilliant place to learn and grow
Pros: - Skyscanner is a great place to learn and grow. Every colleague I've ever met is incredibly eager to go the extra mile to share their wisdom. - Post COVID, management have been consistently making sensible decisions on pointing the business in the right direction for us to outgrow our competitors. - If you outgrow your role, promotions and rotations are encouraged albeit somewhat difficult to set in motion.
Cons: - Wage stagnation is a big problem. If you get promoted you will be stuck at the bottom of the band below market average for a LONG time. Trying to address this is not simple and feels like a losing battle. - Some projects can take a while to get off the ground due to having to align so many people, however, this has been improving significantly with new alignment frameworks in place.

Pros: - look after employees - great tech and smart colleagues - really nice office in Central London - a great product that people love to use
Cons: - the promotion process is over complicated and can be difficult and lengthy, putting people off the process entirely - they could be making bigger and riskier bets with the development of the website and app

Pros: - Smart people who care - Good benefits
Cons: - Some management need to more deeply understand the business

Review Title: Great People, Culture and Opportunities to Learn
Pros:
- The people really care about each other. They are welcoming and helpful and low-ego. If you need support your team is going to be there for you. It's a great place to learn on the job.
 - You feel connected and part of the strategy regardless of the department you are in. We get a lot of updates about progress to the goals in Townhalls and there is a Daily revenue KPI email that keeps people informed of how we are doing as a business. I've never see that level of transparency anywhere else.
- We are very Traveler focused and there is a lot of work being done to make sure the product is accessible to everyone.
- Managers have access to a lot of training and there are specific programs to help people who want to get in to management the opportunity to do that with a support network.
- Incredible Annual Leave benefits, including an additional 5 week holiday on top of your usual leave that you get after 5 years service.
Cons: - Nowhere is perfect but I can't think of anything that needs to be fixed that isn't already in the plan to improve.

Review Title: They don't know what they're doing
Pros: Company Culture (In some areas) Nice offices Good onboarding
Cons: The experience of leadership in the Agile space is extremely questionable. One of the main director in this space believes Scrum Masters are Managers so that says it all really. They're also tracking progress using 'Epic Cycle Time' as their main indicator of progress and they have a 40 page software delivery handbook that everyones forced to read when they join and if you ask questions you're immediately pointed back to the handbook. Basically, they've hired people in very senior roles who have very little experience, and everyones been there for a long time so they haven't seen what it's like in other companies. You will also get fired for having a different opinion or pointing out challenges even if it is part of your role as a coach. I wouldn't apply if you're an experienced Agile Coach would be my advise as you'll be flogging a dead horse and they also don't have a strategy either. They only hire people into the role that haven't had a lot of industry exposure so they can mould them to fit Skyscanner. They also over-hired during covid and are at a stuck point for the next 4-5 years in terms of hiring roles they need to address some of their core challenges. My personal advise would be, save yourself the headache!

Pros: Great culture and great people work at Skyscanner. It strives to do the right thing with people and foster a collaborative culture of improvement across its internal processes and products.
Cons: Sometimes things can take a while to get done across areas due to the high degree of autonomy present within teams. Coordination can be hard.

Pros: Lots of things to learn Work life balance People friendly
Cons: Even though they say they normalize salary for same role, there are still gaps in the pay

Pros: Work culture is awsome. people really care about you the offices are awsome, and we have so many in-office events there is not much work pressure. encouraged to take leaves.
Cons: being less employees, it gets boring in office, especially on days, where employees generally work from home.

Pros: Best culture and life balance I've ever had from an employer. The atmosphere here is fantastic and work interesting and engaging.
Cons: Promotion process is heavy and demanding. Easier to get employed at a level than to be promoted to that level

Pros: There is lot of growth opportunities
Cons: Too much meetings can be overwhelming

Review Title: Good WLB, but lack of growth
Pros: WLB is great, and lots of freedom on choosing what you’d like to work on. Managers are kind and caring.
Cons: Lack of career growth. The business doesn’t have a big potential to go to the next level. The management doesn’t have a clear vision.

Pros: Really care about culture, lots of little day to day office life perks, committed team, excellent attention to diversity and inclusion
Cons: big, old, complicated systems that move slowly.

Review Title: Very humane place to work on an interesting problem space
Pros:
- A lot of smart people that you can keep learning from
- Great work life balance and hybrid working is very well executed
- The company really cares about your wellbeing, your humanity is respected
- When you demonstrate ability, you're being trusted with problems/projects of ever increasing scope and impact
- Great compensation package and base compensation in product design
- New office location and set up is going to be rad!
Cons:
- Pet unfriendly London office
- Lots of change in design leadership in the last couple of years
- Lots of new people come in and compromise gains and rewrite strategy just to have something to list in their resume
- Too many times the first iteration of something is the only iteration of something; some product managers love flaunting that they've shipped something, that they have run N number of experiments - and deemed experiment a failure after heavily descoping and compromising the spirit of the concept
- Lots of red tape - in terms of promotions and career growth(Senior to Principle is notoriously difficult) AND in terms of everything else (any extra curricular initiative dwindles as there's an insane amount of bureaucracy required to get it done)

Pros: Don't pay much tax due to low salaries Engineering teams are slow to build so gives you time to do nothing Engineers have little experience therefore designs don't get questioned.
Cons: Low pay Office location in Edinburgh is not good Office is looking dated Workforce is not diverse

Pros: The benefits are pretty good, such as 5 weeks of paid time off after 5 years of service
Cons: Employee compensation is not great

Pros: Very smart people, who are keen to share knowledge and also learn from your experiences. Willingness to experiment and take chances. Customer first approach Will listen to employees in regards to company vision and if you have a good manager will help support your career progression
Cons: Pivot frequently on strategy - often without completing prior focus.

Review Title: A company with a vibrant culture and traveller first mentality
Pros: 1) well being focused company culture 2) esteemed service that many travellers use 3) you’ll find this phrase used a lot “happy to help!” 4) very global team 5) multi-faceted feedback system
Cons: 1) changes happen very suddenly often times 2) timezone differences with different teams

Pros: A lot of great people still work here. There are lots of opportunities for people willing to do whatever it takes to be the best. There are also lots of opportunities for people interested in focusing on the work, head down, and prefer to take direction.
Cons: The culture has changed dramatically since the pandemic. I no longer feel value-aligned with the company and don't feel comfortable saying more.

Review Title: Great company to start as a grad!
Pros: I find the rotation aspect of the graduate scheme very valuable as we get to explore different areas of engineering in the span of two years. Moreover, real responsibility is given to us from day 1 to make impactful change and when stuck, we can always reach out for help and everyone is always willing to help.
Cons: If you prefer to stay in a single team and don't appreciate the rotation aspect, this may not be the programme for you.

Pros: Great place to stay and work
Cons: Currently not have anthing to share

Pros: Relaxing culture, friendly team, nice office
Cons: Progression is subjective and can take a long time

Review Title: Good employer overall. Could improve management of staff
Pros: Bounced back from the pandemic and retained much of the staff. Staff were incentivised to stay by being given shares in the company. Pay has been really good. Opportunities to progress have been good in the past, these are a bit more limited now given the new shape the business has taken. (See below) I generally feel well cared for as an employee.
Cons: Hasn't quite mastered making innovation viable yet Since the pandemic, Skyscanner has re-focused the product development back to its core meta product. This means there isn't too much scope for any fresh, interesting projects for now. This could change in the future. The company has experimented with some innovative products in the past, but ultimately many of them have been eventually shelved. I have worked on several initiatives that were expensive and eventually turned out to be non-viable. This either because the business model was not viable, or the context of travel changed. Skyscanner could benefit by going back to its start up mindset, to test and learn faster. Management is a weakness There are a few really good managers, but their impact and contributions are not rewarded enough. I personally do not feel well managed, in terms of clear expectations being set or getting constructive feedback in a timely manner. It's a consensus across my team. Most employees are laser focused on their own career progression which can mean there is sometimes a competitive and non-cooperative vibe at times. The emphasis for career progression is on individual contributor work, which means the management focus is not quite there.

Pros: just a really nice place to work
Cons: lack of career progression, specifically within internal growth

Review Title: Great people, great environment, great benefits
Pros: Enjoyed working with the people. Everyone is helpful and cooperative in getting things done.
Cons: A lot of red tape affected the dev schedule. NO concrete release date for the feature since they are working agile and will release it when the item comes into the sprint. This made it hard to work around the feature.

Review Title: Forward thinking company with strong core values
Pros:
Really is a people centric organisation where they fully support employees to develop with training and allocated time for development.
Has a really good internal recognition platform to celebrate successes but also has a fail fast culture which means they celebrate trying something new and working out quickly that it is the wrong thing to do.
A decent reward package with shared ownership being big part of Skyscanner's success.
Working towards changing travel to be sustainable. 
Really orientated to deliver for the traveler and looks for employees that have a passion for travel.
Really passionate about diversity in the workplace with various working groups driving constant improvements.
Cons: Being in travel during covid had been hit by resourcing levels due to leavers. Has however supported staff throughout the period and is recovering strongly with a new strategic direction brought in by the CEO John.

Review Title: Potential is there, but not living up to it at the moment

Cons: * how team organised creates tech constraints in solving tasks * processes ineffective - more talking about problems then trying to solve them * very slow grow perspective - had to perform on next level virtually a couple years to even consider promotion * attrition - most people around either long worked never having other job to compare, or new joiners

Pros: - Great work culture - Cool life - Good tech stack - Some decent benefits

Pros:
Since the development of the 2025 company strategy, the morale in the company feels as though it’s on its way up out of the gloom that has been the pandemic years. 

The move to hybrid working will be a positive one in my opinion (though some may disagree with me on this)… and it seems senior leadership have listened and are making efforts to make sure the culture of the company is still a major draw card for the current and any prospective employees.

Recent announcements have also seen some benefits that were put on hold due to the recovery mode we entered (a result of the pandemic) reinstated - and that’s certainly lifted spirits as well. I feel hopeful about the company’s future once again.
Cons: Compensation reviews can’t come soon enough - (and we’ve been told they are).

Review Title: Very good at pretending to be a fair company
Cons:
- The growth path is allegedly clear, but decisions about promos are made behind closed doors in ways that do not follow the process, e.g. they have a calibration process to ensure parity, but senior leadership can go around it.
- Discriminatory feedback involving mental health issues. This was raised to the people team leadership, but I've seen no outcome from it.
- Software Quality is not what they state in their values. They could have been 1st class engineering in the past, but that is not even close to the current situation.

Review Title: Used to be good,  not any more
Pros:
There are so many smart people, no blame culture in general.
Nice offices at the price of generally low income
Cons:
1) Very high attrition, which means there is so much knowledge lost.
2) Salaries are lacking behind the market, which is the main reason for the high attention. Still, Skyscanner is paying so much money on renting its offices, this doesn't make sense, why would a tech/travel company rent in best locations with very high bills when it cannot afford to raise salaries to keep up with inflation? 
3) Promotion process is chaotic, to say the least.
4) Forcing people back to office, when they know for a fact that the work can be done remotely (looks like senior management use pre-covid mindset).

Pros: Distance to office convenient, could work from home, good work, great relationships with customers and peers.
Cons:
I worked well over 40 hours a week for Akamai. I busted myself to make Akamai look good, to do everything that I could to make my customers happy, because that made me happy. But I never got any credit for the amount of work that I put in to pick up the slack because people were dropping things left and right. But let a small mistake slip through the cracks because you are overworked, you are looked at like you are not worthy to be there. Management never took a look at the operations, even though concerns were raised, but instead they didn't like people raising concerns and honed in on the person raising concerns and in the end, the overworked person trying to fill the gaps is often the one punished. They never fixed and probably still to this day have not fixed the root cause. 

Certain people were on customer accounts that were not serving them well. I was hired to come in and help serve those accounts. I was subjected to several months of grueling training known as "whiteboarding" where you do several hours of really bad online training, work with a mentor, and then the people who are going to be your peers (or in my case whose work I would be taking on) test you. Now that sounds kind of strange right? The people with the bad attitudes, whose accounts were being neglected were doing the test proctoring? That is correct. So, if they knew that you would be taking some of their work, it seemed that they really liked sabotaging you. You are in a room with a whiteboard, a camera, there are people in the room, you have no notes, no references, and you have no idea what people are going to ask you. And there are people purposely try to rabbit hole you so that you bomb the presentation within minutes so that they can have a laugh. And it did happen. I had worked so hard on my presentation and how I was going to put it into my own words, thoughts, pictures, and had presented it to my mentor, who passed off on it, only to be bounced on a question that had nothing to do with what I had been presenting. The audience are in a notepad session where they are writing notes on you and each can see what the others are writing. I watched guys pass their training with flying colors. No hard questions. It was like the high five fist bump macho club. However, there was one guy who minutes into his presentation got rabbit holed and he said "**Explicatory** it" and sat down at the table. He gave up trying and eventually quit. 

As a female, you don't get invited to lunch with the bro club. Even if you work on the same accounts., which leads to things being discussed and you are out of the loop, just because you don't have the right chromosomes. 

I didn't get a raise for years and when I asked why, there were "other people that were making less than me" was the reason. So, no matter if I had a killer year, the customers loved me, and the slacker that was making less than me was still slacking, it didn't matter. Things needed to be equaled out according to management. 

You could take a class, and be reimbursed for it. However, if you missed the deadline in getting your receipt in, you couldn't get it, even with a good reason. And especially if you had a boss who wouldn't bat for you. Why is there a deadline anyway? I got an entire Masters degree paid for by an employer, including books, tuition, and even got a bonus after I completed it. Funny, I did that just fine over a period of 2 years, but took one little course at Akamai and couldn't get reimbursed for it. That is what you contend with when you have a boss that is not in your corner. It could have been reimbursed but they chose not to. 

To work there, you had to be a manly woman to get the respect of your team. Some women would actually lower their voices and act bro-like to get respect. People should be looked at and respected for who they are, not what they have in their pants. 

If I thought my old manager was bad, enter the new manager who was once my peer. He was in love with himself and loved to hear himself talk. Nobody could stand him. He only did what management told him, trampled on his teammates, when he made mistakes, he blamed others, and tried to take credit for so many things in order to get brownie points and they still wouldn't promote him. He had a penchant for always being right and arguing with everyone. Because they ran out of people to promote, he eventually got the management job and we all congratulated him. But eventually, he made my life so bad that I didn't even want to be at work any longer and I put in my 2 weeks notice. My peers and my customers were so confused as to why I was leaving. You have your customers sad that you are leaving, meanwhile your boss is ripping on you in 1:1 meetings, quizzing you on things that you had in training years before and passed and don't use in your day to day job. I tried to say something, but HR isn't your friend. They are looking out for the #1 and it's not you. When several people quit their jobs in a period of months, huge red flags should be going up.

Pros: Great benefits, chill work environment

Review Title: Good culture and solid growth opportunities
Pros: Lots of room for advancement, cross training and your manager won’t block you from switching departments. There are regular wellness days off, and you aren’t expected to be online after your shift hours. People are genuinely very friendly and the senior managers are decently down to earth. It’s not for everyone and if I’m being honest a lot of the people I’ve personally seen get fed up with a lack of progress or recognition are people who really didn’t put in much effort to learn the job they had or contribute much. I’d worked at so many companies that promised me promotions or new roles and just ghosted me. Akamai actually recognized my efforts and helped me grow. With the right skills and ambition you could launch a pretty great career here
Cons: Usual big company bureaucracy but nothing egregious. A lot of people just plain get burnt out. There’s an absolute ton to learn and there’s constantly more material being piled on.

Review Title: Good company, weak leadership, really bad Marketing org
Pros: - Competitive compensation, benefits - Good company politics and business ethics - Flexible work model allowing choice between office, home, or hybrid setup - Tons of highly intelligent individuals and a generally positive corporate culture - Established market presence and customer base
Cons: - Marketing org has a significant lack of management efficiency and accountability, making it the most disorganized I've encountered. - If you're a marketing professional focused on modern, data-driven digital B2B methods, I cannot recommend this organization. The absence of proper analytics and agility, along with outdated approaches, undermines its potential. - The CMO's competency in addressing these problems seems inadequate.

Review Title: Good Employee Experience from a Directionless Organization
Pros: Fantastic employee experience with lots benefits and opportunities for growth. Some of the best managers I've ever worked with who truly care about their team members on personal and professional levels. An extra set of company holidays (wellness days) are available every year. Employees are provided a massive level of freedom and trust to get the work done.
Cons: Upper management and leadership are largely directionless and uncommunicative. Executives don't appear to be on the same page or have concrete goals which leads to a lack of top-down prioritization or decision making. Most leadership has been promoted from within the company, which keeps Akamai behind in industry standards.

Review Title: A Year of Growth and Empowerment: Reflecting on My Journey at MongoDB
Pros:
During my past year in MongoDB, I have witnessed firsthand the company's remarkable growth and expansion. And it's exciting to be part of an organization that is constantly reaching new heights. 
Here are some points that I would consider as Pros: 
1. Comprehensive training resources for new hires to ramp up the knowledge. You dont have to be an expert in database or cloud computing domain to join the company, as long as you are willing to take the challenge and keep learning. 
2. Consistent behavior exhibited by its leadership team, both internally and in public presence. 
3. MongoDB is relatively in smaller scale in my region, but it also means you will be granted more responsibilities to experience, and also experiment new process, new industry, new customers with strong support from internal teams.
4. Product-oriented approach and really care about the developer community and customer feedbacks.
Cons:
1. Sometimes in daily work, you do have to play one-man bank to take care of different tasks that might not technically "in-scope" of your role. 
2. You may need to work or have meetings in hours that not favor your timezone due to the distribution of the global team.

Review Title: Cool place to work if you are not a partner.
Pros: Everyone is amiable and helpful when you need help or learn something.
Cons:
If you work as a partner, you'll always be stuck in your position, there is no place to grow, and all the jobs that are boring or the MongoDB employees don't want to do will be allocated to you. They will always allocate good clients or interesting consulting sessions to their own team, so it's hard to learn something new or work on a cool project. 
But the most demotivating thing is the no-compete agreement with the companies that hire the partners. If you apply for any open position at MongoDB, they won't schedule an interview, even if you're one of the best partner consulting engineers in the company with an overstanding knowledge of MongoDB.

Pros:
I find High-Trust, High-Performance, Healthy Culture in the organization, more of the Values driven, where employees feel valued and respected, leading to an increase in productivity and job satisfaction. MongoDB provide the comfort that every career opportunities dreamed of:-
Employee autonomy
Employee benefits
Always there is motivation to work
Flexible hours
Timely Rewards & Recognition
Best offered compensation
Cons: Nothing i can figure out...

Review Title: Some good people, but traumatic experience
Pros:
- Competitive pay
- Decent benefits, good health insurance
- Snacks and lunch 3x/week in the office
- "Unlimited" PTO (suggested 20)
- Made friends with some coworkers
Cons:
- A VP expressed annoyance about maternity leaves in their department
- A Director referenced the terrible German leader from WWII (Glassdoor counts the name as "bad language") as a good public speaker in a team meeting in an off-the-cuff comment
- A VP was observing said meeting and stayed silent
- A Lead put words in my mouth when speaking to a PM
- A teammate was negging
- Questions you ask if you're a POC will be "forgotten," further perpetuating a stereotype
- The longer you're there, the more you get away with. MongoDB allows its oldest employees to treat others however they want, and will twist things to fit their narrative when you try to stick up for yourself.
- Your experience here will be very department and team specific.

Pros:
Good remunerations and benefits. Super diverse teams, and good work life balance.
By far, the best onboarding process that I ever experienced.
Awesome culture, and people who takes the culture seriously.
Cons: Not so flexible about work remotely anymore.

Pros: Free lunches and snacks in the office.
Cons:
The atmosphere at MongoDB is challenging, with inexperienced engineers promoted to leadership roles lacking necessary experience. There's a lack of emotional intelligence training, and communication seems belittling. It feels like a situation where individuals with inflated egos, akin to children, are managing the company. The dynamic suggests engineers and product teams dominate, while others are perceived as mere minions. Expressing new ideas is met with swift dismissal and sometimes negative labeling.

The technical program director appears unresponsive to feedback, sticking to outdated methods. Instead of fostering an open environment, she retaliates when confronted and lacks a strong engineering background. During culture amp surveys for anonymous feedback, she conducted meetings to identify contributors, even alluding to potential repercussions for her livelihood. Despite notifying HR, no actions were taken.

Pros:
+ Top-notch product 
+ Smart people 
+ Customers love the product
Cons:
+ Toxic leadership 
+ Career progression is vague 
+ Promotions based on who the boss likes 
+ High turnover rates
+ Managers promoted not based on skills but based on tenure in the company

Pros: Pretty good training. All virtual though.
Cons:
Almost all of your success will be tied to your accounts. The other piece of your success is how well you can game the system and look busy to your leader. Most leaders, especially the VP level, are former order takers at the business, who are not good when it comes to advice or sales strategies. The biggest bro culture I have ever seen, if you're not in the club, good luck. If you are, you'll get the best accounts and all of the opps from the people not in the bro club who left. 

Being an Enterprise AE here without a hot patch is about the same day-to-day and pay as an SDR.

They talk a big game about their sales process and MBA of sales, but it seems that is to get reps in the door and convince reps to stay. In my experience since, the sales org is not highly regarded externally. Take a look at all of the people who have left within the past year. I've never seen an exodus like this before.

Review Title: Bro sales culture and moving targets
Pros:
Great product
Smart teams and leaders
Cons:
Micromanaging

Intense "bro" sales culture

My comp structure changed every quarter I worked there and I didn't know my metrics for the first month of the quarter - moving target.

You're never good enough mentality - even if you hit your number every quarter, they want to know what you could have done better, why didn't you ask X questions and how can you improve next time. While that can help with self-reflection and growth, when you are never recognized for accomplishments and only pushed to reflect on what you didn't do, it can be demotivating. There needs to be a balance.

Pros: Comfortable work environment, driven engineering, honest and transparent communication
Cons: Working on open and source available code can invite unwarranted criticism which is distinct from a position that only requires work on proprietary code

Review Title: Just be honest and say you're doing layoffs!
Pros: Great product and long standing leadership has made great decisions for the business.
Cons: The core leadership team CEO & CFO/COO remain strong but as the company grows it is has been making weak leadership hires and beginning to operate as a large company. We are seeing a lot of people leave because of this. Also the intellectual honesty is disappearing. Instead of doing lay offs like every other company in the tech space, they are having bar raising, then underperforming conversations and managing people out as a result. Feels like a way to reduce the size and operating costs of a company without having to pay people severance packages.
