Review Title: Not a good time to be working at MongoDB
Pros: It was a great place to get a technical refresh and get familiarity with cloud provider service offerings and niche database solutions.
Cons: Myself and my team had issues getting paid on Commissions. There is no transparency in the process. We had to wait over 8 months to get $20K that was contractually obligated but they failed to pay. The senior management is focused on cost-savings initiatives and cares little for the employees well being. The West Coast in particular is understaffed and way overworked. If you are female - you are paid less than your male counterparts. There is very little representation of females to men in the sales organization. People are leaving right and left due to the toxic nature of the management team. The senior management is stuck on how things were when they were individual contributors and fail to grasp how the markets, products, number of competitors and space has changed. Issues were raised to senior levels of management and HR and HR only supports the toxic managers. There is no room for growth in the role or within the division unless you want to become a Sales Rep.

Review Title: It's a good company to be with
Pros: The industry puts you in a position to learn and grow a connection across multiple tech ecosystems,
Cons: It could be daunting for those who might not passionate in tech in general

Review Title: Run away as fast as you can!
Pros: Product is excellent and the technology fit is good in current market.
Cons: Just watched a Regional Director humiliate and bully his direct report in a QBR in front of 20 of his peers. Leadership and other management in room said nothing.

Review Title: Great Product but Toxic Culture in Sales
Pros: Great culture outside of Sales, Brand Name, Workplace, Hybrid setup of work from office
Cons: 1. Sales leadership exhibits a highly toxic culture. 2. Excessive micromanagement, frequent unnecessary meetings, and round-the-clock messages from the directors. 3. Top performing Sales directors and Account Executives do not contribute to sales; instead, they manipulate the system (sfdc) to take credit and commissions for the accounts in different regions outside India. 4. The growth team is equally redundant since the product practically sells itself, resulting in the labeling of new clusters and organic growth as upsells. 5. The leadership endorses and supports these unscrupulous practices, with the exception of the new AVP in the region who might not even know of all this in detail.

Review Title: Toxic culture and bad comp plan that’s getting worse each year
Pros:
Health benefits 
Apple work devices (all provided)
Opportunity to grow your professional network
Cons: Where do I begin? This place was once pretty decent years ago, but even then it was a tough place to be from a culture and quota attainment perspective. If you’re a minority of any kind you will likely be the only one in the room if not one of a handful. Expect to be micro managed and work well over 50 hours a week if you want to be viewed as a good employee. Overly complex comp structure that only a small percentage of people actually hit. Lots of bad managers have ended up in middle management positions across sales, customer success, and sales dev. You cannot share feedback unless it’s positive but you have to subject yourself to feedback of any kind at all times. Sales org is a walking HR violation (I saw this in another review) as it’s only men who all look the same. There’s zero diversity of any kind across most regions and they refuse to acknowledge this or do anything meaningful about it. Sales execs and senior leadership leaving left and right over the past 18 months and it looks like that trend is continuing. Managers only care about the numbers and nothing more. You have no room to be person. My manager was responsible for 4 people either asking to leave their team, or who ended up quitting, and that manager is still with the company. Sales org is a good ole boys club and those who fall in line or get close to the right people will get good accounts, grace, and actual mentoring. Customer success org doesn’t seem to be much better. I’ve heard horror stories from other regions about women getting push back for wanting to take their full maternity leave or coming back after leave with all new accounts, etc. The most toxic and exhausting QBR experience with people regularly suffering from massive amounts of stress and anxiety or going to the bathroom to cry. Full of mind games. Also, no team building events besides binge drinking. If they want you gone they will push you until you just quit. Also, the pay is below the standard for sales execs now…If I can sum up this place in a few words: just a traumatizing boys club full of egos that are stuck in an echo chamber of their own beliefs.

Pros: Great training programs and culture
Cons: Depends on you manager on how well you’re start is. Most are great

Review Title: Great company but know what you're getting into
Pros: learning, growth potential, TAM is huge (lot of opportunity)
Cons: culture is a little toxic, focus only on performance, very technical product

Review Title: Great place to work, great role, very demanding work
Pros: - Great learning opportunities - the first two months are the most accurate manifestation of "drinking from the firehose" I have experienced in my 11-year career as an engineer. Seriously, you learn so much useful stuff. - Awesome culture. - Big company but operates in a spokes-and-hubs fashion, so each office feels like a small startup. - Generous compensation and benefits. - Sensible middle and senior management.
Cons: Consulting engineering, which is the delivering role of MongoDB's Professional Services, is a very demanding role. Customer work has somewhat strict hours - you're dedicated to a single customer on a given day and work with them until late afternoon. After that, you must collect and tidy up your detailed notes before they're sent to the customer. Long story short, 9-5 won't cut it here. This creates a tricky situation for working parents in an egalitarian relationship who wish to see their kids during the week and not offload pickup to someone else. Keep that in mind and ask your hiring manager about how flexible the daily routine is for consultants. In the first few weeks in the role, I felt a little lost and almost lost my faith in my ability to do it just because of the daily agenda.

Pros: Helped me to build and own the science of selling. Helped me to earn more than I’ve ever earned. Fantastic leadership  who are consistent and focused, great product and market fit.
Cons: It’s development heavy culture and will only fit you if you fit the specific criteria you and mongoDB have

Pros: Love the product and people. Everyone top down is super technical. 100% employees are aligned with core values of the company which is indeed the best.
Cons: Employees fully remote do not have a great internet reimbursement policy. Like in my case my home is 42.1 mile from MongoDB office and based on Austin peak hour traffic it takes close to 3hrs one way commute that makes it practically impossible. As per the policy you have to be atleast 50 miles away to be eligible.

Pros: Good pay for a graduate
Cons: Repetitive work and average coworkers

Review Title: Classic Case of Money Cannot Buy You Culture
Pros: - Competitive compensation - Benefits - Flexibility - Cross Functional team members(some of them) and Mentors(outside India) can be a delight to work with and can help you learn.
Cons: 1. Leadership hired is extremely short sighted, inexperienced and clearly in positions they are not meant to be in. 2. Mentally abusive Management with a microaggressive approach towards subordinates. Calling them out will only invite retaliation, gaslighting and whistleblower treatment. 3. Experienced folks may have to wait a long time to get meaningful work. HR Teams are equally immature with no accountability or tools to mitigate instances of workplace bias and mental harassment. 4. Women bully women - cannot generalize this as I met some inspiring people but my direct manager was a complex case of bullying, micromanagement, microaggression, false sense of authority especially towards brown women subordinates and a general lack of integrity. 5. Lack of trust, team building, acknowledgments and good morale. 6. No career planning or KPI tracking. Faulty methods of performance evaluation. 7. Poor shift hours catering to serve only the US team.

Pros: Truly trains you to be the best. Amazing Company to be apart of. The commitment to continuous learning and development is evident in the robust training programs designed to empower individuals to reach their full potential. Being part of this organization means immersing yourself in an environment that fosters innovation, collaboration, and a relentless pursuit of excellence.
Cons: Communication isn't always clear and base pay isnt that great compared to other companies with the same role.

Pros:
* Leadership is rock solid
* MongoDB is rapidly gaining market share and developer mindset
* The product roadmap is exciting with lots of great learning opportunities
* Smart people work here
Cons: The biggest issue is that MongoDB is they are no longer a startup. In fact they are a very mature company compared to what they were even 5 years ago. Pains with this now can be seen in slow moving internal processes and having to deal with the "multiple chefs in the ktichen" problem e.g. so many people are now involved in making decisions and have opinions on features/functionality that things move really slow. That said it isn't unique to MongoDB, I would think most companies of this size (over 5,000 employees) have these issues.

Review Title: Comfortably uncomfortable - this is a good thing!

It really is exciting to get to work here every day

Review Title: Lots of potential, lots of hard work
Pros: The company has great values that almost all employees try to embody. Huge focus on customer success and doing the right thing. The product is incredible, one of the best SaaS solutions in the market. The new wave of AI also has MongoDB uniquely positioned to capture much more of the market.
Cons: Lots of hard work, the company expects a lot from all employees. Lots of change happening that can cause confusion and competing priorities.

Pros: They invest alot in personal development and give ADR's alot of resources to understand the technology. Overall MongoDB has great MGMT and great AE's to work with.
Cons: Pay could be alot more competitive, & they dont offer RSU's.

Review Title: Great company with even greater things ahead !
Pros:
Good technology, good positioning with developers. 
Well positioned for the next AI evolution. 
Ambitious and eager to please its employees.
Cons: Too much turnover in the Sales team probably due to high pressure there, not ideal to create long term relationship with users and/or customers.

Pros: I'm in my third year in the sales organization here at MongoDB, and loving it. It's different from any sales team I've been a part of before - from the leadership quality to the development I'm getting here, it's top notch. Can't think of a better place to be right now!
Cons: The expectations and bar are set high. You will feel stretched and challenged, but it's worth it. Don't expect to be promoted after a quarter or two - the bar for promotions is high as well.

Pros: Good benefits and salary if you can work hard.
Cons: People are very intelligent and helpful in the company. Need to work hard to catch up but it pays.

Review Title: Great company- fast paced, good rewards
Pros: Solid sales process, great market presence, a lot of upside if you follow the process and target the right accounts.
Cons: sink or swim type mentality. Quick ramp and expected to hit the ground running.

Review Title: Prioritise competency (together with culture) and hire compentent leaders preferably with larger MNC experience
Pros: Friendly and open environment, cross collaboration is a key part of the culture
Cons: There are a number of senior longer tenured employees with little to none large MNC experience therefore they do not know what to do when faced with new scenarios, lack initiative, lack competency required of their level and spend too much time on detailed work. Also, a lot of time is spent obtaining employees' opinions and decisions seem driven primarily by these opinions. Trying to advocate everyone to be a leader is not effective if the staff themselves are not competent, project priorities don't seem to be mature and appraisals are more focused on encouraging preferred behaviour than actual work deliverables. Too many meetings on leadership (talking about leadership does not train one to be a leader) and rolling out raising-the-bar initiative but there are no concrete standards on what it practically means.

Pros: Lots of nice people who take pride in teamwork and like to help others. Minimal political intrigue. Not a cutthroat environment. Main product is a database. Companies stick with the same tech stack for a long time (too long), MDB will be in business for a long time.
Cons: Too many executives in the biggest job they've ever had and are in way over their heads trying to run an enterprise company. Over-promoted middle managers who don't know what they don't know and allergic to change. Homegrown systems and processes haven't scaled and many groups are behind on industry practices. Collaborative culture has big benefits but at the big price of micromanagenent, too many cooks in the kitchen, and hazy accountability.

Pros:

Cons: OTE could be more competitive

Review Title: Great Product, tech stack and Salary, BAD Work/Life balance
Pros: -- Pay is great. -- Health Benefits are great. -- Equity is ok. -- Product is solid. -- The work is exciting and the technologies used are great for experience.
Cons: -- Extremely overloaded, we pretty much work around the clock. But still pressured constantly that we must "Raise the bar". -- A large amount of employees have horrible attitudes, very rude and zero compassion. -- Priorities change daily/weekly and are in addition to fully loaded planned work. Everything is a priority and immediately pushed on you with expectation that your current "thing" will be finished as it was a commitment. -- Not hiring, which causes tech debt and current workloads to continue to drown the employees which put in the work. -- Remote workers are no longer aided in any way (You pay your own bills, no benefits to help) -- PTO is unlimited, but you will never get to use it because you are lucky if you even get your evenings and weekends off, much less a work day. -- Requirements are never provided, and the work is demanded on an arbitrary timeline that is never realistic. -- Story points are not story points but timesheet style hourly commitments. -- Team development? Not here, everyone has their own full sprints of hours and you are lucky if anyone is helping you or you helping others. -- Even if you are a rockstar, better than average reviews are extremely limited, if that, as a way for the company to cut costs. -- VERY UNEVEN DISTRIBUTION OF EQUITY FROM TOP DOWN

Review Title: Great place to work but must know how to adapt
Pros: - get to work with incredibly smart people - work life balance - employees are treated well, managers are caring - great product - high standards across the board. makes it a great place to work and easy to get stuff done - huge focus on growth and development; leaders invest in your career - unlimited PTO that you are actually encouraged to take (I take at least 4-5 weeks per year) - overall great benefits (Carrot fertility, mental health and personal coaching, affinity groups / ERGs, mentor programs, parental programs and benefits like backup care and parenting guidance, 5 months paid parental leave for both moms and dads)
Cons: - we are not the cheapest option for customers, which can lead to difficult conversations during renewals - some c-level managers can come off as out-of-touch - hypergrowth company means constant change, which can lead to burnout - no 401k match - if you're not in a main office, you miss out on a lot of benefits like free food, networking events, etc - D&I is hit or miss depending which org you're in

Pros: Freedom to excel how you want to
Cons: Growing pains of a growing company

Review Title: Started great, then steadily declined in its culture
Pros: Smart people, competitive compensation, bi-weekly retrospectives on processes and team work, quarterly onsites, and interesting projects. There are still some great people working here, but there are also those who ruin it for everyone else, as you'll see in the cons section.
Cons:
While the company started out mostly great when I joined, many projects were not planned out correctly and resulted in gross underestimation, while churn relieved its original participants from any accountability. This only becomes apparent over time, but by the time one realizes the predicament they are in, they are too heavily invested and overworked to crawl out of it. Its famed culture started to decline soon after the arrival of several top level executives from Amazon, and once tech layoffs became fashionable, management blissfully declared that no layoffs were planned but instead "raised the bar" by vastly reducing the number of overperformers during each review cycle and enforced that 5% must be underperformers. Indeed, the culture continued its rapid descent while the company took on more and more former Amazon executives.

To be fair, promotions were rampant and many people who were not ready for their new roles were promoted too quickly to begin with. Perhaps this was seen as a way to combat the rapid rise, but did little to deal with people who were already in those roles; there were plenty of 'leaders' who are in no position to lead others. These people remained in positions of power while themselves underperformed, and are now pressured to deliver or streamline their costs. This resulted in making demands on their teams that started to overstep reasonable expectations, pushing those team members into the "underperform" category and finally managing them out with a performance improvement plan, despite performing well in every other metric, resulting in termination without severance. Culture, innovation, and work life balance now take a backseat at this company, but I suspect this is only the beginning.

Review Title: Query Team - Hard Time for Junior Engineers
Pros: - Vast majority of employees are extremely friendly and approachable. Everyone is knowledgeable and intelligent. - The work is interesting! The projects are very well thought out despite the problems being so difficult. - Code quality is mostly high. There's a lot of tech debt, but with time this will go away. This is a great company if you want to improve your C++ skills.
Cons: - Team choice is a coinflip. You can have a lead that is very available and will help you with career growth, or one that is invisible. Most leads are too busy with technical work to pay close enough attention to give feedback. Many junior engineers do not get any negative feedback unless they remind their lead many times. There are a few cases where promotions have been implied, but then at the last minute negative feedback is provided and no promotion is given. This is a hard situation to navigate for a junior engineer. - For the most productive engineers, bad behavior is ignored. These engineers are so knowledgeable and crucial to certain projects that consistently bad behavior is overlooked. They can be condescending and unapproachable with no repercussions. Many junior engineers avoid them, even though they are often the best person to ask questions. If you are on a team with one of these individuals and don't have another senior engineer to go to for questions, your career growth will be stunted. If you do ask them questions, they will give a bad performance review to your lead. Difficult situation for junior engineers.

Pros: Work life Balance, Good salary
Cons: Micro-manging , Too much hierarchy.

Pros: MongoDB is a highly reputable SaaS company and the C-suite knows what they are doing. You will learn a lot here. I can't speak highly enough of Dev Ittycheria the CEO, he is the real deal. Work culture is great, supporting a hybrid model (where remote work is allowed but in person is definitely encouraged in the hubs like HQ in NYC).
Cons: The Sales org runs the company, other business functions play second fiddle. Whiplash may arise when the sales leaders return from their annual offsite and present a new framework to the rest of the company. (but it's also a strength in that the Mongo sales team is probably in the top 5% tech sales cultures in the industry.) Where it can come into play is from a resourcing standpoint. Expect that if your team is not in Sales, you will run super lean. Secondly, as the company has become quite established (and big), many of the processes are fully built out. Depending on the org you are in, you may be more of an "operator" vs an "innovator". This comes down to personal preference on what you are looking for. But it definitely felt like a big company when I left, which wasn't the case when I joined.

Pros:
Tech forward
Nice people
Cool projects to work on
Cons: Huge, public company, so things can sometimes move slowly

Pros: Decent pay and some interesting code to write here and there. If you're a database person, the place could be good.
Cons: Snail pace of development. Their touted culture is nothing to be impressed by, I found it pretty lacking to say the least, nearly worst I've seen in my entire career. I didn't feel proud that I worked at MongoDB either. No regrets for leaving.

Pros: The product is great. Significant collaboration with account executives. They essentially bring in the customers. Some teams are better than the others. As an EM your job is to attach professional services to existing ongoing deals and see it through closure. Great pay. Good Benefits. Great work-life balance.
Cons: The scope of work in professional services engagement management team is pretty narrow. Role is limited to selling and not delivery. Not challenging enough. Too many supporting roles with very narrow breadth of responsibilities. This role can be eliminated completely, if they give training to Account executives or Solutions architects, or Consult engineers who actually deliver the work. Leadership is only focused on numbers and not their team. Very poor gender and diversity ratios. Very slow growth potential, especially if you are a person of color. Poor succession planning. Strangely enough the senior leadership keeps getting promoted, yet they keep doing the same job and nothing changes down the line. Poor feedback culture. Managers/Leaders will not help with personal growth. Huge dependency on account executives. Also, as soon as you join, the employee experience team will ask you to drop a review on glassdoor. Most reviews here are when people are in their very early days of employment, so take it with a pinch of salt.

Review Title: Career progression + innovation-driven + massive future opportunity!
Pros: 1. Great product with massive future growth opportunity 2. Reward (pay, equity), recognize and promote high performers who drive impact across the company 3. Encourage experimentation and innovation (tech, Sales, Pre-Sales + Post-Sales approaches) 4. We challenge ourselves to be the best in the industry 5. Leadership - takes action on feedback provided in employee surveys and understands and respects people needs to manage work-life harmony (people are understanding of managing family life schedules & challenges) Personally, I've never progressed in my career faster, or learned more than in my career at MongoDB and I attribute a lot of that to the leadership that encourages and empowers us to "Think Big, Go Far" and "Make it Matter" (2 of our key values). For those who take ownership and initiative with their careers and have the tenacity and persistence to overcome challenges and adversity, there is huge opportunity.
Cons: 1. High pressure and highly demanding - tough to balance everything on our plates. 2. Significant effort and scrutiny on new investment spend (new hires, tools) (understandable with the focus on profitability) 3. More technical product sale - steeper learning curve for non-technical people

Review Title: Best Workplace in my whole career
Pros:
If you enjoy working in the tech industry and possess strong business acumen, MongoDB is the ideal workplace that consistently challenges you. There is always something new to learn, creating an environment that allows you to continuously develop and express yourself effectively. MongoDB boasts an excellent sales structure that adapts to the evolving demands of the industry. Notably, the management actively follows through on their commitments.

From the beginning, I've been impressed with the robust learning structure in place. It is an ongoing process that is essential for performing your job at its best. Moreover, there is ample support from the team and management to aid in your progress, allowing you to shape your career in the direction you prefer. MongoDB provides a dynamic and supportive work culture that encourages personal and professional growth.
Cons: Working at MongoDB is undeniably challenging, offering numerous opportunities to make a meaningful impact and leave your mark. While some may describe it as hard work, I believe it reflects the level of dedication required for optimal performance. Our consistent success quarter after quarter, as evidenced by MongoDB's financial statements, speaks to the effectiveness of this approach. It's a dynamic environment where hard work pays off and contributes to the company's ongoing success.

Pros: Great remote onboarding. They make an effort to ensure you get connected to everyone and understand the products.
Cons: Once you’re out of onboarding, get ready for the fire hose. And don’t expect to make grand process change. They are stuck in their inefficiency and seem fine with it. You’ll be too busy reminding people to review documents to spend time on problems that would create actual value. I’m surprised developers don’t completely run the place (maybe that would be better). There’s a cult mentality in the company. If you are a developer and / or a prior intern who started here and worked your way up, you’re tops. If you’re a program manager, there is a limit to how far you can grow here. The product team needs serious help and are not pulling their weight. Oh and whatever amazing culture they had being a scrappy company has been lost; Amazon execs took over C-Suite.

Review Title: A company that helps build your career
Pros: When I joined MongoDB, I was amazed by the employee-centric focus of the organization and the amazing leaders I had who really helped me guide and build a career in an Administrator Role. Thanks to their continuous support and freedom to explore options, I got my Salesforce Admin Certification, moved into the Sales Technology Administrator role, and continued my growth. Also, having an International team ranging from India to Europe to America increased my exposure, provided opportunities to learn about new cultures, and broadened my horizons.
Cons: A fast-paced company brings various challenges that require amazing skills to make an impact in your position and build an image for yourself.

Review Title: A company that you would learn and experience at the same time.
Pros: It's been a year working in MongoDB. How time flies! I still remember the first day I join, it's the QBR week. I was impressed by the focus and dedication to the work of everyone. The whole team get together and spend quality time to talk and review the work. The leadership team will collect feedback and offer help to what's needed. That just me feel inspired and motivated. Along the year, the feeling still with me. I kept learning and adopt myself to the existing working environment. MongoDB also provide the best staff learning and development support. All new on board staff will need get trained with company background, product knowledge, and professional skills. Also lots of tools that we can leverage, the company grant the access to most of the popular tools in the market. MongoDB also have good package of employee benefit that also include children and partner. The company will have regular all hands meeting by the board, talk about all the things that staff cares and suggested. That's great to have as we are confidence by knowing what's going on inside and outside the company, and the impact it may be.
Cons: As the product is well known globally, the business expand to many regions. The cross functional/region collaboration is important and essential. Lots of meetings for alignment and planning. But we developed No Meeting Wednesday! :) And busy.

Review Title: Rewarding, but challenging opportunity for Enterprise Sellers - a female's perspective
Pros: I felt compelled to write about my experience after reading some recent reviews from female sellers. I'd like to start off by saying that my intent is not to minimize anyone else's experience or condone biased behavior. If you have experienced discrimination because of your gender or for any other reason, that is wrong. With that said, I am a female who has been with MongoDB for 5 years in a variety of sales roles. I have personally felt incredibly supported throughout my time at this company. The sales teams here are top-notch and are full of talented people who I continue to learn from. Sales at MongoDB will challenge you, but it will also be rewarding. Don't get me wrong, there is no question that the number of men in sales outweighs the number of women. However, leadership has acknowledged the disparity and is seemingly putting in a genuine effort to bridge the gap. We have amazing affiliate groups like MDBWomen's Group and Sell Like a Girl which have created opportunities for females and allies to network and find mentors across MongoDB. I'm always humbled to see that senior leadership regularly participates in these events. I'm not sure what other company can say that their female CISO regularly attends affiliate group mentorship events - you're setting an amazing example, Lena. If you're a female in tech sales, I'd encourage you to consider MongoDB. Don't be afraid to ask questions and get a variety of different perspectives.
Cons: MongoDB is a challenging and complex sale. However, put the work in and trust the process.

Review Title: Bigger is not better for employees!
Job Title: Senior Director Credit, Collections and AR
Pros: Company was a better place to work pre-merger. Good place to start for people with no experience or no formal education. Stay 2 to 3 years max then move on.
Cons: Benefits are average and pay is subpar compared to industry standards. The CEO, Rich Hume, is aloof and condescending. He speaks in lofty platitudes along with the rest of the Executive Management team. Executive Management is highly reactive, not proactive. They equivocate on every topic to the point of being pathologically deceitful. The SVP of Credit & Collections, Jay Snyder, is an uncouth rustic individual that runs his division like a medieval fiefdom. He manages and controls everything including the smallest details that should be delegated to lower management. It’s very strange to see an intolerant individual like this in an organization that prides itself in diversity and inclusion. Also, top sales producers are negatively impacted by TD Synnex changing its sales commission structure making it more difficult for sales to meet goals. Eddie Franklin, SVP Sales, had nothing to say about this cut in pay! Less pay for employees and more profits for the Executive team, Board of Directors, and shareholders.

Pros: Able to learn different departments.

Pros: Exposure to many different clients

Pros: The customers and the work you perform are great! Hundreds of different types of equipment to work on, changing all the time. Mostly PoS and small electronics repairs, plus some light I.T. work, particularly in Datacenters, Outstanding local and regional team eager to help you in any way! Lots of overnight work and travel which means more $$.
Cons: The company itself is laughably disorganized. The change their name and "reset" your employment status every few months. No one above your field manager can be contacted for any reason; and no one even knows HOW to reach them. It is a logistical nightmare, as much of your mundane tasks normally performed electronically have to be done by pen and paper, and mailed in (no exaggeration!) It takes them almost 2 years just to send you an employee badge; and by then it's no good because they'd already changed their name 3+ times! To add to the confusion, they are subcontracted by other organizations, so each WO assigned to you requires that you "pretend" that you are working for another company. This requires constant lying to their costumers, and it's basically unavoidable.

Pros: Dynamic, fun environment, great culture
Cons: Ultimately the business was not sustainable.

Cons: Lack of recognition for IT employees when they are exceeding expectations. IT executive team lives in a "glass bubble" and is not in touch with their employees. Work-life balance is non-existent for many departments and non-management employees while the majority of management leaves right at 5 pm. Employees are not treated equally, some are grossly underpaid, and there is an extreme lack of diversity in leadership when it comes to women and LGBTQ+. The company used to list the salary range for every position, but stopped and now underpay some while giving more to others.

Pros: Broadline supplier supporting global customers.

Cons: Tech Data used to be a great company, embraced diversity & inclusion, had a caring & supportive management team, and really felt like a great place to work. That all changed with the merger (now TD SYNNEX) and new management in IT. The new management is not supportive of their employees, is now almost all white men, and no matter what they preach, they no longer embrace diversity and inclusion.

Review Title: Good first job, not for long term
Pros:
My sales team was great. Everyone was very helpful and always telling new hires to ask questions all the time. Working from home 95% of the time is great too if you like the environment. 

Managers are communicative and want you to succeed. The trainings are elaborate and really do take up your first 3 months of working. Overall, a good first entry level position especially if you just graduated college
Cons:
The pay is NOT worth staying more than a year. 35k or $15 an hour is ridiculous especially with the work load. There are no incentives really for the ASR role unless you want to waste your own lunch time every day and sit in on zoom lunches and listen to the vendors speak just to make an extra $15 a day. 

The benefits are not great. I felt regrets and pressure every time i took off work because we are so "short staffed" all the time.

Pros: One of the reasons I love working at BMC is because they truly care about their employees. There are hundreds of programs to fit the needs of every individual and we are always encouraged to reach out when it's warranted. BMC has some of the best healthcare options I have experienced in my occupational career, and they are always willing to listen and determine the best course of action to make sure their employees have everything they need. There are also a ton of opportunities to move around the company if you wish and I have found my management to be incredibly supportive of growth in any form, so there is no backlash to ambition.
Cons: I don't have any true downsides to working with BMC, I guess I would say that the experience you have is what you make of it. The energy you put in to working at BMC is what you are going to get out of it. BMC has a net positive/neutral environment to work with, so if you give it your best to communicate and work towards your ambitions, you won't have any problems.

Review Title: Very toxic place to be at
Pros: Pros are the history that this environment carries. I did not see any other pros.
Cons: No work life balance. Dirty office politics. They will pay employees high money because they don't trust their employees. Poor management threatens employees in the name of cost cutting so that they will not ask for anything else. A sense of status quo even when the market share is being lost. People are highly stressed out in their job which means the company culture is not good. They have people working in there for 10 -15 years and hence they lack the outlook of outside world. They don't hire inexperienced people and ask existing employees to check with family members and friends about what other organisations are doing. They hire contractors and treat them like second class citizens. Appraisals are sole discretion of Managers so they will raise pay for whomever they like. Management is very arrogant and won't listen to their shortcomings. And the list will go on.

Review Title: You will HATE working here--Please read all the reviews
Pros:
This 'Pros' section does not make sense for this company. There is only one Pros - 
Helps to ruin and destroy career aspirations of many.
Cons:
High firing rates. Firing engineers and even new joiners without any reason. To some newbies, they even hired some already working employees of other Singapore companies, and then laid them off within 3 months.

No work-life balance. Bad management. Especially Indian managers have a superiority complex and bossy nature which they have picked up wrongly from the Japanese background.

No manager shows up on time when dealing with employee scheduled meeting. Except a few, everyone gives reason that they are very busy, but in reality no one is busy there. They are just busy playing games and poking nose in others' work.

For those who say salary is high - it is, but not helpful in long run. High salary is because of bonus and AWS. The basic salary is still not high. When applying for other jobs in Singapore, perspective employers only consider basic pay. So it does not provide any edge for new career opportunities.

No clear vision or motivation. They pose as if they are very innovative and out of box. But in reality they are not.

Review Title: Not best but one of the good companies to work for
Pros:
Works Applications went through a lot of dramatic changes these past 4 years with putting in a lot of effort to create something revolutionary but unfortunately could not make it as profitable as wanted maybe suffered losses too, and a lot changed after that :
1) No salary increment
2) No motivation
3) Good technical people leaving the company 
But now once again Works Applications has started to work with new vision, new goals and let's hope we make it. :)

Some would say that sounds much like cons, pros are here for you :
1) You are free to think, that is the best one I have got
You think of new features to support your team, you can pitch your ideas and work on it, not gets better than this anywhere.
2) Competitive Salary
As I said not best but not worst, still competitive.
3) Easy life
We believe that you can do best when you are independent if some manager is always on you to do some work or finish some feature or project you know it feels like bad, money is important but so is independence.
Cons: Just read the first one, it is counted in cons actually by most.

Pros: good for fresh - entry level
Cons: language barrier caused difficult communication

Pros: You can try all the works you want to try.
Cons: Too many mid tier employees have been left recently

Pros:
- New technologies to learn
- Flexible working hours
- Easy to change team to learn new thing
- High paid especially for fresh graduate
- There are some friendly and excellent developers
Cons:
- A lot of hard deadline, working overtime is quite common. It usually we have to work overtime 1 or 2 hours. There are some teams have to work overnight sometimes.
- Military ranking system. All employees are ranked and judged like military soldier
- Bad evaluation system to judge employee performance. It highly depends on team leader or manager's perspective. It's not fair across the company. There are some teams whose leader or managers are good, they don't need to work hard but still get high grade. However, other teams are not under good manager, even they work hard, they still get bad grade. Bad grade means not increase in salary and going to higher rank.
- Deadlines are a lot. Developers usually do not have time to think about good solution to solve problem. My personal opinion is quality product is not so good in term of designing. Later, it will really cost in maintenance phase.

Pros:
Good for fresh grads to gain initial professional experience 

Accepting fresh grads from non cs background 

Nice people around

Nice flexible working hours
Cons:
Core framework team along with upper management have too much power in making technical decisions and every projects have no choice but to use their proposed aka enforced solutions even though they are not relevant to the projects

New joiners bootcamp content is not relevant to projects or products that this company has, and failing the bootcamp can be dangerous because that means you will lose your employment status 

People with good technical knowledge / achievements (including senior software engineers) are not well valued if they dont have management skills

No laptops

Pros:
- Get to work with some of the best minds around the globe : The office environment requires only bright and passionate people. Those who are not motivated enough are sometimes asked to leave.
This according to me is a positive thing.

- Full freedom to come up with your ideas and implement them :Even if you fail, you are praised for your initiative and smart thinking. 

- Work on big web systems which are not something tried before. This drives to innovative thinking and experimenting with latest technologies & research.
Cons: - Just like every growing organization, sometimes it requires to put in a lot of effort. It might be draining a times but there is a sense of achievement once your work comes into production.

Review Title: Unprofessional behavior with no response from management
Pros: I really don't know anything.
Cons:
I am one among a group of around 50+ students who got placed in Works Applications last year(2016 Dec.) from various IITs/NITs, etc. First, they delayed our joining date till October. Now, they have changed several terms in offer letter: 
1) Location which was earlier Singapore has been shifted to Tokyo.
2) They have suddenly decided to close two out of the their three divisions including a) Software Development and b) QA & Testing.  due to which they have decided to increase the difficulty of the STM (training they provide in India for 3 months) and will terminate anyone with grades (B, C and D) after the training. Earlier, they used to terminate only people with D grade after STM. This is resulting in terminating about 75% of the employees (as they mentioned themselves) after training as compared to only 10% last year. They also mentioned that they may even terminate everyone in the worst case.

At last, they have also asked us to leave the company before hand by taking the compensation for 1 month in case we are not satisfied with the above changes in the offer. We find these practices of the company rather unprofessional and would everyone in India to stay away from them.

Pros: I really don't see any pro's for this company.
Cons:
They don't respect your hard work.
They will just revoke your offer anytime they want without any notice period or anything v

Review Title: False promises, Incompetent Tech leaders & management
Pros:
- Work among different Asian work force.
- Experience Japanese work life at close range.
- Revenue comes from "Japanese buy Japanese products only" scheme.
Cons:
- Tech leaders and higher management completely out of touch and are inexperienced with software engineering. 
- Company earns revenue from the tag line "Japanese buy Japanese products only" , which is actually the internal scheme of Japanese business. This companies strictly survives on that.
- Management doesn't choose experts to make decisions but chooses whoever is acting like a dog chasing a bone and saying 'right' even at times when the manager is wrong. This resulted in complete destruction of one of the products and there by loaning to subsidize the share of it.
- False promises for professional growth.
- Company is on financial cringe.
- Most wrong step in giving huge increments and benefits to whoever starts with fashionable new tech rather than testing and adapting stable tech for products.  
- Evaluation scheme to promote employees is the biggest lie, bogus and a huge crap.

Review Title: A good IT company to start with
Pros: Very high salary compared to other Japanese companies, even for new employees. ERP is an industry that won't be outdate in the near future. You can invite your relatives to visit company on Thanksgiving Day, and the company will cover the travel expenses.
Cons: The technologies the company used are somewhat obsolete, though they are trying to apply new techniques such as machine learning. Working time may be much more than American or European companies. Hard to increase your salary much although the base is high, and very few benefits.

Pros:
The team is multi-cultural and I found it enriching to work among half a dozen other nationalities.
Company has a flat hierarchy and the demand on working hours is not high unlike some other Japanese companies.

Certain teams use new technologies and provide good learning experience.
Cons: Not all teams are up to date on the technologies being used. Some products have legacy code base. Different nationalities also pose a language barrier at times.

Pros:
- good salary as a fresh grad
- one free drink per day
- easy to get your leave application approved
- flexible working hour as long as working for 8 hours a day
Cons:
- just think: overemphasis on thinking results in an environment with many incompetent and unprofessional leaders and engineers who can neither PRODUCE clean code nor DELIVER good products. The company prefers the obedient employees to the technically capable ones and elect the former to be leaders.
- no scapegoating: the distribution of responsibility is deliberately blurred, such that those who are truly to be blamed for buggy code, wrong technical decisions and unstable architecture can hide themselves behind their scapegoats.
- breakthrough: many of the breakthroughs just break through the obstacles made within the company, such as unsuitable technical choices and buggy implementations. Highly usable and widely accepted libraries, tools and frameworks are out there, yet the engineering team chose to build our own.
- contingency plan: do we have a contingency plan in the midst of financial struggles?
- human skills: the so-called leaders do not represent or fight for the welfare of his/her subordinates. Often they stand with their leaders and squeeze their subordinates together.
- boss-driven over product-oriented: implementation, troubleshooting and decision-making are driven by bosses' demands, rather than being rooted in facts or product oriented. Development may change course anytime as long as some big bosses want it that way, despite the fact that it breaks development roadmap or apparently violates engineering practices.
- process over engineering: overly complicated processes are made to restrict technical discussion and decisions and writing, submitting and releasing code, which is iconic Japanese Ho-Ren-So culture and greatly endorsed by higher managers. Managers block developers from submitting code, thinking it is able to stabilize the build and improve the quality of products.
- firefighting over troubleshooting: too many engineers are mobilised for putting off sparks instead of solving the root problem. Too many temporary fixes have been made permanent. Firefighters are rewarded and admired as heroes while those who prevent the fire from the very beginning are often neglected.

Pros:
-High salary for fresh graduates, way above the market rate. 
-Flexi-work improves productivity. 
-Sincere and congenial colleagues 
-Some senior staffs are genuinely passionate
-Great breadth in work scope
Cons:
-Salary increments are virtually non-existent before you move up to the next level of hierarchy (they always tell you 10% increments, but subsequently deducts 10% from your annual bonus..). Besides, which company in the 21st century still standardize employee salaries across the globe? Haven't they studied basic compensation bench-marking? To think that they actually do HR systems is unimaginable. 
-Completely clueless in global business operation - half the senior staffs cannot even complete a single sentence in English verbally, not to mention conducting business globally. 
-Lack of competent leadership and training for juniors. 
-Unethical way of doing business that doesn't work outside Japan
-Pessimistic business performance for years (performance is not published as they are not a listed company but you can easily get from research databases)

Pros: 1. If you want to be a shoelicker and get promoted, this is the best workplace for you.
Cons:
1. Just read through the previous reviews, most of the positive reviews are written by managers. You know why, i will tell ya. 

Reason : 
1. No work other than updating tickets. Lot of work man, really. 
2. Get promoted if you are a shoelicker. 
3. They just take orders and do not have any input of their own. 
4. They might be a good engineer but they are not good as a manager and so as their product. 
5. They come in morning, one window they have slack and other has whatsapp, and then they keep posting message, @here update tickets. 
6. They encourage team to merge buggy code and then create 100s of patch tickets, which resulted into failure of so many products. 
7. Evaluation is only about how much buttering you do. People don't even know their tech well and now they are manager and ruining the product. 
8. In short, managers know they are bad at their work, but they are getting really high pay compared to their contribution.

Pros:
* Amazing Work Culture
* Highly Global, Almost 14 different nationalities.
* Can apply and try new ideas and strategies even on associate level

Cons:

Cons:
- Higher up sucks. They dont have a good plan to run company. Actually they had: go public IPO and profit as much as they can. After that they dont care about how the company does. But Japanese stock exchange did not let them(they are not stupid). So their so called worksap-good-company-bubble burst. Just see the glassdoor rating curve over the years.  Their financial status is not good. Their product is not ready and their pocket is running dry.

Review Title: Great vision and strong executives, but long working hours.
Pros: If you want to grow, this is a great place to work. Company has a great vision and is still in the process to achieve them. They are almost like a startup and if you enjoy fast pace and being busy, you will enjoy working here. Unlike a Japanese company, this is a place where the age doesn't matter and what you do matters. Also they have a culture to let you have mistakes and accept them.
Cons: Keeping a work-life balance is very hard. Many people work till the last train which is after midnight and you have to have stamina to keep up. Whenever the delivery time is close. people often work on weekends.

Review Title: We make you happier as a employer and value creator
Pros: We have variety of employee that is very great to create services and ideas to make everyheart happier in Earth. Our AI product AI WORKS is very epochmaking.
Cons: Maybe some top-down approaches are many but your flexibility become better than entering. And a few employees from other firm to become officer are a little lazy.

Pros: It is a great place to learn something. The company provides large space and chance to show your talents.
Cons:
It is a good place for newbies, high initial salary, growing space...
But it is hard to get promotion when you be a experienced worker.

Pros:
- High salary for fresh graduates
The starting pay for fresh graduates is higher than average

- Talented and friendly colleagues (depends on the team)
The office is full of young people. There are some who are really talented and most of co-workers are nice and friendly. 

- Flexible working hours (depends on the team)
The working hours are pretty flexible if deliverables are not due and you do not have meetings to attend. However, there is no option to work remotely. 

- Possibility of transferring to Japan
It is possible to request for a transfer to Japan after you stay for a certain period of time in the company. It's an opportunity for those who wants to experience the Japanese culture. 

- Excellent sales team 
The sales team in Japan is top notch. They are actually able to sell software based on nothing but paper. In fact, they are the ones that are lifting the entire company.
Cons:
- 50 shades of managers
Clueless, racist, incompetent, pushers, know-it-alls, pretenders, and the list goes on. Just name a trait and you have a very high probability of finding a manager like that. 

- Out of touch top management
The top management is completely out of touch with the situation on the ground and the actual status of the product. Because of this, they are making decisions which becomes a hindance or has no impact value. 

- Politics among managers
When you try to request help from other teams, the other team managers always find some way to avoid it instead of trying to find a solution. There is no smooth collaboration between team managers. In the end, nothing gets done and delays keep piling on. 

- Spreadsheets for everything
They love to use spreadsheets for all purposes, instead of using proper tools. This applies even for diagram drawing. Can you imagine how troublesome it is to create complex diagrams in excel? 

- Misallocation of resources
PhD holders do screen mockups; Master's holders do trivial work; Arts graduates write code; Developers write essays and draw UI instead of coding. There isn't a proper allocation based on skills and interest. 

- No experts with experience
The tech architecture leads are wannabes who has no real experience with production software. Their decisions are supported with weak evidence at best. There is no real tech lead who has the know-how and expertise to lead the way. 

- Reinventing the wheel
They love to reinvent the wheel instead of using something that has been battle-tested. Instead of paying a small cost to use commercial software, they pay even more money to reinvent it in-house, which ends up being subpar. Some excellent libraries and frameworks are even open source so it costs nothing to use . They recreate everything in-house, claiming that what is in the market cannot achieve what they want. The outcome is a bloated piece of mess that constantly breaks every step of the way. In addition, the upper management forces these frameworks to be used, which totally hinders productivity. 

- Dubious development cycle
Their "sprints" have all the negatives of agile and waterfall, but none of the benefits. 

- Resistance to change
Even with all the above cons, the higher management refuses to admit their mistake and change their strategy. Instead, they pat themselves on the back and say all is dandy. The bottom level can so clearly see the inherent flaws and there are so many calls for change but it doesn't happen. 

- No structured training
There is no process where people can pick up skills in a natural manner. Because you don't learn much, your skills remain stagnant.

Pros:
Very latest technology
Good organizational Structure.
Good Growth opportunities.
STM training is a great learning experience
Catalog oriented work
Allows you to fail
Cons:
Existing product have older technology
Language barrier if you work for Japanese client
Work load in some teams 
Not very flexible in approach.

Review Title: Proceed with Caution - Toxic Environment, No worklife balance
Pros: There was sparkling water on tap.
Cons:
If you're considering a position at OT, particularly in sales ops with "VB" as the hiring manager, I strongly advise against it. 
During my brief tenure of just under three months, there were three turnovers within the team. The work environment was toxic, with instances of bullying and gaslighting by the manager leading to burnout among team members. 
Additionally, there was a severe lack of work-life balance; I was told time off during critical periods such as the last two weeks of the quarter and the last week of every month, including the period between Christmas and New Year will be denied. This lack of flexibility would pose significant challenges, especially for those with familial responsibilities. 
The manager's behavior was egregious, often resorting to shouting and yelling at employees. Despite reporting these issues to HR, there was no meaningful response or action taken. 
While many IT companies espouse values of empowering women and promoting work-life balance, OT fell far short of these ideals. Proceed with caution, as this environment may not align with your professional or personal well-being.

Review Title: Don't believe the hype, the pay is abysmal.
Pros: Immediate Manager and team are great to work with
Cons: Doesn't matter how good your annual review is you're lucky to get a 2% raise. Follow this up with seeing the CEO on the news the second business day of the year in a segment about how he's already made more money this year than you will. On Jan 3rd. Constant emails touting how much money the company is making. All hands meetings where they brag about revenues. It's disheartening, feels like they're literally rubbing it in your face. Billions in profits, growing year over year while the cost of living is soaring and you realize that you have less buying power than you did when you started years ago, Actually having to buy groceries now at discount stores and flea markets, due to extremely small yearly increases (if you get one at all), Do not believe the inevitable blurb they will add to this that salaries etc... are reviewed regularly and in line with market value. They aren't. That is an out and out lie.

Pros: The work culture is satisfactory. There are ample opportunities available for learning and enhancing your skill set.
Cons: In the context of the FCOE PH, it appears that some leaders exhibit biased behavior and engage in unlawful practices. Specifically, they allegedly refuse to acknowledge resignation letters, which is contrary to Philippine law. Additionally, during one-on-one meetings, there are allegations of gaslighting and power-tripping. These concerning issues should be escalated to the Human Resources department for proper investigation and resolution.

Review Title: Some good people but super liberal left wing ceo
Pros: Good people in many roles
Cons: Got shuffled into different teams more than once and ended up in two sales teams with basically no sales. Then got riffed due to the purchase of.Micro Focus. It was stone cold. " Today is your last day you'll get 2 weeks pay after you ship us back your laptop.  Bye"

Pros: Work culture is just OK. If you know how to manage without putting any efforts and pretend like working, then its good place for you. You should not make the task to look simple by putting more efforts. You should reports lot of issues while working on a task and should resolve them by taking lot of time. The  you will be lauded like you are genius. :)
Cons: Worst management. More number of managers in a team than the team members.. Everyone wants to earn salary by making the chosen person in the team to work hard. No promotions. New people get good position in the team. Old employees who got best  performance rating are reporting to new employees who dont have capacity to justify the role.

Pros: Mostly good  and reasonable people.
Cons:
After  years at HP, HPE, Microfocus and Opentext. With nothing but stellar performance reviews and leading cutting edge tech development. 

The back to office policies (no exception) I believe is what made me a candidate for layoffs. With CEO toughting  in company meetings, that though must be in office 3 days per week. (I know it does not sound hard).

However, with medical conditions, and office remodeling going on, which made bathroom facilities unavailable on the same floor, this became an issue that was in acceptable health wise.

Furthermore, the use of badge in badge out was implemented initially, for Covid contact tracing. Now they have turned the reporting into, monitoring of office attendance. Something the old HP Way would have never worked out. 

When your role is interfacing with India, and Europe. These positions require remote off hours work as well.

 Inflexible management, is management simply making a hard job even harder.

Review Title: Work here for a few years and move on.
Pros:
-Flexible work arrangements
-Good work-life balance. Got to keep working from home even after the pandemic ended.
-Your experience is going to depend on your team and manager. I liked my team and manager, so I had a good experience.
Cons:
-Mediocre to poor corporate benefits (only 1% match on retirement plan)
-Little opportunity for career growth. I was there for 5 years and never offered a promotion or significant pay raise. They eventually just let me go, despite being involved with many projects and having good relationships with colleagues.

Pros: The work culture is satisfactory. There are ample opportunities available for learning and enhancing your skill set.
Cons: In the context of the FCOE PH, it appears that some leaders exhibit biased behavior and engage in unlawful practices. Specifically, they allegedly refuse to acknowledge resignation letters, which is contrary to Philippine law. Additionally, during one-on-one meetings, there are allegations of gaslighting and power-tripping. These concerning issues should be escalated to the Human Resources department for proper investigation and resolution.

Pros: Mostly good  and reasonable people.
Cons:
After  years at HP, HPE, Microfocus and Opentext. With nothing but stellar performance reviews and leading cutting edge tech development. 

The back to office policies (no exception) I believe is what made me a candidate for layoffs. With CEO toughting  in company meetings, that though must be in office 3 days per week. (I know it does not sound hard).

However, with medical conditions, and office remodeling going on, which made bathroom facilities unavailable on the same floor, this became an issue that was in acceptable health wise.

Furthermore, the use of badge in badge out was implemented initially, for Covid contact tracing. Now they have turned the reporting into, monitoring of office attendance. Something the old HP Way would have never worked out. 

When your role is interfacing with India, and Europe. These positions require remote off hours work as well.

 Inflexible management, is management simply making a hard job even harder.

Cons: - Salary is NOT aligned with the market average, so please don't BS us. No major perks or incentives to go above and beyond. They make it a near impossible task to win those navigator points lol. Forget materialistic stuff - just cross functional/cross team recognition would be great.

Pros:
-Pay is OK. Not competitive compared to company size/type, but OK
-Enough other great people working there (all of whom are unfortunately being taken advantage of) that you could meet some good friends
-Free food sometimes
Cons:
This company is the biggest bait-and-switch I have ever seen in Corporate America, and I have seen a lot. 

First they'll recruit you promising the world. Great culture, career opportunities, etc. Their initial pay offering will be below market and they'll justify it as a big company that keeps certain strict pay bands. They'll draw you away from a well paying, stable, comfortable job by promising you the world. 

You will learn fairly quickly that it is almost impossible to get a decent raise, even just enough to keep up with inflation. Even if you are a good employee meeting all expectations, they use "forced curve" annual reviews. So even if you have no performance problems and no actionable feedback, if there are enough "higher performers" in your department, no raise. The "higher performers" will often have more to do with what type of work is available and/or office politics than anything within your control.

This point will vary by department, but EXTREME disorganization. People being hired to report to one manager and then being switched around to report to another. This is not uncommon. There are many incompetent people working here at all levels and not much accountability for you having to do their job for them.

They may (and will!) promise you that the mass layoffs they are doing will not affect your department, right up until the day that you get a call from HR saying your department was slashed by layoffs by 50%. People will be laid off despite zero performance issues. No job stability.

From what I have observed, they did at least 5 rounds of sneaky layoffs, which they did in rounds stealthily so as to try to avoid mass panic and regulatory requirements. All this while touting how wonderful their latest acquisition (that caused the layoffs) will be for the company and its employees. 

After they lay off almost half of your department, they are also surprised when some people panic and quit, your department can't function, and deadlines are missed. So they go into full panic mode re-hiring for the well-performing employees they laid off/lost. Constant cycle of corporate over-hiring, over-layoffs, overcorrection. Absolute waste of good talent, and the most astounding lack of self-awareness by HR and the people making these decisions. 

Finally: absolute bureaucracy at all levels. Be prepared for every minor aspect of your job to take 5 times as long as it needs to, because of the layers of bureaucracy that persist in many departments. HR and IT are especially incompetent, but it is a company-wide problem. This company is bloated, probably beyond repair (and the layoffs don't seem to hit the departments that everyone knows are functionally useless - odd.)

Advice to applicants: don't be fooled, they are the epitome of everything that is wrong with Corporate America, while they put a pleasant face and pay lip service to caring about employees, but only care about the bottom line and will treat you as poorly as is convenient. If the pay and benefits and work experience are worth it to you, take the paycheck, line item on the resume, and run without looking back as soon as you get a better opportunity.

Review Title: The one star is for the way things were...
Pros:
Historically, under a different guise, this would have been an entirely different review...unfortunately, the changes haven't been kind to this business.

If I could no stars, I would.
Cons:
Be prepared for a lack of clear direction and inconsistent leadership. The decision-making process appears to be driven more by budget constraints than by a genuine understanding of the market or customer needs - this spans across the internal operations and the technology too. The company is known in the market as "the place that software goes to die" for a reason and why the business has historically survived on auditing customers.

One of the major cons is the disconnect between the company's stated values, such as "Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion" and the actual work environment. Despite the rhetoric, there's a noticeable lack of diversity in leadership, promotions are based more on personal connections than merit - and this is even less likely if you fall under the category of any traditionally marginalised demographic in the field of Information Technology.

The management, predominantly composed of older individuals, seems resistant to change and innovation. Decisions feel outdated and out of touch with the fast-paced nature of the industry. This makes it challenging for teams to adapt to evolving market trends and meet customer expectations effectively.

Furthermore, the work culture can be toxic, with a pervasive sense of mistrust and lack of transparency. It's as if the leadership is more focused on cost-cutting measures than fostering a healthy and collaborative workplace.

Beware of the graduate programme; it lacks clear direction and valuable suggestions from seasoned professionals seemed to go unnoticed. The teams were guided by peer-to-peer engagement from individuals with minimal experience, akin to the blind leading the blind. Progression within the programme appeared driven solely by cost-cutting motives, as experienced colleagues were let go and replaced by newly "qualified" grads with substantially lower salaries. Consider this before committing to a path that might lack the mentorship and strategic guidance needed for a successful career.

In summary, if you value a dynamic, inclusive, and forward-thinking work environment, OpenText may not be the ideal place for you. The organisation seems stuck in outdated practices and fails to deliver on its promises of a diverse and inclusive workplace. Consider other opportunities where you can thrive without being hindered by the limitations of a company out of touch with the reality of today's business landscape.

Pros: Ken is a founder CEO and he’s built a world class company, products are fantastic.
Cons: Going through massive change at the moment and the current US Sales leader is completely unqualified to lead the team. He’s completely vacant from customer meetings, partner meetings, and his all hands calls are uninspiring. People are leaving in droves and the newly rolled out comp plan is accelerating this change. If you are considering a career at Fortinet demand the fine print before you sign.

Pros: Overall well branded with a strong portfolio and Fabric strategy. Trying to pivot to address SASE and SecOps from a reliance on firewalls/network security. People on the sales side that were there the last several years have made some good money
Cons: Lots of internal org changes including some leadership. Weak channel leadership and unnecessary internal channel conflict. Deal protection for partners is <10% , with vague rules of engagement that leave partners with little recourse and low profitability. Little in the way of formal career development or growth opportunities. In fact I didn’t even have a formal annual review in my tenure. Inspection and micromanagement has increased as growth has slowed. Giant marketing teams that hold the purse strings, with questionable measurable impact and understanding of the channel business needs.

Pros: Good insurance, work from home 2 days a week Mon and Friday
Cons: Really poor onboarding/training. The pay is a 50/50 structure base pay then commission based on the sales team you support and thats if they reach their sales goals so you won't make nearly what they make you think you you'll get. It is not consistent at all. There is no tuition reimbursement to help further your knowledge in the tech world. They say the others will help train, hahaha, that's if they can find the time. Training is a little batter these days but if your right out of college you'd think a company rhis big would have a robust training department. They don't. Which is amazing considering the industry they are in.

Review Title: Pretty good.  Not perfect, of course.
Pros: Most employees are really great people.
Cons: Too much busy work most of the time. Some outdated systems can be frustrating.

Pros: Good sharp technical people and immediate management layer.
Cons: Terrible Executive Management who are not willing to invest in a vertical they know will take 12 to 18 months to win business. Expecting monthly revenue in a vertical that buys on bi-yearly or yearly budget cycles. Found out they have tried with 5 other Sakes Guys and continually “churn” year on year without adjusting the approach. Sales Teams are treated terribly. Technical teams are cherished. If you interview ask them the average length of their Sales Teams in a vertical vs. Technical Teams = if you don’t see a trend you are wearing a blindfold!

Pros:
It's a job
salary is always on time
30 days vacation
Cons:
Very toxic management. It feels like totalitarian regime
People are not allowed to express their opinion or to bring up flaws. If they do, they are being silenced and marked as "negative". 
The managers keep introducing extremely annoying rules and changes, which almost never work. Bring additional pointless tasks all the time.
Sometimes they will introduce changes that seems only there to justify the existence of someone otherwise completely useless.

Company cost cutting a lot, removing bonuses, cutting everything they possibly can lately.

Lower tier managers are just pupets, they are afraid to question any decision or rules coming to them nor bring any flaws higher and try to hide any problems. There is no point to share anything to them as it just goes to a black hole.

The whole work organization is a complete chaos, no proper tiers, everyone doing everything. Senior employees annoyed by noob tasks, junior ones stuck with advanced tasks. 

80% of the job is a call center, answer random phone calls many times from annoying people asking you to "do the needful". Sure at the same time you have to do something more advanced and constantly be interrupted by those calls.

Progress is completely 0. If you want a promotion, make sure to become a puppet to the proper manager. Don't dare to question anything he says, especially on a team meeting.
Although it is questionable how much a "promotion" is worth it, since there are many cases where employees reject promotions because they are traps. 

Management name and introduce positions with fancy names like "cybersecurity engineer" just to be attractive but then you actually do call center work.

I am probably missing something, but the review will become way too long if I will be listing everything. Just stay away from this place unless you are desperate for some job, and especially if you are really skilled IT person.

Pros: Hybrid work, make your own schedule, no micromanagement, educational opportunities, access to high level sales management
Cons: Communication, promotional opportunity, varying job role expectations, unpredictable at times

salary, and offer stock

Pros: Some great products. Great vision. Get to work with cutting edge technology sometimes. You can move around in the company but promote from within is declining. Unlimited PTO with your mangers approval is nice. Lots of product training.
Cons: Depending on who your manager is will drastically influence your experience. Culture is declining and getting more severe. Focus on bottom line is being pushed harder and ruthless layoffs when profit isn't what the street expects makes people nervous. Unrealistic quotas (but that isn't really new). Mangement of quota payouts is *really* poor. The good, helpful, everybody wins culture is fading as external hires dilute it (more promotion from within would help keep it). Lots of managers dont know what they are doing because they are new. Trying to get help from experts on products has become nearly impossible and it was designed to be that way.

Review Title: Think twice before joining Portugal TAC
Pros:
Is a good place to learn, every day you will have a new challenge
My colleagues were amazing
If you want to get Fortinet certificates, you will have access to vouchers
Cons:
- no career plan, if you try to apply for other internal positions you will never be successful, I heard from my manager that they prefer to hire someone from outside that allows you to move.
-a really stressful job, you are like a fireman putting out the fire, people only call to ask for help, and most of the time you will not have time to test, analyze, or to do real troubleshooting, because every problem is the most important one.
-Some customers are rude and will threaten you poorly
-Some customers don't have any IT background, are you will be talking with doors
-The Portuguese TAC is like an island, isolated from the rest of the company, you will only meet other people at the Christmas dinner, and you will never be invited to any event in the company, to tech event outside, nothing
-You will never get any training from other vendors, cloud, etc
-Dont believe in company promises

Pros: Lots of opportunities to learn

Review Title: My 5th The main challenge company poses to you is your ability to reinvent yourself all the time.  on the company
Pros: I’m celebrating 5 years in the company and I would like to share it has been such an amazing ride. From a team of 20 to more than 50 people, I had the opportunity to grow alongside with the team, learning from them and from the experiences along the way, sometimes making mistakes, but always trying to do my best on a company that listens to you, takes you into consideration, and allows you to propose or implement new ways to achieve the objectives we pursue. I hope to continue learning from Fortinet and my team for many more years, accompanying both on their next stages of growth to come !
Cons: The main challenge company will pose to you, is your ability to reinvent yourself all the time.

Review Title: Please consider working here, their culture is not the best
Pros: Good benefits: health insurance, dental insurance and additional annual bonus.
Cons: The company culture can be demanding, and it can be difficult to maintain a healthy work-life balance. The company's leadership structure could be more transparent, and communication between management and employees could be improved, decision-making processes at times feel unclear!. While the company offers stability and routine, there could be more opportunities for career development and internal promotion. There seems to be a focus on results rather than employee well-being. It would be beneficial to see more recognition and appreciation for individual contributions.
