Pros: Good environment to learn and grow
Cons: Financial compensation is not the best

Review Title: Strong on career growth and values
Pros: The organization has a good mix of history and legacy, while being open for new things and growing. There is a lot of space to grow within the organization. Management tries hard to stay true to the organization values and culture. Communication is transparent, key information are easy to access and its easy to be well informed. People are a pleasure to work with, the team is very diverse, open, helpful and invested in each others success.
Cons: Not a con, but something to be aware of joining. The organization is growing and maturing. It comes with its own growing pains, but the opportunities outweigh the challenges. There are a lot of opportunities for impact and career growth.

Pros: Great people to work with, one of the few companies I've seen that has good values involved in their decision making. The projects are interesting, varied and chosen to make a difference in society. The people get along well with each other, and are always up for helping each other out if you have questions. A good variety of projects to work on for various industries. Strong emphasis on learning new skills, and there are regularly training courses you can attend. Work life balance is good, and there are plenty of events organized if you like to be social or learn something outside your usual sphere of knowledge.
Cons: The large variety of projects may mean that you work outside of your usual tech stack sometimes, but they try to match you up with the role as well as possible. The pay is not the highest you can get for this kind of work, but where the pay is higher will likely come with other tradeoffs.

Review Title: Nice on the outside, questionable on the inside
Pros: Flexible work time, medical benefits, personal insurance reimbursement, work from home (if it is still accepted, apparently it is frowned upon but yet they sell this off during recruitment), mobile allowance, monthly get together to share about the company's performance.
Cons: Entitled colleagues, ungrounded expectations, frivolous spending, some work so hard but others can just not do their work and still get away with it. HR will try to find the person who posted this and want to "check" with them on what they can do better - even though the person has left, yes. Makes you wonder if this is really anonymous or not.

Pros:
Inclusion and diversity
Some nice colleagues
Cons: Not enough clients, some projects based on old stacks

Review Title: Good for learning, pay could be better
Pros: -Very nice colleagues -Good for learning -Good work life balance
Cons: -Finding the right project might be tricky -Pay is below industry standard -A lot of menagerial stuff and changes that are not very clear

Pros: On the engineering staff level the company generally does a pretty good job at hiring people with good attitude which results in a very good culture.
Cons: The company's HQ is in Switzerland and they expanded from there to different locations. It often feels like employees from non-swiss locations are treated as second class citizens. The most hilarious thing of all is that the company takes pride it only hires the top 5% of software engineers while is nowhere near close to paying top 5% salaries.

Review Title: A good opportunity for juniors and those who value life quality over payment
Pros: -overall good atmosphere of trust and cooperation -good learning opportunities -solid benefits -easily accessible, helpful management
Cons: -limited salary increases -getting a desired project might be difficult

Pros: -Good mentors to effectively improve your skillsets -Various opportunities outside of your jobscope -good culture -all time favourite company because of the awesome people
Cons: Behind the scenes are messy af

Pros: The company offers good opportunities (projects).
Cons: The salary is, in general, below market.

Review Title: Great Company with Great Culture and Great & Talented People
Pros: Zuhlke is a leading innovation and software engineering company with over 50 year of history. Founded in Switzerland and have footprint across Europe and some Asia countries. People here are all very talented and professional, and Zuhlke has a superb and open culture.
Cons: Team in Asia is still growing but with huge potential and great credential.

Pros:
Certain degree of freedom in choosing projects:
Zuhlke has clients in different fields (mainly medical and financial institutions), it is completely OK to voice out your preference for projects.

Friendly colleagues and good culture:
People here are nice and supportive. Peer engineers are highly capable and easy to work with. There are regular social events to build up team bonding.

No micromanagement:
There is no micromanagement here and your line manager gives you the autonomy to work on your own. However it may not be the same case for the project leaders in client.

Unique benefits:
Being able to work remotely outside of HK (under permission of client) is not something you can find everywhere.

Expanding network:
You will be meeting different people in different clients and be able to expand your network.
Cons:
On bench from time to time:
Sometimes there is just no projects which fits you and you will be on bench between projects. You may have a feeling of not being needed (and it is absolutely not your fault).

Salary not so competitive:
The salary does not really match with permanent bank staff.

Relatively difficult to get promoted:
Client feedback contributes a large portion in determining your performance, but not all the clients are willing to give you a lengthy/thorough feedback to reflect it. Besides that, there are "extra-miles" you will have to cover (eg. hosting knowledge-sharing sessions) to secure a promotion. Being great at client project solely does not cut.

Pros: - Nice and supportive colleagues - Flexible working environment.
Cons: It's very hard to have local company trip due to "Fairness" strictly.

Pros: Good environment to work, support for learning and development.
Cons: Don't have a strong client base. Less stability.

Review Title: The experience depends on the project
Pros: Most of the people are friendly and dedicated. There are great learning opportunities, especially for the beginners. There are lots of different projects, there's bench if you find yourself out of project. There's a large pool of experts from many countries that can support you if you get stuck or encounter something tricky.
Cons: The experience can vary depending on the project, from absolutely amazing to torture. It depends on the client and the project leadership team. Salary is not competitive. That was compensated before by some great benefits, but over the time, there are less and less benefits, and it's becoming more and more difficult to get a permission to use them.

Review Title: Not bad depending on your profile

Cons: Usually pretty old tech stack, possibility to be stuck without a project, very old school company, compensation is mid

Pros: - Very professional and transparent - Tough but fair questions that helped me understand the role better. -Interview Process helped me understand the people, the culture and what drives their work ethic. - Very quick with decisions throughout the process. - Constant communication from the hiring team telling me what to expect in each round.
Cons: N/A - I am yet to begin employment.

Pros: Zuhlke offers a great opportunity to work with various technologies (new and old) applied in various industries internationally in different team setups and roles. This also means that you should be open to leave your comfort zone for a project engagement that might not use your dream tech stack. Employees are empowered and expected to own and drive their career and have a great deal of freedom and flexibility in doing so. The career model expects that engineers engage in various activities beside coding and that they focus on the value we bring to our clients.
Cons:
Be prepared to face and work on the same issues (organizational challenges, communication issues, legacy code, bad quality code) in every client project engagement after every rotation. It's the nature of working in a consultancy. 

The offered trainings in various areas are rather limited. It would be desirable to have an internal training portfolio with regular workshops and courses given by employees.

Review Title: Strong International experience in construction, with 20 years of coordination in civil and MEP engineering

Cons: My analytical skills, my international experience, my adaptation, my responsiveness and my great rigor are qualities that I have been able to develop during 20 years of experience . I was recently to carry out a project in Africa to the tune of 25.5M€, while coordinating and supervisions the teams of all state bodies with tact.

Review Title: Zuhlke - pros and cons in joining with them
Pros: 1.Good interview process, which will inspire you to join them. 2. Multi cultural/ diversified employers (but you will not work with them). You might see/meet them during only company events as you will be working for different clients 3. Good if you are coming from other country so you can start your career in Singapore as they do remote interviews and hire.
Cons: 1. It is a consultancy firm. Meaning they will hire you and deploy in a client office (like an agency). Of course you will have to pass the client interviews and if not you will be on the bench. 2. Most of the time, you will not have a say in which technology/ project you will be working on. You will be just a contract employee with the client. 3. As you are working outside zuhlke office full-time(with clients directly), you will not inherit so called best culture. 4. your contribution will not be visible too as you are working for external client project. 5. Lack of visibility meaning, you will not be recognised. Eventually it might affect your increments/ bonus etc.. 6. Favourism there for europeans mostly. Management think they are the core, They will elevate them to lead positions easily and dump everybody else or dont care about others. 7. Lots of employer branding in social media, but reality is different. 8. High turnover in staff movement. Mostly people work around 1 year.

Pros: - Open culture, easy to speak to management - Technical development - Exchange with professionals on different sectors and practices. - Great place to kick start your career - Rank is not important in the day by day basis
Cons: - Average Second pillar - Salary in the mid-low range for engineers - Minimum per law: Maternity/Parental leave. - Squeeze their margins against salaries, project prices are increased with inflation but employees salaries are not updated - No inclusion policies in place.

Review Title: Probably the best consultant firm you can find in Hong Kong
Pros:
- Work life balance definitely. Although it's a consultant firm they strongly encourage work life balance and enforce it as much as they can. 

- Cutting edge tech and loads of best practices. You'll get to work with loads of awesome, smart, and amazing engineers and you will definitely learn a whole lot from them.

- Trust and support from management. They trust you with the work and with the way you work. Unlike traditional hk companies, they trust you when you call in sick (no doctor's note), they trust that you'll deliver on time. No micromanagement. They give you a plenty of freedom.

- They respect their engineers and they reward their engineers. Definitely a no blame culture and they try to understand the situation whenver something goes wrong. 

- Awesome, fun, and diverse culture. If you're tired of local HK culture, this is the place to be
Cons:
- It is a consultant firm so it's difficult to avoid bad clients. Zuhlke management did they best to be selective and pick out the best projects for their engineers but every now and then they'd end up with a client who'd lie about the nature and the actual work of the project. (Chances are low, I just happened to be unlukcy)

- Salary is average. It's a good salary if you're not already in the banking industry. They can definitely be more competitive in their pay.

- Hong Kong reports to Singapore. I understand that they're trying to unify the standard across Asia but it's not quite fair to have those sitting in Singapore to evaulate you when you're sitting in Hong Kong and they know nothing about you.

Pros: Culture, projects, benefits, events, learning and growth
Cons: There are no downsides at all for now

Review Title: Still good, but not great anymore
Pros: Flexible salary packages, profit sharing, flexible working time, fancy office, cool colleagues, parking, private health insurance, work/life balance...
Cons: The culture has changed significantly compared to the period before Covid. Also, the company has grown a lot, many "old" people left and many new ones came, so it's definitely not the same as it used to be. It's a service provider, with many different clients and projects and technologies, but an employee can't really influence the decision what their next project is going to be.

Review Title: A great company to work for
Pros:
At Zuhlke you'll often get exposed to really challenging projects, and sometimes demanding customers. But you will also receive tremendous supports from your managers, team mates, seniors which makes you feel that there's no problems that we cannot resolve. The people and support you'll get at Zuhlke will make it one of the best places to work for!

Zuhlke invests heavily in their employees, in the form of mentorship, training opportunities and gives employees a lot of empowerment on how they'd like to shape the future of the company.

The people are fun, and have a great sense of humor!
Cons: I can't think of any cons at this point in time.

Pros: The opportunity to work from home was the best thing about this role.
Cons: Don't report training issues or you will be fired. I agree with a previous comment that this is not a good place for minorities (in my opinion); specifically Black Americans. These people required me to repeat a training class that I'd already completed and passed 8 months prior because they didn't want to provide adequate mentor assistance (something they claimed would be available when requested). Their reason for me repeating? Because I had complained about the previous training session, although I wasn't the only person who had complained. However, I was the only employee required to repeat the session. I was even told (by a manager) that my comments might "offend the mentors who had worked hard on the training material". Then, to add insult to injury, I was terminated the day after I was told that I had done a good job on the completion of my second training session. Management is incompetent and gets offended when asked about job scenarios he/she doesn't understand, yet expects the less experienced employee to understand the same material. Mentors would either ignore requests for assistance or postpone it. I even had one mentor to ask if he could postpone assisting me so that he could help his friend with his resume. You may ask, "Why didn't you report it?" Remember....reporting issues will only get you fired... It's already been proven...

Pros: I worked at Cerner for almost 8 years in various roles. The best part of working here was the people I worked with. I loved my coworkers and have even stayed close with them years after leaving the company.
Cons: The pay is notoriously stingy, especially for entry-level positions. If you happen to get hired on in one of those positions be prepared to one of the lowest paid associates if you end up moving to a different department. I was in a senior position after working there for 5 years and I was mentoring new associates who were making more than I was who were just hired on. Could be different now that Oracle owns Cerner.

Review Title: Good mid-level management on a sinking ship
Pros: In the 2010-2017 era, Cerner was an above-average employer for ex-clinicians in the corporate world. While the pay was somewhat below market average, the benefits (including onsite healthcare facilities, great gym facilities, and travel perks) were great.
Cons: Unfortunately, in the years leading up to and following Cerner's acquisition by Oracle, the upsides have diminished to the point of nonexistence. Onsite healthcare is now dissolved, and all but the main KC campus have been sold off (and even that is disappearing with the company's pending move to Nashville). Pay has not risen to meet market, leading to stark compensation divides between Oracle and Oracle/Cerner employees in the same role.

Review Title: Probably one of the best places to work
Pros: The company makes extremely good use of employee engagement surveys. Every single piece of critical constructive feedback I've given has been acted on. The Cloud Apps Director and Principal Engineer Team Leads at this company show that they care for individuals with their actions, and are open-minded continuous learners who lead by example. Amazing benefits package. The company seems healthy and successful despite challenging economic times. C-level and VP-level leadership is doing an amazingly good job.
Cons: This is a tough industry to be in. The work can be demanding (but for those who genuinely want to learn and grow in their career, there is no shortage of room to grow). Grit, courage, and self-driven continuous learner mentality is a requirement for this company, which isn't a con per se, but sometimes conditions are ambiguous and challenging in innovation spaces during uncertain economy. Internal team compositions are sometimes awkward when working across teams, which isn't horrible but there's room for improvement that can make our need for agility and cross-functional knowledge-work less demanding.

Pros: Like all companies, the company culture means nothing if you have a great or horrible manager. In Motional's case, in my experience, there's good company culture and my manager is wonderful as well. I have the freedom to make an impact, and am encouraged to do so. I see negative reviews online (on Blind, for example) before I joined motional about how they are not confident about the company. I have worked for other AV companies. Motional is clearly not the leader in the AV space, but it isn't the worst either. It has huge backing from Mega players like Hyundai and Aptiv, which means A LOT, and we're accelerating towards delivering driverless vehicles in several cities very soon. Their pay structure is also good, with lots of stocks too, (unlike some other places where the stocks will expire if you leave, etc). Work life balance is relatively better, compared to all other AV companies I have heard (or worked) for, which actually results in better efficiency of employees so they can get actually more work done, instead of being forced to slave away for long, inefficient, hours.
Cons: Like all AV companies, this is a new , huge and challenging problem that we all are trying hard to solve for the first time ever. So better planning and foresight can go a long way in increasing efficiency.

As another recent comment here said, people might reasonably be afraid to talk to HR in fears of being singled out. Career growth is vague and not transparent, managers get promoted without having advanced their team, people with limited experience hold senior roles. Certain questions (that happen to be unfavorable to management) aren’t approved/addressed in company-wide meetings. It is a pity, the culture used to be wonderful.

Review Title: The place is great...but not for every profession.
Pros: - Your work will be with the best in the world on the cutting edge, which will definitely change the world for the better. - People are mostly very kind and open to sharing their know-how and insights. - Relatively good compensation. Good perks and insurance coverage. Generous PTO. - Autonomous vehicles are cool in every sense of the word.
Cons: - We are not ready for autonomous vehicles, especially those that are superior to level 3. It's not the technology, but rather the regulations and authorities. It may take quarters or years for your hard work to be widely known. - The company is extremely engineering-friendly. Any other profession could suffer from the unbalanced culture dominated by engineers. - In common with many automotive companies, the company also suffers from dependencies and misaligned goals, since many teams work in silos. - Collaboration between Singapore and the East Coast of the US may impair work-life balance in a negative way. - Leadership could be hypocritical as teams other than engineering functions could be involutional now. You can't expect too much on career development, if you are not an engineer.

Review Title: Company is becoming better each day.
Pros: * Company tries to operate based on the core values. These values help drive the goals/objectives which in turn foster more focused and collective efforts by employees. * Many things are not top-notched but I do see things becoming better each day. * Company is helpful for all kind of work-related visa! * Company seems to have a good relationship with Lyft and Uber.
Cons: * For employee who has been with the company longer, maybe it is harder to get significant number of stocks/shares as opposed to someone who just joined that typically get a significant more number of shares in the company. * It can be hard to get green card sponsorship by the company and the HR handling the matter is not the most helpful and approachable. * Company still seems to have a long way to catch up to competitors like Waymo and Cruise. * Company does not have it own ride-hailing app like what Waymo and Cruise are having. Not sure if this will be good or bad in the long run. For now, I feel it could be a potential minor con assuming Waymo and Cruise have better business model.

Review Title: It's a great place to work!
Pros: I'll start with mentioning I'm biased because I prefer a start-up culture where there are opportunities to take more initiative and have a greater influence over the end product. Motional definitely allows individuals to take ownership of their work and drive solutions cross-functionally across the organization. The leadership are good at being transparent about issues that we're facing and helping solve challenges head-on rather than shying away. Everyone is very open and supportive. There's a solid culture for working together and helping each other rather than just trying to "climb the corporate ladder".
Cons: There are some challenges with overlapping responsibilities and roles across teams. Because every team is empowered to take initiative, many times there are multiple teams that end up working on similar things and duplicating work if they don't coordinate. There's also having "too many cooks in the kitchen". Sometimes many people want to provide their opinion which can inhibit progress from being accomplished. It's nice to have data to make decisions, but sometimes if the data does not exist engineers will struggle to make the best decision possible with the data that is available.

Pros: The unlimited PTO seems to actually be unlimited (obviously within reason). I missed a little over a week with an illness within my first 2 months, and it was not an issue at all. I also have a little vacation time off around the Christmas holiday that isn't an issue either, so I'll have used 2 weeks PTO in my first 2 months. Everyone that I've worked with has been friendly and helpful, both within and outside my team. Everyone that I've worked with has also been very knowledgeable on what they are working on.
Cons: There's a lack of company process, but that is a common thing with startups. This can be a pro and a con, but I've listed it under cons because Motional is working on a safety critical product in a regulated industry. There does seem to be a good understanding of and reliance on ISO-26262, but there aren't a lot of company processes that define the specific implementation of ISO-26262 that Motional wants to follow.

Review Title: Tons of Inertia - For better or worse
Pros: Motional leaders seem to be generally willing to allow contributors to innovate and pursue ideas they find compelling. There is tremendous flexibility and ability to get the job done however the individual sees fit. Surprisingly for a company of its size and with so much influence/investment by major legacy corporations, there is not a lot of needless process and red tape over relatively trivial things. Overall, the attitude seems generally positive, the diversity of people is relatively strong, and the breadth of the company means there is tremendous opportunity for those who wish to find it. The amount of funding Motional has accrued at this point in 2022 has enabled it to become a relatively large company for AV, which even in light of some points of concern instills confidence in the survival of the company for long enough to really begin to truly scale the technology.
Cons: Unfortunately, the evolution of Motional as the confluence of several startups and contributions from an automotive OEM and Tier One supplier show...there is a head-scratching amount of work that is lost and redone between product iterations. There are, also, a surprising number of technical capabilities that younger and/or much smaller companies have already attained that Motional has not. A surprisingly dogmatic approach to technology development (ML models for everything!) restricts the pace of advancement and makes for endless headaches on the part of Validation and test teams. Because Motional has only now begun really investing in commercial partnerships (the prior deployment in Las Vegas was really treated as a side show in a lot of ways), it has relatively informal and lax practices and policies around public-facing operations (though, it should be said, not with respect to safety). The extraordinarily conservative nature of the product design (a safety driver AND a safety operator in every vehicle) makes the path to driverless - a goal toward which all AV companies are working - a steep one, even relative to industry peers. The biggest con, in my opinion, is that the lack of structure creates a lot of confusion and churn, and then an incredible amount of duplicated work. It also leads to strained relationships across functions, when the work one group does is not adequately communicated to another, and then priorities/work/finished product conflicts.

Review Title: Great Workplace Environment with Exciting Challenges
Pros: At Motional you can truly feel like you are making a difference by contributing to challenging problems. The teams are collaborative, leadership is supportive, and the people are friendly. Motional also values work-life balance and demonstrates true value in its employees.
Cons: At times, tasks can seem overwhelming or ambiguous due to the challenging nature of the work but there is always a team around to support you.

Pros: The people at Motional are some of the best in the world. When there are gaps in process or technical hurdles, everyone rallies to create a solution. I've also never seen such a diverse workforce in a tech company (of any size).
Cons: Growth of the employee base has outpaced process, so some process gaps lead to frustration.

Pros: Great community with a very interesting challenging mission at a huge scale.
Cons: Global presence results in sometimes exhausting cross-timezone collaboration processes.

Pros: Work is easy as expectations are low. Just show up and you'll get paid.
Cons: More regression than progress. Cars aren't ready for missions until hours after your shift starts as engineers come and go as they please. Time management is nonexistent. Nepotism rules the majority of promotions. Incompetence is the norm for the majority of VOs. The kicker is the woke policies that dictates the day to day operations. Every week is a holiday for some special victim group that has become popular for corporations to cater to for the all important public optics.

Pros: Very interesting topics to work on
Cons: Have not worked here that long yet

Review Title: Interesting work in an upcoming field
Pros: - Good Pay - Great Colleagues - Good WLB and flexibility (remote/hybrid) - Multi-national
Cons: - Field is not very stable and the product/business model is not ready for deployment yet (for any AV company) - Private stocks

Pros: Reasonable workload, good pay and interesting problems.
Cons: Some departments are no so exciting

Pros: All of it. There wasn't a single thing i could find wrong about this company
Cons: N/A and I really mean that.

Pros: Free lunch paper RSU which is worth nothing
Cons: Bringing in people who are so so biased and wanna blame the non defaulters and kick them out of the company

Pros: Many opportunities for career and personal development. Valuable perks
Cons: Slightly high turnover rate, leading to planning challenges

Pros: Motional is constantly improving and I can see the company getting better every month. As the company is still relatively young, there is a lot of opportunities for growing and building your career.
Cons: Motional is actively trying to fix the gaps in its business and I honestly feel that by the time I post this review, the review would have become obsolete. I like how there is a constant push to improve.

Pros: Great pay and benefits. Work from-home policy for certain positions is very gracious and pay isn't adjusted based on your location. Occasionally will pay for travel to meet team members. Colleagues are very intelligent and some of the best educated I've ever met. The work is meaningful and the goal of the company is a very important one that can change the way we live. Being able to contribute to that goal has given me inspiration that what I'm doing matters.
Cons: Some engineering tasks can take longer than wanted due to CI struggles. There have been a couple of reorganizations in the recent past.

Pros: Great mission and interesting work
Cons: Immature company trying to find its way

Pros: Benefits top rate, especially 401k Work culture collaborative and inclusive Tackling complex and challenging problems
Cons: Execution of strategy hectic Roles not clearly defined or understood

Review Title: Mediocre but has the potential to be GREAT
Pros:
1- Nice office and amenities (the Boston location),
2- Easy going coworkers (for the most part)
3-  Comfortable pace
Cons:
1- Questionable decision-making and poor management team
2- No clear planning/goals/transparency company wide and most people are confused
3- Limited opportunities to learn and grow
4- Stagnating career development, and management went above and beyond to make it look easy on paper but hard to actually move up (looking at you HR)
5- Benefits are good but compensation (the cash part) is nowhere near competitive
6- If you still want to go ahead and take your chances, I’d highly suggest you negotiate well for your salary/compensation package because that’s what you’ll be stuck with for a quite some time

Pros: Nice offices with expected 'Silicon Valley' style perks, engineering teams well resourced with good leadership (especially the hardware side of the company). BD teams were perhaps too effective at securing external partnerships for deployments. Strong financial backing from Hyundai (pay was pretty good for a non-costal job).
Cons:
Program management operated in an extremely myopic fashion; was very clear the program managers in charge were more concerned with having a good 'scorecard' rather than fostering the development of a scalable product.

Despite the strong financial backing of Hyundai, the working relationship was very dysfunctional in most areas, especially engineering and with regard to communication (downplaying) of risks.

I've never seen an HR org more drunk on wokeness & power (and I've worked at Google).

Pros: Diverse workforce, intellectually stimulating and challenging work, and benefits.
Cons: Thin job security and push for on-site work,

Review Title: Fast paced with a great work environment
Pros: - Knowledgeable coworkers with a drive to push the industry forward - Many projects to get involved, little repetition of day to day tasks - Great work environment for all employees. - Flexible WFH (role to role) - Great benefits, open PTO, 401K match -
Cons: - Sometimes poor communication, or late communication after a test / project has already been started - Some projects feel rushed when in fact they are moving slow - Purchasing equipment and tools can be a pain (they are working to fix this)

Review Title: Great organization with big investors but still has that start-up energy
Pros: Motional is a great place to work. The meeting load is manageable and you are really able to find the time to focus on achieving your deliverables, training, and contributing to various interesting projects. All of the campuses are great, with great amenities and meals provided, and fun activities on a regular basis. Motional is also very receptive to fully remote workers  and is great at supporting them.
Cons: I've not found many cons as of yet. As with most companies it can be hard to come up to speed initially.

Pros: - Really Progressive Work Environment - Cool Tech - Long term outlook due to partnerships with Uber and Lyft - Good Benefits
Cons: - Have some challenges to resolve in scaling the company - Understanding what will differentiate Motional from Competitors - Slow transition from engineering driven org to customer product/needs driven org

Pros: Great place to work, good people on the team.
Cons: Pick their friends for promotions

Pros:
Great culture. Very diverse! I feel more comfortable here. The company has a "startup" feel to it. It's very relaxed but also very dedicated to deadlines. Flexible and understanding leadership that strives to reduce burnout.
I see and contribute to continuous process improvements within the team and all ideas are fully supported.
Great potential to move within the company and grow.
Cons:
There are often times there are "too many cooks in the kitchen" to get an initiative done. It's difficult wrangling all the stakeholders in for meetings or discussions at the same time. 
A little TOO many channels in "slack".

Pros: Great company to work for
Cons: No real cons overall a great company

Pros: - Exciting, dynamic atmosphere where you can see your work and results grow - Very interesting blend of start up atmosphere and mature engineering environment - Awesome coworkers and work-life flexibility
Cons: - Restructuring and growing pains can slow down work at times, but are improving

Pros: Good culture and promising tech stack
Cons: Low compensation in over all

Pros: Free lunch, good work life balance, good managers
Cons: A lot of down time

Pros: Onboarding was friendly and welcoming. Training is extensive and they make sure you understand everything that’s being taught. Pay is great.
Cons: No cons as of yet.

Pros:
Flexible to work from home and in office. 
Wonderful staff and team! 
Very accommodating.
Lots of platforms to utilize so you can learn many different aspects of the company at your leisure and also boost your linked in learning!
Great snacks, coffee bar and lunch served each week!
Execs & Managers are very friendly and easy to approach.
Staff is super friendly and helpful!
Great company with room to grow!
The team I have been working with has been great and informative.
Great company culture and environment!
Cons:
I haven't experienced any cons personally. 
I have not had any issues with anything or anyone.

Pros:

- People within smaller teams/orgs are nice to each other
- Compensations and efforts for pay-equity have been great
Cons:

- Inter-team finger pointing in sync up meetings keeps getting worse
- The PMO is adding little value as an organization, though there are good PMs within. This was not helped by the VP of PMO taking up another role, leaving the problems in the PMO they were meant to address a problem for the future without a define path to get better.

Pros: Great office, benefits and pay. Opportunities to learn and grow. Opportunities to visit other offices.
Cons:
The IT team was seen as less than, wasn’t offered equity. Constant lay offs. Low diversity for people of color.
Poor dynamics within the team, terrible morale, lots of finger pointing and poor culture. Unlimited days off, but no room to ever take time off, and shunned when you do.

Pros: Excellent view of the port, very relaxed, cozy, and quiet environment.
Cons: Traffic is a pain in the morning and in the afternoon because we are located in the city.

Pros:
The work life balance has been stressed repeatedly by senior management and encourage to take time when needed. Unlimited PTO is really unlimited PTO here and it shows in the employees. 

Management is there to support and help rather than micro manage. Saves the company precious time and money and encourages self reliance. Management is always there for you if they are needed but not breathing down you neck.

While the company is rather large, it is still relatively new and there is a lot of opportunity for growth and to help make change.

Diversity acceptance is EVERYTHING here. I love seeing all the outreach for the diverse workforce that is present.
Cons:
Health benefits are lacking compared to the AV competition with similar salary.
IE Premium options are employer paid by other companies.

Pros: Intelligent, creative colleagues; passionate about customer experience; good work/life balance
Cons: Some tracks may have minimal room for advancement

Pros: Somewhat intellectually stimulating market to sell to if you enjoy tech and innovation. Coworkers were all cool for the most part. Brand is not very well respected but is known at least.
Cons: Micro management. As a too performing sales person and presidents club winner I wasn’t rewarded with more autonomy, but rather expected to train other more junior incoming sales reps. All for helping out others but not when it isn’t appreciated. Line of business managers are very immature and strange. Mine in particular would get drunk at happy hours and start making weird inappropriate comments. Pay is not on par with industry. Other analyst firms have a better reputation. They also hired way too many sales people in tampa and then laid a bunch off.

Pros: Great research products and analysts.
Cons: Sales culture is lacking. A lot of long time employees who were never formally trained in sales are running sales teams due to tenure. Lack of good training, product marketing and business development. Don't pay well so they can't attract the talent.

Review Title: The Best JOB I have EVER HAD!!!!
Pros: The leadership is strong and transparent in their decision making. It has been a tough year in tech across the industry but that hasnt changed the attitude here. Ryan Patterson leads the CSM division with a humanist approach backed with data driven insights. It makes it easy to do your best work here with such wonderful folks advocating for you.
Cons: I do feel like the CSM group can at times have limited opportunities for growth. A caveat to this is the fact that no one leaves most people have been here almost 20 years. Its tough to make space if no one ever moves on.

Review Title: Good place for young upstarts. Stable, friendly and also forward-thinking.
Pros: IDC is a forward thinking company that plans itself well. The management sees what is ahead for the IT business intelligence market and makes strategic responses such as acquisitions. The company has remained pretty independent through ownership changes - a Chinese conglomerate at one point, then now under Blackstone. One doesn't feel any changes through these changes and it is good from management. There is frequent communication from the management to shed light on the business at large and they really welcome feedback. IDC has long practiced hybrid work, well before COVID. The employees respond in kind by mostly staying around for a long time. They also try to convey messages of inclusivity and integrity. We have numerous workshops to help with personal development.
Cons: Monetary compensation simply isn't on par with many other data jobs in the industry, be it at an IT vendor or elsewhere. The company is pretty tight about that. It is easy to rise from entry level, but afterwards the goal posts and timeline for further advancement are unclear, expectations can be better outlined. This can be an issue for fast risers to leave after a certain point.

Review Title: Great work, bad management and leadership
Pros: The work is great and work life balance is nice
Cons: Bad Management who are tone deaf and slow to change. Also sales and Marketing are not very good at their jobs.

Pros: Interesting work, managers, improved communications by leadership, colleagues are professional, smart, open to collaboration, and good people to work with, many friendships built. Change does seem to be happening now in 2021-2023
Cons: not enough diversity or women in leadership roles, changes come slowly and turnover is slow which exacerbates this, some (not all) folks have been with the company a very long time and these patterns in behavior don't move the needle

Pros: Work-life balance and benefits; office
Cons: Out of sight out of mind.

Cons: Complex organization. Can be slow to make decisions. In transition towards a possible IPO in a few years' time, so the culture may become less like a "family firm" and more industrialized in the near future. Pressure and work/life balance has worsened since Covid-19.

Cons: Some systems and processes need to be updated along with increased staffing to handle the work load.

Pros: great work environment new tampa office

Pros:

-Flexible scheduling
-Very helpful team & management (everyone is so nice and welcoming)

Cons:
It’s a very ‚corporate’ atmosphere, which can be a pro or a con depending on your personal preference. 

You will be tasked with learning A LOT- be prepared to take a ton of notes in your first couple of weeks. It‘s a lot to digest, but if you put in the effort early it will pay off immensely in the end! I am very happy and comfortable after week 5.

Pros: Very inclusive workplace that allows autonomy.
Cons: Pay is lower than the market the company plays in.

Review Title: you'll know from the get go whether you will stay for a long time or not
Pros: people are collaborative and work arrangement is flexible. we are not forced to fully return to office.
Cons: hr process is messy. it is daunting for new hires. on boarding is informal.

Review Title: Headed in the right direction—great time to join
Pros:
Company is growing a lot. Several long time employees told me that this is the best things have been in many years and said I joined at a great time.

Growth is not just luck, it’s built on several strategic initiatives that appear to be working well and can generate long term growth. 

Benefits are competitive, pay is generally competitive.

They recently upped the vacation time a little for newer hires. There are also new unplug days which are essentially random Fridays off.

Flexible working from home or office. Brand new HQ facility that is really awesome with tech-company-like free amenities.
Cons:
Everyone is so busy because of the growth and they’re struggling a bit to find enough people. This might actually be a pro if you’re interviewing because you have a better chance and more negotiating power.

More generally just some growing pains.

Job descriptions and career pathing could use some work as well. For example, I have do not know what numerical metric would merit a promotion.

Pros: Fast paced and CEO treats everyone equal with open door to everyone
Cons: Low pay, not great benefits and lack of retention

Pros: Great place to work. Always aware of the high pace and supporting time away and family time to reset.
Cons: Career path is not always clear.

Pros: Covers the waterfront on market research in the high tech field, especially from a B2B angle.
Cons: I've covered consumer tech, which gets less focus/investment from the exec team.

Pros: Lots of PTO, holidays, and global wellness days.  Colleagues who support and care about each other.
Cons: Poor internal communication.  Some Sr. Management that are not good leaders.

Pros: Stable company who cares about their employees
Cons: Needs to work on better communication across departments and from mid level managers

Pros: Remote work, clear responsibilities, very open to process improvement
Cons: Days can get very busy, especially at end of quarter

Pros: Inclusive, great team, helpful, solid growth opportunities
Cons: Average training, not too many young people

Pros: Employee friendly, great benefits, work-life balance
Cons: Base pay is Ok, limited growth opportunities
